projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE VOYAGE OF ITALY, OR A Compleat Journey through ITALY. In Two Parts. With the Characters of the People, and the DeÅ¿cription of the Chief Towns, Churches, MonaÅ¿teries, Tombs, Libraries, Pallaces, Villas, Gardens, Pictures, Statues, and Antiquities. AS AlÅ¿o of the IntereÅ¿t, Government, Riches, Force, &c. of all the Princes. With InÅ¿tructions concerning Travel.
By Richard LaÅ¿Å¿els, Gent. who Travelled through Italy Five times as Tutor to Å¿everal of the EngliÅ¿h Nobility and Gentry.
Never before Extant.
Newly Printed at Paris, and are to be Å¿old in London, by John Starkey at the Mitre in Fleet-Å¿treet near Temple-Barr, 1670.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE AND MOST TRVLY NOBLE LORD RICHARD LORD LVMLEY VICOVNT WATERFORD &c.
div.p:
It were needleÅ¿Å¿e to tell you, by how many titles this little Orphan booke, claimes the honour of your Lordps protection. FirÅ¿t, by the law of nature, its parent dying in your Å¿eruice, you stand bound to bee a
foÅ¿ter father to it; againe it haueing been my fortune to contribute Å¿omething to the bringing it forth to light, it hath a new relation to you vnder the title by which I haue long agoe conÅ¿ecrated all my endeauours to your Å¿eruice. But to paÅ¿Å¿e by theÅ¿e two, there is yet a third reaÅ¿on, wherby it will appeare, not the effect of choiÅ¿e, but of neceÅ¿Å¿ity, that it should come forth vnder the fauour of your name: The wellgrounded experience which you haue gained in your trauells; the exacte and iudicious account you are able to giue of the places you haue Å¿een, which make a great part of the Å¿ubiect of this booke; the mature iudgment of the intereÅ¿ts of Å¿tates, and manners of people wherof it treats, which in you is not the after fruit of age;
the Gentile and courteous behauiour which you haue acquired, and which charmes all thoÅ¿e who haue the honour to conuerÅ¿e with you: TheÅ¿e, I Å¿ay, are vertues Å¿o peculier to your PerÅ¿on, and Å¿o conÅ¿picuous in the eyes of all the world, that the deÅ¿igne of this Booke being to forme the like in the reÅ¿t of the Gentry of our Nation that pretend to trauell; It would bee a wrong to the publike to let it appeare vnder the Patronage of any other then of him that is the Idea of an accomplisht and consuÌ„mate Traueller. And this, I doubt not, was the reaÅ¿on, why the Author haueing had the honour to haue been a Gouernour to Å¿o many of the flower of our Gentry, made choiÅ¿e of your Lordship to bequeath this worke vnto, by his last Will and Testament: And which
impoÅ¿eth vpon me a neceÅ¿sity, both in compliance to the memory of my worthy friend and fellow traueller, and to the duty I owe vnto your Lordship, by the honour I haue to Å¿ucceed vnto him in his last engagement, to offer vp this his laÅ¿t worke to you, as an euerlasting monument of eÅ¿teeme and gratitude, of him who while hee liued euer was, and of him who liueing euer is.

closer.signed: Your Lordships moÅ¿t humble & moÅ¿t obedient Å¿eruant S. WilÅ¿on.

div.head: A TABLE OF THE NAMES OF THE CHIEF TOWNES contained in this firÅ¿t part.
A PREFACE TO THE READER, CONCERNING TRAVELLING.
div.p: WHEN I firÅ¿t Å¿et pen to Paper to handle this Å¿ubject, I had not the leaÅ¿t thought of the preÅ¿Å¿e; nor of erecting my Å¿elfe into an Author. J onely diÅ¿charged my memory haÅ¿tily of Å¿ome things which J had Å¿een, in Italy; and wrapt vp that vntimely Embrio in fiue sheets of paper, for the vÅ¿e of a noble perÅ¿on, who Å¿et me that taske. Yet this Embrio likeing the perÅ¿on for whom it was conceiued, obliged me to lick it ouer and ouer againe, and bring it into better forme. Second thoughts, and Å¿ucceding voyages into Italy, haue finished it at laÅ¿t; and haue made it what it is; A compleat Voyage, and an exact Itinerary through Italy.

And here I thought to haue drawne
bridle and reÅ¿ted, after Å¿o long a iourney; when a learned friend hauing peruÅ¿ed this my DeÅ¿cription of Italy, deÅ¿ired much to Å¿ee a Preface to it, of my fashion, and CoÌ„cerning Traueling. I could refuÅ¿e nothing to Å¿uch a freind; and haue done it here willingly, both for my owne, and my countryes Å¿ake.
For my owne sake; to preexcuÅ¿e Å¿ome things in my booke, which Å¿ome perchance may diÅ¿like.

For Å¿ome, I feare, will quarrel with my English; and juÅ¿tly, Å¿eeing three long voyages into Flanders, Å¿ix into France, fiue into Italy, one into Germany, and Holland, haue made mee, liue half of my life time in forrain countryes, to the diÅ¿turbance of my owne language. Yet if J bring not home fine language, J bring home fine things: and I haue Å¿een great Ladyes, both in France, and England, buy finde things of chimney-Å¿weepers, and Pedlars, that Å¿poke but courÅ¿e Lombard language, and groÅ¿Å¿e Scotch.

Others perchance will finde fault, that J write merrily Å¿ometimes: And why not? Seeing I write to young men, and for them: and mirth is neuer Å¿o lawfull as in traueling, where it shortens
long miles, and Å¿weetens bad vÅ¿age; that is, makes a bad dinnar go downe, and a bad horÅ¿e go on.

Others will Å¿ay, that I fill my booke with too much Latin: But theÅ¿e muÅ¿t be minded, that I am writing of the Latin country; and that I am caruing for Schollers, who can diÅ¿geÅ¿t Å¿olid bitts, hauing good Å¿tomacks.

Others will Å¿ay, J ieere now and then: And would any man haue me go through Å¿o many diuers countries, and prayÅ¿e all I Å¿ee? Or in earneÅ¿t, do not Å¿ome things deÅ¿erue to be ieered? when things cannot be cured but by ieering, ieering, Å¿ayth Tertullian, is a duty: and I thinke the Cynick PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿truck as great a blow at vice, as the Stoicks.

Others will Å¿ay, I change Å¿tile often, and Å¿ometimes ru â€¢ n Å¿moothly, Å¿ometimes joltingly: Tru â€¢
â€¢ raueled not allwayes vpon Å¿mooth ground, and paceing horÅ¿es: SwiÅ¿Å¿erlande and Sauoye, are much different, from Campania, and Lombardy; and its one thing to deÅ¿cribe a PleaÅ¿ant garden, an other thing to deÅ¿cribe a Venerable Cathedrall: and if in the one, and the other, we haue Å¿eueral lookes; much more
ought we to haue Å¿eueral words in deÅ¿cribing them.

Others will Å¿ay, I affect a world of exotick words not yet naturalized in England: No, I affect them not; I cannot auoyd them: For who can Å¿peak of Statues, but he muÅ¿t Å¿peak of Niches? or of Churches, Wrought Tombes, or inlayd Tables; but hee muÅ¿t speak of Coupolas; of baÅ¿Å¿i rilieui; and of pietre commeÅ¿Å¿e? If any man vnderÅ¿tand them not, its his fault, not mine.

Others will Å¿ay, I hunt too much after Ceremonies, and Church antiquityes. No, I onely meet them. And as a man cannot Å¿peak of Hercules, but he muÅ¿t Å¿peak of clubbs, of combats, of Labours, and victories: Å¿o I cannot Å¿peak of Rome the Christian, but I muÅ¿t Å¿peake of Relicks, Ceremonies, and Religion. Yet I beleeue, I giue my Reader a full drought to â€¢ of prophane antiquityes, MaÅ¿carades, Shews, dreÅ¿Å¿ings, and paÅ¿Å¿etimes.

Others in fine will Å¿ay, that I do but a thing done allready; Å¿eeing two others haue written of this Å¿ubiect in English. Well; if others haue written vpon this Å¿ubiect, why may not I? They did the
beÅ¿t they could, I beleeue; but they drew not vp the ladder after them. The one writes much of Italy, M. Warcupp. M. Raymond. and Å¿ays little: the other writes little and leaueth out much; which I impute to the ones writing out of old Geographers, long after he had been there: and to the others short stay in Italy, when he was there. And if theÅ¿e ingenious gentlemen haue painted out Italy in buÅ¿to onely, and profile; why may not I paint her out at full face, and at her full length? If they, like ancient Statuaryes, haue repreÅ¿ented Italy vnto vs like a naked Å¿tatue; I haue Å¿et her out in all her beÅ¿t Attire, and Iewels. And thus much for my owne Å¿ake.
For my countryes Å¿ake; To read to my countrymen two profitable LeÅ¿Å¿ons. The firÅ¿t, of the Profit of traueling. The Å¿econd: of Traueling with profit.

1. For the first, to wit the Profit of Traueling, its certain, that if this world be a great booke, The profit of traueling. as S. AuguÅ¿tin calls it, none Å¿tuddy this great Booke Å¿o much as the Traueler. They that neuer Å¿tirr from home, read onely one page of this booke; and like
the dull follow in Pliny, who could neuer learne to count further then fiue, they dwell allwayes vpon one leÅ¿Å¿on. They are like an acquaintance of mine, who had alwayes a booke indeed lyeing open upon a deske; but it was obÅ¿erued that it lay allwayes open at one and the Å¿ame place, and by long cuÅ¿tome, could lye open no where elÅ¿e. He then that will know much out of this great booke, the world, muÅ¿t read much in it: and as VlyÅ¿Å¿es is Å¿etforth by Homer as the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t of all the Grecians, becauÅ¿e he had traueled much, and had Å¿een multorum hominum mores & Vrbes, the Cittyes and cuÅ¿tomes of many men: Å¿o his Å¿onn Telemachus is held for a very shallow witted man: and Homer giues the reaÅ¿on, becauÅ¿e his mother Penelope, inÅ¿tead of Å¿ending him abroad to Å¿ee forrain countryes, had allwayes kept him at home, and Å¿o made him a meere Onocephalus, and a homeling Mammacuth. So true is the Å¿aying of Seneca, that Imperitum eÅ¿t animal homo, & Å¿ine magna experientia rerum, Å¿i circumÅ¿cribatur Natalis Å¿oli Å¿ui fine.

2 Traueling preÅ¿erues my yong nobleman
from Å¿urfeiting of his parents, and weanes him from the dangerous fondneÅ¿s of his mother. It teacheth him wholeÅ¿ome hardship; to lye in beds that are none of his acquaintance; to Å¿peak to men he neuer Å¿aw before; to trauel in the morning before day, and in the euening after day; to endure any horÅ¿e and weather, as well as any meat and drink. Whereas my country gentleman that neuer traueled, can Å¿carce go to London without makeing his Will, at leaÅ¿t without wetting his handkercher. And what generous mother will not Å¿ay to her Å¿onn with that ancient? Malo tibi malÃ¨ eÅ¿Å¿e, Senec. quÃ m molliter: I had rather thou shouldÅ¿t be Å¿ick, then Å¿oft. Indeed the coral-tree is neither hard, nor red, till taken out of the Sea, its natiue home. And I haue read that many of the old Romans put out their children to be nurced abroad by Lacedemonian nurces, till they were three yeares old; then they put them to their Vncles, till Å¿eauen, or tenn; then they Å¿ent them into ToÅ¿cany to be inÅ¿tructed in Religion; and at laÅ¿t into Greece to Å¿tuddy PhiloÅ¿ophy.

3. Traueling takes my yong nobleman
four notches lower, in his Å¿elf-conceit and pride. For wheras the country Lord that neuer Å¿aw any body but his Fathers tennants, and M. ParÅ¿on, and neuer read any thing but Iohn Stow, and Speed; thinks the Lands-end to be the Worlds-end; and that all Å¿olid greatneÅ¿Å¿, next vnto a great PaÅ¿ty, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts in a great Fire, and a great eÅ¿tate. Wheras my traueling yong Lord, who hath Å¿een Å¿o many greater men, and EÅ¿tats then his owne, comes home farre more modeÅ¿t and ciuil to his inferiours, and farre leÅ¿Å¿e pufft vp with the empty conceit of his owne greatneÅ¿Å¿. Indeed nothing cured Alcibiades his pride Å¿o much, as to Å¿ee in a Map (shewd him for the nonce by Socrates) that his houÅ¿e and lands, of which he was Å¿o prowd, either appeared there not at all, or onely a little Å¿pot,Senec: or dab: and nemo in puÅ¿illo magnus.

4. Traueling takes off, in Å¿ome Å¿ort, that aboriginal curÅ¿e, which was layd vpon mankind euen allmoÅ¿t at the beginning of the world; I meane, the confuÅ¿ion of tongues: which is Å¿uch a curÅ¿e indeed, that it makes men, who are of one kind, and made to be
Å¿ociable, Å¿o Å¿trangely to fly one an other, that, as great S. AuÅ¿tin Å¿ayth, A man had rather be with his dog, then with a man whoÅ¿e language he vnderÅ¿tands not. Nay, this diuerÅ¿ity of language, makes the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t man paÅ¿Å¿e for a foole in a Å¿trange country, and the beÅ¿t man, for an excommunicated perÅ¿on, whoÅ¿e conuerÅ¿ation all men auoyd. Now, traueling takes off this curÅ¿e, and this moral excommunication, by making vs learne many languages, and conuerÅ¿e freely with people of other countryes.

5. Traueling makes vs acquainted with a world of our kinred we neuer Å¿aw before. For Å¿eing we are all comne from one man at first, and conÅ¿equently all akinn to one another; its but a reaÅ¿onable thing, that a man should, once at leaÅ¿t in his life time, make a journey into forrain countries, to Å¿ee his Relations, and viÅ¿it this kinred: haueing allwayes this Å¿aying of young JoÅ¿eph in his mouth; quaero fratres meos

6. Traueling enables a man much for his countryes Å¿eruice. It makes the merchant rich, by shewing him what
abounds, & wantes, in other countryes; that Å¿o he may know what to import, what to export. It makes the mechanick come loaden home with a world of experimental knowledge for the improueing of his trade. It makes the feild officer, a knowing Leader of an army, by teaching him where an army in forrain countryes, can march Å¿ecurely, paÅ¿Å¿e riuers eaÅ¿ily, incamp Å¿afely, auoid ambuÅ¿cades and narrow paÅ¿Å¿ages diÅ¿cretly, and retreat orderly. It makes the Common Å¿oldier play the Å¿py wel, by making him Å¿peak the ennemyes language perfectly, that Å¿o mingling with them, he may find their deÅ¿ignes, and croÅ¿Å¿e their plottes. In fine, it makes a nobleman fitt for the nobleÅ¿t employment, that is, to bee AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador abroad for his king in forrain countryes, and carry about with him his kings perÅ¿on, which he repreÅ¿ents, and his kings word, which he engageth.

7. Traueling brings a man a world of particular profits. It contents the minde with the rare diÅ¿courÅ¿es we heare from learned men, as the Queen of Saba was rauished at the wiÅ¿dome
of Salomon. It makes a wiÅ¿eman much the wiÅ¿er by making him Å¿ee the good and the bad in others. Hence the wiÅ¿eman Å¿ayth: Sapiens in terram alienigenarum gentium pertranÅ¿iet: bona enim & mala in hominibus tentabit. It makes a man think himÅ¿elf at home euery where, and Å¿mile â€¢ t vniuÅ¿t exile: It makes him wellcome home a gaine to his Neighbours, Å¿ought af â€¢ er by his betters, and liÅ¿tened vnto with admiration by his inferiours. It makes him Å¿it Å¿till in his old age with Å¿atisfaction; and trauel ouer the world againe in his chair and bed, by diÅ¿courÅ¿e and thoughts. In fine its an excellent Commentary vpon hiÅ¿toryes; and no man vnderÅ¿tands Liuy and CaeÅ¿ar, Guicciardin and Monluc, like him, who hath made exactly â€¢ he Grand Tour of France, and the Giro of Italy.

8. Trauelling makes my young Nobleman returne home againe to his country like a bleÅ¿Å¿ing Sunn, For as the Sunn, who hath been traueling about the world theÅ¿e fiue thouÅ¿and and odd yeares, not onely enlightens thoÅ¿e places whi â€¢ h hee viÅ¿its; but alÅ¿o enrich
â€¢ th them with all Å¿orts of fruits,
and mettales: Å¿o the nobleman by long traueling, hauing enlightened his vnderÅ¿tanding with fine notions, comes home like a glorious Sunn; and doth not onely shine birght in the firmament of his country, the Parlament houÅ¿e; but alÅ¿o bleÅ¿Å¿eth his inferiours with the powerfull influences of his knowing Å¿pirit.

9. In fine, Examples (the beÅ¿t PhiloÅ¿ophy) shew vs, that the greateÅ¿t Princes Europe hath Å¿een, theÅ¿e many years, to wit, Charles the V. and the King of Sueden, GuÅ¿tauus Adolphus, Strada de Bello Belg. where both of them great trauelers; the firÅ¿t had been twice in England, as often in Africk, four times in France, Å¿ix times is Spayne, Å¿euen in Italy, and nine in Germany: The Å¿econd had traueld incognito (as M. Wats writes of him) into Holland, France, Italy, and Germany in his youth: which made him Å¿ay afterwards to the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador Mareshal BrezÃ©, in a kind of threatening way, that he knew the way to Paris, as wel as to Stockholme. Adde to this, that the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t and greateÅ¿t among the ancien â€¢
PhiloÅ¿ophers, Plato, Pythagoras
Anaxagoras, AnacharÅ¿is, Apollonius, Architas, and Pi â€¢ tacus, (which laÅ¿t left his Å¿upreame Command of Mytelen to trauel) were all great trauelers; and that S. Hierome (who being no Bishop, and conÅ¿equently not obliged to reÅ¿idence) hauing traueled into France, Italy, Greece, and the Holy Land, purchaÅ¿ed to himÅ¿elf Å¿uch rare acquiÅ¿itions of learning, by his trauels and languages, that among all the ancient Fathers and Doctors, The Church, in her Collect on his day, calls him onel â€¢ , Doctorem maximum, the greateÅ¿t Doctor. And Å¿o much for the profit of Traueling.

Now for as much as concernes the Å¿econd LeÅ¿Å¿on, to wit,The Traueling with profitâ–ª
the Traueling with profit, diuers things are to be taken notice of; Å¿ome by the Parents of thoÅ¿e that trauel; others by thoÅ¿e themÅ¿elues that trauel: of all which I will Å¿peak breefly.

As for the Parents, their greatest care ought to be of prouideing there children (I Å¿peak to men of high condition) a good Gouernour, to trauel with them, and haue a care of their PerÅ¿ons, and breeding: that is, play the part of the Archangel RaphaÃ«l
to yong Tobie, and Lead them Å¿afe abroad, and bring them Å¿afe home: Ego Å¿anum ducam & reducam filium tuum. Tob. 5. v. 20. And here I couldâ–ª wish indeed that Parents could be as happy in their choyce, and finde men Angels for Gouernours to their children, vpon condition they should requite them, as yong Tobie offered to requite the Archangel his Gouernour, whom he tooke to be a man. For the education of children is a thing of that high concerne to the Commonwealth, that in this, Parents should Å¿pair no coÅ¿te whatÅ¿oeuer; but rather imitate the old Lacedemonians, who tooke more care of their youth, then of any thing els in their Commonweath. In Å¿o much that when Antigonus a â€¢ d of them fifty yong youths for hoÅ¿tages, they anÅ¿wered him, that they had rather giue him twice as many made men. Seing then yong youths are the future hopes of families, and Commonwealths, their education ought not to be committed but to men of great parts and excellent breeding. For I haue allwayes thought, that a yong Noblemans train ought to be like his Clothes; His Lacquais and footmen are like his Galoshes,
which he leaues at the dores of thoÅ¿e he viÅ¿its: His Valets de Chambre, are like his night gowne, which he neuer vÅ¿eth but in his chamber; and leaues them there when he goes in viÅ¿its: His gentlemen attendants, are like his Å¿eueral rich Å¿utes, which he wears not all at once, but now one, now an other, and Å¿ometimes none at all of them: His groome is like his rideing cloake, and neuer appears neare him but vpon the road: But his Gouernour â–ª is like his shirt, which is allwayes next vnto his skinn and perÅ¿on; and therefore as yong Noblemen are curious to haue their shirts of the fineÅ¿t linnen: Å¿o should they haue their Gouernours of the fineÅ¿t thread, and the beÅ¿t Å¿punn men that can be found. Hence the ancients as they were carefull in honouring the memory of thoÅ¿e that had binn Gouernours to great Heroes, as of Chyron, Gouernour of Hercules, IaÅ¿on, Paris, Achilles, and other braue heroes; MiÅ¿cus Gouernour of VlyÅ¿Å¿es; Eudorus of Patroclus; Dares of Hector; Epitides of Iulus, Connidas of TheÅ¿eus; all of them choyce men: So they were in chooÅ¿eing the rareÅ¿t men for that great employment,
to be their childrens Gouernours; that is in their language, CuÅ¿todes & comites iuuentutis Principum & magnatum. For not euery honeÅ¿t and vertuous man (as Å¿ome Parents think) is fit for this employmentâ–ª ThoÅ¿e parts indeed would do well in a Stuard and a Soliciter; but many things els, beÅ¿ides theÅ¿e, muÅ¿t concurre to make vp a good Gouernour. I would haue him then to be not onely a Vertuous man, but a VirtuoÅ¿o too: not onely an honeÅ¿t man,The Character of a good Gouernour. but a man of honour too: not onely a gentleman borne, but a gentile man allÅ¿o by breeding: a man not onely comely of perÅ¿on by nature; but gracefull allÅ¿o by art in his garbes and behauiour: a good Å¿choller, but no meere Å¿choller: a man that hath traueled much in forrain countryes; but yet no fickleheaded man: a man of a Å¿tout Å¿pirit, but yet of a diÅ¿creet tongue, and who knowes rather to waue quarrels prudently, then to maintain them Å¿toutly: a man cheerfull in conuerÅ¿ation, yet fearfull to offend others: a man of that prudence, as to teach his pupil rather to be wiÅ¿e, then witty; and of that example of life, that his deeds may make his pupil beleeue his words:
in fine, I would haue him to be an Englishman, no Å¿tranger. I Å¿peak not this out of an enuy to Å¿trangers, but out of a loue to my owne countrymen. For J haue knowne diuers English gentlemen much wrongd abroad by their Gouernours that were Strangers. Some I haue knowne that led their pupils to Geneua, where they got Å¿ome French language, but loÅ¿t all their true English allegiance and reÅ¿pect to Monarchy; others I haue knowne who, being marryed and haueing their Å¿etlements and intereÅ¿t lyeing at Saumur, kept yong gentlemen there all the time they were abroad; and made their parents in England beleeue, that all good breeding was in that poore towne, where their wifes were breeding children. Others I haue knowne who hauing their miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es in the country, perÅ¿waded their yong pupils, men of great birth, that it was fine liuing in a country houÅ¿e, that is, fine carrying a gunn vpon their necks, and walking a foot. Others haue been obÅ¿erued to Å¿ell their pupils to MaÅ¿ters of exerciÅ¿es, and to haue made them beleeue, that the worÅ¿t Academyes were the beÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e they were the best to the cunning
Gouernour, who had tenn pound a man for euery one he could draw thither. Others I haue knowne who would haue marryed their pupils in France, without their Parents knowledge; and haue Å¿acrificed their great truÅ¿t, to their Å¿ordid auarice. Others J haue knowne who haue locked their pupils in a chamber with a wanton woman, and taken the Key away with them. Nay, this I can Å¿ay more, that of all thoÅ¿e Å¿trangers that I haue knowne Gouernours to yong Nobleman of England (and I haue knowne Å¿euen or eight.) I neuer Knew one of them to be a gentleman borne; but for the moÅ¿t part, they were needy bold men, whoÅ¿e cheif parts were, their owne language and Å¿ome Latin; and whoÅ¿e cheif ayme was, to Å¿erue themÅ¿elues, not their pupils.

But to returne againe to our Å¿ubject, the Parent hauing found out Å¿uch a Gouernour for his Å¿onn, as we haue deÅ¿cribed here aboue, he muÅ¿t reÅ¿igne ouer vnto him his full Authority, and command his Å¿onn to obey him: otherwiÅ¿e let the Gouernour be the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t, and the moÅ¿t compleat man in the world, if his pupil do not obey him,
and follow his counÅ¿el, all will go wrong. I haue Å¿een great diÅ¿orders befall for want of this. Hence I haue often thought of great Clemens Alexandrinus, who Å¿ayth wiÅ¿ely, that our Sauiour ChriÅ¿t is the onely true Pedagogue, or Gouernour, becauÅ¿e he can not onely giue the beÅ¿t inÅ¿tructions to yong men, but alÅ¿o can giue them grace to execute thoÅ¿e inÅ¿tructions: whereas other Gouernours (CaÅ¿Å¿andra like) telling their pupils many excellent truths, are not beleeued by them; nor can they force their inclinations to execute them, except the Parents commands come in to their aÅ¿siÅ¿tance: and it is but reaÅ¿onable, that as Gouernours are the Seconds of Parents, in the breeding of their children, Å¿o Parents should Å¿econd Gouernours too, in makeing their children obey them. And Å¿o much for the Parents care.

For the Å¿onÌ„s care, it muÅ¿t bee this. FirÅ¿t to take a view of England before he enter into forrain countryes. This will enure him to trauel, to Å¿ee company, to obÅ¿erue townes and rarityes, and sharpen his appetite for forrain curioÅ¿i â€¢ yes. I would wish him withall in traueling ouer England, to fall in, as often as he
can, with the Iudges in their circuits, not onely to Å¿ee how his country is gouerned in point of judicature, but allÅ¿o to Å¿ee the gentry of Å¿eueral countryes, who flock to great townes in the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿e week. It would be allÅ¿o profitable to him, to caÅ¿t to be at all the cheif HorÅ¿races, where he will eaÅ¿ily Å¿ee allÅ¿o the gentry of the Å¿euerall counties in a compendious view. Haueing thus Å¿een his owne country in a Å¿ummers space, and haueing got his MajeÅ¿ties licence to trauel beyond the Å¿eas (in which Licence I could wish this clauÅ¿e were inÅ¿erted, That all yong gentlemen should at their returne, preÅ¿ent themÅ¿elues to his MajeÅ¿ty, to giue him an account of their trauels and obÅ¿eruations) I would haue him depart England about the beginning of October.

2. At his going out of England, let him take his ayme right; that is, let him ayme altogether at his profit, and not at his pleaÅ¿ures onely. J haue knowne many Englishmen who for want of right ayming, haue miÅ¿Å¿ed the white of breeding, whole heauens breadth. For Å¿ome in traueling, ayme at nothing but to get looÅ¿e, from their
Parents, or Å¿choolmaÅ¿ters, and to haue the fingering of a pretty allowance; and theÅ¿e men when they come into France, care for Å¿eeing no court, but the TenniÅ¿court; delight in Å¿eing no Balls but Tennisballs; and forÅ¿ake any company, to toÅ¿se whole dayes together with a tattered Marker in the Tripot.

Others deÅ¿ire to go into Italy, onely becauÅ¿e they heare there are fine CurtiÅ¿anes in Venice; and as the Queen of the Amazons, in IuÅ¿tin, went thirteen dayes journey out of her country, onely to haue a nights lodgeing with Alexander the Great, Å¿o theÅ¿e men trauel a whole month together, to Venice, for a nights lodgeing with an impudent woman. And thus by a falÅ¿e ayming at breeding abroad, they returne with thoÅ¿e diÅ¿eaÅ¿es which hinder them from breeding at home.

Others trauel abroad, as our ship-boyes do into the Indies: for whiles theÅ¿e boyes might bring home Iewels, Pearles, ad many other things of valew, they bring home nothing but firecanes, parots, and Monkies; Å¿o our yong trauelers, whiles they
might bring home many rich obÅ¿eruations, for the gouerning themÅ¿elues, and others, bring home nothing but Fire-canes, that is, a hotÅ¿pur humor, that takes fire at euery word, and talkes of nothing but duels, Å¿econds, and eÅ¿claireiÅ¿Å¿ements: or elÅ¿e parots, that is, come loaden home with rubans and feathers of all colours like parots, and with a few borowed compliments in their mouths, which make them talke like parots: or els Monkies, that is, Å¿ome affected cringes, shrugs, and Å¿uch like Apish behauiour.

3. At his embarking let him haue a Å¿pecial care not to carry HimÅ¿elf abroad with HimÅ¿elf in traueling. Many men, Å¿ayth Seneca, returne home no better then they went out, becauÅ¿e they take themÅ¿elues along with themÅ¿elues in traueling: and as a man in a feauer, findes himÅ¿elf no better then he was, by changeing his bed; becauÅ¿e he carryes his feauour with him whereÅ¿oeuer he lyes: Å¿o many yong men returne home tyred, and dirted, but not better and wiÅ¿er; becauÅ¿e they caryed abroad their bad cuÅ¿tomes and manners with them. I would then that my yong traueler
should leaue behinde him all willfulneÅ¿Å¿, and Å¿tubborneÅ¿s; all tenderneÅ¿s, and Å¿eeking his eaÅ¿e too much; all effeminatneÅ¿Å¿e and delicateneÅ¿s; all boyish tricks with hands or mouth, and mocking of others; all delighting in being the beÅ¿t man in the company; all familiarity with Å¿eruants, and meane men; all Tauernes, and intemperancy of eating and drinking; hauing that Å¿aying of Seneca often in his mouth, and minde; Major Å¿um & ad majora natus, quÃ m vt mancipium Å¿im corporis mei: I am too great a man, and borne to too great things, for to become the Å¿laue of my body. In fine I would haue him imitate that yong gentleman of whom S. AmbroÅ¿e Å¿peaks; who returning home from forrain trauels, and meeting with his old miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e, a wanton woman, Å¿eemed not to know her; whereat she wondering, told him that â€¢ he was Å¿uch an one: it may be Å¿o, Å¿ayd he, but I am no more I. A rare Apothegme, which I would wish my yong Traueler to take for his motto, as well as this yong man for his exemple.

4. Being thus got out of England,
its a great queÅ¿tion into what country he should firÅ¿t go, to make his aboad. The common courÅ¿e is, to go firÅ¿t into France, and then into Italy, and Å¿o home by Germany, Holand, and Flanders, as J did once: but my opinion is, that its better for a yong man to go first into Italy, and returning by Germany, Holland and Flanders, come into France, to giue himÅ¿elf there the laÅ¿t hand in breeding. And my reaÅ¿on is this; For Å¿eing the intention of traueling, is to make a man a wiÅ¿e man, not a finical man, its better to Å¿eaÅ¿on his minde betimes with a Å¿tayd wiÅ¿e breeding, then to fill it vp to the brime at firÅ¿t, with a phantaÅ¿tical giddy breeding, which hauing once gotten poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the minde, bolts the doore on the inÅ¿ide, locks out all Å¿taydneÅ¿s, and makes my yong man delight in nothing but vanity, clothes, danceing, liueryes, bals, and Å¿uch meere outÅ¿ides. I would therefore haue my yong noblemans Gouernour to carry him immediatly into Italy at fifteen or Å¿ixteen, and there Å¿eaÅ¿on his minde with the grauity, and wiÅ¿e maximes of that Nation, which hath ciuilized the whole
world, and taught Man Manhood. Hauing Å¿pent two, or three yeares in Italy in learning the language, viewing the Å¿eueral courts, Å¿tuddying their maximes, imitating their gentile conuerÅ¿ation, and following the Å¿weet exerciÅ¿es of muÅ¿ick, painting, architecture, and mathematicks, he will at his returne, know what true vÅ¿e to make of France. And hauing Å¿pent three yeares more there, in learning to fence, dance, ride, vault, handle his pike, musket, coulors &c. The Map, hiÅ¿tory, and bookes of Policy; he will be ready to come home at twenty, or one and twenty, a man moÅ¿t compleat both in body, and mind; and fit to fill the place of his calling.

5. I Å¿ay, make true vs of France: For I would not haue my yong traueler imitate all things he Å¿ees done in France, or other forrain countryes.What to be learnt in France, and what not. I would haue him learne of the French a hanÅ¿ome confidence; but not an â€¢ mpudent boldneÅ¿s. He muÅ¿t learne of them to come into Ã Roome with a
â€¢ onne mine; but not to rush into a mans chamber, as they do, without Å¿o much as knocking at the doore. He
muÅ¿t learne of them to dance well, to get a good grace in walkeing, and Å¿aluting, as they do: but he must not dance as he walkes, as many of them do. He muÅ¿t learne of the French, to become any clothes well; but he muÅ¿t not follow them in all their PhantaÅ¿tical and fanfaron clothings. He must learne to fence well, as they do; but I would haue his Å¿word Å¿tick faÅ¿ter in the Å¿cabbard then theirs do. In fine, I would haue him open, ayry, and gallant, as they are: but not affecting to be the Gallands of all Ladyes, as they do.

What in Italy, and what not.So in Italy, J would haue him learne to make a fine houÅ¿e; but J would not haue him learne of the Italians to keep a good houÅ¿e. He may learne of them to be Å¿ober, and wiÅ¿e: but I would not haue him learne of them be gealous and diÅ¿truÅ¿tfull. I would haue him learne of the Italians, to receiue thoÅ¿e that viÅ¿ite him, with great ciuility and reÅ¿pect; but I would not haue him Å¿tand vpon all their little formes and incommodious puntiglios. I would haue him to be free of his Hat, as they are: but I would haue the heart
to go to the Hat, as well as the hand.

Jn Germany I would haue him learne to offer a man a cup of wine at his comeing in;What in Germany, and wha â€¢ not. but I would not haue him preÅ¿Å¿e Å¿o much wine vpon him, as he shall not be able â€¢ o go out againe, as they often do. I would haue him learne of them to go freely to warre for the defence of his country: but I would not haue him learne the cuÅ¿tome of thoÅ¿e vendible souls there, who carry their lifes to market, and Å¿erue any Prince for money. I like well their shakeing hands with you, when you firÅ¿t enter into their houÅ¿es; but I like not their quarreling with you for not pledgeing a health of a yard long, which would ruine yours. I like very much their Å¿ingular modeÅ¿ty and chaÅ¿tity, which allowes not baÅ¿tards to be freemen of the moÅ¿t ordinary trads: but I like not their endleÅ¿Å¿e drinking in feaÅ¿ts, which is able to make them freemen of all vices.

In Holland allÅ¿o I would haue him learne to keep his houÅ¿e and harth neat,What in Holland, and what not. but I would no â€¢ haue him adore his houÅ¿e, and Å¿tand in Å¿uch awe of his harth, as not to dare to make
a fire in it, as they do. I would haue him learne of them, a Å¿pare dyet; but I would not haue him drink Å¿o much, as would keep him both in good dyet and clothes, as they do. I would haue him learne of them their great induÅ¿try, and oeconomy: but not their rude exacting vpon Noblemen Å¿trangers in their Inns, for their Quality Å¿ake onely, as they do. I would haue him learne of them a Å¿ingular loue to his country: but he muÅ¿t take heed of their clownish hatred of Nobility. Thus in all countryes I would haue my yong Traueler do, as men do at a great feaÅ¿t, where ther is no feare of Å¿taruing; that is, not eate greedily of all thats before him, but fall to the beÅ¿t meats, and leaue the worÅ¿t for the waiters.

6. That he may follow the foreÅ¿ayd rule the better, and pick out of euery country whats the beÅ¿t in it, let his Gouernour lead him betimes into the beÅ¿t company; for there the beÅ¿t leÅ¿Å¿ons are to be learned. Now by the word beÅ¿t, I do not meane the greateÅ¿t men in birth, but in parts. For the world is not Å¿o happy, as that the greateÅ¿t men are allwayes the beÅ¿t: but by
the word beÅ¿t, I meane thoÅ¿e that a â€¢ e the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t, the beÅ¿t bred, the beÅ¿t principled, the beÅ¿t behaued, and the moÅ¿t cryed vp by ciuil perÅ¿ons: for of Å¿uch men much is to be learned: Their life is a perpetual lecture; their words Å¿o many oracles; their diÅ¿courÅ¿es Å¿o many wiÅ¿e maxims: and though yong men be not able to bring their dish with them, and clubb wit equally with theÅ¿e men, yet its a great matter to Å¿it still in their company, and be a reÅ¿pectfull catechumen to them. For if it be true which Quintillian Å¿ayth of thoÅ¿e that loue Cicero, Ciceronem amaÅ¿Å¿e, profeciÅ¿Å¿e eÅ¿t, its allÅ¿o moÅ¿t certain, that a man that loues good company, muÅ¿t be good himÅ¿elf in time.

7. And that he may be able to appeare in good company without blushing, his Gouernour muÅ¿t get him, as Å¿oone as he can, to Å¿peak the language of the place in hanÅ¿ome tearmes, and with a good accent. Next he must haue a care that he be well adjuÅ¿ted and Å¿et out in apparel. For if anciently Iewels were called the Vshers of Ladyes, becauÅ¿e all doores flew open to them that
preÅ¿ented themÅ¿elues Å¿o richly adorned: Å¿o now a dayes good clothes may be called mens vshers, Å¿eeing they make way for them into all companyes. He muÅ¿t haue a care that he know his Congies perfectly, and haue a free garbe or carriage; a Cauallier way of entering into a Roome; a gratefull manegeing of his mouth and Å¿miles; a chyronomie, or decent acting with his handes, which may humour his words grauely and freely, yet not affectedly or mimically: in fine, a liberty or freedome in all his actions, which The French call libertÃ© du corps; and it muÅ¿t appeare to be Ã la negligence, and yet muÅ¿t be perfectly Å¿tuddyed a fore hand. And though theÅ¿e things be but the Elements and Alphabet of breeding, yet without them he can neuer Å¿pel gentleman rightly, though his inÅ¿ide be neuer Å¿o good. Indeed its long ago, that great men dwell no more in thatched houÅ¿es.

8. But it is not enough to get him into Language and Garbes, if he get him not into Coach and Liueryes, without which he can neuer appeare at Court, or in good company, eÅ¿pecially
in Rome and Paris; the two cheif townes of long abode abroad. For let a man be of a Race as ancient as the Autocthenes of Athens, who Å¿ayd they were as ancient as the Earth;Plutarch. and let him quarter his coat of Armes with the three Lyons of England, and the three Flower de-lys of France, as I know a gentleman of little Britany doth, (by the grant anciently of both thoÅ¿e kings) yet I dare boldly Å¿ay this, that in Paris no colours blazon a mans nobility behind his coache Å¿o much, as three Lacquais and a Page, in a hanÅ¿ome Liuery. In other townes of France, where yong gentlemen vÅ¿e to liue at firÅ¿t, till they get the language, a couple of Å¿adle horÅ¿es would be very vÅ¿efull, both to take the ayre on, as allÅ¿o to viÅ¿it the gentry in the country at their Å¿ummer houÅ¿es, where a Man will fine great ciuilityes, and diuertiÅ¿ments. BeÅ¿ides rideing out Å¿o in the fresh euenings of Å¿ummer, will not onely weane my yong gentleman from little company, and the crowd of his countrymen who will be then preÅ¿Å¿ing vpon him; but will allÅ¿o afford his Gouernour many fine Å¿olitary occaÅ¿ions of plying him alone with good counÅ¿els
and inÅ¿tructions.

9. And Å¿eing J haue touched Å¿omething aboue of his Å¿eruants, and Lacquais, I will adde this, that Å¿eing it is none of the leaÅ¿t bleÅ¿Å¿ings of a yong gentleman to haue good Å¿eruants about him, it belongs to his Gouernour, not onely to chooÅ¿e him good ones, but allÅ¿o to haue power to turne away bad ones. Many men carry ouer with them English Å¿eruants, becauÅ¿e they were their Å¿choolfellowes, or their tennants Å¿onns: and theÅ¿e are little vÅ¿efull for a long time, and euen then when a man hath moÅ¿t need of Å¿eruants. BeÅ¿ides, they are often too familiar with their maÅ¿ters, their old play-fellowes; and as often troubleÅ¿ome to their Gouernours, by takeing their yong maÅ¿ters part againÅ¿t them; and by raueling out at night, as they get their maÅ¿ters to bed, all that the prudent Gouernour hath been working in the day time. Others carry ouer Frenchmen with them; but theÅ¿e often, by reaÅ¿on of their prerogatiue of language, which their maÅ¿ters want at firÅ¿t, get Å¿uch an aÅ¿cendent ouer them, that they come oftentimes to be too bold, and Å¿awcy with them. For my
part, I would haue his Gouernour, to take him new Å¿eruants in euery place he comes to Å¿tay; and thoÅ¿e Å¿ightly, rather then too Å¿prightly youths: Dull people are made to tugg at the oare of obedience, Å¿ayth AriÅ¿totle, w â€¢ iles witty people are fitter to Å¿it at the helme of command.

10. But I am to blame to giue aduice to Gouernours whom I Å¿uppoÅ¿e to be wiÅ¿er men then my Å¿elfe; and therefore will end here, by wishing them a good journey, and Å¿afe returne: To the effecting of both which, I found no better Å¿ecret, them that in my laÅ¿t journey, which was to be mounted vpon our owne horÅ¿es, (fiue of vs together) and to Å¿pare for no coÅ¿t: for by this means, we went at our owne rates, and eat to our owne mindes: Å¿o true is the Italian Prouerbe; Picole giornate, egrandi Å¿peÅ¿e, ti conducono Å¿ano al tuo paeÅ¿e.

In fine, I would haue my yong traueler make the Å¿ame prayer of God, as Apollonius Thyanaeus made to the Sunn, at his going out to trauell, that is, that hee would bee Å¿o fauourable to him as to shew him all the BraueÅ¿t and BeÅ¿t men in the world.

div.head: THE VOYAGE OF ITALY.
div.p: BEFORE I come to a particular deÅ¿cription of Italy, as I found it in my Fiue Å¿eueral voyages through it, I think it not amiÅ¿Å¿e to Å¿peak Å¿omething in General, of the Country it Å¿elf, its Inhabitants, their Humours, Manners, CuÅ¿tomes, Riches, and Religion.

For the Country it Å¿elf, it Å¿eemed to me to be Natures Darling, The Fertility of Italy. and the EldeÅ¿t SiÅ¿ter of all other countryes; carrying away from them, all the greateÅ¿t bleÅ¿Å¿ings and fauours; and receiuing Å¿uch gracious lookes from the Sun and Heauen, that if there be any fault in Italy, it is that her Mother Nature hath
cockered her too much, euen to make her become Wanton. WitneÅ¿Å¿e luxuriant Lombardy, and Campania antonomaÅ¿tically Foelix, which Florus, Trogus, and Liuy think to be the beÅ¿t parts of the world, where Ceres and Bacchus are at a perpetual Å¿trife, whether of them shall court man the moÅ¿t, she by filling his barnes with corne; he by making his cellars Å¿wimme with wine: Whiles the other parts of Italy are Å¿weating out whole ForeÅ¿ts of Oliue-trees, whole woods of Lemmons, and Oranges, whole fields of Rice, Turky wheat, and Muskmillions; and where thoÅ¿e Bare Hills, which Å¿eem to be shauen by the Sun, and curÅ¿ed by Nature for their barrenÌ„es, are oftentimes great with child of pretious Marbles, the ornaments of Churches and Palaces, and the Reuenews of Princes: witneÅ¿Å¿e the Prince of MaÅ¿Å¿a: whoÅ¿e beÅ¿t Reuenues are his Marble Quarries: Nature here thinking it a farre more noble thing to feed Princes, Then to feed sheep. It abounds allÅ¿o in Å¿ilks and Å¿ilkwormes; out of which they draw
a notable profit; and for the feeding of them they keep a world of Mulberry trees whoÅ¿e leaues are the food of thoÅ¿e little wormes, whoÅ¿e excrement is our pride; thus, Adam like, we are clade in leaues againe, but leaues once remoued. Its rich allÅ¿o in paÅ¿turage and cattle, eÅ¿pecially in Lombardy, where I haue Å¿een cheeÅ¿es of an exceÅ¿Å¿iue greatneÅ¿Å¿e, and of a ParmeÅ¿an goodneÅ¿Å¿e. The Å¿urface allÅ¿o of the earth is couered with many curious Å¿imples, aÌ„d wholeÅ¿ome hearbs: HenÅ¿e Å¿o many rare eÅ¿Å¿ences, cordials, parfumes, Å¿weet waters, and other odoriferous diÅ¿tillations Å¿o common here, that ordinary Barbers, and LandreÅ¿Å¿es will Å¿pinkle them in your face and parfume your linnen with them, ouer and aboue your bargain. Hence none of the meaneÅ¿t things to be Å¿een in Italy, are the fondaries or Å¿tilling houÅ¿es of the Great Duke of Florence, the Å¿peciarie or Apothecaries â€¢ hops, of the Dominicans of S. Marco, and of the AuguÅ¿tins of S. Spirito in Florence; of the Roman Colledge, and of the Minimes of
Trinita di Monte in Rome: where euen death it felf would find a cure in nature, if it were not a curÅ¿e from the author of nature. In fine, it excells in all kind of prouiÅ¿ions, either for dyet, or Å¿port; and I haue Å¿een in Rome whole cartloads of wild boares, and VeniÅ¿on, brought in at once to be Å¿old in the market; and aboue threeÅ¿core Hares in Florence brought in, in one day by the two companyes of Hunters, the Piaceuoli and Piatelli, on a general hunting day.

An obiectioÌ„ againÅ¿t Italy.Yet after all this, Å¿ome cryout againÅ¿t Italy, for being too hot; and paint vs out its ayre as an vnwholeÅ¿ome peÅ¿tilential ayre; its Å¿un, as an angry Comet, whoÅ¿e beames are all pointed with plagues and feauers; and the country it Å¿elf, as a place, where Å¿taruing is the onely way to liue in health; where men eat by method and art; where you muÅ¿t carry your body Å¿teddily, or els Å¿pill your life; and where there are Å¿o many prouincial Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿es and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es; as the catarres of Genua,
the Goute of Milan, the Hemorrhoids of Venice, the falling Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e of Florence, the Feauers of Rome, and the Goistre of Piedmont.

For my part, when I am told that there were in Plynies time,AnÅ¿wer. fourteen millions of men in Italy:Baltazar Bonifacius in hiÅ¿t. Ludicra l. 13. c. 1 â€¢ . when I read, that there are now aboue three thouÅ¿and Cittyes in Italy, and moÅ¿t of them Cittyes of Garbo: when I meet with national diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in euery other country, as the Kingseuil in Spayne, the Poxe in France, the conÅ¿umption in Portugal, the cholick in England, the deÅ¿Å¿entery in GaÅ¿cony, the headacke in TolouÅ¿e &c. when I reflect, how this Sun hath bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lombardy, and made Campania Happy: when I call to mind, that it hath filled the Cellars of Italy with aboue Thirty Å¿eueral forts of wines: when I remember, what health it hath powred into Å¿eueral hearbs here, what admirable fruits it furnisheth the markets with all, what ornaments it affords to Gods houÅ¿es, ouercruÅ¿tting
allmoÅ¿t all the cheif Churches of Italy, Sol & homo generant hominem. Plutarchus in Graccho. with exquiÅ¿it marbles; when I conÅ¿ider in fine, how this Sun hath helpt to make Å¿o many braue Soldiers, and Schollers, I dare not Å¿peak ill of the Sun, or ayre of Italy, leaÅ¿t Balzac check mee, as Gracchus did him who Å¿poke ill of his mother, with a Tu Matri meae maledicis,
â€¢ alzacin 1. volum: liter. quae Tiberium Gracchum genuit? DareÅ¿t thou Å¿peak ill of that Sun which helpt to make CaeÅ¿ar?

The InhabitaÌ„ts and their wits.Yes, yes, its this great bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God, warme Sun, which hath Å¿o throughly baked the Italian wits, that while (according to the obÅ¿eruation of Charles the V) the French appeare not wiÅ¿e, but are wiÅ¿e: the Å¿paniards appeare wiÅ¿e, but are not wiÅ¿e: the Dutch neither appeare wiÅ¿e, nor are wiÅ¿e; The Italians onely both appeare wiÅ¿e, and are wiÅ¿e. Hence the Italians anciently afforded vs thoÅ¿e prodigies of wit and learning, and Å¿et vs thoÅ¿e fair coppies in liberal arts and Å¿ciences, which all men follow, but none attain vnto Å¿o
much, as thoÅ¿e that write the Italian hand; that is, the moderne Italians themÅ¿elues.

For if the Italians anciently had their Virgil, their Ouid, PoÃ«ts Ancient, and Moderne in Italy. their Horace, their PerÅ¿ius, and Propertius in PoÃ«try; the moderne Italians Å¿purr cloÅ¿e vp to them, and haue their TaÅ¿o, their Petrarck, their Sannazarius, their Marino, and Guarini.

If the old Italians had their SaluÅ¿t, HiÅ¿torians. Liuy, Tacitus, and Valerius Maximus in hiÅ¿tory; the moderne Jtalians haue their Guicciardin, Bentiu â€¢
glio, Dauila, Strada, and BaptiÅ¿ta FregoÅ¿us, Å¿urnamed the Å¿econd Valerius Maximus.

If the ancient Italians had their pompous Orators, their Cicero, Orators. HortenÅ¿ius, Porcius Latro, Iunius Gallio, Aulius FuÅ¿cus &c. The moderne Italians haue their Panigarola, Manzini, Varchi, and Loredano.

If the ancient Italians had their VaÅ¿t knowing Varro;Prodigies of learning. the moderne Italians haue their omniÅ¿cious Baronius, who red allmoÅ¿t all that other men had written, and wrot
more allmoÅ¿t, then other men can read.

Diuines.If the ancient Italians had their Diuines, writing of the Number and Nature of their Gods, to wit, Varro and Tully; the moderne Italians haue their Diuines too, their inimitable S. Thomas of Aquin, and his learned Å¿econd Cardinal CaÃ¯etan.
PhiloÅ¿ophers.If the ancient Italians had their PhiloÅ¿ophers, their Pliny, their Cato, their Seneca &c. the moderne Jtalians haue their Ficinus, their Cardan, and their Picus Mirandula.

Architects.If the ancient Italians had their rare Architects, Statuaries, Painters; the moderne Jtalians haue their BrunelleÅ¿chi, Palladio, Fontana, and Cronaco, in Architecture; their Bandinelli, Donatello, Oli â€¢â€¢ ri â€¢ , and Bernini in Sculpture;Sculptors. their Raphael, Michel Angelo, Titian, and Sarto, in painting.Painters.

If in fine, the ancient Italians had their braue Captains, their Scipio, Ancient and moderne Captains. Duilius, Marius, and CeÅ¿ar, the moderne Italians haue their Scipio too, towit, their Alexander FarneÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e true actions make
Romances blush, hauing done that really, which Fables can Å¿carce faigne in galantry: Their Duilius too, towit, their Andrea Doria, the Neptune of the Ligurian Seas, who alone taught his country not to Å¿erue: Their Marius alÅ¿o, towit, their braue CaÅ¿truccio, who from a Comman Å¿oldier mounted vp by deÅ¿erts to the higheÅ¿t military commands in the Emperors army; and Å¿o Å¿titched his fortune as he went along to honours, that it neuer raueled out againe, or failed him: In fine, their CaeÅ¿ar too, towit, the Marquis Spinola, or rather, the Achilles of Jtaly, who tooke that Troy, of OÅ¿tende, after three years Seige. This Seige was farre more famous then that of Troy, becauÅ¿e farre truer. For in the Seige of Troy, it was PoÃ«try onely that made the warre, that framed and filled the woodden horÅ¿e with worthyes;See VerÅ¿tegan in his reÅ¿titution of decayed intelligence. that draged Hector round about the walls. It was pen and inck that killed Å¿o many men Å¿omno vin â€¢ que Å¿epultos; and Troy was eaÅ¿ily burnt, becauÅ¿e it was built of PoÃ«ts Paper.
But at OÅ¿ten all was reall, and all Europe allmoÅ¿t, who had their forces, or eyes there, were witneÅ¿Å¿es of it; and all this done by Spinola an Jtalian.

The Jtalian Humour.As for the Jtalian humour, it is a midling humour, between too much grauity of the Å¿paniard, and too great leuity of the French. Their grauity is notwithout Å¿ome fire, nor their leuity without Å¿ome fleame. They are apish enough in Carneual time, and vpon their Å¿tages, as long as the viÅ¿ard is on; but that once off, they are too wiÅ¿e to play the fooles in their owne names, and owne it with their owne faces. They haue Å¿trong fancies, and yet Å¿olid iudgements; A happy temper, which makes them great Preachers, Politicians, and Ingeniers; but withall they are a little too melancholy and gealous; They are great louers of their brethren and neare kinred, as the firÅ¿t freinds they are acquinted withall by nature; and if any of them lye in paÅ¿Å¿e and fair for aduancement, all the reÅ¿t of his relations will lend him their purÅ¿es, as well
as their shoulders, to help him vp, though he be but their younger brother. They are Å¿paring in dyet, both for to liue in health, and to liue hanÅ¿omly: making their bellyes contribute to the maintenance of their backs, and their kitchen help to the keeping of their Å¿table. They are ambitious Å¿till of honours, remembering they are the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors of the maÅ¿ters of the world, the old Romans; and to put the world Å¿till in mind of it, they take to themÅ¿elues the glorious names of Camillo, Scipione, Julio, Mario, Pompeo &c. They are as Å¿enÅ¿ible allÅ¿o of their honour, as deÅ¿irous of honours; and this makes them Å¿trickt to their wifes euen to gelouÅ¿y, knowing that for one Cornelius Tacitus, there haue been ten Publij Cornelij; and that Lucius Cornificius is the moÅ¿t affronting man. They are hard to be pleaÅ¿ed, when thy haue been once read hoat with offence; but they will not meet reuenge in the face, and feild; and they will rather hire it, then take it. In fine they affect very
much compounded names, as Pi â€¢
colomini, Capilupo, Bentiuoglio, MaleÅ¿pina, Boncompagno, Maluezzi, Riccobono, MalateÅ¿ta, Homodei, and Å¿uch like marryed Names.

Their maÌ„ ners.As for their Manners, they are moÅ¿t commendable. They haue taught them in their bookes, they practiÅ¿e them in their actions,See MonÅ¿ignor Caza, Stephano Guazzo, Baltazar CaÅ¿tiglioÌ„e and they haue spred them abroad ouer all Europe, which owes its Ciuility vnto the Jtalians, as well as its Religion. They neuer affront Å¿trangers in what habit Å¿oeuer they appeare; and if the Å¿trangeneÅ¿Å¿e of the habit draw the Jtalians, eye to it, yet he will neuer draw in his mouth to laugh at it. As for their apparel, or dreÅ¿Å¿e, its commonly black, and modeÅ¿t. They value no brauery but that of Coache and horÅ¿es and Staffiers; and they Å¿acrifize a world of little Å¿atisfactions to that main one of being able to keep a Coache. Their Points de Venice, ribans and goldlace, are all turned into horÅ¿es and liueries; and that money which we Å¿pend in treats and
Tauernes, they spend in coache and furniture. They neuer whiÅ¿per priuately with one another in company, not Å¿peak to one another alowd in an vnknowne tongue when thy are in conuerÅ¿ation with others, thinking this to be no other then a lowd whiÅ¿pering.

They are preciÅ¿e in point of Ceremony and reception;Their Ceremonies. and are not puzzeled at all, when they heare a great man is comeing to viÅ¿it them. Theres not a man of them, but he knowes how to entertain men of all conditions; that is, how farre to meet, how to place them, how to Å¿tile and treat them, how to reconduct them, and how farr. They are good for Nunciatures, EmbaÅ¿sies, and State employments, being men of good behauiour, lookes, temper, and diÅ¿cretion, and neuer outrunning their buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. They are great louers of MuÅ¿ick, Meddales, Statues, and Pictures, as things which either diuert their melancholy, or humor it: and I haue read of one Jacomo Raynero a shoomaker of Bolognia, who gathered together Å¿o many curious
Meddals of Gold, Å¿iluer, and braÅ¿Å¿e, as would haue becomne the Cabinet of any Prince. In fine, they are extreamely ciuil to one another, not onely out of an awe they Å¿tand in one towards another, not knowing whoÅ¿e turne it may be next, to come to the higheÅ¿t honours; but allÅ¿o out of a natural grauity, and ciuil education, which makes euen Å¿choolboyes (an inÅ¿olent Nation any where elÅ¿e) moÅ¿t reÅ¿pectfull to one another in words and deeds; treating one another with VoÅ¿tra Signoria, and abÅ¿taining from all gioco di mano. Nay maÅ¿ters themÅ¿elues here, neuer beat their Å¿eruant, but remitt them to juÅ¿tice, if the fault require it, and I cannot remember to haue heard in Rome, two women Å¿cold publickly, or man and wife quarrel in words, except once; and then they did it Å¿o priuatly and Å¿ecretly, and Å¿colded in Å¿uch a low tone, that I perceiued the Italians had reaÅ¿on about them euen in the middÅ¿t of their choler.

Their particular customes.As for their particular cuÅ¿tomes, they are many. They marry by their
eares, oftener then by their eyes; and Å¿carce Å¿peake with one another, till they meete before the Parish PrieÅ¿t, to Å¿peake the indiÅ¿Å¿oluable words of wedlock. They make children go barehead till they be four or fiue years old, hardening them thus againÅ¿t rhumes and catarres when they shall be old. Hence few people in Italy go Å¿o warme on their heads, as they do in France; men in their houÅ¿es wearing nothing vpon their heads but a little calotte; and women for the moÅ¿t part, going all barehead in the midÅ¿t of winter it Å¿elf. Women here alÅ¿o wash their heads weekly in a wash made for the nonce, and dry them againe in the Sun, to make their hair yellow, a colour much in vogue here among Ladyes. The men throw of their hats, cuffs, and bandes, as well as their cloaks, at their returne home from viÅ¿its, or buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, and put on a gray coate, without which they cannot dine, or Å¿upp; and I haue been inuited to dinner by an Italian, who before dinner, made his men take of our hats and cloaks,
and preÅ¿ent euery one of vs (and we were fiue in all) with a coloured coate, and a little cap to dine in. At dinner they Å¿erue in the beÅ¿t meats firÅ¿t, and eat backwardsâ–ª that is, they beginn with the Å¿econd courÅ¿e, and end with boyld meat and pottage. They neuer preÅ¿ent you with Å¿alt, or braines of any fowle, leaÅ¿t they may Å¿eeme to reproach vnto you want of wit. They bring you drink vpon a Sottocoppa of Å¿yluer, with three or four glaÅ¿Å¿es vpon it; Two or three of which are Å¿trait neckt glaÅ¿Å¿es (called there caraffas) full of Å¿eueral Å¿orts of wines or water, and one empty drinking glaÅ¿Å¿e, into which you may powre what quantity of wine and water you pleaÅ¿e to drink, and not Å¿tand to the diÅ¿cretion of the waiters, as they do in other countrys. At great feaÅ¿ts, no man cuts for himÅ¿elf, but Å¿eueral caruers cut-vp all the meat at a Å¿ide table, and giue it to the waiters to be carryed to the gheÅ¿ts; and euery one hath the very Å¿ame part of meat carryed vnto him, to wit, a wing
and a legg of wild fowle &c. leaÅ¿t any one take exceptions that others were better vÅ¿ed then hee. The Caruers neuer touch the meat with their hands, but onely with their knife and forke, and great Syluer Å¿poone for the Å¿auce. Euery man here eats with his forke and knife, and neuer toucheth any thing with his fingers, but his bread: This keeps the linnen neat, and the fingers Å¿weet. If you drink to an Italian, he thanks you, with bending, when you Å¿alute him, and lets you drink quietly, without watching (as we do in England) to thank you againe when you haue drunk: and the firÅ¿t time he drinks after that, will be to you, in requitall of your former courteÅ¿y.

They count not the houres of the day as we do, from twelue to twelue; but they beginn their count from Å¿unÅ¿et, and the firÅ¿t houre after Å¿unÅ¿et, is one a clock; and Å¿o they count on till four and Twenty, that is, till the next Å¿unÅ¿et againe. I haue often dined at Å¿ixteen a clock, and gone abroad in the euening, to take
the ayre, at two and twenty. They call men much by their ChriÅ¿ten names, Signor Pietro, Signor FranceÅ¿co, Signor Jacomo &c. and you may liue whole years with an Italian, Nomen, quaÅ¿i no
â€¢ amen. S. Aug. and be very well acquinted with him without knowing him, that is, without knowing his diÅ¿tintiue Å¿urname. People of quality neuer viÅ¿it one another, but they Å¿end firÅ¿t, to know when they may do it without troubleing him they intend to viÅ¿it: by this meanes they neuer rush into one anothers chambers without knocking, as they do in France; nor croÅ¿Å¿e the deÅ¿ignes, or buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of him they viÅ¿it, as they do in England with tedious dry viÅ¿its; nor find one another either vndreÅ¿Å¿ed in clothes, vnprouided in compliments and diÅ¿courÅ¿e, or without their attendants, and traine about them. In the Å¿treets men and women of condition Å¿eldome or neuer go together in the Å¿ame coache, except they be Å¿trangers, that is, of an other towne, or country: nay huÅ¿bands and wifes are Seldome Å¿een together in the Å¿ame coache, becauÅ¿e all men
do not know them to be Å¿o. In the Å¿treets, when two perÅ¿ons of great quality meet, as two EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, or two Cardinales, they both Å¿top their coaches, and compliment one another ciuily, and then retire; but Å¿till he that is inferiour muÅ¿t let the others coache moue firÅ¿t. If any man being a foot in the Å¿treet, meet a great man, either in coache, or a foot, he muÅ¿t not Å¿alute him in going on his way, as we do in England and France, without Å¿topping; but he muÅ¿t Å¿tand Å¿till whiles the other paÅ¿Å¿eth, and bend reÅ¿pectfully to him as he goes by, and then continue his march. In fine, of all the Nations I haue Å¿een, I know none that liues, clothes, eats, drinks, and Å¿peaks Å¿o much with reaÅ¿on, as the Italians do.

As for their Riches, Their Riches. they muÅ¿t needs be great. That which is viÅ¿ible in their magnificent Pallaces, Churches, MonaÅ¿teries, Gardens, Fountains, and rich furnished Roomes, Å¿peaks that to be great which is in their coffers: and that which the King of Å¿payne drawes viÅ¿ibly
from Naples euery yeare, shews what the other parts of Italy could do for a need, if they were put to it by neceÅ¿Å¿ity. Nay, I am of opinion, that the very SacriÅ¿ty of Loreto, the Gallery of the Duke of Florence, and the TreaÅ¿ory of Venice, would vpon an emergent occaÅ¿ion of a Gothick, or Turkish inuaÅ¿ion, be able to maintain an army for fiue yeares Å¿pace; and the Plate in Churches and MonaÅ¿teryes, would be able to do as much more, if the owners of it were Å¿oundly frighted with a new Gothick irruption. As for the Riches of particular Princes in Italy, I will Å¿peak of them, as I view their Stats here below.

In fine, as for their Religion, its purely that which other countrys call by its true name,Their Religion. Catholick; and which in England they commonly call, the Religion of the PapiÅ¿ts. And though there they think to nickname the Catholick by calling him PapiÅ¿t, yet the well inÅ¿tructed Catholick knowing that the name of PapiÅ¿t, comes not from any SectmaÅ¿ter, as CaluiniÅ¿t, Lutheran, Socinian, and BrowniÅ¿t doe; nor from
any Sectary meeting place, as Hugonots from the Gate of Hugo in Towers in France, neare vnto which they mett priuately at firÅ¿t to teach and dogmatiÅ¿e: nor from any publick Å¿ectary action, as AnabaptiÅ¿ts, Dippers, Quakers &c. do: but from the word Papa, which Å¿ignifies Father, and is not the name of any one man, or Pope, but onely Å¿ignifies his Fatherly office of PaÅ¿tor; tho Catholick I Å¿ay, is no more troubled at this name of PapiÅ¿t, then he was when hee was called in the late troubles, RoyalliÅ¿t (for adhearing to the king, which is not the name of any of our kings,Rex eÅ¿t nomen officij. S. Ambr. but his office onely) and not CromwelliÅ¿t, which was the name of one adhearing to a particular man called Cromwell, and an vnlawfull vÅ¿urper of Power. As for the true name indeed, which is Catholick, it is Å¿o knowne to belong to thoÅ¿e of the Roman Church, that beÅ¿ides that all thoÅ¿e of that Church haue euer called themÅ¿elues by no other name then this of Catholick, the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t of ProteÅ¿tants alÅ¿o acknowledge
it publikely to be their diÅ¿tinctiue name: witneÅ¿Å¿e that Å¿olemne meeting at MunÅ¿ter, Å¿ome yeares ago, about the General Peace of ChriÅ¿tendome, where the Publick JnÅ¿trument of that Peace sheweth plainly how that the ProteÅ¿tant Plenipotentiaries (the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t men of that Religion) treated with the PapiÅ¿ts, as Å¿ome call them, vnder the name of Catholicks: and though in many other titles and denominations, they were very wary and Å¿crupulous, euen to the long Å¿uÅ¿penÅ¿ion of the Peace, yet they willingly concluded, Å¿ubÅ¿cribed, and Å¿igned that Peace made with them, vnder the name of Catholicks. I Å¿ay this onely, for to make men vnderÅ¿tand, what the true name of the Religion practiÅ¿ed ouer all Jtaly is, to-wit, Catholick.

Haueing Å¿ayd thus much of Italy in Generall, I will now come to a particular DeÅ¿cription of it, according to the ocular obÅ¿eruations I made of it in fiue Å¿eueral Voyages through it. In which DeÅ¿cription if I be a little prolixe, it is becauÅ¿e I rid not
PoÅ¿te through Italy, when I Å¿aw it; nor will I write poÅ¿te through it in deÅ¿cribing it; being aÅ¿Å¿ured, that Epitomees in Geography are as diÅ¿satisfactory, as Laconick Letters would be in Å¿tate Relations; and that the great Atlas, in nine great volumes in folio, is not onely Atlas Maior, but alÅ¿o Atlas Melior.

div.head: The Å¿eueral wayes by which a man may go into Italy.
div.p:
THE ordinary wayes which an Englishman may take in going into Italy, are fiue: to wit, either through Flanders and Germany; and Å¿o to fall in at Trent, or TreuiÅ¿o, and Å¿o to Venice. Or els by France, and Å¿o to MarÅ¿eilles, and thence to Genua by Sea. Or els by land from Lyons through SwiÅ¿serland, the GriÅ¿ â€¢ ns country, and the Valteline, and Å¿o pop vp at BreÅ¿cia. Or els from Lyons againe through the ValeÅ¿ians country, ouer Mount Sampion, the Lake Maior, and Å¿o to Milan. Or els in fine, from Lyons Å¿till, ouer Mount Cenis, and Å¿o to Turin, the
neareÅ¿t PoÅ¿teway. I haue gone, or come, all theÅ¿e wayes in my fiue voyages into Italy, and though I preferre the laÅ¿t for Å¿peed and conueniency; yet I will deÅ¿cribe the others too, that my yong Traueler may know how to Å¿treere his courÅ¿e, either in time of plague or warre.

div.head: My firÅ¿t Voyage into Italy.
div.p:
MY firÅ¿t voyage was through Flanders and Germany, and Å¿o to Trent. The way is, from England, to Dunkerque; from thence to Furne, Newport, OÅ¿tend, Bruges, Gant, BruÅ¿Å¿els, Louain, Liege, Colen, Mayence, Francfort, and Å¿o croÅ¿Å¿ing to Munichen, the Court of the Duke of Bauaria, and from thence to AuÅ¿burg, and InÅ¿pruck, you come Å¿oone to Trent, which Å¿tands vpon the confines of Germany, and lets you into Italy, by TreuiÅ¿o belonging to the Venetians. To deÅ¿cribe all theÅ¿e foreÅ¿ayd places would take me too much time from my deÅ¿igne of deÅ¿cribing Italy, and therefore I
content my Å¿elf onely to haue named them.

div.head: My Å¿econd Voyage.
div.p: MY Å¿econd Voyage was by the way of France, where I Å¿tarted from Paris, and made towards Lyons; in the way I tooke notice of theÅ¿e places.

YÅ¿Å¿one a neat houÅ¿e belonging then to MonÅ¿ieur EÅ¿Å¿olin. YÅ¿Å¿one: The houÅ¿e is Å¿o pritty, that I think it worth the trauelers Å¿eeing, and my deÅ¿cribing. It Å¿tands in the shade of a thick groue of trees, and is wholly built and furnished al' Italiana. Vnder the Å¿ide of the houÅ¿e runns a little brooke, which being receiued into a BaÅ¿in of freeÅ¿tone, iuÅ¿t as long as the houÅ¿e, and made like a ship, (that is, sharp at both ends and wide in the middle) it is clouen, and diuided in two, by the sharp end of this ship, and conueighed in cloÅ¿e channels of freeÅ¿tone, on both Å¿ides of the ship or baÅ¿in, into which it emptyes it Å¿elf by Å¿eueral tunnels, or pipes: Å¿o that all this water
Å¿pouting into the open ship on both Å¿ides, by four and twenty tunnels, makes vnder the windowes of the houÅ¿e Å¿uch a perpetual purleing of water, (like many fountains) that the gentle noiÅ¿e is able to make the moÅ¿t iealous man Å¿leep profundly. At the other end of the houÅ¿e this water yÅ¿Å¿ueth out of the other end of the Å¿ayd ship, and is courteouÅ¿ly intreated by Å¿eueral hidden pipes of lead, to walke into the houÅ¿e, inÅ¿tead of running by Å¿o faÅ¿t: Which it doth, and is preÅ¿ently led into the Cellars, and Buttery; and not onely into theÅ¿e, but alÅ¿o into the kitchen, Å¿tables, chambers, and bathing roome, all which it furnisheth with water either for neceÅ¿Å¿ity, or pleaÅ¿ure. Then being led into the curiours garden, its mett there by a world of little open channels of freeÅ¿tone built like knots of flowers; all which it fills brimfull, and makes euen Flowers of water. Then running vp and downe here and there among the fragrant delights of this garden, as if it had forgotten its
errand to the Sea, it Å¿eems to be Å¿o taken with thoÅ¿e Å¿weet beds of flowers, and Å¿o deÅ¿irous of reÅ¿ting vpon them, after Å¿o many miles runing, that i â€¢ offers to turne it Å¿elf into any poÅ¿ture, rather then be turned out of this Å¿weet place.

From YÅ¿Å¿onne I came to Fontainbelleau, Fontainbelleau. where I Å¿aw that Kingly houÅ¿e, the NoneÅ¿uch of France. It Å¿tands in the midÅ¿t of a great ForreÅ¿t full of Royal game, and was the place of delight of Henry the Fourth. The houÅ¿e is capable of lodgeing four kings with their Å¿eueral Courts. The Court of the Cheual blanc is a noble Å¿quaire of building;The Court of the Cheual Blanc but the lowneÅ¿Å¿ of the buildings and lodgeings shews, they are for the lower Sort of people, and the Å¿eruant-lodgings to the Royal appartiments. The Oual Court is a good old building.The Oual Court. The Kings and Queens lodgings with their Cabinets groane vnder their rich guilt roofes. The Gallery of Å¿taggs heads is a Å¿tately roome,The Gallery of Å¿taggs heads. then which nothing can be more Caualierly furnished; except Å¿uch an other gallery hung with Turkish Å¿tandards wonne in
warre. The other long Galleries of Romances and Fables, The Galleries of RomaÌ„ces. painted by Simon VoyÃ«t and other, are much eÅ¿teemed: the onely pitty is, that Å¿uch true painting should not haue been employed vpon true hiÅ¿tories. The Salle of the Conference, The Salle of the Conference. is a Å¿tately Roome, where the Bishop of Eureux (afterwards called the Cardinal du Perron) in preÅ¿ence of king Henry the Fourth, See the Publick Acts of this Conference printed an. 1601. the Chanceler, fiue Iudges of both Religions, and the whole Roome full of learned men, Å¿o confuted MonÅ¿ieur PleÅ¿Å¿is Mornay, the Achilles of thoÅ¿e of Charenton, that after the firÅ¿t dayes Conference, he durÅ¿t neuer enter the liÅ¿t againe, as he promiÅ¿ed; but dyed Å¿oone after fuller of shame, then yeares. The Hall for maskes, and the Lodgings of Madame Gabrielle with her picture ouer the Chimney like a Diana hunting,Madame Gabriells picture. are fine Roomes: yet the fair picture cannot hinder men from blameing her foule life; nor from cenÅ¿ureing that Å¿olaeciÅ¿me of the painter, who made chaÅ¿te Diana looke like Madame Gabrielle. The Chappels. There are alÅ¿o here two Chappels, the old,
and the new. The old one is a poore thing; and Å¿eems to haue been built for hunters: but the new one is both neat and Å¿tately, and built vpon this occaÅ¿ion, as a Bishop in France told me. A Å¿panish EmbaÅ¿sador reÅ¿ideing in Paris in Henry the IV. his time, went one day from Paris to Fontainbleau, to Å¿ee this French EÅ¿curial. Arriueing, he lighted after his countryes fashion, at the Chappel doore (the old Chappel) and entring in, to thank God for his Å¿aif arriual, he wondered to Å¿ee Å¿o poore and dark a chappel, and asking with indignation whether this were the CaÅ¿a di Dios? The houÅ¿e of God? he turned preÅ¿ently a way with Å¿corne, Saying, No quiero Veer mas; I care for Å¿eeing no more: not Å¿taying to Å¿ee that place, where the king had Å¿o a fine a houÅ¿e, and God Å¿o poore a Chappel. This being told the laÅ¿t king Lewis the XIII. he commanded forth with the new Chappel to be built in that Å¿umptuous poÅ¿ture we now Å¿ee it.

Going out of the houÅ¿e, you finde a hanÅ¿ome Mail, and Rare Ponds of water, which euen baptize
this place with the name of Fontainbelleau. In theÅ¿e Ponds, as alÅ¿o in the moat about the houÅ¿e, are conÅ¿erued excellent Carps;Old Carps Å¿ome whereof were Å¿ayd to be a hundred years old: which though we were not bound to beleeue; yet their very white Å¿cales, and dull moueing vp and downe, might make men beleeue that there are gray Å¿cales, as well as gray haires; and decayed fishes, as well as decrepit men: eÅ¿pecially when Columella Å¿peaks of a fish of his acquaintance,De re RuÅ¿t in CaeÅ¿ars fish ponds neare PauÅ¿ilipus, which had liued threeÅ¿core years; and GeÅ¿nerus relates, that in a fishpond neare Haylprum in Suabe, a fish was catched anno 1497, with a braÅ¿Å¿e ring at his gills, in which were engrauen theÅ¿e words: I am the firÅ¿t fish which Federic the Å¿econd, Gouernour of the world put into this Pond the 5 of October 1203. By which it appears, that this fish had liued two hundred and Å¿ixty odd yeares. But to returne againe to our Carps of Fontainbelleau, its an ordinary diuertiÅ¿Å¿ement here to throw a halfpenny loaf into
the moat among the Carps, and to Å¿ee how they will mumble and iumble it to and fro; how others will puff and Å¿nuff and take it ill, not to haue part of it; and how in fine, they will plainly fall to blowes, and fight for it. You would wonder, how Å¿uch hoat paÅ¿Å¿ions should be found in cold water: but euery thing that liues, will fight for that which makes it liue, its Vittails.

Hauing Å¿een Fontainbelleau, An old InÅ¿criptioÌ„ concerning Englishmen. I Å¿aw on extraordinary thing in the reÅ¿t of the way to Lyons, but an old InÅ¿cription in letters of gold, vpon a woodden Fabrick, a mile before I came to Montargis, importing, that the English being encamped here, had been forced to rayÅ¿e their Seige before Montargis, by reaÅ¿on of great raynes and Å¿uddain inundations. Some of the French hiÅ¿torians will haue it, that it was the Count de Dunois, that forced the English to rayÅ¿e the Seige here: but I had rather beleeue publick inÅ¿criptions, then priuate flattery: and it was more honourable for the English to be ouercome by God, then by men.

Montargis.From hence I paÅ¿Å¿ed through Montargis, a neat pleaÅ¿ant towne; in the great Hall of whoÅ¿e CaÅ¿tle, is painted the hiÅ¿tory of the dog that fought a Duel with the Murderer of his MaÅ¿ter; and it is not Å¿trange that the Dog, that had put on humanity, ouercame him that had put it of, to eÅ¿pouÅ¿e the deuouring humour of a Dog. This is the chief towne of the GaÅ¿tinois.

Briare.From hence I went to Briare where I Å¿aw the cut channel that ioynes Loire and Sene together in trafick,The Coniunction of Loire and Sene. whoÅ¿e bedds oftherwiÅ¿e Å¿tand wide from one another in Å¿ituation.

From thence to CoÅ¿ne, la CharitÃ©, Pougues famous for wholeÅ¿ome Å¿tincking waters; Neuers, famous for glaÅ¿Å¿e houÅ¿es; Moulins, famous for kniues and Cizars: la PaliÅ¿Å¿e where they make excellent winter bootes: Roanne where Loire beginns to be nauigable: and Å¿o ouer Terrara hills to Lyons.

Lyons is one of the greateÅ¿t and richeÅ¿t townes in France. It Å¿tands vpon the riuers Saone, Lyons. and RhoÅ¿ne, (Araris and Rhodanus) and intercepting
all the merchandize of Burgondy, Germany, and Italy, It licks its fingers notably, and thriues by it. It expreÅ¿Å¿eth this in its looks: for here you haue hanÅ¿ome people, noble houÅ¿es, great jollity, frequent balls, and much brauery: all markes of a good towne: and could it but intercept either the Parlament of Aix, or Grenoble, it would be as noble as its name, or as its Catedral Chapter, A noble Chapter. whoÅ¿e Deane and Prebends are all counts, and noble of four deÅ¿centsâ–ª they got the title of counts thus: A great conteÅ¿t arriÅ¿eing between the Chapter of S. Iohns Church, and the Count de ForeÅ¿ts called Guigo, for Å¿ome rights ouer the towne of Lyons which they both pretended to; at laÅ¿t anno 1166. they came to an agreement, vpon this condition, that the Count should leaue to the Chapter his County of ForeÅ¿ts; which he did; and Å¿o euer Å¿ince the Decane and Prebends haue been called Counts of S. Iohn.
The cheif things to be Å¿een in Lyons are theÅ¿e.

1. The great Church, or Cathedral,
called Iohns Church. S. Iohns Church. Its the Seat of an Archbishop, who is Primat of Gaule. S. Irenaeus was a great ornament of this Church, as was alÅ¿o Eucherius. Vpon Å¿olemne dayes the Canons officiate in Miters like Bishops. They Å¿ing here all the office by heart, and without booke, as alÅ¿o without prickÅ¿ong muÅ¿ick, organs, or other inÅ¿trumens, vÅ¿eing onely the ancient plainÅ¿ong. The High Altar is like thoÅ¿e of Italy, that is, open on all Å¿ides, with a Crucifixe and two little candleÅ¿tiks vpon it. I neuer Å¿aw any hangings in this Church, not vpon the greateÅ¿t dayes, but Venerable old walls. The clock here is much cryed vp for a rare peice.

The Towne houÅ¿e.2. The Å¿tately new Towne houÅ¿e, of pure white freeÅ¿tone, able to matche that of AmÅ¿terdam; and indeed they Å¿eemed to me to be twinns; for I Å¿aw them both in the Å¿ame yeare as they were in building. The curious Å¿taircaÅ¿e, and Hall aboue, are the things moÅ¿t worthy taking notice of, the owne for its contriuanc; the other
for its painting.

3.Other Rarities. The JeÅ¿uits Colledge and fair Library. 4. The CarthuÅ¿ians MonaÅ¿tery vpon a high Hill. 5. The Minimes SachriÅ¿ty well painted. 6. The reÅ¿ts of the old Aqueduct vpon the Hill. 7. The Mail, and the Å¿weet place of Belle Cour. 8. The Heart of Å¿aint Francis de Sales in the Church of the ViÅ¿itation in Belle Cour. 9. The CharitÃ© where all the poore are kept at worke with admirable oeconomy: It looks like a little towne, haueing in it nine courts, all built up with lodgeings for the poore, who are about fifteen hundred, and diuided into Å¿eueral ClaÅ¿Å¿es, with their Å¿eueral Refectories and Chappels. 10. The Head of S. Bonauenture in the Cordeliers Church. 11. The CaÅ¿tle of Pierre AnciÅ¿e, built vpon a rock. 12. NoÅ¿tre Dame de Fouruier Å¿tanding vpon a high hill, from whence you haue a perfect view of Lyons.

13.The rare Cabinet of MonÅ¿ieur Seruier. LaÅ¿tly the rare Cabinet of MonÅ¿ieur Seruier a moÅ¿t ingenious gentleman; where I Å¿aw moÅ¿t rare experiments in Mathematiks and
Mechanicks; all made by his owne hand: as the Å¿ympatheticall balls, one Å¿pringing vp at the approach of the other held vp a pretty diÅ¿tance off: the demonÅ¿tration of a quick way how to paÅ¿Å¿e an army ouer a riuer with one boat, and a woodden bridge eaÅ¿ily to be foulded vp vpon one cart: the mouÅ¿e dyall, where a little thing, like a mouÅ¿e, by her inÅ¿enÅ¿ible motion, markes the houres of the day. The Lizard Dyal is much like the former, onely the mouÅ¿e moues vpon a plain frame of wood which hath the houres marked on it; and the Lizard creeps vpward from houre to houre. The night dyall, shewing by a lighted lamp Å¿et behinde it, the houres of the night, which are painted in colours vpon oyled Paper, and turne about as the time goes. The TortoiÅ¿e dyall, where a peice of cork cut like a TortoiÅ¿e, being put into a puter dish of water, which hath the twelue houres of the day marked upon its brims, goeth vp and downe the water a while, Å¿eeking out the houre of the day that
is then; and there fixeing it Å¿elf without Å¿tirring. The Rare engine teaching how to throw Grenados into beÅ¿eiged townes, and into any preciÅ¿e place without fayling. The way how to Å¿et vp a watch-tower with a man in it, to looke into a towne from without, and Å¿ee how they are drawne vp within the towne. a way how to change dineing Roomes three or four times, with their tables, the Seats and gheÅ¿ts being by the turning of a wheele tranÅ¿ported Å¿itting, out of one Roome into another; and Å¿o into three or four more Roomes variouÅ¿ly hung with tables couered. The Desk dyall, which throwes vp a little ball of yuory without reÅ¿t, and thereby marketh the houre of the day, and sheweth what a clock it is: the Dyall of the Planets repreÅ¿enting the dayes of the week by Å¿eueral figures in iuory of the planets: the Oual dyal in which the needle that markes the houres, shrinketh in, or Å¿tretcheth out it Å¿elf according as the oual goes: the dyall shewing to euery one that
