toucheth it his predominant paÅ¿sion; with a world of other rare curioÅ¿ityes, all made by this ingenious gentleman.

Leauing Lyons, I embarked in a Cabanne, or little couered boat, and deÅ¿cending the rapid RhoÅ¿ne, I came poÅ¿te by wather, to Vienne;Vienne. were Pontius Pilate, bannished hither, threw himÅ¿elf off a high Tower, and killed himÅ¿elf. The Cathedral of this towne is a faire Church dedicated to God, in the honour of S. Maurice: there are neither Pictures, nor hangings in this Church.
Tournon.From hence I went to Tournon, where I Å¿aw a good Library in the Colledge.
Valence.Thence to Valence in DauphinÃ©, where Law is taught.

Pont S. EÅ¿prit.From whence I came to Pont Saint EÅ¿prit famous for its long bridge of therty three arches, and for the bones of a Gyant which are conÅ¿erued in the Dominicans Conuent here; And from hence to Auignon.

Auignon. Auignon is the head towne of a little country, called Vulgarly the
Le Contad d'Auignon. It belongs to the Pope, hauing been purchaÅ¿ed by one of his predeceÅ¿Å¿ors anciently of Iane Queen of Naples and CounteÅ¿Å¿e of Auignon: and it Å¿erued for a Å¿aif retreat to diuers Popes conÅ¿ecutiuely, during the troubles of Italy which laÅ¿ted aboue Å¿eauenty yeares. At laÅ¿t, Italy, and the Popes territories there, being cleared by the admirable courage and conduct of braue Cardinal Albornozzo, who conquered againe all the Popes eÅ¿tate, The Pope, Greg. the XI, returned home againe to Romeâ–ª of the foreÅ¿ayd Cardinal Albornozzo I cannot omit to tell one thing; that after his great Å¿eruices rendered to the Pope, being enuyed by Å¿ome of the Court, who had perÅ¿waded his HolyneÅ¿Å¿ to call him to an accompt for the great Å¿ommes of monye he had Å¿pent in reduceing againe the whole Å¿tate of the Pope vnto its obedience; he brought the next morning a cart laden with chaines, bolts, locks and keys belonging once to thoÅ¿e townes which he had retaken for the Pope, and placeed
it vnder the Popes window: then going vp, and deÅ¿iring his HolineÅ¿Å¿ to draw to a window to Å¿ee his accompts the better, he opened the window, and shewed him below, the Cart laden with chaines, bolts, locks and keys, Å¿aying: Holy Father, I Å¿pent all your money in making you master againe of thoÅ¿e townes whoÅ¿e keys, locks, bolts and chaines you Å¿ee in that cart below. At which the Pope admireing, deÅ¿ired no more accompt of him, who proued his honeÅ¿ty by whole cart loads of Å¿eruices. Euer Å¿ince that time, Auignon hath belongd to the Pope; and he gouerneth it by a Vice-Legat immediatly, the Popes Nep â€¢ ew pro tempore being allwayes Legat of this towne.

The rarities.The things I Å¿aw here were theÅ¿e. 1. The Cathedral Church with diuers tombes of Popes in it that dyed here. 2. The Church of S. Didier, with the tombe of Peirus Damianus who followed the Pope hither: He was famous for his learned works, and his knowne Å¿anctity. 3. The Church of the CeleÅ¿tins,
with the tombe, and neat Chappel of Cardinal Peter of Luxenbourg, a yong man of a great family, and of a greater Å¿anctity. 4. The CarthuÅ¿ians MonaÅ¿tery in the bourg of Villeneuue, where you shall Å¿ee much good painting. 5. The Dominicans fair Conuent, with the Chappel and true Picture of S. Vincentius Ferrerius a holy man of this Order. 6. The Cordeliers Church famous for its wideneÅ¿Å¿e, and yet not Å¿upported by any pillars. Here lyes buryed Madame Laura rendered Å¿o famous by Petrarchs VerÅ¿es: not that the was a dishoneÅ¿t woman, but onely choÅ¿en by him, to be the poÃ«ticall miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e of his Å¿onnets. 7. The Church of the Fathers of the ChriÅ¿tian doctrine, with the body, yet entire, of the Founder of their order P. CaeÅ¿ar de Bus, a man of Å¿uch Å¿ingular Å¿anctity, that Cardinal Richlieu banished hither, whiles he was onely Bishop of LuÅ¿on, offered and vowed a Å¿yluer Lampe to God at the tombe of this holy Bea â€¢â€¢ . 8. The fine freeÅ¿tone walls of this towne, the admirable Bridge, many hanÅ¿ome
Pallaces, and curious gardens. 9. The trading of this towne, which conÅ¿iÅ¿ts much in Å¿ilkÅ¿tuffs, parfumed gloues, rubans, and Å¿ine paper. 10. The inhabitants here, who loue to go well adiuÅ¿ted and appeare in fine clothes.

Aix.From Auignon I went by Land to Aix in Prouence, an VniuerÅ¿ity, a Parlament towne, and one of the neateÅ¿t townes in France: of the Parlament of this towne MonÅ¿ieur du Vair was the firÅ¿t PreÅ¿ident, and a Å¿ingular ornament, by reaÅ¿on of his famous eloquence. This towne is the Å¿eat of an Archbishop; and is now poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by Cardinal Grimaldi who is Archbishop here. From hence I went to MarÅ¿eilles.

MarÅ¿eilles. MarÅ¿eilles is a very ancient towne, built 633 yeares before our Sauiours time, and Å¿o famous anciently for learning, that it was compared with Athens. It Å¿tands vpon the Medeterranean Sea, and hath a moÅ¿t neat hauen and harbour for ships and gallyes. I Å¿tayd here eight dayes to wait vpon the returne of two Gallies of Genua, that had brought
an EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour from thence into France, and were to returne within a few dayes. In this time I had leiÅ¿ure to make a little excurÅ¿iue Voyage to the famous place of deuotion called La Sainte Beaume, La Å¿aincte Baume. where S. Mary Magdalen liued a moÅ¿t penitential life in theÅ¿e mountains and deÅ¿erts, See Baronius ad an. 35. Gordons Cronology. Gerard of Nazareth in a treatiÅ¿e ex profeÅ¿Å¿o. euen after she had been aÅ¿Å¿ured of her pardon by out Sauiour himÅ¿elf. The place it Å¿elf is able to make any man that conÅ¿idereth it well, melt into Å¿ome pennance too, and Å¿igh at leaÅ¿t, to Å¿ee how much she (a woman) did, and how little he (a man) doth; for excellentiÅ¿Å¿ima animaduertenti, ne mediocria quidem praestare, rubori oportet eÅ¿se, Å¿aith a great Author. In MarÅ¿eills it Å¿elf there remaine Å¿ome prints of her begunn pennance:Valer. Max. but she that had been a Å¿inner in the Cytie (and perchance by that occaÅ¿ion onely) thought the DeÅ¿ert a Å¿afer place;Mulier peccatrix in ciuitate. and Å¿o shewed her conuerÅ¿ion to be true, by flying the occaÅ¿ions of her former Å¿inns.

If you aske me, how Mary Magdalen came hither; I muÅ¿t aske
you,See Baron. an. 35 Genebrad Gautier. ChaÅ¿Å¿anus. and MonÅ¿ieur du Vair. how IoÅ¿eph of Arimathia came into England: and learned Baronius will anÅ¿wer vs both, by telling vs, that vpon a perÅ¿ecution rayÅ¿ed againÅ¿t the ChriÅ¿tians in HieruÅ¿alem; Mary Magdalen, her SiÅ¿ter Martha, her brother Lazarus, with IoÅ¿eph of Arimathia and diuers others of the firÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tians, were expoÅ¿ed to Sea in a ship without Å¿ayles, without rudder, without anker, without pilot, and yet the ship came happily to MarÅ¿eills; where Lazarus preaching the faith of ChriÅ¿t, was made the firÅ¿t Bishop of this towne; and IoÅ¿eph of Arimathia came into England.

Neare to Saincte Beaume Å¿tands, the towne of S. Maximin famous for the Church of S. Maximin gouerned by Dominican Fryers:S, Maximin. In this Church are to be Å¿een many famous Relicks of S. Mary Magdalen; as her head in a ChryÅ¿tal caÅ¿e enchaÅ¿ed in gold: her body in a guilt chaÅ¿se, and diuers other rich things.

Haueing Å¿een MarÅ¿eilles, I embarked in the forÅ¿ayd Gallies, and was nine dayes in them before I
arriued at Genua; haueing Å¿een in the way, Toulon, Nice, Antibo, Monaco, and Sauona.

Thus I paÅ¿Å¿ed, though tediouÅ¿ly, yet Å¿ecurely from France into Italy by Sea: and I could allmoÅ¿t wish my Traueler to take the Å¿ame courÅ¿e, if he were Å¿ure to finde two Gallies well manned as I did, to carry him thither. OtherwiÅ¿e to venture himÅ¿elf (as men ordinarily with extraordinary danger do) in a little Feluca, a boat little bigger then a pair of oares,Pyrrho dicebat, nihil intereÅ¿Å¿e, inter vitam & mortem. is a thing I would wish none to do, but Pyrrhonians, and Indifferents who think danger and Å¿ecurity to be the Å¿ame thing. For my part, though I dare not Å¿ay with that cowardly Italian, who being laughed at for running away in a battle, anÅ¿wered: I was not affrayd, but onely had a mind to try, how long a mans skinn, well kept, would last: yet I dare Å¿ay with Generous Cato, that I repent me Å¿oundly, if euer I went by water, when I could haue gone by Land.

div.head: My third Voyage.
div.p: MY third Voyage into Italy was againe by the way of Paris and Lyons: but now by Geneua and SwiÅ¿Å¿erland.
Parting then from Lyons I paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer the Grand Credo, a Å¿mart hill; through Nantua Å¿tanding vpon a Lake, and in two dayes came to Geneua.

Geneua, Geneua. like a good Å¿inke at the bottom of three Å¿treets, is built at the bottom of Sauoye, France, and Germany, and therefore fit to receiue into it the corruption, of the ApoÅ¿tatas of the Roman Church.

The things which I Å¿aw in Geneua were theÅ¿e: 1. The great Church of S. Peter, The rarities. the Cathedral anciently of the Bishop of this towne. In the Quire I Å¿aw yet remaining the Pictures of the twelue Prophets on one Å¿ide, and the pictures of the twelue ApoÅ¿tles on the other Å¿ide, all engrauen in wood. The pictures alÅ¿o of the BleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgin Mary, and S. Peter, in one of the windows. Here alÅ¿o I Å¿aw the Tombe of the Duke of
Bouillon General of the army of Germans, called then in France the Reiters, who in the battle of Aulneau were beaten by the Duke of GuiÅ¿e and forced to fly to Geneua, haueing laÅ¿t 1800 of their men vpon the place, moÅ¿t of them with charmes about their necks, which they thought would haue made them shott free. Mounting vp to the Å¿teeple, I Å¿aw a fair Bell with a Crucifix caÅ¿t vpon it, shewing whoÅ¿e it was; and four good peices of ordinance, that none may Å¿ay, the Church of Geneua wants EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Cannons. And a little below in the Belfree, there liue in Å¿eueral Chambers, three or four families of husbands and wifes and Å¿ucking children begotten there; contrary to the Canons of any other Church, except thoÅ¿e of Geneua. From the top of this Church you haue a fair proÅ¿pect vpon the lake and neighbouring countryes; which makes them brag here, that they can Å¿ee from their Å¿teeple, into Å¿ix Å¿eueral principalities, to wit, their owne, France, Sauoye, SwiÅ¿Å¿erland, the
ValeÅ¿ians, and the Franchecounty: But I told them, it would be a greater brag, to Å¿ay, that they could Å¿ee into no other country, or dominions but their owne. 2. I Å¿aw the ArÅ¿enal, little, but well Å¿tored with defenÅ¿iue armes. They neuer forget to shew the Ladders of the Sauoyards, who attempted to Å¿urpize this towne by Å¿caleing, but were themÅ¿elues taken and beheaded Ã la chaude, leaÅ¿t Å¿ome Prince should haue interceded for them. 3. The Towne houÅ¿e with the Chamber where the MagiÅ¿trats (Å¿omething like the Hogen Mogens of Holland) Å¿it in CounÅ¿el. 4. They shewd me here a Library but none of the beÅ¿t. 5. The admirable Trouts here, able to make the poore ApoÅ¿tatas wish for their Lent againe; were it not, that the Capons here are full as good in their kinde.

As for the Gouerment of this towne, it was anciently Monarchical, and the Bishop was Prince of it vnder the Duke of Sauoye: but Farel and Caluin comeing hither with their anarchical Presbyterie, droue the Bishop Peter de la Beaume
out of the towne; and eÅ¿tablished there a kinde of Democratie, or rather, a kind of AriÅ¿tocratie, mingled of Laymen and MiniÅ¿ters. Yet the Bishop keeps Å¿till his title, and the Chapter its reuenews and Lands, which happily lye in Sauoye out of the reach of the short iuriÅ¿diction of Geneua. Both the Bishop and Chapter reÅ¿ide in AniÅ¿y in Sauoye, and officiate in the Cordeliers Church. of this Seat was Bishop the late Canonized Saint, S. FranciÅ¿ de Sales, a man of Å¿ingular Å¿weetneÅ¿Å¿ and piety,Petrus a S. Romualdo in Diario. mingled with zeale and diÅ¿cretion. I haue red of him, that in his life time, he made four thouÅ¿and Å¿ermons to the people.

Hauing thus Å¿een the little All of Geneua, I made towards SwiÅ¿Å¿erland, leauing the Lake on my right haÌ„d;The Lake of Geneua or rather takeing it on my right hand; for it would needs accompany me to LauÅ¿anna, where it tooke leaue of me, or I of it.

This Lake is abÅ¿olutly the faireÅ¿t I haue Å¿een: its fairer then either the Lake Maior, the Lake of Como, the Lake of Zuric, the Lake of
WalenÅ¿tat, the Lake of JÅ¿ee, the Lake of Murat, or the Lake of Garda. In Å¿ome places this Lake of Geneua is eight miles broad, and well nigh fifty miles long. I haue red of a Å¿tranger, who traueling that way alone in winter, when the Lake was all frozen ouer, and couered with Å¿now, tooke the Lake for a large plain, and rid vpon it eight, or ten miles to the towne: Where lighting at his Inn, and commending the fine plain ouer which he had ridden, was giuen to vnderÅ¿tand, that he had ridden, if not in the air, at leaÅ¿t fifteen fathom aboue ground; at which, the poore man reflecting vpon the danger he had been in, fell downe dead with the conceit of it. Thus we are troubled not onely at euils to come but at euils paÅ¿t; and are neuer Å¿o neare the danger of death, as when we are newly paÅ¿t it. No animal but man, hath this folly.

LauÅ¿anna.Leauing then, as I Å¿ayd, the Lake I came Å¿oone after, to LauÅ¿anna in SwiÅ¿serland, belonging to the Canton of Berne. Here I Å¿aw an ancient Church of a noble Å¿tructure, and
once a Bishops Cathedral, but now poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by MiniÅ¿ters of Caluins communion; and the man that shewed vs the Church (though no Catholick) aÅ¿Å¿ured vs, that the records of that Church bore, that MaÅ¿se had been Å¿ayd in it thirteen hundred yeares agoe.SwiÅ¿Å¿erland.

From LauÅ¿anna I went towards Soleur, skirting through the Cantons, Å¿ometimes of Berne, Å¿ometimes of Fribourg, and Å¿ometimes in one dayes iourney, I paÅ¿Å¿ed into a Catholick Canton, and by and by, into a ProteÅ¿tant Canton againe: for here Catholick and ProteÅ¿tant Villages are mingled together, and make the country looke like the back Å¿ide of a pair of tables checquered with white and black. In one Village you haue a CroÅ¿Å¿e Å¿et vp, to Å¿ignifie that it is Catholick belonging to the Canton of Friburg; by and by in an other Village, a high flag with the picture of a Beare in it, to Å¿ignifie, Berne Å¿ignifies as much as Beare. that it belongs to the Canton of Berne, and is ProteÅ¿tant: and yet they liue ciuilly and neighbourly together without
quarreling about Religion.

Soleur,PaÅ¿Å¿ing thus a long, I came to Soleur (Soloturrum in Latin) a neat towne and Head of a Canton. They are all Catholicks here: and here it is that the French EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours to the SwiÅ¿Å¿ers, alwayes reÅ¿ide, as the Spanish EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors do at Lucerna. This towne is very ancient, as the golden Letters vpon the clock teÅ¿tifye;Petrus Romualdus in Cronolog. TreÅ¿or. to. 1. pag. 83. in fol. for thoÅ¿e words make Soleur to be onely yonger then her SiÅ¿ter Treuers, which, as Aeneas Syluius writes, was built 1300 yeares before Rome. As for Soleur, I find in good Cronologers that it was built 2030 years after the creation of the world.

From Soleur I went to Murat, a little towne famous for a great battle fought hard by it, by the Duke of Burgondy, and the SwiÅ¿Å¿ers. For the the Duke of Burgondy beÅ¿eiging Murat, Murat. the SwiÅ¿Å¿ers came vpon him with a great army, and defeated him. I was told here that the Duke Å¿eeing his army defeated, and himÅ¿elf enuironed on one Å¿ide by the Lake here; and on the other Å¿ide, by the enemyes conquering army, choÅ¿e rather to truÅ¿t
himÅ¿elf to the Lake, then to his ennemyes. Wherevpon Å¿purring his horÅ¿e into the Lake,The Lake of Murat. one of his Dages, to Å¿aue himÅ¿elf alÅ¿o, leaped vp behind him as he tooke water. The Duke out of feare either perceiued him not at firÅ¿t, or diÅ¿Å¿embled it till he came to the other Å¿ide of the Lake which is two miles broad: The Å¿tout horÅ¿e tugged through with them both, and Å¿aued them both from drowning, but not both from death. For the Duke Å¿eing in what danger his page had put him, Å¿tabbed the Page with his dagger. Poore Prince! thou mighÅ¿t haue giuen an other offering of thanks giueing to God for thy eÅ¿cape then this; nay, thou mighÅ¿t haue been as ciuil as thy horÅ¿e, and haue Å¿paired him, whom beaÅ¿ts and waues had Å¿aued: At leaÅ¿t by that means, thou mighÅ¿t haue Å¿aueed thy owne honour, by Å¿aueing that poore page who offended rather out of feare of death, then out of malice; and thereby thou mighÅ¿t haue truly Å¿ayd, that thou hadÅ¿t not loÅ¿t all thy men in that battle. But
paÅ¿Å¿ion is a blind thing: Nothing is Å¿o dangerous to man, as man; and, as I obÅ¿erued aboue, we are neuer in greater danger, then when we think we are paÅ¿t danger. Thebones of the Burgundians Å¿lain in this battle, are Å¿een in a great Chappel, which Å¿tands a little diÅ¿tant from the towne, and vpon the road, with an inÅ¿cription vpon it touching the time and circumÅ¿tances of this defeat.

From Murat I made towards Zuric, a head towne alÅ¿o of a Canton. It Å¿tands moÅ¿t Å¿weetly vpon a Lake whoÅ¿e cryÅ¿talin waters would delight any body elÅ¿e but SwiÅ¿Å¿ers. They are all here, Swinglians; and when Mareshal D'EÅ¿trÃ©e the French EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to Rome, paÅ¿Å¿ed that way, and lodged at the great Jnn of the Sword, as he was combing his head one morning in his combing cloth, with his chamber window open, Å¿ome of the townes men, who Å¿aw him (from an other oppoÅ¿it window) putting on that combeing cloth, and thinking it had been a PrieÅ¿t putting on the
Amice and veÅ¿ting himÅ¿elf for to Å¿ay MaÅ¿Å¿e before the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour in his chamber, began with a Dutch clamour to Å¿tirre vp the people to a mutiny about the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours houÅ¿e, and to call for the PrieÅ¿t, that was Å¿aying of MaÅ¿Å¿e: The EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour at firÅ¿t, not vnderÅ¿tanding the cauÅ¿e of this vproare about his houÅ¿e, rann downe with Å¿word in hand, and in his combeing cloth, to check the firÅ¿t man that should darre to enter his lodgings: but vnderÅ¿tanding at laÅ¿t, that his combing cloth had cauÅ¿ed this iealouÅ¿y, hee laughed at their folly, and retired away contented.

The beÅ¿t things to be Å¿een in Zuric are theÅ¿e. 1. The neat ArÅ¿enal furnished with Å¿tore of fair Cannons and armes of all Å¿ortes. 2. The great Library, but in this much leÅ¿Å¿e eÅ¿teemed by mee, becauÅ¿e a woman had the Key of it, and let vs in to Å¿ee it. This peice of falÅ¿e Latin at the entrance, diÅ¿guÅ¿ted me with all that I Å¿aw there, and made me haÅ¿ten out quickly: Good Libraries should not fall en quenoÃ¼ille.
3. The Wheeles which draw vp water from the Lake of themÅ¿elues, and empty it into Å¿eueral Pipes, & Å¿o conueigh it all ouer the towne.

4. The publick great drinking hall, where there are a world of little tables for men of Å¿eueral corporations or trayds to meet at, and either talk there of their buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿, or make drinking their buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿. Ouer euery table hangs the Å¿igne of each trad, as a LaÅ¿t for shoomakers, a Å¿addle for Å¿adlers, a Å¿word for cutlers &c. There is a great Bell that rings to this meeting place euery day at two a clock, and when I heard Å¿o Å¿olemne a ringing, I thought it had been to Å¿ome Church deuotion, not to a drinking aÅ¿Å¿embly.

From Zuric I went by water, that is, vpon the lake a whole dayes iourney,A long Bridge. and paÅ¿Å¿ed vnder a bridge of wood which croÅ¿Å¿eth quite ouer the lake for two miles. Its entertained at the coÅ¿t of the King of Spayne, to paÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿oldiers which he often rayÅ¿eth in the adiacent countryes.

From hence I went to Coire, Coire. or Cear, the head towne of the GriÅ¿ons. The Bishop and the Clergy of the great Church, with Å¿ome few others liuing within the precincts of the CloiÅ¿ter of the great Church, are Catholicks, and performe their deuotions in the Church without controll: the reÅ¿t of the inhabitants are Swinglians, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e the towne; yet they Å¿uffer the Bishop, and his Clergy to liue quietly in the midÅ¿t of them. They shewed me here in this Church, diuers fine Relicks, eÅ¿pecially the Head (enchaÅ¿ed in Å¿yluer) of our ancient Brittan King Lucius, S. Lucius the firÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian King. the firÅ¿t Christian king that euer made profeÅ¿Å¿ion of ChriÅ¿tian. Religion, and the firÅ¿t who helpt to plant it here. The ancient Church office here relates all this, as their Church bookes shewed me.

From the GriÅ¿ons I went to the Country of the Valtaline;The Valtaline. a country Å¿ubiect to the GriÅ¿ons and keeping its fidelity to them euen when it would not haue wanted aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance from Spayne and Italy, if it would
haue been falÅ¿e to its Superiors the GriÅ¿ons vnder the colour of Religion: thoÅ¿e of the Valtaline being all Catholicks, and their Å¿ouuerains the GriÅ¿ons CaluiniÅ¿ts. In a little towne of the GriÅ¿ons (called Herberga) I was shewed a cheeÅ¿e (and giuen to taÅ¿te of it too) by myne hoÅ¿te, the Maior of the towne, a CaluiniÅ¿t in Religion, and a Venerable old man, who aÅ¿Å¿ured me Å¿eriouÅ¿ly, that that cheeÅ¿e was a hundred years oldâ–ª a Venerable CheeÅ¿e indeed! and well nigh as old as his Religion.

Mount Berlin.Between theÅ¿e two countryes of the GriÅ¿ons and the Valtaline, Å¿tands the great Hill Berlino: ouer which I paÅ¿Å¿ed; and fell from thence upon PoÅ¿ciauo a little bourg, and Å¿o to our Ladyes of Tirano a neat Church with a fair Inn hard by it.
Le Splug.Others, to auoyd the Å¿now of Berlino, are forced now and then (as I was once) to paÅ¿Å¿e ouer the mountain Splug, which is hill enough for any traueler.

Mount Aurigo.From our Ladyes of Tirano I went vp a Å¿mart hill called Mount
Aurigo, and Å¿o makeing towards the Lake of WallinÅ¿tade, The Lakes of wallinÅ¿tade, & JÅ¿ee. I paÅ¿Å¿ed it ouer in boate; as I did alÅ¿o Å¿oone after, that of IÅ¿ee; and Å¿o fell into the territories of BreÅ¿cia in Italy belonging to the Å¿tate of Venice.

div.head: My fourth Voyage.
div.p: MY fourth voyage into Italy was from Lyons againe and Geneua, S. Maurice. where I now tooke the Lake on my left hand, and paÅ¿Å¿ing along the skirts of Sauoye, I came to Boueretta, a little Village, and Å¿o to S. Maurice the firÅ¿t towne in the Valetians country, This towne is Å¿o called from S. Maurice the Braue Commander of the Theban Legion, in the primitiue times, and who was martyred here for the profeÅ¿Å¿ion of ChriÅ¿tian Religion together with his whole Legion. Hence an Abbey was built here by SigiÅ¿mond King of Burgondy, and called S. Maurice.

Now, this country is called the country of the ValeÅ¿ians, The ValeÅ¿ians. from the perpetuall Valley in which it lyeth.
The people haue for their Prince the Bishop of Sion the cheif towne of the country. Their Valley is aboue four dayes iourney long, beÅ¿ides their hills which are two more: MoÅ¿t of their little townes and Villages Å¿tand vpon hill Å¿ides, leauing all the plain country for tillage and paÅ¿turage. Their houÅ¿es are low and darke, many of them hauing no windowes, and the reÅ¿t very little ones. Sed caÅ¿a pugnaces Curios anguÅ¿ta tegebat. As for the people here, they are all Catholicks, Å¿inceare honeÅ¿t men, of Å¿tout courage, yet of innocent liues, much Å¿now quenching their luÅ¿t, and high mountains Å¿taueing of from them all luxe and Vanity, the harbingers of Vice. They haue short hair on their heads, but beards in folio. They are got Å¿o farre into the grande mode, as to weare breeches and doublets; but thats all: for otherwiÅ¿e their clothes looke as if they had been made by the Taylors of the old Patriarcks; or as if the fashion of them had been taken out of old hangings and tapiÅ¿try.
In fine, both men and women here are great and maÅ¿Å¿iue, and not eaÅ¿ily to be blowne away: Å¿o that I may iuÅ¿tly Å¿ay of this people, as Cardinal Bentiuoglio Å¿ayd of the SwiÅ¿Å¿ers, that they are good for the Alpes, and the Alpes for them. One thing I obÅ¿erued particularly in this windy country, which is, that they haue many natural fooles here, which makes me thinck it no vulgar errour, which is commonly Å¿ayd, that the climats that are moÅ¿t agitated with winds produce more fooles, then other climats do.

As for their Å¿trength,Their Strength. vpon a defenÅ¿iue occaÅ¿ion, they can aÅ¿Å¿emble forty thouÅ¿and men together vnder their knowne Commanders, who are often times the Innkeepers in whoÅ¿e houÅ¿es we lodge; but out of their owne pit they are not to be feared, haueing neither Å¿pirits, nor Å¿innews: that is, neither ambition, nor money, to carry on a forrain warre.
From S. Maurice I went to Martigni a great Inn in a poore Village,Martigni and from thence to Sion.

Sion. Sion (anciently Sedunum,) is the cheif towne of the country, and Å¿tands in the center of it. Here the Bishop, who is Prince, reÅ¿ideth with his Chapter and Cathedral on one hill, and his CaÅ¿tle Å¿tands on another hill hard by. The Court of this Prince is not great, becauÅ¿e of his, and his peoples quality. A good Bishop hath Å¿omething els to do, then to be courted,The beÅ¿t Gards of a Prince. and good plain people muÅ¿t follow their trads, not Courts. This Prince hath no Gards, becauÅ¿e no fears: and if danger should threaten him, his people, whoÅ¿e loue is his onely ArÅ¿enal, Plus tutatur Amor haue hands enough to defend him. So that the Prince and People, that isâ–ª the Body Politick of this Å¿tate, Å¿eemed to mee like the Body natural in man, where the Å¿oul and the body being freinds together, the Å¿oul directs the body, and the body defends the Soul.
Lucia.From Sion I went to Lucia, but lodged a quarter of a mile from the towne; and from thence I reached Briga at night.

Briga. Briga is a little Village Å¿tanding
at the foot of great hills; where haueing reÅ¿ted well all night, at the Colonels houÅ¿e (the beÅ¿t Inn here) we began the next morning to clime the hills for a breakfaÅ¿t. For the Å¿pace of three houers our horÅ¿es eaÅ¿ed vs, the aÅ¿cent not being Å¿o Å¿urley as we expected from Å¿o rugged a brow of hills: but when wee came to the Å¿teep of the hill it Å¿elf Mount Sampion, Mount Sampion. (one of the great StaircaÅ¿es of Italy) we were forced to compliment our horÅ¿es, and go a foot. It was towards the very begining of October when we paÅ¿Å¿ed that way, and therfore found that Hill in a good humour; otherwiÅ¿e its froward enough. Haueing in one houres time crawled vp the Å¿teep of the Hill, we had two houres more rideing to the Village and Inn of Sampion: where arriueing, we found little meat for our great Å¿tomacks, and cold comfort for all the hot Å¿tincking Stone.

At laÅ¿t haueing payd for a dinner here, though we Å¿aw nothing we could eate, we were the lighter in purÅ¿e, as well as in body, to walke
well that afternoone, rather then that afterdinner. To deÅ¿cribe you the rough way we had between Sampion and Deuedra, downe hill alwayes, or fetching about hills vpon a narrow way artificially made out of the Å¿ide of thoÅ¿e hills, and Å¿ometimes Å¿ticking out of them, as if it had been plaiÅ¿tered to them, were able to make my pen ake in writing it, as well as my leggs in walkeing it. And here I found the Prouerb falÅ¿e which Å¿aith, that its good walking with a horÅ¿e in ones hand: for here we could neither ride, nor lead our horÅ¿es Å¿ecurely, but either the one, or the other were in danger of Å¿tumbling, that is, of falling fiue hundred fadome deep. For here, as well as in warre, Å¿emel tantum peccatur, a man need but Å¿tumble once for all his lifetime: Yet by letting our horÅ¿es go looÅ¿e with the bridle on their necks, and makeing a man go before each horÅ¿e, leaÅ¿t they should iumble one another downe (as I once Å¿aw the like done by horÅ¿es in SwiÅ¿Å¿erland) we arriued Å¿afely at
Deuedra that night.Deuedra. You would do well alÅ¿o to light from horÅ¿e at the going ouer all the little trembling Bridges of wood which you will finde there, remembring the Italian Prouerb, which Å¿aith: Quando tu Vedi vn Ponte, falli piu honore che iu non fai a vn Conte.

Haueing repoÅ¿ed all night in the houÅ¿e of the Signor CaÅ¿tellano, DomodoÅ¿cela. we went the next morning to DomodoÅ¿cela a litle garriÅ¿on towne of the Å¿tate of Milan, troubleÅ¿ome enough to trauelers that paÅ¿Å¿e from Milan this way, and carry piÅ¿tols and gunns without licence.

From DomodeÅ¿cela we paÅ¿Å¿ed through a fine plain country to Marguzzi, Marguzzi. Lake Maior. a little Village Å¿tanding vpon the Lake Maior (anciently called Lacus Verbanus) where making our bargain with our boatmen ro carry vs in one day from thence to SeÅ¿to, & keep aloof of from the command of all the CaÅ¿tles, which now and then warne boates to come in; and vnder pretence of Å¿earching them for marchandize, Å¿topp paÅ¿Å¿ingers till they haue
Å¿crewed a peece of monny out of them.

S â€¢ Å¿to.Arriueing Å¿aif at SeÅ¿to that night we tooke Coache the next day for Milan, and dineing at Ciuita CaÅ¿tellanza, Ciuita CaÅ¿tellanza. arriued be times at that great towne which was called anciently Altera Roma: a Å¿econd Rome.

div.head: My fift Voyage.
div.p: MY fift voyage into Italy was Å¿till from Lyons, but now by the way of Mount Cenis, and Turin, the ordinary PoÅ¿t rode, and I think the eaÅ¿yeÅ¿t way of all the reÅ¿t.

Parting then from Lyons on horÅ¿eback, we paÅ¿Å¿ed through Verpillier, La Tour du Pin, BeaunoyÅ¿in (whoÅ¿e bridge parts France, and Sauoy) and came in two dayes to the foot of Mount Aiguebellet, the threshold of the Alpes: This is a pretty breathing hill,Mount Aiguebellet. and may be called, the Alpes foule ouer, or the Alpes in a running hand and not in that fair Text hand which I found Mount Cenis to be in. It hath all the lineaments and shapes
of the great Alpes, that is, much winding and turning; deep precipices, Marons, or, men with little open chairs, to carry you vp and downe the hill for a crowne; and much Å¿tumbling worke. In fine this hill reÅ¿Å¿embles Mount Cenis, as a proper man may do a Gyant.
Hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed this Hill, and by it through the very clowds, we fel as it were out of the skyes, vpon Chambery the cheif towne of Sauoy, Chambery. and where the Parlament reÅ¿ides,

We caÅ¿t to be there at the Å¿olemne Entry, which this Duke made for his new SpouÅ¿e the third daughter of the late Duke of Orleans, The Entry of the DutcheÅ¿Å¿e of Sauoy. when she came firÅ¿t into this country. To deÅ¿cribe all the Triumphal Arches in the Streets, with their Emblems and mottos rarely painted; the Å¿tately Throne a litle out of the towne, where the Duke and DutcheÅ¿Å¿e receiued the compliments of their Å¿ubiects; the rich liueries of the young towneÅ¿men on horÅ¿back; the gallantery of the Noblemen and gentlemen of the country (800 in all)
their horÅ¿es at fine as they; the Parlament men, and other officers of IuÅ¿tice all in black veluet gownes; the Clergy and Religious marching in the mean time humbly a foot and in proceÅ¿Å¿ion; the Dukes two companies of horÅ¿e in veluet coats of crimoÅ¿in colour embrodered with gold and Å¿yluer; The Pages and footmen of the Duke and DutcheÅ¿s in crimoÅ¿in Veluet layd thick with gold and Å¿yluer lace; in fine, the Duke and DutcheÅ¿Å¿e on horÅ¿eback as brillant as the Å¿un, would fill a book alone, which I haue no mind to do, Å¿eing there is one extant already in a iuÅ¿t volume.

Leauing then Chambery the next day after the Shew, Montmelian. we went to Montmelian to dinner. This is a Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle vpon a high rock, ouerlooking the riuer IÅ¿ere, IÅ¿ere. and commanding the paÅ¿Å¿age here which is Å¿traight between the hills. The Å¿trength of this CaÅ¿tle appeared when it withÅ¿tood the Royal army of Lewis the XIII of France for fifteen months, and made him rayÅ¿e the Seige when he had done.
Here is Å¿till a Å¿trong garriÅ¿on in it, and Å¿tore of ammunition, and all things neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the defence of a Å¿trong place. They shewed vs in it their deep well for fresh water in the midÅ¿t of a high rock; their excellent peeces of Artillary, one whereof is Å¿ayd to carry four miles, that is, to Fort Barreau a little Fort belonging to France, which is two leagues from hence, and which you Å¿ee from this CaÅ¿tle.

From Montmelian we had rough way to Aiguebelle;Aiguebelle S. Å¿o thence to S. Iohn Morian,
S. Iohn Morian. to S. Michel, and at laÅ¿t to LaÅ¿nebourg, which Å¿tands at the foot of Mount Cenis the higheÅ¿t of all the hills I paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer in my Å¿eueral voyages into Italy, LaÅ¿nebourg. or out of it; to wit, Sampion, Berlin, Splug, and S. Godarde.
This Hill of Mount Cenis parting Sauoy and Italy, shall be the place where I will now begin my DeÅ¿cription of Italy, haueing hitherto onely deÅ¿cribed the Å¿eueral wayes into it.

div.head: The deÅ¿cription and Voyage of Italy.
div.p: Mount Cenis.ARRIVEING then, as I Å¿ayd before, at the foot of Mount Cenis, anciently called CiniÅ¿ium; and reÅ¿ting all night at LaÅ¿nebourg we agreed with the Marons, to carry vs vp the hill, and downe the Hill, as alÅ¿o euer the plain, and in fine, all the way to NoualeÅ¿e it Å¿elf. All this is to be expreÅ¿Å¿ed in your bargain with then, otherwiÅ¿e they will cauil with you, and make you go ouer the plain a foot. The price is, a Spanish piÅ¿tol for euery man thats carryed. ThoÅ¿e that are Å¿trong and vigorous, ride vp vpon mules, and walke downe a foot.

We began to mount at our going out of our Inn at LaÅ¿nebourg, and hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed by La RamaÅ¿Å¿a (where men are poÅ¿ted downe the Hill vpon the Å¿now in Å¿ledges with great celerity and pleaÅ¿ure) after two houres tugging of our chairmen, or MaroÌ„s, we came to the top of the hill, and a little after to the PoÅ¿thouÅ¿e,
and the little HoÅ¿pital vpon the plain: Thence paÅ¿Å¿ing by the Chappel, of the TranÅ¿is (that is, of thoÅ¿e who are found dead of cold in the Å¿now, and are buryed here) we came to the great CroÅ¿Å¿e and Tauerne, where we began to deÅ¿cend. This Hill of Mount Cenis is four miles in the going vp, four miles vpon the plain, and two in its deÅ¿cent to NoualeÅ¿e.
Arriuing about noone at NoualeÅ¿e, NoualeÅ¿e. we dined, horÅ¿ed, and went that night to SuÅ¿a.

SuÅ¿a, anciently SegeÅ¿ium, is a Å¿trong towne, and one of the gates of Italy. For this reaÅ¿on,Suza. the French in their late long warre with Spayne, kept it a long time in their hands, as well as Pignorola, which they Å¿till keep vpon treaty, to let them into Italy, when they haue a mind. Its Å¿trength conÅ¿iÅ¿ts wholly in a CaÅ¿tle built vpon a high rock cloÅ¿e to the towne, and commanding all the paÅ¿Å¿age betwixt the two mountains.Le pas de SuÅ¿e. This towne is famous in the latter hiÅ¿tory, for the Å¿mart action of the French, when they beat downe the twelue Å¿eueral
Barriers, whereby the Duke of Sauoy thought to haue choaked their paÅ¿Å¿age.Piedmont This â€¢ action is famous in hiÅ¿tory, by the name of le Pas de Suze. S. AmbroÅ¿io. Here at SuÅ¿a begins Piedmont.
From SuÅ¿a we went to S. AmbroÅ¿io, & paÅ¿Å¿ed by Riuolle a fine houÅ¿e of the Dukes, Riuolle. Å¿tanding in good ayre, and at night we came to Turin.

Turin. Turin, anciently called AuguÅ¿ta Taurinorum, is Å¿ituated in a plain neare the foot of the hills and vpon the bancks of the riuer Po, The Riuer Po. which begins here to be nauigable, and from hence carryes boats to Ferrara, ChioÅ¿a and Venice. This Po is a noble riuer, and very large in Å¿ome places,Petrus a S. Romualdo Cron. to. 1 eÅ¿pecially a little below Ferrara; yet I haue read that in a great drouth which happened in the yeare of the world 2470 it was dryed vp and rendered innauigable.

The Duke of Sauoys titles, and greatneÅ¿Å¿.This Turin is the Seat of one of the greateÅ¿t Princes in Italy, the Duke of Sauoy, and Prince of Piedmont, who is alÅ¿o treated with the title of Altezza Reale, and Vicario
Generale del Imperio in Italia. This houÅ¿e of Sauoy which now gouerns here, came anciently from Siguardo King of Saxony, in the yeare of ChriÅ¿t 636, and hath conÅ¿erued it Å¿elf euer Å¿ince, that is, for a thouÅ¿and and odd years in a continual Å¿eries of heroical Princes, whoÅ¿e Pedegree was neuer vitiated nor interrupted by any degenerate offÅ¿pring. Fiue Emperors, and four Kings haue yÅ¿Å¿ued out of this houÅ¿e.

Anciently the Dukes of Sauoy kept their Court at Chambery, or els at Bourg en BreÅ¿Å¿e, a country now belonging to France, vpon exchang with the MarquiÅ¿at of Saluzzo; as many of their tombes curiouÅ¿ly cut in marble in the AuguÅ¿tins Church there yet shew. It was Amadeo the Vof that name, Duke of Sauoy, that transferred the Court to Turin. It was alÅ¿o this Amadeo who in memory of his Granfather Amadeo the IV, who had defended Rhodes Å¿o brauely, inÅ¿tituted the kinghthood of the Annunciata, with this Å¿ingle motto in the collar
of the order F. E. R. T. Å¿ignifying, that Fortitudo Eius Rhodum Tenuit. His Subiects.

The Å¿ubiects of this Prince are Å¿ayd to be about eighteen hundred thouÅ¿and Å¿ouls. His whole country with Piedmont and all,His countryes extent. is iudged to be two hundred miles long, and fifty broad. His forces thirty three thouÅ¿and foot,His forces and fiue thouÅ¿and horÅ¿e: and his Reuenews to be about a million of crownes,Reuennues. beÅ¿ides what he can now and then rayÅ¿e out of that fat country of Piedmont. His JntereÅ¿t is,His intereÅ¿t. to keep well with France, and not fall out with Spayne.

As for the towne it Å¿elf of Turin, its almoÅ¿t Å¿quar, and hath four gates in it;The towne of Turin. a Å¿trong Cittadel with fiue baÅ¿tions to it; its well furnished with good prouiÅ¿ions in the market; it Å¿tands in a fat Å¿oyle, which makes it a little too durty in winter, and it is an vniuerÅ¿ity.
The things to be Å¿een in Turin.The cheif things which I Å¿aw here, were theÅ¿e.

The Holy Syndon.1. The Domo, or Great Church, in which is kept with great deuotion the Holy Syndon, in which
our Sauiours body was wound vp and buryed: of the Verity of this Relick Å¿ee Baronius in his EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical HiÅ¿tory ad an. 34 num. 138. Its keept in a Chappel ouer the High Altar and showne publickly vpon certain dayes, and priuatly To EmbaÅ¿sadours and Prelats, as they paÅ¿Å¿e that way. The late DucheÅ¿Å¿e Madame ChriÅ¿tina, began to make a fine Chappel for to keep it in, but is was not quite finished when I paÅ¿Å¿ed that way laÅ¿t. The Chappel is all of black marble adorned with Å¿tately black marble pillars: indeed winding sheets (Å¿uch as this Relick is) are things of mourning, and are beÅ¿t Å¿et out in a mourning way.

2. The Cittadelle Å¿tanding at the back of the towne,The Citadelle. and keeping it in awe. This Duke and his mother found the conuenience of this Cittadelle, when by factions within the towne againÅ¿t them, they were forceed to this Cittadelle, and there weather it out Å¿toutly, till Å¿uccour comeing to them from France, made them maÅ¿ters againe of the towne, and their enemyes.

3. The Dukes new Pallace hanÅ¿omely bu â€¢ lt with a fair Court before it,The Pallace. a great Piazza, and a large open Å¿treet leading vp to it. The Chambers are faire, and hung with hangings of cloth of TyÅ¿sue of a new and rich fabrik, with rich embrodered beds, chairs, Å¿tools, cloth of State, and Canopies. The DutcheÅ¿Å¿es Cabinet, the curious bathing place aboue, hund round with the true pictures in litle of the prime Ladyes of Europe:The bathing place. The curious inuention for the DutcheÅ¿Å¿e to conuey her Å¿elfe vp from her bedchamber to that bathing roome, by a pully and a Å¿wing, with great eaÅ¿e and Å¿aifty: the great Hall painted curiouÅ¿ly: the Noble Å¿taircaÅ¿e: the old long Gallery 100 paces long,The old Gallery. with the Pictures in it of the Princes and PrinceÅ¿Å¿es of the houÅ¿e of Sauoy, with the Statues of the ancient Emperours and PhiloÅ¿ophers in marble, with a rare Library locked vp in great cubbords, are the cheif rooms and ornaments of this Pallace. I Å¿aw alÅ¿o the Appartiments or lodgeings of the old DutcheÅ¿Å¿e Madame
ChriÅ¿tina, which ioyne to the old Gallery, and in her Cabinet I Å¿aw many choyce pictures.

4. The new Å¿treet, The new Å¿treet. which runeth from the Pallace to the Piazza Reale, is a fair Å¿treet and built vniformly. The shops below afford great conueniency to the townes men, and the fair lodgings aboue to the noblemen and Courtiers.
5.The Piazza Reale. The Piazza Reale is built hanÅ¿omly vpon Pillars, like our Couent Garden, and is full of nothing els but noblemens houÅ¿es.
6.The Augustins Church. The AuguÅ¿tins Church called S. Carlo, Å¿tanding in this piazza, adornes it much, being a neat Church and the beÅ¿t contriued that I Å¿aw in this towne.

7.The Capucins Church. The Capucins Church vpon a hill out of the towne, is aboue the rate of Capucins: but you muÅ¿t know who gaue it, not who haue it. From hence I had a perfect view of Turin with the country about it.

8.La Venerie Royale. Some three miles out of the towne I Å¿aw a neat houÅ¿e of the Dukes, called La Venerie Royale.
The Court Å¿et round with Å¿tagg â€¢ heads; the chambers full of good Pictures; the Hall painted with great Pictures of the Duke, his mother, his Å¿iÅ¿ters, and other Ladyes all on horÅ¿eback as if they were going a hunting; the place where they keep pheaÅ¿ants, partridges, and other Å¿uch like birds, the Å¿table for 100 horÅ¿e, and the neat dogkennel, are the beÅ¿t things to be Å¿een in this houÅ¿e.

La Valentine.9 On the other Å¿ide of the towne, about a mile of, I Å¿aw the old DutcheÅ¿Å¿es houÅ¿e called La Valentine. It Å¿tands pleaÅ¿antly vpon the banks of Po, and is adorned with great variety of pictures. In fiue or Å¿ix roomes, on the right hand of the houÅ¿e, they shewed me a world of pictures of all Å¿orts of Flowers: on the left hand, as many of all Å¿orts of birds, with other pictures curiouÅ¿ly painted. The four pictures repreÅ¿enting the four Elements, with all that belongs to them, as all the birds that fly in the air; all the beaÅ¿ts that are found vpon the Earth; all the fishes and shells that are found
in the water; and all things that belong to fire, are Å¿o curiouÅ¿ly painted in their Å¿eueral particular shaps & colours, that theÅ¿e four peeces are and abridgment of all nature, and the admiration of all that behold them. There are Å¿ome other good peeces here too; as the Magdalen fallen into an extaÅ¿ie: the rapt of the Sabins; and diuers others. The others houÅ¿es about the towne, as Millefleur belonging to the Duke; the Villa of the PrinceÅ¿Å¿e Marie; with diuers others which shew themÅ¿elues vpon the Hill Å¿ide, are very Å¿tately, and worth Å¿eeing.

Hauing thus Å¿een Turin, From Turin to Genua. we left the ordinary road, which leads to Milan (to wit, by the way of Vercelle and Nouara, two Å¿trong townes frontier to one another, through which I paÅ¿Å¿ed in another voyage) and to auoyd two armyes which lay in the way, choÅ¿e to Å¿teere towards Genua by the low way of Sauona. And paÅ¿Å¿ing through a melancholy country by Altare and other little townes for the pace of three daies, we came at laÅ¿t to Sauona.

Sauona. Sauona (anciently called Sabatia, or Sabatium) is the Å¿econd towne, or eldeÅ¿t daughter of Genua; and like a good daughter indeed she Å¿tands alwayes in her mothers preÅ¿ence, yet keeps her diÅ¿tance: it being within Å¿ight of Genua, yet fiue and twenty mils off. It Å¿tands vpon the Mediterranean Sea, or, as they call it here, vpon the Riuiera di Genoa. Its fortified both by art and nature, thar is, by regular Fortifications towards the Sea, and by luÅ¿ty Apennin hills towards the Land. Yet whiles Sauona feared no danger from either Sea, or Land, it was almoÅ¿t ruined in the yeare 1648. by fire from heauen, to wit, ligthning; which falling vpoÌ„ a great Tower, in the midÅ¿t of the towne, where gunpowder was kept, blew it vp vpon a Å¿udden, and with it, threw downe two hundred houÅ¿es round about it, and houÅ¿es of note. For paÅ¿Å¿ing that way Å¿ix months after, and walking among the ruines, I Å¿aw in many of the houÅ¿es, which were but half fallen downe, curious painted chambers and fine
guilt roofes, which shewd me of what houÅ¿e many of theÅ¿e houÅ¿es had been; and of what weak defence guilt roofes and painted walls are againÅ¿t the artillery of heauen thunder and lightning.

This towne is famous in hiÅ¿tory for the interview of two great kings here, to wit, Lewis the XII of France, and Ferdinand King of Naples. This interview paÅ¿Å¿ed with demonÅ¿trations of mutuall ciuilityes, not ordinary in interviews of Princes. For Lewis feared not to go into the Gallyes and ships of Ferdinand without gards and vnarmed: and Ferdinand remained for many dayes together in this towne belonging the â€¢ to Lewis, whom he had lately Å¿tipt of the kingdome of Naples, and beaten him to boot in a battle.
Of this towne were Iulius Secundus, and Sixtus Quartus, two Popes of the houÅ¿e of Roueri: and two great Cardinals, Peter, and Raphael Riarii.

Embarking at Sauona in a Feluca we rowed along the Shoare (called
la Riuiere di Genoa) vnto Genua it Å¿elf; and all the way long we Å¿aw Å¿uch a continual Å¿uburbs of Å¿tately Villas and Villages, that theÅ¿e Å¿cantlings made vs in loue which the whole peece it Å¿elf, Genua. La Riuiera di Genua. I confeÅ¿Å¿e, I neuer Å¿ew a more Å¿tately abord to any Citty then to this: and if we had not had Genua full in our Å¿ight all the way long, we should haue taken Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Å¿tately Villages for Genua it Å¿elf; and haue imitated HoÅ¿tingus the leader of the Normans, who comeing into Italy about the yeare 860 with a great army, and finding Luna (a towne in the confines of Genua) Å¿o Å¿umptuouÅ¿ly built, thought really it had been Rome, and there vpon takeing it,Dreido a S. Quintino lib. 1. de morib. & Act. Norman. he gloryed that he had Å¿acked the miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e of the world; Gratatur tenere Å¿e Monarchiam totius Imperii, per vrbem quam putabat Roman â€¢ , Å¿ayth his HiÅ¿torian.
Sayling thus along this pleaÅ¿ant coaÅ¿t, we came betimes to Genua.

Genua. Genua is one of the chief townes that Å¿tand vpon the Mediterranea â€¢ Sea, and one of the beÅ¿t in Italy. The

It Å¿tands upoÌ„ the Å¿ide of a hill, and riÅ¿eing by degrees, appears to thoÅ¿e that looke vpon it from the Sea, like an Amphitheater. Heretofore it was only fortified by marble bullworks,The walls that is, great hills of marble which backt it vp: but Å¿ome forty years ago, it was enuironed, with new-walls, carrying Å¿ix miles in compaÅ¿Å¿e, and yet finished in eighteen months.

The Hauen heretofore was very vnÅ¿afe, and many ships which had tuggd through the moÅ¿t dangerous Seas abroad, were Å¿een to Å¿ink here in the hauen at home;The Hauuen. the French then maÅ¿ters of Genua, not Å¿uffering her to shut vp her hauen, leaÅ¿t she should shut them out. But Å¿ince shee hath shaked off the French yoak, she hath loked vp her TreaÅ¿ures, and bolted the doore on the inÅ¿ide, by that admirable Mola which croÅ¿Å¿ing almoÅ¿t quite ouer the baye, or, hauen, doth not onely bolt out all enemyes, but euen

The Pharos.At one end of this Mola Å¿tands the Pharos vpon a little rock, with a Lantern vpon it, to giue notice, by knowne Å¿ignes, what ships, how many, and from what Å¿ide they Come: or els to guide their owne ships home Å¿afely in the night. As for the towne it Å¿elf of Genua, its moÅ¿t beautifull to behold:The Cittye it Å¿elfe. many of the houÅ¿es being painted on the outÅ¿ide, and looking as if they were turned inÅ¿ide out, and had their Arras hangings hung on their outÅ¿ides. The tops of their houÅ¿es are made with open galleries, where the women Å¿it together at worke in cluÅ¿ters, and where alÅ¿o they dry their haire in the Sun after they haue washed it in a certain wash a purpoÅ¿e for to make it Yellow, a

The Å¿treets are very narrow:The Å¿treets Å¿o that they vÅ¿e here few coaches, but many Sedans and Litters. This makes the noyÅ¿e in the Å¿treets leÅ¿Å¿e, and the expence in the purÅ¿e Å¿maller. Yet I muÅ¿t except the Strada Noua here, which for a Å¿pirt,Strada Noua. Å¿urpaÅ¿Å¿eth all the Å¿treets I euer Å¿aw any where elÅ¿e for neatneÅ¿Å¿ and proportion; and if it had but breath ynough to hold out at the Å¿ame rate, a little longer, it would be the true Queen-street of Europe: Ordinary houÅ¿es are Å¿o out of countenaÌ„ce here, that they dare not appeare in this Å¿treet where thers nothing but Pallaces,
and Pallaces as fine as art, and coÅ¿t; or as Marble, and Painting can make them.

The Domo.1. The Domo, or great Church of S. 2 After the Domo, I Å¿aw the Church of the Annunciata, The Annunciata. which draweth vp the Ladder after it for neatneÅ¿Å¿. Its Å¿till in building, and not quite finished.Gli Signori Lomelini. 8. But that which is the moÅ¿t taking in Genua, is that which is out of Genua; I meane, the Å¿tately Suburbs of San Pietro in Arena, San Pietro in Arena. where for a mile together, Villas adorned with marbles, painting, Å¿tatues, Gardens, Arbours of GelÅ¿omin, Orange, and Limon trees, grotts, ponds, Giuochi d'acqua, fountains, high wales, with shades borne vp by Marble Pillars &c. compoÅ¿e of many pallaces and gardens, Å¿uch a beautifull Landskip, that the whole place Å¿eemed to mee,

The beÅ¿t Villas, or Pallaces here, are thoÅ¿e of Hieronymo Negro, and that of the Imperiali: the firÅ¿t beautifyed with all the graces of Italian furniture, as alÅ¿o with Gardens, Walks, Ponds, Water works, Allees &c: the other, beÅ¿ides all theÅ¿e, hath an excellent ProÅ¿pect: for the maÅ¿ter of this houÅ¿e can Å¿ee out of one window of it, twelue thouÅ¿and crownes a yeare of his owne, onely in let houÅ¿es. The other Pallaces here expect I should Å¿ay Å¿omething of them, and they deÅ¿erue it well; but realy to giue them their full due, I can onely Å¿ay this of them, that they aught to be Å¿een by the eye, not deÅ¿cribed by the pen.

9.The Villa of the Duke d'Oria. As you returne from San Pietro in Arena to the towne not farre from the Gates, Å¿tands the Villa, or Pallace of the Duke d'Oria. I reÅ¿erued this for the laÅ¿t, pour faire
bonne bouche. It Å¿tands vpon the SeaÅ¿ide, and its garden towards the Sea is built vpon three rowes of white marble Rayls borne vp by white marble pillars, which aÅ¿cending by degrees, is Å¿o beautifull to behold from the Sea, that Å¿trangers paÅ¿Å¿ing that way to Genua, take this garden for a Å¿econd ParadiÅ¿e. In the midÅ¿t of it Å¿tands the rare Fountain of Neptune, repreÅ¿enting the true lookes of Braue Andrea D'Oria the Neptune of the Ligurian Sea, and the man who put his country out of Liuery, and taught it, not to Å¿erue. All along one Å¿ide of this Garden, Å¿tands a Cage of Iron, about a hundred paces long; and Å¿o high that it fetcheth in a world of laurel & other trees, clad with chirping birds of Å¿eueral Å¿orts; and to make the poore birds beleeue that they are rather in a wood, then in a priÅ¿on, the very Cage hath put euen the wood it Å¿elf in priÅ¿on. Then entring into the Pallace, we found it moÅ¿t curiouÅ¿ly adorned with rarityes, and riches, Å¿utable to the countrys humour, and the maÅ¿ters
purÅ¿e. Its true, when this Queen of Spayne paÅ¿Å¿ed from Germany into Spayne, by the way of Milan and Genua, the Gouernour of Milan told her, that she should Å¿ee in d'Orias pallace here, many fine things, but all borrowed of the townÅ¿men. Which d'Oria hearing of before hand, cauÅ¿ed to be written ouer the great Gates of the Pallace, where the Queen was to enter and lodge, theÅ¿e words in Spanish, By the grace of God, and the Kings fauour, thers nothing here borrowed. It may be, the cunning Gouernour of Milan thought by telling the Queen this, to oblige the Duke D'Oria to preÅ¿ent Å¿ome of his beÅ¿t things to the Queen, to shew her that they were his owne; as its Å¿ayd, the late Duke of Buckingham did in France, by breaking his dyamond hatband among the Court Ladyes, who Å¿ayd he had onely borrowed it; but the wiÅ¿e Italian by this trick, both kept his owne, and yet Å¿atisfyed the Queen. Indeed he hath things here both too good to be giuen away, and
too great to be carryed away: witneÅ¿Å¿ thoÅ¿e rare Syluer tables which are in his Warderobe, one whereof weigheth twenty-four thouÅ¿and pound weight. From the Pallace we were led ouer the Å¿treet to his great garden vpon the hillÅ¿ide, where all the graces that can make vp a garden, are found.
As for the Gouerment, fashions, Wealth, Å¿trength, and IntereÅ¿t of Genua, I found them to be thus.

Their Gouerment, is Democratical, or Popular, by a Dog â€¢
(choÅ¿en euery two years) and eight Senators, The Gouerment. who liue with him in the Pallace, and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him with their counÅ¿ell. The great CounÅ¿ell here, which is the foundation of the Gouerment, conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of four hundred men choÅ¿en indifferently out of all the families of the towne. TheÅ¿e deliberate with the Signoria of all things that belong to warre or peace. Anciently, as I hinted before, Genua was vnder the French domination, till Andrea D'Oria Å¿et it free. HiÅ¿tories write of it that Berengarius the third, and
the Sarazins, Å¿o ruined Genua, that they left it Å¿wiming in its owne blood: Which ruine was forewarned by a prodigie of a fountain of blood which rann in the very Å¿treets of Genua. It had like to haue Å¿wmme a Å¿econd time in its blood, when Lewis the XII of France entering into Genua victoriouÅ¿ly with Å¿word in hand, threatning the vtter ruine of that people; was pacifyed by the mournfull cryes of four thouÅ¿and little Children, who clad in Å¿ackcloth and placed in the great Piazza cryed out to the King in a piercing accent, MiÅ¿ericordia e Pieta, Mercy and Pitty. But Å¿ince Genua shooke off the French Yoke it hath liued perpetually Gealous of the FreÌ„ch, eÅ¿pecially Å¿ince it diÅ¿couered, Å¿ome years paÅ¿t, diuers attempts of France againÅ¿t it, whiles the French had Portolongone and Piombino.

For this reaÅ¿on, the GenueÅ¿i leane much to the Spanish Faction; and Fashions following Faction, Their Fashions. they leane alÅ¿o much to the Spanish Fashion both in humour and apparel. Hence I found here broad hats
without hat-bands, broad leather girdles with Å¿teel buckles, narrow britches with long waÅ¿ted doublets and hanging Å¿leeues, to be Ã la mode, as well as in Madrid. And I found all the great Ladyes here to go like the Donnas of Spayne in Guardinfantas, that is, in horrible ouergrowne Vertigals of whale-bone, which being put about the waÅ¿te of the Lady, and full as broad on both Å¿ides, as she can reach with her hands, beare out her coats in Å¿uch a huffing manner, that she appears to be as broad as long. So that the men here with their little cloÅ¿e britches, looked like tumblers that leap through the houps: and the women like thoÅ¿e that danced anciently the Hobby-horÅ¿e in country Mummings. Two of theÅ¿e Ladyes meeting one another in theÅ¿e narrow Å¿treets, make as great an Embarras, as two carts of hay do vpon London bridge: and I haue Å¿een their Ladiships Å¿trangely puzzled, how to iuggle themÅ¿elues into a narrow Sedan, or Littar: indeed half of my Lady hangs out. For my
part I admire that this iealous Republick doth not feare, leaÅ¿t Å¿ome of theÅ¿e Ladyes (vpon a diÅ¿guÅ¿t) should carry a Å¿et of little short gunns vnder her coats, and vnder pretence of preferring a petition to the Senate aÅ¿Å¿embled, giue them a broad Å¿ide or two, and make a horrible confuÅ¿ion in the Republick. If all this bulk of clothes, which make the women here looke like haycocks with armes and heads, be allowed them by their wiÅ¿e huÅ¿bands, to render them more viÅ¿ible, and leÅ¿Å¿e able to go priuately into any Å¿uÅ¿pected houÅ¿es, its good policy: otherwiÅ¿e, moÅ¿t certain it is, that the wifes gownes cheat horribly the HuÅ¿bands britches, of almoÅ¿t all the Å¿tuff.Guardinfanta Å¿ignifies a Child-preÅ¿eruer I haue onely heard (and it was from a Nobleman of Genua) of one Lady here that made right vÅ¿e of theÅ¿e Guardinfantas; and it was shee, who Å¿eeing her onely Å¿onn (a yong nobleman of Genua about eighteen years old) already condemned to priÅ¿on, and ready to be condemned to the Å¿caffold for a heynous crime, got leaue to viÅ¿it
him in priÅ¿on as often as she pleaÅ¿ed; and at laÅ¿t, by meanes of a good Guardinfanta of Å¿teele, inÅ¿tead of whale-bone, she tooke vp her Å¿onn vnder her coats in that Guardinfanta, and marching out of the priÅ¿on grauely, as she vÅ¿ed to do, by leaning vpon two ancient women, as the Fashion is here for great Ladyes to do, she carryed him home Å¿o; and being there deliuered of him a Å¿econd time, without a midwife, she Å¿ent him preÅ¿ently out of the country to be nurÅ¿ed and kept. Thus she Å¿aued her families honour. Was not this a true Guardinfanta, which preÅ¿erued thus the life of a child? But was not this alÅ¿o a gallant mother that went with a child who was full eighteen years old when his mother bore him? The onely pitty was, that this gallant mother had not the happineÅ¿Å¿ once to be mother of a gallant Å¿onn, Å¿eeing she had had the trouble of bringing forth Å¿uch a Å¿onn twice.

Their Riches.As for their Riches, I am told they paÅ¿Å¿e not a million and two hundred thouÅ¿and crownes a yeare. Indeed
the King of Spayne Philip the II aboue a hundred years ago, borrowed of this Republick the Å¿umm of eleuen millions, and keeps them Å¿till in his hands, to keep this Republick in awe; yet paying the intereÅ¿t duly vnto them. So that the Common purÅ¿e here is nothing Å¿o rich as that of Venice, though the particular men here are farre richer then thoÅ¿e of Venice. They haue great trading both with France and Spayne, and are great Banquiers makeing the ChaÌ„ge, in all the bancks of Europe go as they pleaÅ¿e. BeÅ¿ides, they vtter a world of Taffetas, Veluets, Sattins, Points of needle worke and diuers other things of Value.

As for their Strength, Their Strength. its enough to defend themÅ¿elues, Å¿carce enough to offend others. For Genua is backd vp by the Apennins, where all paÅ¿Å¿ages are eaÅ¿ily made good againÅ¿t inuaders; and it is Å¿o well fortifyed on the other Å¿ide by the Sea it Å¿elf, twelue or fourteen good Gallyes, twenty ships of warre, and its incomparable Molo, that they could Å¿cuffle notably in their owne
defence. BeÅ¿ides, Genua is fortifyed not onely with its Hills and Sea, but alÅ¿o with its new walls and bullworks of Å¿tone; nay, and with its Bonewalls too, that is, with a Lacedemonian wall of a world of inhabitants, and with the IlluÅ¿trious Families of d'Oria, Spinola, Grimaldi Sauli, Durazzi, Catanei, and others, whoÅ¿e Å¿eueral names would go almoÅ¿t for Å¿eueral armyes. Yet for a need, they can rayÅ¿e thirty thouÅ¿and men, and arme them well out of their ArÅ¿enal. I confeÅ¿Å¿e heretofore they were Å¿trong enough to offend others; For they made warre againÅ¿t the PiÅ¿ani, and worÅ¿ted them: They Å¿et alÅ¿o vpon the Iland of CorÅ¿ica, diÅ¿tant from Genua about a hundred miles, and tooke it. This Iland gaue the Republike of Genua more honour then profit: for it being once a Kingdome, giues Å¿till to Genua the title of SereniÅ¿Å¿ima, and a CloÅ¿e Regal Crowne ouer its Coat of Armes. In fine, the GenueÅ¿i were Å¿trong enough heretofore, to lend great Å¿uccours to Godfrey of Bullen in his holy conqueÅ¿t
of HieruÅ¿alem. Hence vpon the very Arca of the Holy Sepulcher in HieruÅ¿alem, are written theÅ¿e words: Praepotens GenuenÅ¿ium praeÅ¿idium.

As for their IntereÅ¿t, Their IntereÅ¿t. it Å¿eemed to mee to be farre more Spanish, then French, by reaÅ¿on of the great profit they draw from Spayne, which correÅ¿ponds with the rich State of Milan in men and monyes, by meanes of the GenneÅ¿i: yet they are well with all ChriÅ¿tian Princes, except with the Duke of Sauoye who pretends to Sauona.

As for the Learned men of this towne,Their learned men. I find them not to be Å¿o many. The rich Banquier is more eÅ¿teemed here, then the learned Diuine. Yet I finde here alÅ¿o Å¿ome famous for learning, to wit, BaptiÅ¿ta FregoÅ¿us, or, FulgoÅ¿us, who for his Å¿ingular parts being choÅ¿en Doge of Genua, and by his owne diÅ¿loyal kinred chaÅ¿ed from Gouerment and country, comforted himÅ¿elf in his Å¿tuddyes; and haueing obÅ¿erued many particular things in hiÅ¿tory, he reduced them to heads, and left vs a iuÅ¿t volume of Memorable Å¿ayings
and Deeds of the ancients: for which work he is Å¿tiled by Alberto Leandro, the Valerius Maximus of Italy. He wrote in Italian, and dedicated his booke to his Sonn. The other learned men of this towne are IuÅ¿tinianus, Balus, MaÅ¿cardi, and ChriÅ¿topher Columbus.
Genua alÅ¿o hath giuen to the Church three Popes, Adrian the V. Innocent the IV, and Innocent the VIII.

The Academy of Wits.Here is an Academy of Wits called the Adormentati; which together with the other Academyes of the like nature in all the townes of Italy, I would wish my Traueller to viÅ¿it particularly, that he may Å¿ee how farr the Jtalians excell vs in paÅ¿Å¿ing their time well, and how its much better to Å¿pend the week in making of Orations and VerÅ¿es, then in drinking of Ale and Å¿moaking of Tobacco.

Alexandria.

Some Å¿ay he refuÅ¿ed to bee Å¿erued by Bourbon, looking vpon him as a revolted Trayter, rather then as an ennemy: indeed the braue FrÃ«nch Knight Bayard (Å¿urnamed, the Cheualier Å¿ans peur who died in this battle,) being found expireing in the feild, by Bourbon, who Å¿ayd to him, Poore Bayard! I pitty thee; anÅ¿wered him with all the courage and life that was left him; No, Traytor, J am not to be pittyed, who dye nobly Å¿eruing my King and country: but thou rather art to be pittied, who
liueÅ¿t Ã Traytor to thy king and country. As for the King he was led priÅ¿oner into Spayne, where he was kept at Madrid till he payed his ranÅ¿om. Hence the Spaniards brag, that they had once a French king priÅ¿oner, and the French had neuer any King of Spayne priÅ¿oner: but the French anÅ¿wer, that their King had not been priÅ¿oner had he fought as the Kings of Spayne do of late, that is, by Proxie, and not in perÅ¿on. to it; two hundred Churches within it, and three hundred thouÅ¿and Å¿ouls dwelling in it. Its called Milan quaÅ¿i Midland, being a pure Mediterranean Towne, and hauing (which is a wonder) not Å¿o much as a riuer of its owne running by it; but is onely Å¿erued by two Channels cut out of the Ticine and the Adder. This towne hath heretofore Å¿uffered much by warre; great townes being the faireÅ¿t Markes to shoot at, and Milan hath been forty times shot at by Sieges, and twenty times Hit and taken, haueing had the misfortune to haue been vnder diuers factions and Rulers: as the Emperours, the Turriani, the ViÅ¿conti, the Sforze, the French, and the Spaniards, who now keep it, mercÃ¨ al CaÅ¿tello, which

A Mandragora. 3. a bird without feet called by AriÅ¿totle Apodes. 4. a Å¿tone out of which is drawne a thread, which

The little round Cabinet flat aboue, like a childs drum, with a Å¿mooth glaÅ¿Å¿e: The maÅ¿ter Å¿etting little ships, coaches, &c. vpon the glaÅ¿Å¿e, they wheele and moue vp and downe as it were of themÅ¿elues: when all is done by a Å¿ympathetical vertue and by the maÅ¿ters turning Å¿ecretly

A peece of a thunderbolt, which the Canon himÅ¿elf Å¿ayd he had cut out of a mans thigh Å¿trucken with it. 10. Diuers peeces of Coral iuÅ¿t as it growes in the Sea. 11. A little Pillar two handfull high of marble, Å¿o carcked, that it gapeth wide on one Å¿ide with the crack, and yet holdeth together faÅ¿t on the other Å¿ide, as a great Å¿tick of green wood doth, when it is bent Å¿o farre on one Å¿ide as to gape, and yet Å¿ticks together on the other. 12. A world of rich iewels, Å¿trange Å¿tones, cameos, pictures, cryÅ¿tals, little infants in waxe in glaÅ¿Å¿e caÅ¿es, and many other exotick rarityes, which are better Å¿een then deÅ¿cribed.

21. Some Pallaces here:Some Pallaces. as that of the Gouernours, rather vaÅ¿t then

22. The Castle, The CaÅ¿tle. or Citadelle, one of the beÅ¿t in Europe, in the opinion of the Duke of Rohan a competent jugde. It Å¿tands within and without the towne, that is, at the back of the towne, like a rod

The large Å¿treets in it; the Å¿tately houÅ¿es and Pallaces for the chief commanders; the neat piazzas; the number of well furnished shops in all kindes, euen goldÅ¿miths too; the fiue fountaines, or Wells, not to be dryed vp; the Mill; the HoÅ¿pital; the Church; with eight or ten Chaplains in it, and a Curate; the faire place of armes capable of Å¿ix thouÅ¿and men; two hundred great peeces of Cannon vpon the walls; the Å¿ix Royal baÅ¿tions, the regular fortifications or outworks; the vnderground way from one baÅ¿tion to an other; the infinit heaps of Cannon bullets, Å¿ome whereof weigh 800 pound weight; the three large and deep ditches round about the CaÅ¿tle; the Å¿tately

The shops23. The shops of CryÅ¿tals, where you haue a world of curioÅ¿itys in cryÅ¿tal: as watch caÅ¿es, twizercaÅ¿es, little boxes, pictures cut in cryÅ¿tal, croÅ¿Å¿es and beads of cryÅ¿tal &c. The Academy of witts.24. Here is an Academy of wits, called the NaÅ¿coÅ¿ti, or Hidden men. But Why Hidden? Å¿eing Wit, like the Sun, should shine publickly, and not bury it Å¿elf; except it be to shew vs, that as the Sun neuer shins brighter, then after he hath been hidden in a Cloud: Å¿o wit neuer shins more, then after

25.The learned Men. The moÅ¿t famous men of this towne for learning, haue been theÅ¿e: Valerius Maximus for hiÅ¿tory: Alciatus, Decius, and IaÅ¿on for Law: Cardan for PhiloÅ¿ophy: Panigarola, and Paulus Aresius, for Sermons: Bonacina for Canon Law; and Octauius Ferrarius (whom I knew lately in Padua) for belle lettere.

The DomoThen I went to the Domo, whoÅ¿e Cupola was painted by the rare

LaÅ¿tly to The Capucins, The Capucins. in whoÅ¿e Church lyes buryed my noble Heros, Alexander FarneÅ¿e Duke of Parma, Alexander FarneÅ¿e. whom I cannot meet in this my voyage without a compliment. The Reuenues of this Prince are Å¿ayd to be Å¿ix hundred thouÅ¿and crownes a yeare.The Dukes Reuenues. Hee is now of the
French faction;His intereÅ¿t. His forces and in all his territories hee can rayÅ¿e 28000 men.

Of the true houÅ¿e of EÅ¿tÃ¨, was the braue CounteÅ¿Å¿e Matilda, CounteÅ¿Å¿e Matilda. the dry-NurÅ¿e, as I may Å¿ay, of the Roman Church. His intereÅ¿t.From thence paÅ¿Å¿ing the riuer we came Å¿oone to Fort Vrban, a Cittadel moÅ¿t regularly built by the command of Pope Vrban the VIII, from whom its called.His forces Its Å¿o Å¿trong, that it is not afrayd to Å¿tand, night and day,Fort Vrban. alone in the fields, and vpon the frontiers of the Popes EÅ¿tate. PaÅ¿Å¿ing from hence through

Bologna is one of the greateÅ¿t townes of Italy, Bologna. and one of the hanÅ¿omeÅ¿t. Its the Å¿econd of the Popes Dominions; and the Chief VniuerÅ¿ity of Italy for Law. This country was anciently called FelÅ¿ina, Gallia CiÅ¿alpina, Gallia Togata, to diÅ¿tinguish it from Gallia Braccata, The country in France neare Narbonne, And from Gallia Comata, The Country in France called la Guienne. The towne it Å¿elfe.As for the towne of Bologna now, its excellently well builtâ–ª and for the moÅ¿t part, vpon arches, like the Couent Garden in London; onely the pillars are round. TheÅ¿e Arches bring great conueniency to the inhabitants who can walk all the towne ouer coole and dry, euen in Iuly and Ianuary. Its fiue miles in compaÅ¿Å¿e, and an excellent Å¿ommer towne, were it not that the ayre is not altogether Å¿o pure, and the wines heating.Jts Gouerment. Its gouerned By a Legat a Latere, Å¿ent hither by the Pope, and in change, it Å¿ends an EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to Rome, to reÅ¿ide there: Å¿o that Bologna is treated by Rome, rather like a SiÅ¿ter, Its Priuiledges. then Ã Subject; and deÅ¿eruedly, Å¿eing Bologna fell not to the Church any other way but by her free giuing her Å¿elf to the Pope; reÅ¿eruing onely to her Å¿elf Å¿ome particular Priuileges; as power to Å¿end EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to Rome; and that if any toweÅ¿man kill another,
and can but eÅ¿cape away, his goods cannot be confiÅ¿cated.

1. The Dominicans Church and Conuent. The Dominicans Church. In the Church, I Å¿aw the tombe of S. Dominick, Founder of that Order. 5. Turning from hence on the left hand, I went to S. Michael in BoÅ¿co a Å¿tately MonaÅ¿tery of Oliuetan Fathers, S. Michael in BoÅ¿co. Å¿tanding vpon a high hill. S. Petronios Church.9. Then I viÅ¿ited San Petronio Å¿tanding in the end of the great Piazza, of which Church Leandro Alberto writ a hundred years ago, that he thought it would not be ended but with the worlds end. 12.The Legats Pallace. After the Churches and MonaÅ¿terys, we went on with viÅ¿iting the reÅ¿t of the towne, and Å¿aw the Pallace of the Popes Legate: in this Pallace I Å¿aw the rare Cabinet and Study of Aldrouandus, to whom Pliny the Second if he were now

Seeing theÅ¿e ManuÅ¿cripts I asked whether the man had liued three hundred years, or no, as its Å¿ayd Ioannes de Temporibus, In Charles the greats time did: but it was anÅ¿wered me, that he liued onely fourÅ¿core and three: a short age for Å¿uch a long work: but it sheweth vs how farre a man may trauel in Å¿ciences in his life time, if he riÅ¿e but betimes, and Å¿purr on all his life time with obÅ¿tinate labour. Certainly had he wrote before Salomons time, Salomon would haue changed his Å¿aying, and inÅ¿tead of Å¿ending the Å¿lothfull man to learne of the piÅ¿mire how to labour, he would haue Å¿ent him

14. The Spanish Colledge founded here by noble Cardinal Albornozzo, The Spanish Colledge. deÅ¿erues to be taken notice of. Its well built, with a hanÅ¿ome Church and fiue PrieÅ¿ts to Å¿erue it. The intention of his Colledge is to furnish all the King of Spayns dominions in Italy with able MagiÅ¿trats and officers of IuÅ¿tice. None can liue in it but Natural Spaniards (except the Chaplains) and thoÅ¿e Spaniards muÅ¿t be Doctors of the Law before they can be admitted hereâ–ª they onely learne the language and cuÅ¿tomes of the countryes, and perfect themÅ¿elues in the Å¿tudy of the Law, that they may bee fitt to fill vp the firÅ¿t vacant places of Iudicature that fall either in the State of Milan, in the kingdome of Naples, or in Sicily. They haue a reuenew of twelue thouÅ¿and
crownes a year. They keep two Coaches, liue very nobly, and lodge all Spanish EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, Cardinals, and Prelats of their nation that paÅ¿Å¿e this way. In the Colledge you Å¿ee the pictures of many great StateÅ¿men and Cardinals, and others, who haue been of this Colledge: but no picture pleaÅ¿ed me like that of their braue founder noble Cardinal Albornozzo which is in the Church, and repreÅ¿enting him in the Å¿ame poÅ¿ture he was in, when he recouered all the Popes Å¿tate in Italy, vnto the Pope then at Auignon; of which I haue Å¿poken Å¿ufficiently aboue in deÅ¿cribeing Auignon.

The 2 Towers.15. The two Towers here in the midÅ¿t of the towne, the one very high and Å¿traight called, de gli AÅ¿inelli; the other low and bending, called la CariÅ¿enda. They would make vs beleeue that this bending tower was made crooked a purpoÅ¿e; and its Å¿trang to Å¿ee how moÅ¿t men make it their buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿ rather to Å¿ee this low crooked tower, then the other, which is hoth higher and Å¿traighter. But
thers no maÅ¿tery to make things ill, and to miÅ¿Å¿e of our aymes: and I rather think the CariÅ¿Å¿enda or low Tower, went not vp higher, becauÅ¿e the Architect perceiued it went vp awry. But we Å¿trangers admire euery thing in Å¿trange countryes, and that makes that none admire vs: Vpon which occaÅ¿ion I would wish my yong traueler neuer to admire any thing in outward shew, but to looke curiouÅ¿ly at euery thing without crying out, Ã´ che Belae CoÅ¿a! This will get him and his Nation farre more honour, for Admiration is but the daughter of Ignorance; and Magnanimus, (Å¿aith AriÅ¿totle) nihil admiratur.

16. Then the HouÅ¿es here,The HouÅ¿es in Bolognia. which are generally well built, and in Sommer time, Å¿etting open their dores & gates towards the Å¿treet, you may looke quite through their courts, entryes, portches, houÅ¿es, and a huge way into their gardens, which euen from thence, will Å¿alute your eye with dainty perÅ¿pectiues, fountains, and fresh verdure; and your noÅ¿e too with curious Å¿mells of

The Nobility.17. TheÅ¿e fine houÅ¿es are full alÅ¿o of Nobility, and I remember to haue Å¿een here at a CorÅ¿odi Paglio vpon MidÅ¿ommer day the long great, Å¿treet lined quite through with coaches on both Å¿ides, & thoÅ¿e coaches double lined with Ladyes and Caualiers of Garbo. 20.The Academy of wits. But that you may not think them better fed, then taught; they haue erected here an Acadamy of wits called, Gli OtioÅ¿i, or, Jdlemen, by a figure of Rhetorick called a Lye, or per antiphraÅ¿im, becauÅ¿e they are not idle. Cardinal Bentiuoglio, The Marquis of Maluezzi, and Iohn BaptiÅ¿ta Manzini; the firÅ¿t, the Titius Liuius of his age, the Å¿econd, the Lucius Florus of his age; and the third, the Marcus Tullius of his time. 21. He that deÅ¿ires to know the particular hiÅ¿tory of Bologna, let him read Bartholomeo Gal â€¢ otti, The HiÅ¿torians. and Giouanni Garzo, where hee shall finde how Bologna Å¿uffered much anciently by the two oppoÅ¿it factions of the Lambertazzi and the Geremei. Hauing thus Å¿een Bolognia, and being armed with a Bolettina di
Sanita, Remember this Bolettina, Traueler. taken here, to make vs be let paÅ¿Å¿e into the State of Florence, we Å¿teered on horÅ¿eback towards Florence and reacht it in two dayes. The firÅ¿t dayes journey by Pianora, Loiano, Scarga L'Azino, Pietra Mala, and ouer the Apennins, The Apennin Hills. was long and tedious enough, till the night came, at which time we were much recreated with the Å¿ight of a Fire which appeared Å¿ome two miles off in the Å¿ide of a montain on our left hand. This fire appears here frequently eÅ¿pecially in clowdy wheather: and it appeared to mee for an hour together as I road along, to be Å¿till of the Å¿ame bigneÅ¿Å¿e, and of the Å¿ame glowy colour (fornace like) and of a perfect round forme, and not pyramidal, as other flames are. The country people here call this fire, La Bocca d' Inferno, Hells mouth; and I knowe not why they may not as well call this fire Å¿o, as Tertullian calls VeÅ¿uuius and Aetna (two burning montaines) Fumariola inferni, Tertul. l. de Poenitent. c. 12.
Hells chimneys. Taken in fine, with this fixed meteor, we
forgot the tediouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿ of the way and came to Fiorenzuola. Fiorenzuola. The next morning paÅ¿Å¿ing by Scarperia and Il Ponte wee arriued betimes at Florence

I confeÅ¿Å¿e, I Å¿tirred not out of my Inn that night, becauÅ¿e fair Florence (as the Prouerb calls her) is not to be Å¿een in fowle linnen,My arriual at Florence. and rideing boots: but getting vp betimes the next morning, I gaue my eyes Å¿uch a breakfaÅ¿t as Princes eyes would bee glad to feed vpon.
But before I come to the particulars of what I Å¿aw in Florence, I will conÅ¿ider it in great, and then come to the Detail of it.Florence.

Diuers good Authors are of opinion that this towne was firÅ¿t built by Syllas Å¿oldiers, to whom he had giuen this Å¿oyle for their Å¿eruices done him in his Ciuil warrs. They built it neare the current of two riuers (Arno and Munio) and from thence it was called at firÅ¿t Fluentia (as Coblentz in Germany, from the meeting of riuers, is called Confluentia.) Afterwards by the Inhabitants it was called Florentia,
by reaÅ¿on of the fruitfull Å¿oyle which made it florish with all delicacies; as alÅ¿o for the florishing wits of the inhabitants, who were Å¿o famous anciently in point of witt, that the very Romans vÅ¿ed to Å¿end their children firÅ¿t into ToÅ¿cany, to be bred in learning and Religion, and then into greece to learne Greek and PhiloÅ¿ophy.
Haueing enquired the name of this towne, I began to deÅ¿ire its better acquaintance, and attained it eaÅ¿ily in a months Å¿pace which I Å¿pent here: The things I obÅ¿erued moÅ¿t were theÅ¿e.

The Chappel of S. Laurence.1. The Chappel of S. Laurence, which is the neareÅ¿t thing that euer eye beheld. All the inÅ¿ide of it is to be ouercruÅ¿ted with IaÅ¿per Å¿tones, of Å¿eueral colours and countryes, with other rich Å¿tones, all aboue marble, and all Å¿o neatly polished and shining, that the Art here exceeds the materials. a moÅ¿t gallant manner, and of moÅ¿t exquiÅ¿it polished Å¿tones, with a great cushen of Å¿ome richer Å¿tone, and a Ducal crowne of pretious Å¿tones repoÅ¿eing vpon that cushen. Ouer theÅ¿e Tombes the Statues of all the Great â€¢ ukes, at full length, and in their Ducal habits, all of braÅ¿Å¿e guilt, are to be placed in Niches round about the Chappel. The roof is to Vaulted all ouer with an ouercruÅ¿ting of Lapis Lazuli (a blew pretious Å¿tone with vaines of gold in it) which will make it looke like heauen it Å¿elf. Between each tombe are inlayd in the walls, the armes, or Scutchions of the Å¿eueral townes of the Great Dukes dominions, all blazoned according to their Å¿eueral colours in herauldry, by Å¿eueral pretious Å¿tones which compoÅ¿e them: and theÅ¿e are not made in little, but are fair great Scutchions made purpoÅ¿ely of a larg Å¿iÅ¿e for to fill vp the voyd places between the Tombes. The townes are theÅ¿e; Florence, Siena, PiÅ¿a, Liuorno, Volterra, Arezzo, PiÅ¿toia, Cortona, Monte Pulciano &c.
which contributed (I Å¿uppoÅ¿e) Å¿omething each of them to this coÅ¿tly Fabrick in fine, this Chappel is Å¿o rich within with its owne shining bare walls, that it Å¿corns all hangings, painting, guilding, moÅ¿aick work, and Å¿uch like helpers off of bare walls, becauÅ¿e it can find nothing richer and hanÅ¿omer then its owne pretious walls. Its now aboue threeÅ¿core years Å¿ince it was begun, and there are ordinarily threeÅ¿core men at work dayly here, and yet thers onely the Tombe of Ferdinand the Second perfectly finished. The very Cushen which lyeth vpon his Tombe, coÅ¿t threeÅ¿core thouÅ¿and crownes, by which you may geÅ¿Å¿e at the reÅ¿tâ–ª indeed theÅ¿e Å¿tately Tombes make almoÅ¿t death it Å¿elf looke louely, and dead mens ashes grow proud againe. As for the Altar and Tabernacle of this Chappel, I will Å¿peak of them by and by, when I deÅ¿cribe the Gallery of the Great Duke, where they are kept till the Chappel be finished.

2. The Church of S. Laurence,

Anne and our BleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady, in chiaro e oÅ¿curo, by Fra Bartolomeo, commonly called Del Frate, is Å¿o wel a deÅ¿igned peece, that a Duke of Mantua, haueing Å¿een it, offered to buy it at any rate, but was refuÅ¿ed. Bibliotheca Laurentiana, the Catalogue of whoÅ¿e bookes is printed at AmÅ¿terdame an: 1622, in octauo.

The Great Dukes Gallery.3. The Gallery of the old Pallace. This is that Gallery Å¿o famous, and Å¿o frequently ViÅ¿ited by all Strangers. At your entrance into this Gallery,
