B. In mentem Å¿celeris Venit, & F. abÅ¿tinuit.
The four corner letters Å¿ignifying that Michael Angelus Bonarota Fecit. Pictures of famous Souldiers. Among the pictures, I tooke particular notice of theÅ¿e Souldiers, of Hannibal that frighted Rome: of Scipio that tooke Carthage and vanquished Hannibal: of Pyrrhus that made the Romans glad to make peace with him: of Scanderbeg that made the Great Turk afrayd to fight with him: of Venerius that helpt to winn the battle of Lepento: of Alexander FarneÅ¿e that neuer loÅ¿t battle:
of CorteÅ¿ius that found out new countryes: of Magellanus that found out new Seas â–ª of Andrea D'Oria who beat the French by Sea: of GaÅ¿ton de Foix who had beat the Spaniards by land if he had but knowne how to vÅ¿e his Victory: of the Duke of Alua, who onely lamented deying that he had neuer fought a pitchd battle with the Turks: of Anne de Montmorency who dyeing was glad to dye in a pitchd batle againÅ¿t the Hugonots: of Eccelino the Paduan Tyrant, of whom no man can Speak any good: of CaÅ¿trucio of whom no man can Å¿peake any ill; with a world of other braue Heros with whoÅ¿e true lookes I was very glad to be acquainted.Pictures of Learned Men. Among the pictures of the learned men I tooke particular notice of theÅ¿e Italians, to wit, Petrarck, ArioÅ¿to, Ioannes CaÅ¿a, Poggio, Macchiauel, Guiciardin, Paulo Iouio, Sannazario, Bocaccio, Platina, BrunelleÅ¿chi, Michael Angelo, Raphael Vrbin, Columbus, Americus, and Galileo, with many others too long to relate, and too many to be rememberd.
Hauing thus gazed our fill at theÅ¿e Å¿tatues and pictures, and by particular taking notice of-them, complimented the great Worthyes they repreÅ¿ent, we where let into the great Cabinets, or Chambers which joyne vpon this Gallery.

The Armory.FirÅ¿t, we Å¿aw the Armory, that is, three or four great chambers full of exotick curioÅ¿ityes: as, the habits of two Indian Kings made of Parrats Feathers Å¿owed together: the habits of Å¿ome IaniÅ¿Å¿aryes in Turky, of read veluet Å¿et thick with little nayles of gold, which they can take out and dreÅ¿Å¿e vp other Å¿utes with: the habit of the King of China: the skin of a horÅ¿e paÅ¿ted vpon a woodden horÅ¿e, the mane of which horÅ¿e is kept there in a box all at length, and it is aboue fiue elles long: This horÅ¿e had been Å¿ent to the Great Duke by the Duke of Lorraine. Here is a great piÅ¿tol of gold. The piÅ¿tol with eighteen barrels in it, all to be shot off at once and Å¿cattering deÅ¿peratly about a Roomeâ–ª Å¿ix little cannons Å¿et in Å¿tarre wiÅ¿e. The little BraÅ¿Å¿e Cannon which may be taken in peeces preÅ¿ently, and Å¿et together
as Å¿oone, and Å¿o be carryed eaÅ¿ily into any Å¿teeple, or tower: Å¿uch Cannons as theÅ¿e might eaÅ¿ily be carryed in deep countryes, and ouer high mountains, euery Soldier carrying a peece. The Å¿tatue in braÅ¿Å¿e of the King of Spayne, Philip the fourth on horÅ¿eback, iuÅ¿t of the bigneÅ¿Å¿ of that of gold which the Great Duke Å¿ent to the Å¿ayd King of Spayne for a preÅ¿ent; It was made by rare Iohn di Bologna. Then I Å¿aw the armour for horÅ¿e and man of two Kings of PerÅ¿ia. The armour of the Great Duke Ferdinand, a goodly man. The King of Swedes Cornet taken in Germany in a battle. The buckler with the MeduÅ¿as head on it, painted by Michael Angelo. A Turkish Bell to ring in time of battle. A horne vÅ¿ed in Turkey to call men to their Moskyes inÅ¿tead of bells, as we haue. The head of a halbard ringing like a bell. A halbard to fould vp in three, and to carry vnder your cloake priuatly. A Å¿taff of a white cane, in which are curiouÅ¿ly engrauen in black, the
hyÅ¿toryes of the ApocalipÅ¿e. It was the Duke of Vrbins. In fine, the loadÅ¿tone holding vp threeÅ¿core pound weight of iron, and holding one key to an other, for a matter of fiue, or Å¿ix keyes.

After the armory, we were let into the fiue Cabinets full of pretious iewels,The 1. Cabinet. pictures, and other rare curioÅ¿ityes. cabinet, or two, of yuory cupps brought out of Germany by Prince Matthias. In the 2 Cabinet I Å¿aw two great Globes; which were made in this roome, being too great euer to be carryed out, or brought into it by the doore.The 2. Cabinet I Å¿aw alÅ¿o here a curious table of polished Å¿tones repreÅ¿enting a towne in Bohemia, w â€¢ th diuers pictures of men, horÅ¿es, and Landskips: where there is a tree repreÅ¿ented moÅ¿t naturally, becauÅ¿e it is repreÅ¿ented by the very wood of a tree Petrifyed into Å¿tone, and looking like wood as it was; and shinning like polishd Å¿tone, as it now is. The Å¿tatues, or buÅ¿tos of three or four of the Great Dukes, in Porphyry. A curious looking glaÅ¿Å¿e ouer the inÅ¿ide of the doore, which

In the 3 Cabinet I was showne a curious table of polished Å¿tones repreÅ¿enting perfectly the towne and hauen of Ligorne. The 3. Cabinet. A great Cabinet of Ebeny beÅ¿et with pretious Å¿tones on the outÅ¿ide, and with the hiÅ¿tory of the holy Scriptures curiouÅ¿ly expreÅ¿Å¿ed in miniature in Å¿eueral little Å¿quars of rich Å¿tones Å¿et here and there. In the 4. Cabinet, called Jl Tribuno we Å¿aw more riches then in all the others. This Tribuno is a great roome built rouÌ„d with a Cupola, whoÅ¿e vault is painted with a deep Å¿anguin red, Å¿et full with the shells of Mother of pearle.The 4. Cabinet. The walls of this roome are hung with green Å¿ilk, and loaden with excellent pictures of the prime maÅ¿ters of the world, Titian, Raphael, Andrea del Sarto, Vinci,

The great Cabinet of Ebeny Å¿tanding at the further end of this Tribuno, full of ancient meddals of gold Å¿yluer, and braÅ¿Å¿e, of the ancient ConÅ¿uls, and Emperors, all digeÅ¿ted into their Å¿euerall Å¿eries; and yet this Cabinet is almoÅ¿t as rich without, as it contains riches within; being Å¿et without with pretious Å¿tones of a vaÅ¿t biggneÅ¿Å¿ and value; to wit, a Saphir as broad as a twenty shilings peece, and half an niche thick; a ruby full as great, but farre
richer; an emmeraud not inferiour to the reÅ¿t; a pearle as big as an ordinary wallnut; a world of Diamonds and other leÅ¿Å¿er Å¿tones, but all of Å¿o great value, that this Cabinet, with that which is in it, is valued to be worth fiue hundred thouÅ¿and crownes. LaÅ¿tly, I Å¿aw here the great round table made of inlayd pretious Å¿tones, polished neatly; a table able to make the moÅ¿t hungry Å¿tomack forget its gumbing, to feed its eyes vpon the vnroaÅ¿ted birds which together with curious flowers compoÅ¿e this admirable table; Pearles, Rubies, Saphirs, Cornelians, Emmerauds, Lapis Lazuly &c. are employed here artificially to the makeing of theÅ¿e birds & flowers. Youl conceiue better of this table when I shall tell you that it is worth a hundred thouÅ¿and crownes, and that it was fiftheen yeares in makeing, and yet thirty men wrought at it dayly.The 5. Cabinet. In the midÅ¿t of it is the great Balle of the Armes of the Duke of Florence in pretious Å¿tones.

The 5. Cabinet Å¿tanding at the
further end of this Gallery, containeth the Altar and Tabernacle, which are to be Å¿et vp in the new Chappel of S. Laurence deÅ¿cribed aboue. Hauing viewed them Å¿ix Å¿euerall times exactly (as I did) you will perchance be of my opinion, that this Tabernacle made for to keep the BleÅ¿Å¿ed Sacrament in, is able, or nothing is able, to make a mends in Å¿ame Å¿ort, to our Sauiour for his courÅ¿e lodgeing in Bethleem, when he was borne in a Å¿table and lodged in a manger. The cryÅ¿tal pillars curiouÅ¿ly wrought, and being a full elle long, with their Capitelli of pure gold: the four like pictures of pretious Å¿tones which were fiue yeares each of them in cutting: the Variety of other pretious Å¿tones Å¿et thick here and there, and of great Å¿ize: the neat contexture of other polished Å¿tones of Å¿euetall colours and luÅ¿tre: the pictures of inlayd pretious Å¿tones, which compoÅ¿e the Antependium of the Altar: the variety of rich Cameos which are Å¿et here and there, and cut into pictures: in

5. DeÅ¿cending from hence, we where led into the great Hall of this pallace, a vaÅ¿t roome painted on all Å¿ides of the Walls with bold painting, repreÅ¿enting the Victoires of the Florentins anciently. 12. Going from hence we were preÅ¿ently at the Domo. The Domo. This, I beleeue, was the fineÅ¿t Church in Italy when it was built. It was anciently called S. Reparatas Church; but Å¿ince it is called Santa Maria Florida, a fit name for the Cathedral of Florence. would be turned vp Å¿ide downe one day; Å¿o this Architect thought that the world would be turned inÅ¿ide out one day, and that then his Church would bee the faireÅ¿t in the world, and all lined with marble: As it is, it lookes a little hypocritically; though the Å¿tructure within be of a notable contriuance. On the top of it Å¿tands mounted a fair Cupola (or Tholus) made by BrunelleÅ¿chi a Florentin. The Cupola. This was the firÅ¿t Cupola in Europe; and therefore the more admirable for hauing no Idea after which it was framed; and for being the Idea of that of S. Peters in Rome, after which Å¿o many yong Cupolas in Rome, and els where, haue been made Å¿ince. Peters Church, and viewing attentiuely this Cupola of Florence, vÅ¿ed to Å¿ay to it; Como te non voglio: meglio di te non poÅ¿Å¿o. The Å¿traight paÅ¿Å¿age vp to the Ball is neatly contriued, like a round chymney of white marble, with hols on both Å¿ides, and brazen Å¿teeps croÅ¿Å¿e thoÅ¿e holes, to climbe vp eaÅ¿ily, by hand and foote, the paÅ¿Å¿age being clane and Å¿mooth. From the top of this Cupola, takeing a perfect view of Florence vnder vsâ–ª and of the whole country about it, with the Å¿ight of two thouÅ¿and Villas or country houÅ¿es Å¿cattered here and there, round about the towne, we came downe againe to view the inÅ¿ide of this

The Quire is round, and perpendicularly vnder the Cupola, being of the Å¿ame bigneÅ¿Å¿: and vpon Å¿olemne dayes when the wax candles are lighted round about it, it lookes gloriouÅ¿ly: otherwiÅ¿e in wintertime it Å¿eems too dark. Looking vp from the Quire to the Cupola, you Å¿ee it painted on the inÅ¿ide with the repreÅ¿entation of heauen, hell and Purgatory. The painters were Georgio VaÅ¿ari and Thaddeo Zucchari. Behinde the high Altar are the rare Å¿tatues of Adam and Eue, by the hand of Bandinelli. neare the doore of the SacriÅ¿ty, you may read an inÅ¿cription, importing how that in this towne of Florence had been held a General Ceuncell,

The golden Diploma of this vnion written both in Latin and Greek, and Å¿ubÅ¿cribed vnto by the hands of the Pope and Cardinals on the one Å¿ide; and by the Emperour of ConÅ¿tantinople with the Patriarch of ConÅ¿tantinople and the Greek BiÅ¿hops on the other Å¿ide;Leandro Alberti in DeÅ¿cript: Jtal. and authenticated by the leaden Å¿eale of the Pope, and the golden Å¿eale of the Å¿ayd Emperour, is kept in the Archiuiis or RegiÅ¿ters of Bologna. The Councell of Florence. In this Council both the Pope of Rome Eugenius the IV. and Paleologus the Emperour of ConÅ¿tantinople, were preÅ¿ent, with the creame of Bishops, both of the EaÅ¿terne, and Westerne Churches; and in this Councell not onely the ProceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Holy GhoÅ¿t from the Father and the Sonn was vindicated; but alÅ¿o Purgatory was proued to the Greeks out of their owne Greek Fathers, as well as out of the Latin Fathers; and diuers other points of coremony and practiÅ¿e were aÅ¿Å¿erted and made good. and Patriarch, and the other Greek Bishops (except reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿ Marcus EpheÅ¿inus) Å¿ubÅ¿cribed; as did alÅ¿o the Armenians, Ethiopians, Georgians, and Iacobites, who all hereupon were admitted to Communion by the Roman Church. I cannot omit here to take notice of a little round pillar in the Piazza, neare this Baptistery, with the figure of a tree in iron nayled to it, and old words engrauen vpon it importing, that in this very place Å¿tood anciently an Elmetree, which being touched caÅ¿ualy by the hearÅ¿e of S. Lady with our Sauiour vpon her knee, and S. IoÅ¿eph in a cumbent poÅ¿ture leaning upon a Å¿ack full Å¿tufft, and reading in a booke. The picture of the BleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgin is admirable for Å¿weetneÅ¿Å¿ and majeÅ¿ty. This picture is called La Madonna del Sacco,
it got Andrea Å¿uch credit, that Titian himÅ¿elf preferred it before all the peeces he had euer Å¿een, and vÅ¿ed often to Å¿ay: that it grieued him, that he could not often Å¿atiate his Å¿ight with the beholding of Å¿o rare a picture: and Michel Angelo talking once in Rome with Raphael Vrbin concerning painters, Å¿ayd thus to him: There is vn huom â€¢ e â€¢ tto, a little fellow in Florence (meaning this Andrea) who had he been employed in great matters as thou art, would make thee Å¿weat againe. VirtuoÅ¿i make a great diÅ¿pute which of thoÅ¿e three painters was the moÅ¿t excellent: Raphael Vrbin, Michel Angelo, or Andrea del Sarto. But the wiÅ¿eÅ¿t giue euery one his particular praiÅ¿e or excellency: Raphael was excellent in colori: Michel Angelo in deÅ¿igne: and Andrea in makeing things Å¿eeme to be of rilieuo, and looke as God made them, that is, pulpy and riÅ¿eing vp like liuing flesh. Haueing thus admired the worke of Andrea we entred into the Church of the Annunciata, and there Å¿aw the curious Å¿yluer Altar, behind
vpon the wall, is kept the miraculous picture of the Annunciation which giues the name of Annunciata to this Church. The little picture of our Sauiour, about a foot and a half long, which is Å¿een vpon the outÅ¿ide of the Tabernacle, is of the foreÅ¿ayd Andreas hand, & much eÅ¿teemed. In this Church lyeth buryed Baccio Bandinelli a famous Sculptor, in a curious marble tombe, with his owne, and his wifes picture, engrauen in marble by his owne hand. Behinde the Quire lyes buryed Ioannes di Bologna, a famous Sculptor alÅ¿o, as his Å¿eueral works in Florence shew him to haue been; as the Rapt of the Sabins, Before the old pallace. The Centaure in the Å¿treets. The Chappel of S. Antoninus in S. Markes Church. This Chappel in the Annunciata here; and the golden horÅ¿e and man Å¿poken of aboue in the Dukes Armory, do wittneÅ¿Å¿.

18. From hence hauing firÅ¿t Å¿een the Statue of the Great Duke Ferdinand on horÅ¿eback in braÅ¿Å¿e, which Å¿tands in the piazza before the

If you aske me whether of the two, Painting, or Sculpture, is to be preferred, though a blind man being choÅ¿en iudge once of this queÅ¿tion,
when he was giuen to vnderÅ¿tand that in the Å¿mooth painting there were head, armes, leggs, hands and feet, as well as in the bulky Å¿tatue which he had felt, iudged preÅ¿ently for painting; yet Michel Angelo himÅ¿elf preferred Sculpture before painting, as the body is to be preferred before the Å¿uperficies of a body. But to returne againe to the Tombe of this great artiÅ¿t, I found Å¿ome words vpon the tombeÅ¿tone, but thoÅ¿e Å¿o dull and hard to be read in that darke corner, that one in the company choÅ¿e rather to make him a new Epitaphe, then read that which is written there: and it was this:
Cur indignemur mortales morte perire?
Ecce, Å¿tupor mundi! hÃ®c Angelus ipÅ¿o perit.

19.The Abbey. Not farre from hence Å¿tands the Abbadia, an Abbey of Benedictin Monks. The occaÅ¿ion of building this MonaÅ¿tery and many others by this Hugo, is too long to tell, and perchance would not finde beleef euery where. Its told publickly euery yeare vpon S. Thomas his day in high MaÅ¿Å¿e time here, by Å¿ome one or other of the chief witts of the Academy of the CruÅ¿ca; and he thats

22. Hauing thus viÅ¿ited the chief things in the towne, I viÅ¿ited Å¿ome places out of the towne; and chiefly, the Poggio Jmperiale, Poggio Imperialle. a Villa belonging to the Great DutcheÅ¿Å¿e, and about a good mile diÅ¿tant from the towne. In other roomes we Å¿aw a world of rare pictures, as the Venus of Titian, though I think it be but a coppy: the admirable S. Hierome of Alberto Dureo: a Magdalen of Raphaels hand: a S. Iohn BaptiÅ¿t of Carauagios hand: an Adam and Eue of Alberto Dureo: the Piety of Pietro Perugino, that is, the picture of our BleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady with our Sauiour dead vpon her knee; S. Iohn Euangelist and
three other perÅ¿ons Å¿tanding, or kneeling by, with weeping faces and moÅ¿t Å¿ad lookes; its one of the moÅ¿t moueing peeces that I euer beheld. Prato-Lino.23. An other day we went to Pratolino a Villa of the Great Duke, Å¿ome Å¿ix milles diÅ¿tant from Florence. 24. I went alÅ¿o to Lampeggio a

25.The Å¿table â€¢ . Returning to the towne againe, we Å¿awe the Great Dukes Å¿tables full of excellent well maneged horÅ¿es.

26.The Wild beaÅ¿ts. Neare to the Å¿tables Å¿tands the Å¿erraglio where the wild beaÅ¿ts are kept, which they make fight often againÅ¿t one another. Here I Å¿aw Lyons, Leopards, Tygers, Beares, Woolfs, wild boares and foxes, all which they can let out Å¿eueraly at the dores of their Å¿eueral denns, into a fair court to fight, and when they haue done, they can bring them back againe into their denns by a fearfull machine of wood made like a great Green Dragon, which Ã man within it rowles vpon weeles; and holding out two lighted torches at the eyes of it, frights the fierceÅ¿t
beaÅ¿t thereby into his denn. The Prince and the Court in the mean time, Å¿tanding high aboue may Å¿ee the combats of theÅ¿e wild beaÅ¿ts with eaÅ¿e,In the Cronology of Petrus Romualdus to 1. pag. 15. and without danger. I haue read, that a Lyon here one eÅ¿capeing out of this place by chance, and running vp and downe the Å¿treets, met at laÅ¿t (all others flying into houÅ¿es) a little child, who had neither feare nor wit enough to retire; and Å¿eazed vpon him. 27. I Å¿awe alÅ¿o here diuers Pallaces of noblemen vpon occaÅ¿ion of their FeÅ¿tine. For it is the cuÅ¿tome here in winter, to inuite the chief Ladyes of the towne (marryed women onely) to come to play at cards in winter euenings for three or four hours Å¿pace; and this one
night in one pallace, another night in another pallace. Thither the Ladyes go, and finde the houÅ¿e open to all comers and goers both Ladyes and gentlemen, that are of any garbe. In euery chamber the dores are Å¿et open, and for the moÅ¿t part you shall Å¿ee eight, or ten chambers on a floore, going out of one an other, with a Å¿quar table holding eight perÅ¿ons, as many chairs, two Å¿yluer candleÅ¿ticks with waxe lights in them, and Å¿tore of lights round about the roome. At the houre appointed, company being comne, they Å¿it downe to play, a Caualier Å¿itting between euery Lady, and all the women As fine in clothes and iewels, as if they were going to a Ball. The dores of all theÅ¿e roomes being open, the light great, the women glittering, and all glorious, you would take theÅ¿e pallaces to be the enchanted Pallaces of the Old King of the Montains. Any gentleman may come into theÅ¿e pallaces and Å¿tand behinde the gameÅ¿ters, and Å¿ee both how modeÅ¿tly they play, and how
little they play for. In the mean time thers a Å¿ide chamber alwayes open for gentlemen to go in to, and refresh themÅ¿elues with wine Å¿tanding in Å¿now, or with limonade, or Å¿ome Å¿uch cooling drinks, which are alÅ¿o offered to the Ladyes. In a great roome bellow, at the entrance of the pallace, there is a long table for gameÅ¿ters that loue to play deep, that is, that loue to play onely for money.

Their Sports.The Florentins enioying by the goodneÅ¿Å¿ and wiÅ¿dome of their excellent Princ, the fruits of peace, haue many other recreations, where the people paÅ¿Å¿e their time chearfully and think not of rebellion by muttering in corners. For this reaÅ¿on, both in winter, and Å¿ommer, they haue their Å¿eueral diuertiÅ¿ments. In winter their Giuoco di Calcio (a play Å¿omething like our football,Jl Giuoco di Calcio. but that they play with their handsâ–ª) euery night from the Epiphany till Lent, with their Principi di Calcio. This being a thing particular to Florence, deÅ¿erues to be deÅ¿cribed. The two
factions of the Calcio, the Red, and the Green, chooÅ¿e ecih of them a Prince, Å¿ome yong Caualier of a good purÅ¿e. TheÅ¿e Princes being choÅ¿en, chooÅ¿e a world of Officers, and lodge, for the time, in Å¿ome great pallace; where they keep their courts, receiue EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors from one another, and giue them publik audience in Å¿tate, Å¿end poÅ¿te to one another, complaine of one anothers Å¿ubiects, & take priÅ¿oners from one another; heare their counÅ¿ellers one after another, diÅ¿Å¿wadeing from, or perÅ¿wadeing to warre; giue orders for Å¿etling their affairs at home, heare the complaints of their Å¿ubiects, ieere their enemy Princes in embaÅ¿Å¿yes; and at laÅ¿t reÅ¿olue to, fight, with proclayming warre. Dureing theÅ¿e Å¿erious treatyes which laÅ¿t for many nights the Secretaryes of Å¿tate (two prime witts) read before their Å¿eueral Princes bills for regulating and reforming the abuÅ¿es of their Å¿ubiects; and read openly petitions and Å¿ecret aduiÅ¿es: in all which they ieere a world of people in the
towne, and show prodigious wit. In fine, hauing Å¿punn out thus the time till neare Carnauale, or shroftide, the two Princes reÅ¿olue on a battle at Calcio, to be fought in the Piazza of Santa Croce, before the Great Duke and Court. Vpon the day apointed, the two Princes of the Calcio come to the place in a moÅ¿t Å¿tately Caualcata with all the yong noblemen and gentlemen of the towne, vpon the beÅ¿t horÅ¿es they can finde, with Å¿carfs, red, or green, about their Armes. Haueing made their Å¿eueral Caualcatas before the Great Dukes throne or Å¿caffold, they light from their horÅ¿es, and enter into the liÅ¿ts with trompets Å¿ounding before them, and accompanyed with a Å¿tately train, and with their combatants in their Å¿eueral liueryes. Hauing rancked themÅ¿elues a prety diÅ¿tance one from the other, their Å¿tandard bearers at Å¿ound of trumpet, carry both at once, their Å¿tandards to the foot of the Great Dukes Å¿caffold. This done, the Ball, or Ballon is throwne vp in the midÅ¿t between
them, and to it they go with great nimbleneÅ¿Å¿, Å¿leight, and diÅ¿cretion; and Å¿ometimes they fall to it in deed and cuff handÅ¿omely: but vpon payne of death, no man muÅ¿t reÅ¿ent afterwards out of the liÅ¿ts, what euer happened here; but all animoÅ¿ities arriÅ¿eing here, end here too. At laÅ¿t, that Å¿ide which throwes, or Å¿trikes the Ballon ouer the rayles of the other Å¿ide, winns the day, and runns to the standards, which they carry away till night, at what time the conquering Prince enterteins them at a FeÅ¿tino di Ballo at Court, made to Å¿ome Lady; and where all his chief Officers and combatants dance alone with the Ladyes at the Ball, none els being permitted to dance with them that night. BeÅ¿ides theÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿times,Other PaÅ¿times. they haue once a week, danceing at the Court from twelfth day till Lent, at which Balls, all the Ladies of the towne are inuited, to the number Å¿ometimes of two hundred, and theÅ¿e all marryed women, and all inuited by a particular ticket. Then
their Å¿eueral Operas, or muÅ¿ical Drammata acted and Å¿ung with rare coÅ¿t and arte. LaÅ¿tly their publick running at the ring, or at the facchin, for a peece of plate. And in Å¿ommer, they haue their Å¿eueral danceing dayes, and their frequent CorÅ¿i di Palio vpon certain knowne days & for knowne prizes, and all before the good Prince, who countenanceth all theÅ¿e Å¿ports with his preÅ¿ence, thinking wiÅ¿ely, that thers leÅ¿Å¿e hurt in puplick mirth, then in priuate mutinyes:
The Court.Hauing Å¿ayd thus much of Florence, I will now Å¿ay Å¿omething of the Court, the Gouerment, strength, Gentry, Riches, IntereÅ¿t, Language, and Learned men of this towne.

For the Court its clearly one of the beÅ¿t of Italy. Great riches make it looke plump, and giue it an excellent en bon point. The noble Pallace the Prince, his Title of SereniÅ¿Å¿imo, his Train and Retinew of noble Officers and gentlemen, his Å¿tore of Pages, Palfreniers, Gards of SwiÅ¿Å¿ers with halbards,
his Troupe of horÅ¿e wayting vpon him, make this Court appeare Å¿plendid. The Duke himÅ¿elf alÅ¿o who makes this Court, The Great Duke. makes it a fine Court. His extraordinary Ciuility to Å¿tangers, made vs think our Å¿elues at home there. He is now aboue fifty, and hath a AuÅ¿trian looke and lip, which his mother Magdalena of AuÅ¿tria SiÅ¿ter to the Emperour Ferdinand the II. lent him. He admits willingly of the viÅ¿its of Å¿trangers, if they be men of condition; and he receiues them in the midÅ¿t of his audience chamber Å¿tanding; and will not diÅ¿courÅ¿e with them, till they be couered too. Its impoÅ¿Å¿ible to depart from him diÅ¿guÅ¿ted, becauÅ¿e he pays your viÅ¿it with as much wit as ciuility: and hauing enterteined you in his chamber with wiÅ¿e diÅ¿courÅ¿e, he will entertein you in your owne chamber too with a regalo of dainty meats, and wines, which he will be Å¿ure to Å¿end you. The Great DutcheÅ¿Å¿e too is an other main pillar of this Court.The Great DutcheÅ¿Å¿e She is of the houÅ¿e of the
Duke of Vrbin, once a Souerain Prince in Italy, but now extinct in her Father who was the laÅ¿t Duke: and she had been Å¿ouerain of that Dutchy, had she been of the Souerain Å¿exe: but what nature refuÅ¿ed her in Å¿exe, it hath giuen her in beauty, and Å¿o made her a greater Å¿ouerain, euen of Florence. In a word, Florence the Faire, was neuer Å¿o faire, as was the faire DutcheÅ¿Å¿e of Florence when I Å¿aw her firÅ¿t. Of her the Great Duke hath two Å¿onnes. CoÅ¿mus the Prince of ToÅ¿cane hath married one of the Daughters of the late Duke of Orlians. Hee is a great Traueller and hath viÅ¿ited moÅ¿t of the Princes courts of ChriÅ¿tendome. The name of this family is Medices; a family which h â€¢ ah giuen to the Church four Popes, and to France two Queens. This family is ancient, and came firÅ¿t out of Athens. It was alwayes conÅ¿iderable dureing the Republick of Florence, The Medicean Family. but farr more Å¿ince it hath got the Å¿tart of all the other families to farre, as to become their Souerain. The beginning of
the greatneÅ¿Å¿ of this family came from CoÅ¿mus Medices Å¿urnamed Pater Patriae. See AlfonÅ¿o LoÅ¿chi in his compendi. HiÅ¿tor. This man being very rich and of a liberal mind, Å¿pent four hundred thouÅ¿and crownes in publick and priuate buildings, and one hundred thouÅ¿and crownes more in loane monyes to the poore citizens. TheÅ¿e generous actions which should haue got him the loue of all men, purchaÅ¿ed him the hatred of Å¿ome of the great ones, who accuÅ¿eing him of affecting Souerainty, rayÅ¿ed a Å¿trong faction againÅ¿t him. The heads of this faction where Rinaldo Albizzi, Pala Strozzi, Ridolfo Peruzzi, and Nicolo Barbadori. TheÅ¿e men corrupting the Å¿uffrages of the Senate, cauÅ¿ed CoÅ¿mus to be clapt vp, with an intention to take away his life. CoÅ¿mus in priÅ¿on, fearing poyÅ¿on, abÅ¿tained from meats four dayes together, and dyed almoÅ¿t for feare of being killed: At laÅ¿t hee was reÅ¿cued from this melancholy humor by his honeÅ¿t keeper; who gaue him Å¿uch aÅ¿Å¿urances, that he should not be poyÅ¿oned, that he tooke meat
againe, and kept in his vital breath which was almoÅ¿t come to his lips. Then his keeper (not content to be half courterous) haueing recouered his body, Å¿troue to recouer his mind too, which was Å¿ore Å¿pent with feares and melancholy; and for this purpoÅ¿e, brought vnto him the buffon of Bernardo Guadagni then Confaloniero, The chief MagiÅ¿trate of the Republick, who with his witty ieaÅ¿ts, Å¿o cheared him vp with mirth, that he began not onely to think of liuing againe, but alÅ¿o of getting out from thence, that he might liue long. To this end he works with the buffon to carry a promiÅ¿e in writeing from him to the Confaloniero, of 1000 crownes of gold, vpon condition he would free him. The buffon vndertakes it, and money takes with the Confaloniero, who vnder pretence of examining the cauÅ¿e to put him to death, finds him onely worthy of baÌ„nishment; to which he condemns him; and the place of his banishment was Venice. This was it that he deÅ¿ired. For being at Venice, he wrought
Å¿o well by Freinds with the people, that loued him, that he was reÅ¿tored againe to his country, and got the title of Pater Patriae by a publick decree. By this title his family grew into that eÅ¿teem, that it ouertopt the reÅ¿t, and in time wrought it Å¿elf into Souerainty.

For the Gouerment of Florence, it is now Monarchical, and deÅ¿potical, The Gouerment. the Great Dukes will being abÅ¿olute; all great buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es paÅ¿Å¿ing through his knowledge and likeing: Å¿o that he wants nothing of a King, but the name; and that too he almoÅ¿t hath vnder the name of Great Duke.

As for the Strength of this State;The Å¿trength. it hath 20 EpiÅ¿copal cittyes; 500 litle walled townes; Å¿trong Forts on the confines: and can make an army of forty thouÅ¿and foot, three thouÅ¿and horÅ¿e, twelue Gallies, two GalleaÅ¿Å¿es, two Galleonies, and twenty ships of warre.

For the Gentry, it is a Gentry dyed in graine, that is, its both witty, and rich. The Å¿ubtil ayre of this country, and the Academy
of the CruÅ¿ca haue sharpened them into much wit: and their good husbandry,The Gentry of Florence. and vnder-hand traffick hath put them notably into purÅ¿e. For they think it no diÅ¿grace to haue a banco at home, and meet dayly at the exchange about traffick and trayding; while their wifes Lady it in coach with their hanÅ¿ome liueries. This makes them hold vp their nobility by the chinn, and not onely preÅ¿erues their familyes from Å¿inking; but rather makes them Å¿wime in a full Å¿ea of honour: they being enabled thereby to buy great offices for their children in other courts, whereby they often make them mount to the higheÅ¿t dignityes: when they are there, no man reproches vnto them the way they tooke to come thither, whether by water, or Land; by traffick, or by the Å¿word; by the Å¿choole-booke, or count-booke. If the French gentry would follow this way, they might haue shoos and Å¿tockings for their children (which Å¿ome of them want in the country) where with to keep their noble
blood warme in winter.

For the Riches of this Prince,Riches. they are about a million and a half of PiaÅ¿tri, or crownes. TheÅ¿e are his annual reuenews; beÅ¿ides his iewels; forfeitures; and his Datij: which laÅ¿t, are of vaÅ¿t profit to him.

The IntereÅ¿t of this Prince is much AuÅ¿trian, IntereÅ¿t. and conÅ¿equently Spanish: yet not Å¿o farre, as to break with France, to which he opens his ports and paÅ¿Å¿ages for his owne Å¿ake. He loues to haue no warre in Jtaly, becauÅ¿e he hath Å¿omething to looÅ¿e: and though he loue to haue the Pope his freind, yet he cares not for hauing any of his Å¿ubiects Pope. A Pope of his family, Clement the VII, hauing made him what he is, he is affrayd a Pope of Å¿ome other Florentin family would Å¿triue to make him what he was.

As for the Language of Florence its pure, but in their books,The Language not in their mouths: They do Å¿o choke it in the throat, that its almoÅ¿t quite drownd there; nor doth it recouer
it Å¿elf againe till it come to Rome, where Lingua ToÅ¿cana in bocca Romana is a moÅ¿t Å¿weet language. The Academy of the CruÅ¿ca hath much contributed to the enriching of this language with choice words.The Academy of Wits. The rich Dictionary made by this famous company, and called from them, the CruÅ¿ca, was forty yeares in compileing, but it will be in vogue as long as men shall Å¿peak Italian.

The learned men.Finally, for the Learned men of of this towne in later times, they are theÅ¿e; MarÅ¿ilius Ficinus the ChriÅ¿tian Platonick; Dante and Petrarck in PoÃ«try: Guicciardin in HiÅ¿tory: Poggio in raillery: VeÅ¿p â€¢
cius in Geography: AccurÅ¿ius in law: Michel Angelo in painting: Ioannes CaÅ¿a in practical morality: Naclantus in diuinity: Galilaeo in AÅ¿tronomy: Doni, Luigi, Alemanni, and others in belle lettere.
He that deÅ¿ires to know the HiÅ¿tory of Florence, The HiÅ¿torians. let him read Giouanne Villani, Matthaeo Villani, Scipione Ammirato, and the life of Gran CoÅ¿imo.

Hauing thus Å¿een faire Florence, we deÅ¿ired to Å¿ee Ligorne, and make an excurÅ¿iue iourney by PiÅ¿toia, PiÅ¿toia. Lucca, and PiÅ¿a. PiÅ¿toia is an ancient towne in a plain country. Of this towne is Clement the IX, this preÅ¿ent Pope, of the ancient Family of RoÅ¿piglioÅ¿i: aÌ„d that is all I can Å¿ay of it. For it looks baldly of it, either out of pure old age, els by reaÅ¿on of our neighbourhood to Florence, which hath fleeced it, or which I rather think, by reaÅ¿on of its ciuil factions heretofore, which almoÅ¿t ruined it quite.

Lucca is a prety little Commonwealth, Lucca. and yet it Å¿leeps quietly within the boÅ¿ome of the Great Dukes State. But that State may wiÅ¿ely feare none, which no State feares; and the great Duke is vnwilling to meaÅ¿ure his Å¿word, or take vp the cudgels againÅ¿t little Lucca, leaÅ¿t the world should cry shame vpon him, and bid him meddle with his match. This little Republick looked in my eye,Its Gouerment. like a perfect mapp of old Rome â–ª in its begining.
Its Gouerned by a Confaloniero and the gentry. The great CounÅ¿el conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of 160 citizens who are changed euery yeare. Its vnder tho Emperors protection; and it hath about thirty thouÅ¿and Å¿ouls in it. Approching vnto it, it looked like a pure low-country towne, with its brick walls, large ramparts Å¿et round with trees, and deep moates round about the walls. It hath eleuen baÅ¿tions, Its Å¿trength. well garded by the townesmen, and well furnished with CannoÌ„s of a large Å¿iÅ¿e. The towne is three miles in compaÅ¿Å¿e; it hath thirty thouÅ¿and muskets, or half muskets in its ArÅ¿enal, eight thouÅ¿and pikes, two thouÅ¿and breÅ¿t peeces of musket proof, and Å¿tore of great artillery. The whole State, for a need, can arme eighteen thouÅ¿and men of Å¿eruice,Its Reuenews. and it hath about fiue hundred thouÅ¿and French liures a yeare. It was in this towne that CaeÅ¿ar, Pompey, and CraÅ¿Å¿us met, and agreed among themÅ¿elues that all things in Rome should paÅ¿Å¿e as they pleaÅ¿ed.

The chief things to be Å¿een here
are, The Cathedral, called S. Martins, whoÅ¿e Bishop hath the enÅ¿ignes of an Archbishop, to wit, the vÅ¿e of the Pallium, and the CroÅ¿Å¿e; and whoÅ¿e Canons in the Quire weare a rochet and Camail, and miters of Å¿ilk like Bishops.
2. The towne houÅ¿e, or Senate houÅ¿e, where the Confaloniero liues dureing the time of his charge.
2. The Church of S. Frediano belonging to the Canon Regulars, where, in a Chappel on the left hand, is the Tombe of S. Richard King of England, who dyed here in his pilgrimage to Rome.
4. The Augustins Church, where is Å¿een a hole where the Earth opened to Å¿wallow vp a blaÅ¿pheming gameÅ¿ter.
Of this towne was Pope Lucius the III. the two famous men of this towne, the one for Å¿oldiery, the other for learning, were, braue CaÅ¿trucio, and Sanctes Pagninus a great Hebrician.

There are fiue townes more belonging to Lucca, to wit, Ca-magior,
Viareggia, MontignoÅ¿o, CaÅ¿tilione, and Minucciano.

PiÅ¿a.From Lucca we went to PiÅ¿a, Å¿ome ten miles off. This was once the head towne of a florishing Republick, and then the Numantia of Florence, and Å¿corning its yoke: but now it croucheth to it. It Å¿tands in no very good ayre, and therfore hath been vexed with diuers plagues. The graÅ¿Å¿e in the Å¿treets of this VniuerÅ¿ity, read me this lecture, and I beleeued it. Wherupon I reÅ¿olued to Å¿tay here one day onely, in which time I Å¿aw.

1. The Domo, The Domo. whoÅ¿e Canons officiate in Scarlate like Cardinals. This is a neat Church for Å¿tructure, and for its three brazen dores hiÅ¿toryed with a fine baÅ¿Å¿o rilieuo. Its built after la maniera TedeÅ¿cha, a fashion of building much vÅ¿ed in Italy four or fiue hundred yeares ago, and brought in by Germans or TedeÅ¿chi, Å¿ayth VaÅ¿ari.

The bending Tower.2. Neare to the Domo Å¿tands, (if leaning may be called Å¿tanding) the bending Tower, Å¿o artificialy made, that it Å¿eems to be falling,
and yet it Å¿tands firme: Ruituraque Å¿emper, Å¿tat (mirum) moles.

3. On the other Å¿ide of the Domo, is the Campo Santo a great Å¿quare place cloiÅ¿tered about with a low cloiÅ¿ter curiouÅ¿ly painted. It â€¢ called the Campo Santo, becauÅ¿e therein is conÅ¿erued the Holy earth brought from HieruÅ¿alem in 50 Gallies of this Republick, an. 1224. TheÅ¿e Gallies were Å¿ent by the Republick of PiÅ¿a, to Å¿uccour the Emperour Aenobarbe, in the Holy Land â–ª but hearing of his death when they came thither, they returned home againe loaden with the earth of the Holy Land, of which they made this Campo Santo.

4. Some good Colledges there are but vnfrequented then by reaÅ¿on of a late plague:Some Colledges. none running faÅ¿ter from the plague then Å¿chollers, eÅ¿pecialy when it comes neare to the Å¿chools.
5.The Library. The publick Library is much enriched with the acceÅ¿Å¿ion of Aldus Manutius his Library.

6.The PhyÅ¿ick garden. The garden of Simples may be rare, but wee not vnderÅ¿tanding this
hearbe language: haÅ¿tened to the houÅ¿e of the Knights of S. Steuen.

The Knights of S. Stephano.7. This is the onely Order of Knighthood that I perceiued in Florence; and its very common. They weare a red croÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿atin vpon their cloaks; and profeÅ¿Å¿e to fight againÅ¿t the Turks. For this purpoÅ¿e they haue here a good houÅ¿e, and maintenance. Their Church is beautifyed without with a hanÅ¿ome faciata of white marble; and within with Turkish EnÅ¿ignes and diuers Lanterns of capitaneÅ¿Å¿e gallies. In this houÅ¿e the Knights liue in common, and are well maintained. In Their TreaÅ¿ory they shew you a great buckler all of Pearle and Diamonds, wonn in a battle againÅ¿t the Turks. Indeed bucklers of Diamonds, do but show our enemyes where we are, and what they may hope for by killing vs. They haue in their Cancellaria, a Catalogue of thoÅ¿e Knights who haue done notable Å¿eruice againÅ¿t the Turks; which Å¿erues for a powerfull exhortation to their Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ors, to do, and dy brauely. In fine, theÅ¿e Knights may
marry if they will, and liue in their owne particular houÅ¿es, but many of them chooÅ¿e celibate, as more conuenient for braue Å¿oldiers: wifes and children being the true impedimenta exercitÃ»s.

Heretofore, during the great diÅ¿orders of the Guelfs and the Gibelins, Anno 1282, this towne was gouerned by Vgolin a proud man, who ruled here deÅ¿potically. This man inuiteing one day all his friends to a great feaÅ¿t, began in the midÅ¿t of it to brag, that nothing was wanting to him: yes (Å¿ayd on of his beÅ¿t friends, becauÅ¿e on who flattered him not) thers one thing yet wanting to thee, Vgolin, to-wit, the Anger of God, which is not farre from thee. And it proued true, for preÅ¿ently after, the Gibelins ruÅ¿shing into the pallace of Vgolin (chief of the Guelfs) killed in his Å¿ight one of his Å¿onns and his nephew, and taking him with two other of his Å¿onns and three nephews they shut him vp in a Å¿trong Tower, and threw the Keys into Arno: where the poore man that braged
euen now in a feaÅ¿t, dyed Å¿oon after of hunger; hauing firÅ¿t Å¿een his children and nephews dye of hunger in his armes. A rare example to teach proud men, that thers often but one day between a powerfull man, and a poore man: between a great FeaÅ¿t, and a great FaÅ¿t. Here in PiÅ¿a were called two Councils, the one 1409. the other 1511.

Ligorne.From PiÅ¿a we went to Ligorne, (Portus Liburnus in Latin) through a pleaÅ¿ant forreÅ¿t. This is the onely hauen the Great Duke hath; and the mouth which letteth in that food which fatteneth this State. We Å¿tayd not long here, the Å¿eaÅ¿on preÅ¿sing vs to be gone, and this towne, being Å¿oone Å¿een. For the towne its but little, yet one of the neateÅ¿t hauen townes a man can Å¿ee. Heretofore it was not Å¿ufferable by reaÅ¿on of the bad ayre; but Å¿ince Ferdinan the firÅ¿t built it a new, and dryed vp the neighboring Fenns (gathering much of the water into a cut channel, which goes from hence to PiÅ¿a, and carryes great boats) the towne is twice as wholeÅ¿ome,
and thrice as rich as it was.

The things I Å¿aw in this towne were theÅ¿e. 1. The Mole which shutts vp the hauen. 2. The Lanterne which with Å¿eauen lights guides in ships in the night, 3. The Hauen it Å¿elf where ships lye Å¿afe, and the little hauen within that, which Å¿erues for a withdrawing roome to the great hauen, where the Gallyes retire themÅ¿elues. 4. The Å¿tatue of Ferdinand the firÅ¿t in marble, with the Statues in bronze of four Å¿laues at his feet. TheÅ¿e are the 4 Å¿laues that would haue Å¿tolne away a galley and haue rowed here themÅ¿elues alone; but where taken in their great enterprize. 5. The Greek Church. 6. The CaÅ¿tle. 7. The Tower in the Sea where they keepe gunpowder. 8. The Iews Synagogue. 9. Two windmills which are rare things in Italy, and therefore muÅ¿t haue a place here among the rarityes of this towne.

I found not any Academy of wits here, nor any records of any learned men of this towne. All the Latin here is onely, Meum, and Tuum,
and their wits are exerciÅ¿ed here, how to make good bargins, not good Bookes. Indeed what should the MuÅ¿es do here amongÅ¿t the horrible noyÅ¿e of chaines, of carts, of balling Sea men, of clamorous porters, and where the Å¿laues of Barbary are able to fright all learning out of the towne with their lookes, as all Latin with their Language. Yet I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e, they Å¿tudy here belle Lettere: for if the true belle Lettere bee Letters of exchange, your marchand here, if you preÅ¿ent him a Letter of exchange from his correÅ¿pondent, will read it ouer, and ouer againe, and Å¿tudy vpon it, before he giue you the contents of it in money.

Hauing finished this excurÅ¿iue journey, we returned againe to Florence; and hauing reÅ¿ted our horÅ¿es a day or two, we tooke a new riÅ¿e from thence to Rome which Å¿eemed to becken en vs, and whither the main torrent of our curioÅ¿ity hurryed vs.

Some three miles Beyond Florence we paÅ¿Å¿ed vnder a MonaÅ¿tery of
CarthuÅ¿ians Å¿eated vpon a round hill; whoÅ¿e Å¿eueral celles and little gardens (walled about) branching out on all Å¿ides, like Å¿euerall BaÅ¿tions, made this MonaÅ¿tery looke like a Å¿piritual Fort, or deuout Cittadel.

From hence paÅ¿Å¿ing through Å¿an: San: CaÅ¿siano. CaÅ¿Å¿iano we arriued at night at Poggi-Bonzi a little towne famous for perfumed Tobacco in powder,Poggi Bonzi. which the Italians and Spaniards take farre more frequently then we, as needing neither candle nor tinderboxe to light it withall; nor vÅ¿eing any other pipes, then their owne noÅ¿es.

From Poggi-Bonzi we came at dinner to Siena. Siena. This is the Å¿econd towne of the Florentin State. It was heretofore a powerfull Republick commanding threeÅ¿core miles into the country, and now and then, beating the Florentins: but a laÅ¿t, after much Å¿trugling, this woolf receiued the muzzle,The armes of Siena, are a Woolf. and Siena is now the humble Å¿eruant of Florence. This happened an â€¢ 1555.

This towne is Å¿eated in a very
wholeÅ¿ome ayre and Å¿oyle, and therefore much frequented by Å¿trangers. Its called Senae in Latin from the Senones, people of Gaule, who comeing into Italy with Brennus, built this towne. The Å¿treets are all paued with bricks Å¿et vp edgeway, which makes the towne alwayes dry and neat. Its built high and low, with many high towers in it, built anciently in honour of its well deÅ¿eruing citizens who had done Å¿ome Å¿pecial Å¿eruice in the Republick; and this makes it Å¿een thirty miles off on Romes Å¿ide. The people here are very ciuil, and euen Å¿ociable too; which together with the good ayre, the good exerciÅ¿es for gentlemen, the good language, and the great priuiledges, make many Å¿trangers draw bridle here, and Å¿ommer it at Siena, the Orleans of Italy.
The prime things I Å¿aw here were theÅ¿e.

The Domo.1. The Domo, one of the neateÅ¿t Cathedrals of Italy, though it be built a la maniera TedeÅ¿cha. Its all of black and white marble within
and without. The FontiÅ¿pice is carued curiouÅ¿ly and Å¿et thick with Å¿tatues. Yet it wants a larger piazza before it, to giue it its full grace. The inÅ¿ide of this Church is very takeing. Vnder the roof immediatly runns a row of white marble-heads of all the Popes till this time. The Pauement is the beÅ¿t in the world;The rare Pauement. and indeed too good to be trode on; hence they couer a great part of it with bords hanÅ¿omely layd together, yet eaÅ¿y to be taken vp, to show Å¿trangers the beauty of it: Its of marble inlayd into pictures, and thoÅ¿e very great ones: Å¿eueral great marbles of Å¿eueral colours makeing the shadows and the lights, and compoÅ¿eing all together Å¿uch a new kind of MoÅ¿aick worke, as all men admire, but none dare finish. This worke was begun by Duccio SaneÅ¿e, and afterwards carryed on by Domenico Beccafumi, but not finished by him, Å¿ayth VaÅ¿ari. They told me here that is was Meccharini, that made this pauement; but I had
rather beleeue VaÅ¿ari. That part which they vncouered for vs, repreÅ¿ented the hiÅ¿tory of Abraham going to Å¿acrifice his Å¿onn IÅ¿aac; and the hiÅ¿tory of the Machabees; and the like. I confeÅ¿Å¿e, I Å¿carce Å¿aw any thing in Italy which pleaÅ¿ed me better then this pauement. On the left hand (within the Church) Å¿tands the Library painted with a rare FreÅ¿co which is yet rauishing and liuely after two hundred yeares:The Library. Indeed the braue actions of Aeneas Syluius (afterwards Pope Pius II) which theÅ¿e pictures repreÅ¿ent, deÅ¿erue to be painted by the Å¿un beames. The pictures are of the hand of Pietro Perugino, Raphaels MaÅ¿ter: but when alls done, giue me bookes in a Library, not pictures. In the Church you Å¿ee the Å¿tatues of Alexander the III, of Pius II, of Paulus V, & of Alexander the VII. all Popes, and natiues of Siena.

S. Katharine of Siena.2. I Å¿awe here the Å¿eueral places which S. Katharine of Siena had made famous by her deuotions: as,
her Chamber, where she receiued the holy Å¿tigmats, now turned into a Chappel: the Chamber where she liued: with other memorials of her deuotions, in the Dominicans Church; where they alÅ¿o shew her head, and finger: her body being transferred to Rome, and lyeing in a little Chappel within the SacriÅ¿ty of the Dominicans, at the Minerua.

3.Other Rarities. The other things ordinarily showne here, are the great HoÅ¿pital: the houÅ¿e of Pius II, of the family of the Piccolomini: the great Piazza: the pillar with the woolf of braÅ¿Å¿e vpon it: the marble Pillar as you come into the towne from Florence, with the armes of the Empire and of Portugal vpon it; becauÅ¿e here it was, that the Emperour met Eleonora of Portugal and marryed her in preÅ¿ence of Aeneas Syluius then Archbishop here, and afterwards Pope Pius II.

I Å¿aw here the Academy of wits called gli Intronati:The Academy of Wits. why they should take that ambitious name I knowe not, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be in reference to the Å¿aying of Ã PhiloÅ¿opher, who
Å¿ayd, that then finally kingdomes should be happy, when either PhiloÅ¿ophers should be choÅ¿en Kings, or Kings playd the PhiloÅ¿ophers. Indeed AriÅ¿totle holds that they that are Å¿trong of body, are made to Å¿erue, and tug at the oare of commands: and they that are Å¿trong in wit, are borne by nature to Å¿it at the helme, and command others.

5. This towne hath furnished the Church with a General Council of a hundred and thirty Bishops, called by Nicolas the III: with three great Saints, S. Bernardin reformer of the Minorits; S. Katharine the holy Virgin; and Beatus Colombanus InÅ¿titutor of the Order of the IeÅ¿uati, a man of great learning and Sanctity: with fiue good Popes, to wit, Alexander the III of the houÅ¿e of Bandinelli; Pius II, of the houÅ¿e of Piccolomini; Paulus V, of the houÅ¿e of BurgeÅ¿i; and Alander the VII, of the houÅ¿e of ChiÅ¿i: And in fine, it hath furnished the world with two champions in learning AmbroÅ¿ius Politi (or Catharinus) who wrote learnedly againÅ¿t
Luther and EraÅ¿mus; and Adriano Politi who wrote againÅ¿t Ignorance by his learned Dictionary.
He that would know in particular the hiÅ¿tory of Siena, The HiÅ¿tory. let him read Orlando Maleuolto.

From Siena we went to Bon Conuento, Tornieri, San Quirico, inconÅ¿iderable places vpon the rode, and Å¿o to Radicofino a Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle vpon a high hill built by DeÅ¿iderius King of the Longobards. Radicofino. This is the laÅ¿t place of the Florentin state, but not the leaÅ¿t in Å¿trength.
Dineing here at the Great Dukes Inn at the bottom of the hill, we went to lodge at Aquapendente, which is Å¿ome 12 miles off, and the firÅ¿t towne of the Popes Å¿tate.

This towne Å¿tands vpon a hill,Aquapedente. from which the waters trickling downe Å¿oftly are Å¿ayd to hang there, and giue it the name of Aquapendente. Of late this towne is made a Bishops Seate by the Demolition of CaÅ¿tro, and the remooual of the Bishops Seat from thence hither, which happened vpon this
occaÅ¿ion. CaÅ¿tro was a towne belonging to the Duke of Parma, Thither Pope Innocent the X. Å¿ent a good Bishop to gouerne that flock; but the Bishop vpon his arriual being killed there, the Pope Å¿ent Conte Vidman (General then of the Church) with order to demolish CaÅ¿tro; and he himÅ¿elf transfered the Bishops Å¿eat from thence to Aquapendente, and all this according to the Canon law, which ordains, Can. ita nos 25. qu. 2. that that Citie which kills its Bishop should be depriued of the Bishops Å¿eat euer after.

From Aquapendente we came to a little towne called San Lorenzo, and not long after,BolÅ¿ena. to BolÅ¿ena, anciently called Vrbs VolÅ¿inenÅ¿ium. Here it was that happened the famous Miracle in confirmation of the Real preÅ¿ence of ChriÅ¿ts body and blood in the BleÅ¿Å¿ed Sacrament, which happened an 1263, and which gaue occaÅ¿ion to Pope Vrban the IV to command that the FeaÅ¿t of Corpus ChriÅ¿ti should be kept holyday euer after. The Miracle
is related by Leandro Alberti the Camden of Italy, and by learned Onuphrius Panuinus in the life of Vrban the IV.

We paÅ¿Å¿ed alÅ¿o that morning by the Å¿ide of the Lake of BolÅ¿ena;The Lake of BolÅ¿ena in the midle of which is a little Iland in which AmalaÅ¿uinta Queen of the Ostrogoths, a woman of Å¿ingular parts, was miÅ¿erably murthered by her neareÅ¿t kinred. Heres alÅ¿o a little Conuent of Capucins.

Hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed along this Lake a great while,BoÅ¿co Helerno. we entered at laÅ¿t into a wood called anciently Lucus VolÅ¿inenÅ¿ium, and now, BoÅ¿co Helerno. It was formerly a dangerous paÅ¿Å¿age for Bandits: but now its free from danger, Å¿ince Sixtus Quintus purged the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical State of that Vermin, by makeing a Law, that whoÅ¿oeuer should bring in the head of a Bandit, should haue pardon, impunity, & recompence too of Å¿ome hundred crownes, wher vpon the Bandits Å¿oone deÅ¿troyed one another.

From this wood we Å¿oone came to MontefiaÅ¿cone Å¿tanding vpon a hill. Its a Bishops Seat,MontefiaÅ¿cone. and famous
for excellent MuÅ¿catello wine; and this wine is famous for hauing killed a Dutchman here who drunk too much of it. The Å¿tory is true, and thus. A Dutchman of coÌ„dition traueling through Italy, Å¿ent his man before him alwayes, with a charge to looke out in the Inns were the beÅ¿t Wine was, & there write vpon the Wall of the Inn the word, EST, that is to Å¿ay, Here it is. The Å¿eruant comeing hither a little before his MaÅ¿ter, and finding the wine excellently good, wrote vpon the Wall EST, EST, EST, Å¿ignifying thereby the Å¿uperlatiue goodneÅ¿Å¿ of this wine. The MaÅ¿ter arriues, lookes for his Mans handwriting; and finding three ESTS, is ouer ioyed. In he goes, and reÅ¿olues to lye there; and he did Å¿o indeed: for here he lyes Å¿till; buryed firÅ¿t in wine, and then in his graue. For drinking too much of this good wine, he dyed here, and was buryed by his Å¿eruant in a Church here below the Hill, with this Epitaph vpon his Tombe, made by the Å¿ame Å¿eruant, Propter EST,
EST, EST, herus meus mortuus eÅ¿t. It was here alÅ¿o, that the gallantry of the braue Roman General Camillus appeared very much. For while he was beÅ¿ieging this towne, called then P â€¢ aliÅ¿cum, or Phalerii, a treacherous Å¿choolmaÅ¿ter hauing brought vnto him the chief of the yong youths of the towne, whom he had deceitfully drawne vnto the Roman Camp, vnder pretence of takeing the ayre a broad: by which means Camillus might haue frighted their Parents to an vnworthy rendition: the braue Roman who Å¿corned to ouercome by any other way then that of Gallantry, cauÅ¿ed the Å¿choole master to bee Å¿tripped & his hands to be tyed behind his back, and to be led into the towne againe, with the little youths whipping him as he went, till he had brought them home againe. This nobleneÅ¿Å¿ of Camillus tooke the towne preÅ¿ently, becauÅ¿e it tooke with the towneÅ¿men; who admireing the Romans GeneroÅ¿ity, Å¿ubmitted willingly to Camillus, who had choÅ¿en
rather to take towns By this owne Æ²alour, then by other mens iniquity: Indeed (as Valerius Maximus Å¿ayth) it did not become Rome built by the Å¿onn of Mars, to take towns otherwiÅ¿e then Martially.

From MonteÅ¿iaÅ¿cone we went downe the Hill by an eaÅ¿ie deÅ¿cent vnto Viterbo. Viterbo. This is an EpiÅ¿copal Seat, Å¿tanding in a wholeÅ¿ome ayre, and therefore called Viterbium, as it where, Vita Vrbium. Here are excellent fountains of water, and Å¿tore of them: but its pitty none of them runn with good wine, to make a mends for the bad, which are moÅ¿t of them Vini cotti. The two factions here of the Gatti & the MaganeÅ¿i (theÅ¿e Å¿tanding for the VrÅ¿ini, thoÅ¿e for the ColonneÅ¿i) ruined heretofore Viterbo ouer & ouer againe. In the Domo there are the tombes of 4 Popes, as alÅ¿o in the FranciÅ¿cans Church Å¿ome tombes of Popes, and of S. RoÅ¿a: you Å¿ee the body of that Saint yet entire though buryed aboue 100 years ago. She lyes along in her tombe, and is Å¿een by the drawing
of a curtain from before her.

Heres an Academy of wits called Gli OÅ¿tinati, to shew perchance,The Accademy of Wits. that a man cannot be learned without obÅ¿tinate labour and paynes. Hence the PoÃ«t makes his learned man to be one who multum Å¿udauit & alÅ¿it: and PerÅ¿ius tells vs, that his delight was to grow pale with obÅ¿tinate night Å¿tudy: Velle Å¿uum cuique eÅ¿t &c.
div.q: At me nocturnis juuat impalleÅ¿cere chartis.
div.p: About a mile from Viterbo Å¿tands a neat Church and Conuent called Madonna del Querco, and as farre againe beyond that, Ã fine houÅ¿e with a garden of water works and Fountains, worth Å¿eeing.

From Viterbo (being vpon our owne horÅ¿es) we went to Å¿ee Caprarola a Å¿tately HouÅ¿e belonging to the Duke of Parma. Caprarola The houÅ¿e is held to be one of the fineÅ¿t in Italy for Architecture. Its Å¿tands a little out of the trauelers rode, but not of his way: for its much in a mans way to Å¿ee Å¿uch a louely houÅ¿e as this. It Å¿tands vpon the Å¿ide of a
hill, and from one of the Balconies it shews you Rome Å¿ome two and thirty miles off. Its built in a Pentagone (if I remember well) without, and round within. The chambers for all that, are Å¿quare, and well proportioned. The chief of theÅ¿e chambers are painted by the hand of Pietro OrbiÅ¿ta, flourishing thus vpon the noble actions of Paulus III. Among the other chambers, the whiÅ¿pering chamber is curious: for four men here Å¿tanding each one in one of the four corners of this great chamber, heare diÅ¿tinctly what any of them whispers in a low tone in his corner, their faces being turned to the wall; and yet thoÅ¿e that Å¿tand in the midÅ¿t of the chamber cannot heare it. The other chamber is no leÅ¿Å¿e curious where Å¿tanding in the midÅ¿t of it, and Å¿tamping hard with your foot, thoÅ¿e that are without at the dore think they heare the cracks or reports of PiÅ¿tols. The other roomes here alÅ¿o, as the kitchin all of one Å¿tone, the low Caue alÅ¿o with the pillar in it, cut likewiÅ¿e
out of a rock, and bearing vp the whole pauement of the round court which lets light into this Caue by diuers round grates of iron, are worth the beholding: Then the Garden vpon the HillÅ¿ide with the great variety of waterworks, grottes, and wetting Å¿ports, are all curious things. Hauing walked this garden about, youl deÅ¿erue after Å¿o much water, a little wine, which will not be wanting to you from the rare cellar lyeing vnder the great TerraÅ¿Å¿e before the houÅ¿e: and perchance youl think the wineworks here as fine as the waterworks.
From Caprarola we fell into our way againe at MonteroÅ¿a, MonteroÅ¿a. from whence paÅ¿Å¿ing by Bacano, and the HoÅ¿teria del Storto, we came at night to Rome.

All the way from MonteroÅ¿a to Rome almoÅ¿t, belonged anciently to the Veientes (Å¿o called, Å¿ayth BeroÅ¿us, from their carrying about with them in carts, all their goods) Neare to Bacan is a lake out of which runns the riuer Varca, Varca. anciently called Cremera, neere vnto
which the Veientes killed in one battle, three hundred Fabii, that is, the whole family of the Fabii (who had vowed themÅ¿elues to death for the commonwealths Å¿eruice) except one little boy not able to beare armes, from whom Fabius Maximus, The terrour of Hannibal, and Romes buckler deÅ¿cended.

Vpon this rode alÅ¿o Å¿tood anciently the towne Veii, Veii. a towne which held out tenn Å¿ommers againÅ¿t the Romans, and Å¿tood in need of no leÅ¿Å¿e man then Camillus to take it. This towne was once Å¿o great, that Rome being deÅ¿troyed almoÅ¿t by the Gauls, the Senators held a conÅ¿ultation in the Comitium, whether they should retire to Veii, and leaue Rome quite, or rebuild againe Romes walls: but during this conÅ¿ultation, the troops returning out of garriÅ¿on arriued by chance into the Comitium, where the Centurion entring, and not thinking the Senators had been there, cryed out to the Standardbearer, Valer. Max. l. 1. c. 5. Signifer Statue Å¿ignum, hic optime manebimus: which words the Senators
hearing, cryed out to one an other; Accipimus omen; and preÅ¿ently layd aÅ¿ide all further thought of retireing to Veii.

Some twelue miles before we came to Rome, we Å¿aw the Cupola of S. Peters Church, and were as glad to Å¿ee it a farre off, as the weary Troians in Aeneas his company, were glad to Å¿ee Jtaly after Å¿o much wandering. Some few houres after, hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed by an old tombe, which Å¿ome call Neros Tombe, and ouer the Ponte Molo (of which more in my 2. part) we entred into Rome by the Via Flaminea, and Porta del Populo.

div.trailer: The end of the FirÅ¿t Part.

div.p: THE VOYAGE OF ITALY: OR A COMPLEAT IOVRNEY THROVGH ITALY. THE SECOND PART WITH THE CHARACTERS OF THE People, and the deÅ¿cription of the chief Townes, Churches, MonaÅ¿teries, Tombes, Libraries, Pallaces, Villas, Gardens, Pictures, Statues, Antiquities: AS ALSO OF THE INTEREST, Gouerment, Riches, Force, &c. of all the Princes.
By RICHARD LASSELS Gent. Opus poÅ¿thumum: Corrected & Å¿et forth by his old friend and fellow Traueller S. W.
PRINTED AT PARIS By VINCENT DV MOVTIER, M.DC.LXX.

div.head: THE SECOND PART OF THE VOYAGE OF ITALY.
div.p: BEING arriued at Rome, we lodged in an Inn for three, or four days, till we had found out, and furnished, a houÅ¿e to our Å¿atisfaction. That done I began preÅ¿ently my InqueÅ¿t, and made Hue and Cry after euery little thing which time Å¿eemed to haue robbed vs of.

But as we approach not to great perÅ¿ons in Italy without informing our Å¿elues firÅ¿t of their titles; that we may know how to Å¿tile them: Å¿o before. I bring my Reader acquainted with Rome, I think it not
a miÅ¿Å¿e to tell him how this great Citie is comonly called.

And although Rome were anciently Å¿tiled the Head, and MiÅ¿treÅ¿se of the world; an Earthly GoddeÅ¿Å¿e; The Eternal Citie; The Compendium of the World; The Common Mother, and Nurce of all Vertues; (while she was yet Heathen;) Yet Å¿inc hir Ladyship was Baptized and became ChriÅ¿tian (though she haue had great Elogies made of her by the Holy Fathers,) I find no Title Å¿o honorable to hir as that of Roma la Santa, How Rome is stiled. Rome the Holy; which is giuen hir by the Common Prouerb; and common Prouerbs are nothing elÅ¿e but the obÅ¿eruation of common SenÅ¿e: For wheras the other Cities of Italy are Prouerbially called either Faire, Gentile, Rich, Proud, Fatte, or Great; as Florence, Naples, Venice, Genua, Bologna, Milan; Rome only is Å¿tiled the Holy:Roma la Santa. and this deÅ¿eruedly, for many reaÅ¿ons.

FirÅ¿t, For being the Seat of ChriÅ¿ts Vicar vpon Earth, S. Peter and his SucceÅ¿Å¿ors, to the number
of 240 and odd Popes.

2. For hauing been watered at the rootes by the preaching and blood of the two glorious ApoÅ¿tles S. Peter and S. Paul. Which made S. Leo, Å¿peaking to Rome of theÅ¿e two great ApoÅ¿tles, Serm. 1. de Natal. ApoÅ¿t. Petri Paul. make her this ApoÅ¿trophe. Hi Å¿unt qui te ad hanc gloriam prouexerunt, vt gens Å¿ancta, populus electus, ciuitas Sacerdotalis & Regia, per Å¿acram Beati Petri Å¿edem caput orbis effecta, latius praeÅ¿ideres religione diuina quam dominatione terrena.

3. For hauing been looked vpon in all ages, as the Center of Catholick Communion: and the place where the Matrix and Radix EccleÅ¿ia, the Mother Church and the Radical Church (as S. Cyprian calls hir) did flourish alwayes.
4. For hauing been washed and purged in the blood of Å¿o many thouÅ¿and Martyrs in the primitiue times, which euen baptized Rome a new, and made it be called by Holy Fathers Nona Sion: a New Sion.

5. For hauing Å¿o many Saints
bodyes lyeing in its Churches; and Å¿o many Churches within its precincts, which are aboue there huÌ„dred in all.
6. For hauing been the happy occaÅ¿ion of conuerting moÅ¿t of the Nations of Europe, and many others out of Europe, vnto the faith of ChriÅ¿t, by Prachers Å¿ent from thenc.
7. For haueing been the DepoÅ¿itary (as S. Irenaeus calls her) of the Holy Apostolical Traditions and doctrine, which haue alwayes been conÅ¿erued in her Church.
8. For hauing alwayes conÅ¿erued the Symbole of the creed inuiolably (Å¿aith S. Hierome) and for neuer hauing runn in a by-channel of errour.

BeÅ¿ides theÅ¿e foreÅ¿ayd reaÅ¿ons, Rome may deÅ¿eruedly be called Holy, for the many & Å¿ingular acts of Charity which are done there dayly more then in any other place.Great Charityes in Rome. Charity is the Queen of Vertues; and if euer I Å¿aw this Queen in her throne, it was in Rome. For there I Å¿aw no euil, either of body,
or mind, but it had its remedy, if curable; at leaÅ¿t its comforts if incurable.

For the firÅ¿t, to wit, Euils of body, Remedyes for euils of the body. it hath is HoÅ¿pitals, and thoÅ¿e many, and many of thoÅ¿e are HoÅ¿pitals in folio. BeÅ¿ides no Pilgrim comes to Rome, but he findes Rome, as Adam did ParadiÅ¿e, with the table couered, and bed made ready for him. Poore yong girles finde portions either for husbands or nunneries, according to their choice; Infants whom cruel & vnlawfull mothers, like wolfes, expoÅ¿e to death, Rome receiues to life;Meretrices lupas vocabant vnde Luparia. AuguÅ¿tin. de Ciuit. Deil. 18. c. 21. and thinks it but a Å¿utable AntipelargeÅ¿is to nurrish wolfes children, Å¿eing a shee wolfe nurrished her Founder being expoÅ¿ed by men. Fooles too and Madmen, Å¿o much the more miÅ¿erable, as not being Å¿o much as Å¿enÅ¿ible of their condition (for Å¿aepe calamitatis Å¿olatium eÅ¿t noÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ortem Å¿uam) haue here thoÅ¿e that take care of them. Poore men finde HoÅ¿pitals when they are Å¿ick;Quint. Curt. and gentlemen, whom nature hath not exempted from common miÅ¿eries,
Rome exempts from common HoÅ¿pitals; and not being able to giue them better health, she giues them at leaÅ¿t better accommodation in their Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿. Here you shall finde an Apothecaries shop, founded by Cardinal Francis Barberin with an yearly reuenue of twelue thouÅ¿and crownes, and this for euer; to furnish the poore with phyÅ¿ick gratis.

Here you shall finde the HoÅ¿pital of the Holy Trinity which in the Jubily yeare of Clement the VIII, is found to haue treated at table in one day fifteen thouÅ¿and pilgrims: and in the whole yeare fiue hundred thouÅ¿and. The laÅ¿t Iubily yeare 1650, I my Å¿elf was preÅ¿ent one day, when the Å¿ayd HoÅ¿pital treated nine thouÅ¿and Pilgrims that day: the Pope himÅ¿elf (Jnnocent the Tenth) and many of the Cardinals hauing been there to wash the feet of the pilgrims,AlmoÅ¿t euery nation hath an HoÅ¿pital in Rome. and to Å¿erue them at table. Adde to this, that euery nation hath here its Å¿eueral HoÅ¿pital and Refuge, with Church and Churchmen to Å¿erue it. As the English Colledge, once
an HoÅ¿pital for the English: That of the Anima, for the Germans: That of the S. Lewis, for the French: That of S. Iacomo, for the Spaniads: That of S. Antony of Padua, for the PortugueÅ¿i: That of S. Iulian for the Flemmings: That of S. AmbroÅ¿e for the Lombards: That of S. Iuo for the Britons: That of S. Hierome for the Illyrians: That of S. Marie Egyptiaca for the Armenians: That of S. Stephano for the Hungarians: That of S. StaniÅ¿laus for the Polonians. BeÅ¿ides a world of others. Nay almoÅ¿t euery corporation or body of artiÅ¿ans haue their HoÅ¿pital among themÅ¿elues, which they maintaine. In the Church of the 12 Apost. they chooÅ¿e yearly 12 noblemen & one Prelat who is called their Prior: TheÅ¿e go into every corner of Rome to Å¿eeke out poore men who are ashamed to beg, & yet are in great want. TheÅ¿e bashfull poore men put their names into a coffer well locked vp and Å¿tanding in a publick place, by which meanes theÅ¿e charitable noblemen finde them out and relieue them.

What shall I Å¿ay of the publick charity of the Pope himÅ¿elf well knowne to all? BeÅ¿ides a world of priuate charities which he giues by his Secreto LimoÅ¿ini â€¢ ro to thoÅ¿e that are ashamed to beg publickly.

The like do many Cardinals by their owne hands; and in that high meaÅ¿ure, that Cardinal Montalto (to name no more) is found by his books of Accounts, to haue giuen away aboue a hundred and Å¿euen thouÅ¿and crownes to the poore. Of which pious Cardinal I cannot omit to write this following Å¿tory, as I haue learned it from very good relation.

p.q:
An ingenious peece of Charity.A poore widdow of Rome mother of one onely daughter both yong and hanÅ¿ome, got her liuing honeÅ¿tly by her owne, and her daughters labour; and rubbed out poorly, but yet honeÅ¿tly: Now it happened, that this widdow falling Å¿ick, and her daugther haueing enough to do to tend her, their wrork went on Å¿o faintly, and their gains came in Å¿o Å¿lowly, that at her recoueryâ–ª
she found her purÅ¿e as much Å¿pent, as her perÅ¿on. Whereupon being called on for the quarter rent of her chaÌ„ber, and not knowing what to doe, she was aduiÅ¿ed by her ConfeÅ¿Å¿arius to go to Cardinal Montalto (who gaue publick audienc thric a week to all the poore in Rome) and to beg as much of him, as would pay her little debt. PreÅ¿Å¿ed therefore by her great neceÅ¿Å¿ity, & emboldened by the fame of the charity of this good Cardinal, she entred the pallace, and found him in his great hall, giuing care and almes to all thoÅ¿e that could giue him a good account of their wants. In her turne she, and her yong daughter approached vnto him Å¿itting at his tables end; and expreÅ¿ing modeÅ¿ty her wants cauÅ¿ed by her three months Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿, she humbly beÅ¿ought his Eminence, to giue her fiue crownes for to pay the rent of her chamber, and pacify her Landlord who otherwiÅ¿e threatened to put her out of dores. The Cardinal Å¿eeing
as much modeÅ¿ty in her looks as Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿ in her countenance; and likeing well, that she did not go about to fright him into charity, by vrgeing the danger of being forced one day to expoÅ¿e her daughter to lewd courÅ¿es (a common Rhetorical figure of begars in all contryes) wrote downe in a little paper, 50 crownes to be giuen to her; and folding vp the paper, he bid her carry it to his Å¿eruant below at the entrance of the pallace, who kept the Cardinals bills and payed the contents of them. She did Å¿o with humble prayers of thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e; and the Å¿eruant vpon Å¿ight of the paper, preÅ¿ently threw her out 50 crownes, and bid her make an acquittance for it. The poore woman Å¿eing 50 crownes counted out for her who had asked but 5; and fearing leaÅ¿t the Å¿eruant vpon Å¿ight of her hanÅ¿ome daughter, might haue done this by way of bribery, told him Å¿martly, that though she were poore, yet she was honeÅ¿t,
and that she Å¿corned to go by one corruption to an other. The honeÅ¿t Å¿eruant ciuily replyed, that he vnderÅ¿tood not her words: nor I your deeds, Å¿ayd she, I asked the Cardinal 5 crownes, he granted me my requeÅ¿t, and why then do you offer me 50 crownes? The honeÅ¿t Å¿eruant, to shew his innocency, shews his maÅ¿ters hand writeing importing 50 crownes. Then your maÅ¿ters hand, Å¿ayd she, for haÅ¿te, out shot his intentions: I asked him for 5 crownes, and more in conÅ¿cience I cannot take. The Å¿eruant, though he knew his maÅ¿ters generoÅ¿ity, yet to take all Å¿cruple from the poore woman, locked vp his monye and papers, and deÅ¿ired the poore woman to go vp with him to the Cardinal againe, to cleare this doubt. The Cardinal hearing from his Å¿eruant the whole paÅ¿Å¿age and that the poore woman was affrayd his hand had been miÅ¿taken in writeing 50 crownes inÅ¿tead of 5; tis true, Å¿ayd he, my hand was miÅ¿taken
indeed; and calling for his pen againe, as if he would haue corrected the cypher which made the bill 50, he put in an other cypher, and Å¿o made it 500 crownes; reading it now a lowd to his Å¿eruant and the poore woman; commanding her to beÅ¿tow her daughter with that money; and if it where not enough, to come againe to him, and he would make it vp. A true Roman Charity.

div.p:
Remedies for euils of the mind.As for thoÅ¿e Charityes which concerne the mind, if a Great King of Egypt wrote ouer his Library dore,OÅ¿ymunduas: apud Herodot. Medicina Animi, PhyÅ¿ick for the mind: here in Rome I finde Å¿tore of Å¿uch PhyÅ¿ick in Libraryes, Colledges, MonaÅ¿teries, and deuout companies. And firÅ¿t for Libraries; you shall finde here (beÅ¿ide the Libraries of euery Religious houÅ¿e) the incomparable Library of the Vatican:Publike Libraries (of which more below) thoÅ¿e alÅ¿o of Cardinal Barberin; of the Duke of Altemps; that of the Sapienza; and that of the AuguÅ¿tin â€¢
; the laÅ¿t two being open to all men euery
day, with a courteous gentleman to reach you any booke, and a learned ManuÅ¿cript in folio adreÅ¿Å¿ing you to the authors that treat of any Å¿ubiect you deÅ¿ire to be informed of, which affords great help to the painfull Å¿tudent. Then the Colledges and Seminaries of almoÅ¿t all nations where youths are both fed and bred vp in learning for nothing.Colledges.
Adde to this, the Variety of MonaÅ¿terys and Conuents, MonaÅ¿teries. both of men and women, where they may hide themÅ¿elues Å¿ecurely donectranÅ¿eat iniquitas.

Then the taking away of yong girles, HouÅ¿es for yong girles. at ten or twelue yeares old, from their poore Å¿uÅ¿pected mothers; and the bringing them vp vertuouÅ¿ly vnder carefull matrons of knowne Vertue, till they either chooÅ¿e the Nuptial Flammeum, or the Å¿acred Velum.

Then the Remedies for ill marryed women, Remedies for ill marryed women. whoÅ¿e vnaduiÅ¿ed choyce (marriages being often made for IntereÅ¿t) or incompatible humours force to a corporal Å¿eparationâ–ª and leaÅ¿t Å¿uch vnfortunate women
should either liue incontinently indeed, or giue Å¿uÅ¿picion of it they are prouided here with a houÅ¿e where they liue retiredly vnder Lock and Key, till they either reconcile themÅ¿elues againe to their huÅ¿bands; or vpon iuÅ¿t occaÅ¿ions, leaue them for euer. Ouer the dore of this houÅ¿e is written, Per le donne mal maritate,

The Conuent of Penitents.Then the Conuent of Penitent whores (that none may perish in Rome who haue a mind to be Å¿aued) called Sancta Maria Magdalena in CorÅ¿o; where many of thoÅ¿e poore Magdelens haue led Å¿uch penetential liues (as the bloody walls of their Celles, cauÅ¿ed by their frequent diÅ¿ciplining, shewed to all Rome in a conflagration of that monaÅ¿tery) that Paulus Quintus himÅ¿elf being informed of it, would needs be carryed thither, to Å¿ee thoÅ¿e bloody chambers from the Å¿treet; and hauing Å¿een them, wept for ioye; and I can Å¿carce hold from cryeing out: O foelix culpa!

What shall I Å¿ay of the Congregregation
of Aduocats and Attorneis, Charity of Lawiers in Rome. inÅ¿tituted in Rome, where they meet once a week to examin poore mens law Å¿utes; and either dehort them from proceeding in bad cauÅ¿es; or proÅ¿ecute good cauÅ¿es for them at the coÅ¿t of this Congregation?

What shall I Å¿ay of Å¿eueral pious Clergy men (eÅ¿pecially the good PrieÅ¿ts of the Oratory, Broken-friend-Å¿etters. happy in this employment, who make it their taske to reconcile diÅ¿agreeing families, and with great zeale and piety exhorte firÅ¿t the one, then the other of the partyes, interuene between them, Å¿peake well of the one to the other, cleare and take away iealous miÅ¿vnderÅ¿tandings, and in fine, peece againe broken neighbors?

What shall I Å¿ay of the four Sermons dayly in the ChieÅ¿a noua by the moÅ¿t learned and good PrieÅ¿t of the Oratory, Four Sermons dayly in one place in Rome. who being moÅ¿t of them learned men, as Baronius, BoÅ¿ius, IuÅ¿tinianus, Renaldus &c and able to flye high, yet in their Å¿ermons Å¿toup to a low pitch, and a popular facile way, which aymes rather at
conuerÅ¿ion, then oÅ¿tentation; and doth great good, though it make little noyÅ¿e? Dominus in le â€¢ i aura.

Weekly Å¿ermons to the Iewes.What shall I Å¿ay of the weekly Å¿ermon to the Iewes vpon Saturday; where they are bound to be preÅ¿ent to the number of three hundred, and where the Pope entertains a learned Preacher to conuince them out of their owne Å¿criptures; and thoÅ¿e that are conuerted, are prouided for in the HoÅ¿pital of the Catechumens, till they be throughly inÅ¿tructed? I haue Å¿een diuers of them baptized.

The Å¿cholae Pi â€¢ .What shall I Å¿ay of the Scholae piae in Rome, a company of good Religious men, who looke like IeÅ¿uits, Å¿aue onely that they go barefoot in Å¿andals? TheÅ¿e good Fathers make a profeÅ¿Å¿ion to teach poore boyes gratis their firÅ¿t grammar radiments, and to make them fit to bee Å¿ent to the JeÅ¿uits Å¿chools; and hauing thaught them thus in the Å¿chools, they accompany them home in the Å¿treets, leaÅ¿t they should either learne waggery as they go
home, or practiÅ¿e it. Nay theÅ¿e humble men make it their profeÅ¿Å¿ion not to teach higher Å¿chools, where there might be Å¿ome profit and honour, at leaÅ¿t Å¿ome Å¿atisfaction and pleaÅ¿ure: but they content themÅ¿elues to go bare foot, and teach onely the lower Å¿chools and firÅ¿t rudiments; by which they neither grow wiÅ¿er, nor richer: A Å¿trange mortifyed trade; But Beati pauperes Å¿piritu.

What shall I Å¿ay of the Fathers of the Agonizants, The Fathers of the Agonizants. whoÅ¿e vocation is to be the Seconds of thoÅ¿e who f â€¢ ght againÅ¿t death in Å¿elf; that isâ–ª whoÅ¿e profeÅ¿Å¿ion is, to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t thoÅ¿e that are in the agonie of death; and to help them to make then thoÅ¿e pious Acts which Christians should moÅ¿t of all then rouze themÅ¿elues vp to?

What can be Å¿ayd more? yes Rome not content, to haue fed, to haue bred, to haue conuerted, baptized reconciled the liuing; and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted the dyeing; she extends her charity euen beyond death it Å¿elf, and hath inÅ¿titued a pious Confraternity
called, La Compagnia de' Morti, La Compagnia de Morti. whoÅ¿e office is to bury the dead, and to viÅ¿it thoÅ¿e that are condemned, and by praying with them, exhorting them, and accompanying them to the execution, help them to dye penitently, and bury them being dead, and pray for their Å¿ouls being buryed; After which, charity can do no more to man: and therefore I will conclude, that Å¿eing Å¿uch Å¿ingular acts of charity, both for body and minde, are practiÅ¿ed no where Å¿o much as in Rome, its true which I aÅ¿Å¿umed aboue, that Rome deÅ¿erues to be called, The Holy.

Haueing Å¿ayd thus much â€¢ f the title of Rome, I will now, make my Reader better acquainted with her, by deÅ¿cribing the particularyties which I obÅ¿erued here. And that I may not ramble in writeing of Rome, as moÅ¿t men do in viÅ¿iting of it, I will begin at the Bridg called now Ponte Angelo, and from thenc make the whole gyro of the Citie in order.Ponte Angelo.

Arriuing then at the Bridg called
anciently Pons Aelius becauÅ¿e it was built by the Emperor Aelius Adrianus, but now called Ponte Angelo, becauÅ¿e it was vpon this Bridg that S. Gregory the Great Å¿aw an Angel vpon the Moles Adriani sheathing his Å¿word after a great plague: here wee Å¿aw the Å¿tately new decoration of Iron worke with the twelue Marble Å¿tatues Å¿et vpon it by this preÅ¿ent Pope Clement the IX. and looking downe into the riuer on the left hand, wee Å¿aw the ruines of the Triumphal bridg.

This bridg was called the Triumphal Bridge, The Triumphal Bridg. becauÅ¿e over it, Triumphs were accuÅ¿tomed to paÅ¿Å¿e anciently to the Capitol. This made it Å¿o proud, that it Å¿corned that any ruÅ¿tiks, or country fellowes, should paÅ¿Å¿e ouer it; and got a Decree of the Senate for that purpoÅ¿e. But pride will haue a fall; and the proud Triumphal Bridg hath got Å¿uch a great one, that thers but iuÅ¿t Å¿o much of it left, as to shew, where it was once; Å¿o true is the Å¿aying of AuÅ¿onius, Mors etiam Å¿axis nominibuÅ¿que venit.

At firÅ¿t the Romans were modeÅ¿t enough in their Triumphs, as in all other things: hence Camillus was content with four white horÅ¿es in his Chariot; but afterwards luxe and exceÅ¿Å¿e banishing out of the Citie, old modeÅ¿ty, they began to Å¿triue who should be the moÅ¿t vaine in this point. Hence Pompey was drawne in triumph,Vanity in Triumphs by four Elephants; Mark-Antony, by four Lyons; Nero by four Hermaphrodites, which were all four both horÅ¿es and mares: Heliogabulus by four Tygers; Aurelianus by Å¿ix Å¿taggs; and Firmicus by eight AuÅ¿tridges.

CaÅ¿tel Angelo.At the end the Ponte Angelo Å¿tands the CaÅ¿tel Angelo, Å¿o called becauÅ¿e, as I Å¿ayd before, S. Gregory in a Å¿olemne ProceÅ¿Å¿ion during the plague Å¿aw an Angel vpon the top of Moles Adriani sheathing his Å¿word, to Å¿ignify, that God's anger was appeaÅ¿ed. Before this Miracle happened, it was called Moles Adriani becauÅ¿e the Emperour Adrian was buryed here. It was built anciently in a round forme, of vaÅ¿t Å¿tones,
going vp in three rowes, or Å¿toryes leÅ¿Å¿er and leÅ¿Å¿er, till you came to the top; where Å¿tood mounted that great pineapple of braÅ¿Å¿ guilt, which we Å¿ee now in the garden of the Beluedere. Round about it were Å¿et in the wall great marble pillars, and round about the Å¿eueral Å¿toryes Å¿tood a world of Statues. This Moles being found a Å¿trong place, BelliÅ¿arius put men into it to defend it againÅ¿t the Gothes; and they defended themÅ¿elues in it a great while, by breaking the Statues in peeces, and throwing them vpon the heads of the Gothes that beÅ¿ieged them. Since that time, Diuers Popes haue turned it into a formal CaÅ¿tle. Boniface the VIII, Alexander the VI, and Vrban the VIII, haue rendered it a regular CaÅ¿tle, with fiue Å¿trong baÅ¿tions, Å¿tore of good Cannons, and a conÅ¿tant gariÅ¿on maintened in it. From this CaÅ¿tle I Å¿aw diuers times theÅ¿e Fortifications; and below diuers great peeces of artillary made of the braÅ¿Å¿e taken out of the Pantheon; and they shewed vs one great Cannon which was made of
the brazen nayles onely that nayled that braÅ¿Å¿e to the walls of the Pantheon; the length and forme of thoÅ¿e nayles, is Å¿een vpon that Cannon, to shew vnto poÅ¿terity how great they were, with theÅ¿e words vpon it, ex cla â€¢ is trabialibus Porticus Agrippae. Petri, and are couered with braÅ¿Å¿e by the command of Eugenius the IV, whoÅ¿e memorable actions, to wit, th â€¢ crowning of the Emperor SigiÅ¿mond, and the reunion of the Greek Church with the Latin, are expreÅ¿Å¿ed in them.
