Peters Church. that the Pyramids of Egypt, the walls of Babylon, the Pharos, ColoÅ¿Å¿us, &c. were but heaps of Å¿tones compared to this fabrick: that it hath put all antiquity to the blush, and all poÅ¿terity to a Non plus: that its Å¿eueral parts are all incomparable MaÅ¿ter-peeces: its pictures all originals: its Å¿tatues perfect models: That it hath a reuenue of aboue twenty thouÅ¿and pounds a yeare onely for the fabrick: that it hath coÅ¿t till the yeare 1654,The reuenue of S. Peters Church. (The accounts being then Å¿ummed vp) Forty millions of crownes: that moÅ¿t of the Popes Å¿ince Iulius the II his time (and they haue been twenty three in all) haue hartened and aduanced this workâ–ª that the prime Architects of the world, Sangalla, Bramante, BaldaÅ¿Å¿ere, Buonarota, Giacomo della Porta, Giouani Fontana,

But I cannot paÅ¿Å¿e euer Å¿o the long Gallerie leading to the Beluedere, The Gallerie of the Conclaue. in which is kept the Conclaue of all Popes: in this one great roome fifty, or threÅ¿ecore, Cardinals lodg, and haue euery one two chambers, one for himÅ¿elf, and the other for his ConclauiÅ¿t. When the children are growne fit for inÅ¿truction,
they are Å¿et to trads. The girles are carefully brought vp by religious women there, till they be fit for Mariage or a Nunnery, according to their vocation.

S. Onofrios. Church.From hence I went to S. Onofrios Church vpon the hill, where I Å¿aw the Tombe and picture ouer it, of rare Torquato TaÅ¿Å¿o, The Tombe of Torquato TaÅ¿Å¿o. whoÅ¿e warlike MuÅ¿e is able to inÅ¿pire mettle into his Readers breaÅ¿t, and diÅ¿poÅ¿e him to the engagement of a new CroiÅ¿ade againÅ¿t the Turks. This I can Å¿ay of him, that if Virgil hindered him from being the f â€¢ rÅ¿t of PoÃ«ts, he hindered Virgil from being the onely PoÃ«t.

Returning downe againe, and going along the Longara, Longara. I Å¿aw the Å¿tately pallace of the Duke of Saluiati on the right hand, and the Villa of ChiÅ¿i (now called the garden of FarneÅ¿i, Villa ChiÅ¿i. on the left hand. In this Villa I Å¿aw rare painting attributed to Raphael Vrbin.

Queen ChriÅ¿tinas Pallace.Ouer againÅ¿t this garden, liues now the Queene of Suede, in whoÅ¿e Pallace beÅ¿ides the rare hangings of cloth of gold, & of arras hangings
of Å¿ilk and gold, I Å¿aw a curious collection of pictures, originals all, and of the prime maÅ¿ters of the world: That of Sr Thomas Moor â€¢
is, without doubt, of Hans Holbains hand, and a rare peece.

PaÅ¿Å¿ing on the Longara Å¿till, I came to the Porta Septimiana, Å¿o called from Septimius Seuerus who built here his Therme; and Å¿o vp the Hill to Saint Pancratius his Gate, S. Pancratius his Church. and to the Church of that Saint poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed now by diÅ¿calced Carmelits. Vnder this Church is the Caemeterium Calepodit, Caemeterium Calepodii where many Martyrs bodies were buryed. Here was buryed CreÅ¿centius the tyrant, who Å¿eazing vpon the CaÅ¿tle Angelo Å¿wayd all in Rome for a while.

From hence I went to the Villa Pamfilia, Villa Pamfilia. which is hard by. Its a new Villa, but Å¿eated high, and from the terraÅ¿Å¿e vpon the top of the houÅ¿e, you haue a fine proÅ¿pect. There are diuers good pictures and Å¿tatues in the houÅ¿e, and fine waterworks, and a grotta in the garden. The beÅ¿t pictures here are, the Crucifixion of S. Peter, and the ConuerÅ¿ion of
S. Paul, of Michel Angelos hand. The entry of the Animals into the Arke of Noe, is a rare peece the beÅ¿t Å¿tatues are the wraÅ¿tling of Jacob with the Angel in white marble: Senecas Å¿tatue: and the BuÅ¿to of Innocent the X of porphyry: and his head in braÅ¿Å¿e.

Returning again into the towne the Å¿ame way we came, I Å¿aw the braue Fountaine made by Paulus Quintus, The Fountaine of Paulus V. who cauÅ¿ed the water to be brought thither from the Lake of Bracciano aboue thirty miles off, by a Å¿tately Aqueduct; and from hence it is diÅ¿perÅ¿ed into the City and there makes new fountains.

Hard by Å¿tands the Conuent of FranciÅ¿cans vpon a Hill, called S. Pietro Montorio, San Pietro Montorio where S. Peter was crucifyed with his head downeward, in that very place of the court where thers now a round Chappel â–ª entring into the Church I was much taken with the picture for the high Altar repreÅ¿enting our Sauiours Transfiguration. It was the laÅ¿t and beÅ¿t peece of Raphael Vrbins making, and then I may Å¿ay,
it is the beÅ¿t in world: I geÅ¿Å¿e it to be the beÅ¿t of Raphaels peeces, becauÅ¿e dyeing he commanded that this picture, of all his pictures, should be Å¿et vp at his feet after his death. In this Church lyes buryed the Earle of Tyrone who fled from Ireland hither in Queen Elizabeths time. Here are two fine Å¿tatues in marble of S. Peter and S. Paul, of the hand of Michel Angelo.

Going out of this Church,Mons Janiculus you haue a fair Å¿ight of Rome under you from this hill. This Hill was anciently called Ianiculus; and vpon it was buryed Statius the PoÃ«t; and at the foot of it Numa Pompilius.

Neare the foot of this Hill Å¿tands the Church and Conuent of the Scala, La Scala belonging to the DiÅ¿calced Carmelits. The High Altar is very â€¢ eat; and the good Fathers shewd vs in a little Chappel within the Conuent the foot of S. ThereÅ¿a, which â€¢ s plainly Å¿een through a cryÅ¿tal in which its kept.

Not farre from hence Å¿tands Santa Maria Trasteuere, Santa Maria TranÅ¿teuere. the first Church
built in Rome (Å¿ayth Baronius) and built there where anciently Å¿tood the Tabernae meritoriae;Tabernae Meritoriae. where the maimed Å¿oldiers receiued their pittance dayly. The Guilt roof, and the two rowes of marble pillars, do much beautify this Church. Vnder the High Altar is yet Å¿een the place where oyle yÅ¿Å¿ued out, as from a Fountain, a little before our Sauiours birth, as denounceing his birth to be at hand, who was to be called ChriÅ¿tus, that is annointed. In this Church lye buryed Cardinal HoÅ¿ius a moÅ¿t learned Trent Father, and Cardinal Campegius the Popes Legate in England in Henry the VIII time. You Å¿ee here the Å¿tone that was tyed about the neck of S. Calixtus Pope when he was throwne into a Well.
Here alÅ¿o you Å¿ee great round Å¿tones which where hung at the fee â€¢ of the Martyrs to torment them.

S. FranceÅ¿co in Ripa Grande.The Conuent of FranciÅ¿can Fryer â€¢
called S. FranceÅ¿co in Ripa Grand â€¢
is hard by; where I Å¿aw the Chamber where great S. Francis lodged when he liued in Rome. Its now
turned into a Chappel. In the Church there is an excellent picture of Piety, made by Caraccio. Here in the Church is the tombe of Beata Ludouica Mathei of the the third order of S. Francis.
I tooke the Ripa grande in my way,Ripa Grande. and Å¿aw there the boates of marchandiÅ¿e which come to Rome from Ligorne, GiuitÃ Vechia, Naples, and other places, and diÅ¿embark their goods here.

From the Ripa I went to S. Cicilies Church built where her houÅ¿e was,S. Cicilies Church. and where she was put to death for the Christian religion. Vnder the High Altar of this Church is the tombe of this primitiue Saint,
S. Cicilyes Tombe. with her Å¿tatue in a couchant poÅ¿ture, and iuÅ¿t as her body was found in Clement the VIII time, wrapt vp in vayls Å¿tayned with blood; and couered with a robe of gold. The neat decoration before the High Altar, with the Å¿yluer lamps burning before the Tombe of this Saint, was the foundation of Cardinal Sfondrati. At the end of this Church, as you
come in, are Å¿een yet the Å¿toues in which S. Cicily was shut vp in her owne houÅ¿e, to be Å¿tifled, but that failing, she was beheaded. The Å¿toues are yet entire, and shewing the manner of the ancient Å¿toues. In the Church portch I found the Tombe of one Adam, an English Bishop of London, and Cardinal of this tittle;Cardinal Adams Tombe. who dyed in Rome an. 1397. it hath theÅ¿e verÅ¿es vpon it.

q.l: Artibus iÅ¿te pater famoÅ¿us in omnibus Adam
Anglia cui patriam, titulum dedit iÅ¿ta Beatae

div.p:
S. ChryÅ¿ogono.Not farre from this Church Å¿tands S. ChryÅ¿ogonus his Church, a neat Church repayred Å¿ome yeares ago by Cardinal BurgheÅ¿i. The four pillars of the High Altar, looke as if they were of Å¿and and criÅ¿tal petrifyed together. On the left hand of the wall neare the great dore, lyes buryed Robert Archbishop of York, Cardinal Robert Archb. of Yorke. and titular of this Church but this was all I could learne
out of the TombÅ¿tone.

Hauing thus wandered ouer the TraÅ¿teuere, I made towards the Ile of S. Bartholomew in, which Å¿tands a good HoÅ¿pital and a Conuent of FranciÅ¿cans, in whoÅ¿e Church repoÅ¿eth, vnder the High Altar, in a faire porphyrie Tombe, the body of S. Bartholmew ApoÅ¿tle. S. Bartholomews Tombe. This Ile was anciently called InÅ¿ula Tiberina, and it was firÅ¿t made by the corne of Tarquinius Superbus, which being (after his ejection out of the City) pluckt vp by the rootes, and throwne into the riuer, by reaÅ¿on of the quantity of earth that Å¿tuck to the rootes, Å¿topped here where the water was low; and this Å¿toppage once begun, all the mud of the riuer came afterwards to Å¿top here too, and Å¿o in time, to forme a little Ile in the midÅ¿t of the riuer.

Going out of the Ile by the bridge of four heads (anciently called Pons Fabricius) which ioynes this Ile with the City, Ponte quatro Capi. I looked downe the riuer on my right hand, to Å¿ee the Pons Sublicius, Pons Sublicius. which Cocles alone
defended againÅ¿t an army, till the bridge was cut downe behind him: which he perceiuing, leapt into the riuer armed, and Å¿wome Å¿afe to his fellow Citizens, who were as glad to Å¿ee him come off Å¿afe, as to finde themÅ¿elues Å¿afe. It was called Pons Sublicius, from the word Sublica in Latin, which Å¿ignifies great beams of wood, of which it was made: it was afterwards built of Å¿tone by Aemilius. From this bridge the wicked Emperor Heliogabalus was throwne into the riuer and drowned with a great Å¿tone about his neck.

The Iewry.No Å¿ooner was I ouer this bridge, but I Å¿aw on my left hand, the great back dore of the Jewry; for here the Iews liue all together in a corner of the towne, and are locked vp euery night. I entred into their Synagogues here (which they call their Å¿chooles) where they meet vpon Saturdays and Å¿ing and pray. I wondered at firÅ¿t, that they had learned no more manners in theÅ¿e their Å¿chooles then to enter into them to pray, without either puting of hats, lifting vp eyes, or bending of
knees, to the Great Iehoua, whom they rather feare then loue. MoÅ¿es going to him, put of this shooes, and I expected, that theÅ¿e men should, at leaÅ¿t, haue put of their hatts at the entrance into their Synagogues: but they are Archclownes; and their fowle towels, at the entrance into their Synagogues, told me as much. I once Å¿aw a circumciÅ¿ion, but it was Å¿o painfull to the child, that it was able to make a man heartily thank God that he is a ChriÅ¿tian. And realy If the little child could Å¿peak and wish, I beleeue he would wish him Å¿elfe the greateÅ¿t curÅ¿e in the world, and to be a woman rather then a man vpon Å¿uch termes. I Å¿aw alÅ¿o a marriage here performed with many ceremonyes.

Returning out of the Jewry by the Å¿ame gate I entred, I Å¿aw on my left hand, the Pallace of Princ Sauelli: its built vpon the ruines of the Theater of Marcellus, Theatrum Marcells. built by AuguÅ¿tus in honour of his Nephew Marcellus: it was capable of fourÅ¿core thouÅ¿and men.

Santa Maria in CoÅ¿medinPaÅ¿Å¿ing on, I came to an ancient Church called Santa Maria in CoÅ¿medin, or in Schola Graeca, where S. AuÅ¿tin before his conuerÅ¿ion, taught Rhetorick. In the portch of this Church Å¿tands a great round Å¿tone cut into the face of a man, with a great wide mouth, commonly called, La bocca della VeritÃ ,Bocca della VeritÃ . The mouth of Truth; but this not being affirmed by the Mouth of truth, I dare not beleeue it. I rather beleeue it Å¿erued in Å¿ome old building for a gutter Å¿pout: I know, truth may Å¿peake lowd, and haue a wide mouth; but he that takes euery wide mouth for the mouth of Truth, is much miÅ¿taken.

S. Maria Egyptiaca.The next Church I came to was Santa Maria Egyptiaca: it was the Temple of the Sun and Iupiter. This Church is neatly adorned with curious chanelled pillars. It belongs to the Armenians, who haue an HoÅ¿pital alÅ¿o here belonging to the Catholick Pilgims of that country: and the Pope allowes them to celebrate MaÅ¿Å¿e here after their owne Armenian rite.

On the other Å¿ide of the great piazza, Å¿tands the Church of S. Steuen. Its rounded with chanelled pillars alÅ¿o. It was anciently the Temple of Iuno Matutina morneing Iuno, or Alba Dea, the Breake of day GoddeÅ¿Å¿e: a GoddeÅ¿Å¿e which our Ladyes, that neuer riÅ¿e till noone, would neuer haue been deuout to.

CloÅ¿e by this Church (which Å¿tands by the riuer Å¿ide) the great Sinke of Rome, The Cloaca Naxima. called Cloaca Maxima, emptyed it Å¿elf into Tyber. And though this were but a Sinke, yet it deÅ¿erues to be mentioned among the rare magnificencies of ancient Rome. For it was noblely built by Tarquinius PriÅ¿cus, of freeÅ¿tone, arched ouerhead, with a world of Å¿prings running into it: and it was Å¿o great, that a Cart might haue gone in it. This Å¿ink was one of the evident tokens of the greatneÅ¿Å¿ and magnificence of Rome anciently;Markes of Romes greatneÅ¿Å¿ anciently. and indeed a farre greater euidence then that of Heliogabulus, who cauÅ¿ed all the Å¿piders webbs of Rome to be gathered together
and weighed, that by Å¿o many poundweight of Spiders-webbs, the greatneÅ¿Å¿ of Rome might the better be conjectured.

Going on from hence by the riuer Å¿ide, I came to the foot of the Mount Auentin and left on my left hand a Chappel belonging to the Knights of Malta. Our antiquaries tell vs, that neare to this place Å¿tood the Temple of the Bona Dea, The Temple of Bona Dea. into which no man was to enter: and that Cacus his denn was alÅ¿o in the Å¿ide of this Hill, into which he dragd Hercules his oxen by the tayles,Cacut his denn. that no man should finde out his theft by the footÅ¿teps. Vpon the Å¿ide of this hill Å¿tood alÅ¿o the Scalae Gemoniae, Scalae Gemoniae. downe which criminal perÅ¿ons were tumbled into Tiber.

S. Alexius his Church.Going vp this Hill I went to S. Alexius his Church, where I Å¿aw, the wooden Å¿taires vnder which this Saint lodged for Å¿eauenteen years in his owne Fathers houÅ¿e (after fifteen years abÅ¿ence) without being knowne to any body, till after his death. The body of this Saint lyes vnder the high Altar, together with that of
S. Bonifacius the Martyr.
Hard by vpon the Å¿ame Hill, Å¿tands S. Sabinas Church, S. Sabinas Church. whither the Pope comes vpon Ash wensday in a Å¿olemne caualcata accompanyed with the Cardinals.
Here alÅ¿o vpon this Hill, Å¿tood anciently the Temple of Liberty and the Romans ArmiluÅ¿trium. The ArmiluÅ¿trium.

DeÅ¿cending from hence I made towards S. Pauls Gate; and in the way I Å¿aw on my right hand the Hill called Mons TeÅ¿tiacius, Mons TeÅ¿tacius which was made of the broken pots throwne there in the Romans time by the Potters. Its half a mile about, and 160 foot high.

A little nearer the Gate of S. Peul I Å¿aw the Tombe of Caius CeÅ¿tius, The Tombe of C. CeÅ¿tius. built like a Piramid of Egypt, and all of pure white marble. This is the moÅ¿t entire worke of all the ancient Roman works. This CeÅ¿tius (as the words vpon his Tombe importe) was Å¿eptemuir epulonum, that is, one of thoÅ¿e Å¿eauen men called Epulones anciently,Epulones. becauÅ¿e they had the deuouring of thoÅ¿e
banquets which were Å¿et before the Gods in their LectiÅ¿terniis, in the Temple of Jupiter Capitolinus.

The Gate of S. Paul.PaÅ¿Å¿ing thence through the Gate of S. Paul, anciently called Porta Tergemina; and Porta OstienÅ¿is; I went to S. Pauls Church a little mile from the towne. In the way I tooke notice of a little Chappel on the left hand, where S. Peter and S. Paul tooke leaue of one another; before they were led to Martyrdome.

S. Pauls Church.Soone after I came to S. Pauls Church â–ª here S. Paul was buryed by Lucina a Roman Lady, and therefore Constantin the Great built this Church in the honour of S. Paul as he had done that of S. Peter mentioned aboue. Its built croÅ¿Å¿ewiÅ¿e, and the body of it is 477 foot long, and 258 broad; with a hundred pillars in all, Å¿et in four ranks, all of them ancient round marble pillars taken out of the Baths of Antoniuns, In proaemio. Å¿ayth VaÅ¿Å¿ari. Yet in all this vaÅ¿t body of the Church there are no Chappels, nor
any decoration, except at the very end of it, neare the great dore, where there is an Altar with theÅ¿e words in a Å¿tone ouer it; Hic inuentum eÅ¿t caput S. Pauli. The moÅ¿t remarkable things which I Å¿aw here, were theÅ¿e.

1. The high Altar, with a Canopy of Å¿tone like a Tabernacle, borne vp by four porphyry pillars, and adorned with Å¿tatues. Vnder the Altar repoÅ¿eth half of the bodyes of S. Peter and S. Paul (as I obÅ¿erued before in S. Peters Church) and as the inÅ¿cription vpon the Å¿ide of the Altar here affirmes in theÅ¿e words: Sub hoc altari requieÅ¿cunt glorioÅ¿a corpora ApoÅ¿tolorum Petri & Pauli pro medietate. Behind this Altar Å¿taÌ„ds the ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of S. Paul like that of S. Peter deÅ¿cribed aboue. Vnder the little low dores which let the PrieÅ¿t into the steps of the Altar are written theÅ¿e words in golden letters, Limina ApoÅ¿tolorum, Limina ApoÅ¿tolorum. which make me bold to hold againÅ¿t Å¿ome moderne writers, that this was the preciÅ¿e place, and not the dore of the Church, which was called Limina ApoÅ¿tolorum.

2. In the old Arche in the top of the roof, is yet Å¿een a peece of MaÅ¿aick worke repreÅ¿enting our Sauiour in the midÅ¿t of the four and twenty Elders of the ApocalypÅ¿e. This peece was made there twelue hundred yeares ago in the time of S. Leo the great; and at the coÅ¿t of Placidia Galla (daughter of TheodoÅ¿ius, and Å¿iÅ¿ter of Honorius) as the two verÅ¿es in that Arch teÅ¿tify thus:
Placidiae pia mens operis decus homne reportat,
Gaudet Pontificis Å¿tudio Å¿plender â€¢ Leonis.

The miraculous Crucifix.3. The famous Miraculous Crucifix (Å¿tanding in a Chappel on the EpiÅ¿tle Å¿ide of the High Altar) which Å¿poke to S. Bridgit. Baron. This Crucifix fauours the opinion of thoÅ¿e who affirme that there were two nayles in our Sauiours feet.
4. The neat Chappel and Tabernacle of the B. Sacrament; with the rare pictures relating there vnto, made by Caualier Lanfranco.

5. The picture of the Altar of S. Steuen made by a Lady of Bolognia
called Lauinia Fontana.

6.Baron ad Ma â€¢â€¢â€¢ Rom â€¢
â€¢â€¢ 0 Mar â€¢â€¢â€¢ . The chief Relicks kept here are, the Head of the Samaritan woman conuerted by our Sauiour: the Arme of S. Anne mother of our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady: and the Chaine of S. Paul.

From S. Pauls Church I went to the Tre Fontane aboue a mile and a half off, and in the way, I paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer the place where S. Zeno, and ten thouÅ¿and ChriÅ¿tians were martyried at once by the command of Diocletian the Butcher. Their blood made this way holy all along.

Arriueing at the Tre Fontane I Å¿aw there three Churches Å¿tanding within a place anciently called,Tre Frontane. Ad Aquas Saluias. The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e three Churches is that of S. Vincent and AnaÅ¿taÅ¿e, The Church of S. Vincent and AnaÅ¿taÅ¿e becauÅ¿e of their Relicks Å¿ent hither. For about the yeare 627. the Emperor Heraclius Å¿ent the Head of S. AnaÅ¿taÅ¿ius with the picture of the Å¿ame Saint vnto Pope Honorius the FirÅ¿t. Baronius an. 627. A courteous Father, of S. Bernards Order here, did me the fauour to shew me neare the high Altar, this Head, and this
Picture. TheÅ¿e two are moÅ¿t authentical things; for the atteÅ¿tation of them is in the very Acts of the Å¿econd Concil of Nice held an. 789, where to prooue the lawfullneÅ¿Å¿ of Å¿acred Images againÅ¿t the IconoclaÅ¿ts,
â€¢â€¢ e Å¿acred Council cites a miracle wrought by this very picture of S. AnaÅ¿taÅ¿ius: Baron. An. 627 and an. 713. and Baronius quotes diuers others wrought by the Å¿ame picture.

The round Church.In the Å¿econd Church here, to wit, the little round Church on the righ â€¢ hand, there is a famous picture of S. Bernards ExtaÅ¿is. Vnder this Church I was led into a Vault where many of the bodyes of the foresayd ten thouÅ¿and ChriÅ¿tians, who were martyred with S. Zeno, are buryed. This vault goes a mile vnderground.

Tre Fontane.In the third place Å¿tands the little Church of the Tre Fontane, Å¿o called becauÅ¿e S. Paul was here beheaded, and where his head iumpt thrice, three fountains gushed out. Vpon an Altar on the left hand, is an excellent Picture of S. Peters crucifixion, of the hand of Guido
Rheni. On the other Å¿ide is Å¿een a little block (within an yron grate) vpon which they Å¿ay S. Pauls head was cut off.
Going from hence I went ouer the fields to the Church of the Annuntiata one of the nine Churches of Rome viÅ¿ited by Pilgrims;The Annunciata. and from thenc to S. SebaÅ¿tians.

S SebaÅ¿tians Church,
S. SebaÅ¿tians Church. is one of the Å¿eauen Churches, and of great deuotion by reaÅ¿on of the Catacombes which are vnder it. Here I Å¿aw the Tombe of S. SebaÅ¿tian vnder an altar on the left hand: many relicks kept ouer an altar on the right hand: and the Vault vnderneath where Pope Steuen was beheaded in his owne Seat of Å¿tone, and where S. Peters and S. Pauls bodyes were hidden many yeares.

Thenc I was let into the Catacombes which are vnder this Church, The Catacombes. and which from thenc running many miles vnder ground, made anciently a ChriÅ¿tian Rome vnder the Heathen. There were divers of theÅ¿e Catacombes in the primitiue
times, and they were called diuerÅ¿ly: Arenaria, Cryptae, Areae, Concilia Martyrum, Poliandria, but moÅ¿t frequently Caemeteria, that is, dormitoria, becauÅ¿e here repoÅ¿ed the bodyes of the holy Martyrs and Saints qui obdormiuerunt in Domino. But the greateÅ¿t of all theÅ¿e Caemeteria was this of Calixtus. Caemeterium Calixti. In theÅ¿e Catacombes dureing the perÅ¿ecutions rayÅ¿ed againÅ¿t the ChriÅ¿tians by ten Heathen Emperors, the faithfull beleeuers, together with their Popes and Pastors, vÅ¿ed priuatly to meet to excercice their Religion, and Å¿teale their deuotions; that is, to heare MaÅ¿Å¿e in little round Chappels painted ouer head poorely; MiniÅ¿ter the Sacraments; bury the dead Martyrs and ConfeÅ¿Å¿ors in the walls of the long alleys, preach, hold conferences; and euen celebrate Councils too Å¿ometimes. I deÅ¿cended Å¿eueral times into Å¿eueral parts of theÅ¿e Catacombes with a good experienced guide (which you muÅ¿t beÅ¿ure of) and with waxe lights (torches being too Å¿tifeling) and wandered
them vp and downe with extraordinary Å¿atisfaction of minde. The Å¿treets vnder ground are cut out with mens hands and mattocks. They are as high as a man, for the moÅ¿t part, & no broader then for two men to meet. All the way long, the Å¿ides of theÅ¿e Alleys are full of holes, as long as a man, and Å¿ometimes there are three rowes, one ouer an other, in which they had buryed their Martyrs and ConfeÅ¿sors: and that poÅ¿terity might afterwards know which were Martyrs, which ConfeÅ¿Å¿ors; they engraued vpon the Å¿tone which mur'd them vp, or vpon one of the bricks, a Palme branch, in Å¿igne of a Martyr; and a Pro ChriÅ¿to in Cyphers for a ConfeÅ¿Å¿or. Its recorded, that during the forÅ¿ayd perÅ¿ecutions, a hundred Å¿eauenty four thouÅ¿and Martyrs were buryed here in this Cametery of Calixtus: among whom were nineteen Popes Martyrs. Hence theÅ¿e Catacombes haue alwayes been eÅ¿teemed as a place of great deuotion, and much frequented by deuout perÅ¿ons. The words ouer the dore, as you deÅ¿cend
into them from the Church of S. SebaÅ¿tian, tell you, how S. Hierome confeÅ¿Å¿eth, S. Hierom. in Ezechiel. c. 40. that he vÅ¿ed euery Sunday and Holyday, during his Å¿tay in Rome, to go to theÅ¿e Catacombes. And a picture hung ouer the Å¿ame dore sheweth how S. Philip Neri vÅ¿ed to frequent theÅ¿e holy places in the night; and from whence, I beleeue, he Å¿ucked that true Å¿pirit of the primitiue Church, which reigned in him, and Å¿till reigneth in the breaÅ¿ts of his moÅ¿t vertuous children, the pious PrieÅ¿ts of the Oratory of Rome, whom I muÅ¿t alwayes prayÅ¿e whereÅ¿ouer I find them, becauÅ¿e I alwayes find them either writeing holy things, or liuing them; that is, either writeing books fit to be liued, or liuing liues fit to be written. Indeed its incredible how much the preÅ¿ence of theÅ¿e Holy Martyrs bodyes, hath Å¿anctifyed this place: in Å¿o much that no man enters into the catacombes but he comes better out, then he went in. Catholicks come out farre more willing to dye for that faith, for which Å¿o many of their anceÅ¿ters
haue dyed before them. The AduerÅ¿aryes of the Roman Church come out more Å¿taggered in their fayth, and more milde towards the Catholick Religion, to Å¿ee what piety there is euen in the bowels of Rome; AtheiÅ¿ts come out with that beleefâ–ª that Å¿urely there is a God, Å¿eing Å¿o many thouÅ¿ands of Martyrs haue teÅ¿tifyed it with their blood.

From S. SebaÅ¿tians I went to the place hard by called Capo di Boue Å¿tanding vpon the Via Appia. It is a great building faced about with marble Å¿tones. It was the Sepulcher of Metella wife of rich CraÅ¿Å¿us. Capo di Boue. Its now called Capo di Boue becauÅ¿e of the oxe heads cut in marble which compoÅ¿e the cornice that runns about the top of this Moles. Entering into it you will wonder at the thickneÅ¿Å¿ of the walls which are aboue eight ells thick. It was begun to be pulled downe, eÅ¿pecialy the great marble Å¿tones on the outÅ¿ide of it, to make vp the Fontana di Treui; but Cardinal Barberino would not Å¿uffer it to be Å¿o defaced.

CloÅ¿e by Å¿tand the ruines of the
Pretorium, The Pretorium. the Quarters of the Pretorian Bands, which the Emperours lodged here, a little out of the throng of the towne, that they might not occaÅ¿ion Å¿o eaÅ¿ily tumults; and that they might exerciÅ¿e themÅ¿elues often in the Circo of Caracalla which was hard by.

Circus CaracallaThis Circus was made by the Emperor Caracalla, and is the moÅ¿t entire of all the Circos that were in Rome. You Å¿ee where the Carceres, or Å¿tarting place was, where the Meta; where the Guglia were. You Å¿ee how long it was, and the walls yet show you what compaÅ¿Å¿e it carryed. In the midÅ¿t of it Å¿tood that Guglia which now Å¿tands in the midÅ¿t of Piazza Nauona. I Å¿aw it lye here broken in three peeces, and neglected quite till the Earle of Arundel our late Lord Mareshal, Offering to buy it & hauing already depoÅ¿itated threeÅ¿core crownes in earneÅ¿t for it, made the Romans begin to think that it was Å¿ome fine thing, and Å¿top the tranÅ¿porting of it into England. At laÅ¿t it light vpon a good Å¿tone-Å¿etter, who joyned
it Å¿o well together that it now Å¿tands Å¿treight againe vpon a rare baÅ¿is, and adornes the very heart of Rome: Thanks to that ingenious architect Caualier Bernini who Å¿et it vp there in the anno Sancto, & whom it Å¿et vp too againe in the Popes fauour Innocent the X. which he had loÅ¿t, by a crack in the roof of the Portch of S. Peters Church, cauÅ¿ed by the heauy Å¿teeple which he had placed vpon it.

Neare the end of the Circus of Caracalla, Å¿tands an old round Temple, The Temple Vertue & Honour. with an other little Ante-Temple, cloÅ¿e ioyned to it; and out of which you go into the other. what if this were the Temple of Honour? into which there was no paÅ¿Å¿age, but through the Temple of Vertue, which was ioyned cloÅ¿e to it, as this is: to manifeÅ¿t, that Vertue is the way to Honour. Now its certain that theÅ¿e two Temples Å¿tood not farre from the Porta Carpena (now called S. SebaÅ¿tians gate) as theÅ¿e two do. But I declare, that this is but gheÅ¿ing.

Hard by the forÅ¿ayd old Temple
there is an Eccho which heretofore (as they Å¿ay) would repeat after you a whole verÅ¿e of Virgil, The Eccho. but if Å¿o, it was my fortune to finde her when she had catched a cold: for I could get nothing from her but the two laÅ¿t words of a Å¿entence. Indeed AuÅ¿onius calls the Eccho, the tayle of words; and Å¿ympoÅ¿ius Å¿ayth, that the Eccho is like a modeÅ¿t Virgin: which Å¿peaks nothing but when she is asked.

Returning from S. SebaÅ¿tians towards the towne againe, I paÅ¿Å¿ed by a little Chappel called, Domine quo Vadis? and ancienthy called, Sancta Maria ad paÅ¿Å¿us. Its called Domine quo vadis? becauÅ¿e our Saviour appareing here to S. Peter flyeing out of the priÅ¿on of Rome, was asked by Peter, Domine, quo vadis? Domine quovadis. Lord whither go you? And he anÅ¿wered: Vado Romam vt ibi iterum â€¢ rucifigar. J am going to Rome, there to be crucifyed againe: which words Peter vnderÅ¿tanding rightly, of ChriÅ¿ts Å¿uffering in his members, the faithfull beleeuers, returned againe to Rome, and was Å¿oone after crucified.
In the middle of this Chappel are Å¿een the prints of our Sauiours feet in a white marble Å¿tone with an iron grate ouer them.

Entring into the towne by S. SebaÅ¿tians gate, I went on Å¿treight to the Church of S. Nereus and Achilleus,
S. Nereus and Achilleus of which Church Baronius was Cardinal. The bodyes of theÅ¿e Saints are vnder the High Altar. Cardinal Baronius cauÅ¿ed this Church to be painted with the hiÅ¿tories of Saints and martyrs, to excite others to deuotion by their exemples

AlmoÅ¿t ouer againÅ¿t this Church, San SiÅ¿to. Å¿tands the Church of S. SiÅ¿to with its monaÅ¿tery made famous by S. Dominick, who made it his habitation, and by whom God rought many miracles here. It Å¿tands in a moÅ¿t vnholeÅ¿ome place called anciently the PiÅ¿cina publica, becauÅ¿e the people vÅ¿ed to wash themÅ¿elues here. Here are buryed S. Sixtus, Antherus, Lucius, Lucianus, Sotherus, & Zepherinus, Popes and martyrs.
Heres a fine picture of S. Vincentius Ferrerius.
From thence I went towards the the Porta Latina, and there Å¿aw the Church where S. Iohn EuangeliÅ¿t was put into a caldron of boyling oyle. S. Iohn A â€¢ Portam Latinam.

Then Following the walls of the towne for a good while, I came at laÅ¿t to S. Iohn Laterans Church,
S. Iohn Laterans Church.
The Popes Cathedral. the mother-Church of all Churches in the world, and the Popes Cathedral. In Å¿aying this, I haue Å¿ayd enough; and I Å¿ay this after the words which are written in the architraue ouer the Portch of this Church, and after the Bull of Gregory the XI. who declared this Church to be the Popes chief Å¿eat, and to haue the preeminency ouer the other Churches, Orbis & Vrbis; euen ouer S. Peters Church too by name. It was built by ConÅ¿tanti â€¢ the Great vpon mount Caelius, and dedicated to our Sauiour himÅ¿elf, for whoÅ¿e Å¿ake it deÅ¿erueth the headship ouer all the other Churches in the world, as he, to whom it is dedicated, is the Head of all the Elect. yet it is called diuerÅ¿ly by EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Authors, Sometimes
BaÅ¿ilica ConÅ¿tantiniana, becauÅ¿e ConÅ¿tantin built it: Å¿ometimes BaÅ¿ilica Saluatoris, becauÅ¿e it was dedicated to our Sauiour. Sometimes BaÅ¿ilica S. Ioannis, becauÅ¿e it was neare to the two Chappels dedicated to the two S. Iohns, in the Baptistery of ConÅ¿tantin: Å¿ometimes it was called, BaÅ¿ilica S. Ioannis in Laterano, or S. Iohn Laterans Church, becauÅ¿e it was built vpon the place where Plautius Lateranus the deÅ¿igned ConÅ¿ul, had a fair houÅ¿e and a garden, which Nero the Tyrant made bold withall, hauing firÅ¿t made bold with their maÅ¿ter, by killing him. Now this,Tacitus, and Iuuenal. Å¿at. 10. and the other great Churches of Rome are called BaÅ¿ilicae, either becauÅ¿e they are built after a Royal and Å¿tately manner, or elÅ¿ becauÅ¿e they are built to the King of Kings.

As for this Church of S. Iohn Lateran, It is here that the Pope taketh poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of his Papal charge, after he hath been choÅ¿en, and conÅ¿ecrated Bishop (yf he were none before) in S. Peters Church. For this reaÅ¿on all the chief EpiÅ¿copal
functions of the particular DioceÅ¿e of Rome, are performed here; as the conÅ¿ecrating of Bishops and PrieÅ¿ts, the conferring of the Sacrament of Confirmation: the Baptizeing of conuerted Iewes and Infidels. For this reaÅ¿on its looked vpon by the Popes with great reÅ¿pect, and hath been not onely beautifyed by them with coÅ¿tly decorations, Å¿uch as thoÅ¿e, that Clement the VIII, and Innocent the X made; but alÅ¿o fauoured by them with great prerogatiues; one declareing by his Papal Decree, that this is the Mother Church of all Churches; another fixeing her the euery altar it Å¿elf (of wood) on which S. Peter and the primitiue Popes had offered Sacrifice; another allowing the Clergy if this Church the precedency ouer the Clergy of all other Churches in publick proceÅ¿sions, and to carry before them two Crucifixes; another fixeing here the Heads of Saint Peter and Saint Paul.
As for the things moÅ¿t to betaken notice of here, they are theÅ¿e.
1. The Soffita or roof of this Church moÅ¿t richly guilt.
2. The body of the Church all made new almoÅ¿t by Pope Innocent the X, as to the inÅ¿ide of it.

3. The rare painting that runns croÅ¿Å¿e the Church from the Å¿tately Organs to the Altar of the B. Sacrament, containing the chief actions of ConÅ¿tantin the Great, and other hiÅ¿tories. That of the AÅ¿cenÅ¿ion of our Sauiour, with the ApoÅ¿tles looking vp after him, is of the hand of Caualier GioÅ¿eppe. The HiÅ¿tories and figures about the Chariot of ConÅ¿tantin, are of the hand of Bellardino. That of the apparition of our Sauiour, that of Mount Soracte, that oueragainÅ¿t ConÅ¿tantins BaptiÅ¿me, are all of the hand of Paris Romano. That of the BaptiÅ¿me of ConÅ¿tantin is of the hand of Caualier Ricelli. In the Quire of the Canons the picture of the S. John is of the haÌ„d of Cauallier GioÅ¿eppe. In fine, the picture of our Sauiour in the very Tribuno, or AbÅ¿ide, was the firÅ¿t picture that appeared publickly in
Rome, and which was miraculouÅ¿ly coÌ„Å¿erued in the burning of this church There are diuers in others pictures in that Vaulted Tribun in MaÅ¿aick worke; and Å¿ome Å¿imbolical figures relating to our Sauiours life and paÅ¿Å¿ion, which were much vÅ¿ed anciently in Churches, as you may Å¿ee in many other Churches, and in the rare booke called, Roma Soterranea.

5. The Altar of the B. Sacrament adorned by the coÅ¿t of Clement the VIII, With a curious and pretious Tabernacle of rich polished Å¿tones, and with four pillars of braÅ¿Å¿e guilt, about fifteen foot high. Ouer this Altar is the Table it Å¿elf vpon which our Sauiour eat the PaÅ¿chal Lambe before his PaÅ¿Å¿ion, and then preÅ¿ently inÅ¿tituted the Holy Sacrament, of which the PaÅ¿chal Lambe was but a figure.
6. The braÅ¿en Tombe of Martin the V, of the houÅ¿e of Colonna, who was choÅ¿en Pope in the Council of ConÅ¿tance.
7. The Tombe of Alexander the III, of the houÅ¿e of Bandinelli in Siena, neatly adorned by Pope Alexander the VII, who tooke his name of Alexander from him.

8. The Tombe of Laurentius Valla
a learned Roman, and Chanon of this Church; of whom, as the reÅ¿torer of pure Latin language after Gotick BarbarouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿, Latonius Å¿ung thus:Apud â€¢ um in Elog. doct â€¢ r. viror.
Romulus eÅ¿t Vrbis, Valla eÅ¿t idiomatis author:
Hic reparat primus, primus vt ille Å¿tr â€¢ it.

9. In old Gotick Letters vpon the Architraue of the portch of this Church you read theÅ¿e Leonine verÅ¿es,
Dogmate Papali datur ac Å¿imul Jmperiali.
QuÃ²d Å¿im Cunctarum Mater & Caput EccleÅ¿iarum.

10. In the CloiÅ¿ter of this Church, I Å¿aw the Chaire of Porphiry, which vÅ¿eth to be placed neare to the Great dore of the Church on that day the Pope taketh poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of his charge in this Church; in which Chaire the Pope is placed a while, and at his riÅ¿eing from it againe, the Quire Å¿ings this verÅ¿e of the 112 PÅ¿alme, SuÅ¿citat de puluere egenum & de Å¿tercore eregit pauperem: and this Ceremony and pierced Chair are onely to put the
Pope in minde of his humane infirmityes, Caeremia le Roma num l. 1 Å¿ect. 2. c. 3. amidÅ¿t His glorious exaltations, and the peoples applauÅ¿es. For Å¿o alÅ¿o the Greek Emperors on the day of their coronation, had a great many marble Å¿tones, of Å¿eueral colours, preÅ¿ented to them, to chooÅ¿e which of them they would, to make their Tombe of. This was,Zenar. and Cedren. to put them in mind of their mortality admidÅ¿t thoÅ¿e great honours.

But its Å¿trange to Å¿ee how the enemies of the Popes, giue out maliciouÅ¿ly, that this Chair (whoÅ¿e vÅ¿e we Å¿ee Å¿o plainly in the vety Ceremonial of Rome) was onely intended, ad explorandum Å¿exum, and to hinder the inconueniency of another Pope Ioanne. For this reaÅ¿on I think it not amiÅ¿Å¿e to examin a little this fable of a shee Pope, or of a Pope Ioanne.

I am not affrayd at all to call this a fable, The Fable of Pope Ioanne. both for the vnlikelineÅ¿Å¿e of it in generall; as alÅ¿o for the Å¿uÅ¿pected authority of its firÅ¿t broachers; the contrarietyes in the Å¿tory; and the little credit giuen
vnto it by the learnedeÅ¿t aduerÅ¿aryes of the Roman Church. FirÅ¿t, what can be more vnlikely then that a woman should Å¿urpriÅ¿e Å¿uch a wiÅ¿e nation as the Italians are,VnlikelineÅ¿s of this fable. and Å¿o groÅ¿Å¿ely? what more vnlikely, then that a woman should paÅ¿Å¿e her youth in thoÅ¿e Å¿euere Å¿tudyes, which are required in Popes, without being knowne to have wrongd, or diÅ¿couered her Å¿exe; and that she muÅ¿t juÅ¿t do it, when she was in a declineing age, at which age Popes ordinarily are choÅ¿en? What more vnlikely, then that a woman findeing her Å¿elf great with child, should venture to go Å¿o farre a foot in a proceÅ¿Å¿ion? What more vnlikely, then that, if there had been Å¿uch a shee Pope, the Greek Church (which then was at odds with the Roman Church) should haue paÅ¿Å¿ed it ouer in Å¿ilence, and not haue obraided her with Å¿uch a diÅ¿gracefull PaÅ¿tor, eÅ¿pecially Å¿eing the Roman Church had obraided the Greek Church with hauing an Eunuch for her chief Patriarch? What in fine more vnlikely then that there should haue
been Å¿uch a shee Pope Å¿o publikly conuinced to haue been a woman, & that AnaÅ¿taÅ¿ius Bibliothecarius who worte the liues of the Popes Å¿ome thirty yeares after that pretended time, and who muÅ¿t haue liued in her time, Å¿peaks nothing of any Å¿uch woman,Enemyes charge no proof. or any Å¿uch Å¿trange accident?

Secondly, the firÅ¿t broachers of this Å¿tory make it Very much Å¿uÅ¿pected, Å¿eing Martinus Polonus, and Å¿ome others of the Emperors faction (then at Vari â€¢ nce with the Popes) are the firÅ¿t that mentioned this fable: and Platina, HearÅ¿ay no conuiction who quotes no higher authors for it, grounds a Å¿tory of this conÅ¿equence vpon no better authority then a weake, Å¿i dice, us fayd.

Thirdly, the apparent contradictions in the Tale, Contradiction in the tale, a Å¿igne of falÅ¿ity. conuince it of falÅ¿ity: as that this Ioanne was an English woman borne in Mentz, which all men know to be a Rhenish towne in Germany: and that she had Å¿tudyed at Athenes in Greece, which long before this time had been deÅ¿troyed.

Fourthly, the little credit giuen
to it by the learnedeÅ¿t aduerÅ¿aryes of the Roman Church, AduerÅ¿aryes confeÅ¿Å¿e it to be a fable. to wit, four prime Ministers of France (who take this hiÅ¿tory for a meere fable) proues Å¿ufficiently that its worÅ¿e then an old wifes tale. For M. Blondel a French MiniÅ¿ter (whom I knew in Paris aboue twenty yeares ago) and a man of that account there, that he was choÅ¿en to anÅ¿wer the learned booke of Cardinal Peron: this Blondel, I Å¿ay, made a booke in French (printed at Amsterdam by Bleau Anno 1647 in octauo) On purpoÅ¿e to shew, that this Å¿tory of a shee Pope called Joanne, was a meere fable. And that we may not think that Blondel alone of all ProteÅ¿tant MiniÅ¿ters, held this for a Fable, MonÅ¿ieur Serrauius a great CaluiniÅ¿t and CounÅ¿elor of the Parlament of Paris, in a letter of his to SalmaÅ¿ius, hauing mentioned to him this booke of Blondel, addeth theÅ¿e words:EpiÅ¿t. Serrauii Noli autem credere primum aut Å¿olum Ã¨ nostris Blondellum ita Å¿enÅ¿iÅ¿Å¿e: quamuis FortaÅ¿Å¿is nemo vnquam fortius & preÅ¿Å¿ius iÅ¿tud Å¿olum
conclaueait. Fuere enim in eadem Å¿ententia non incelebres inter Reformatos Theologi: & adhuc vigent in hac Vrbe inÅ¿ignes fide & pietate viri, Chamier. qui audierunt ex ore Camerii, Å¿e iÅ¿tam hiÅ¿toriam Vulgo creditam, fabuloÅ¿is deputare. Vidi nuper Å¿criptas literas docti & vegeti Å¿enis, tibique & mihi amiciÅ¿Å¿imi, Petri Molinaei, Du Moulin. quibus idem Å¿emper Å¿ibi eÅ¿Å¿e viÅ¿um affirmabat.

Penes me Å¿unt literae Samuelis Bocharti, Bochart. quibus teÅ¿tatur Å¿ibi eÅ¿Å¿e pro comperto vanum & fictitium, quicquid hactenus de ea Å¿it proditum. Thus MonÅ¿ieur Serrauius in a priuate letter (though his Å¿onn after his death printed his litters) to a freind of the Å¿ame religion: And thus you Å¿ee, how this fable maintained highly a long time by the AduerÅ¿aries of the Roman Church, expired at laÅ¿t (as all lyes do) and was carryed to its graue vpon the shoulders of four French MiniÅ¿ters, Blondel, Chamier, du Moulin, and Bochart. If I haue been a little too long in this digreÅ¿Å¿ion you will pardon me: We are all debtors to
Truth; and all men ought to be glad to Å¿ee themÅ¿elues diÅ¿abuÅ¿ed.

The BapiÅ¿tery of ConÅ¿tantine.Going out of the little back dore of this Church, I went to Å¿ee the BaptiÅ¿tery of ConÅ¿tantin the Great, Our moÅ¿t Noble Countryman, and the firÅ¿t Emperour that publickly profeÅ¿Å¿ed ChriÅ¿tianity. This BaptiÅ¿tery is built round, and in the center of it, in a deÅ¿cent of four Å¿teps, Å¿tands the very Font, in which the Å¿ayd Emperor was baptized by Pope Syluester. Its enuironed with low rayles of marble, and adorned with ten, or twelue great pillars of Porphyrie (the faireÅ¿t in Rome) which beare vp the painted Vault ouer the Font: Å¿o that people Å¿tandin about theÅ¿e rayles, may Å¿ee conueniently the baptizeing of Jewes and Infidels in the pitt below. Vpon the Walls of the round Chappel, are painted in FreÅ¿co, the moÅ¿t memorable actions of ConÅ¿tantin the Great: as his ViÅ¿ion of the CroÅ¿Å¿e in the ayre, with theÅ¿e words aboue it, In hoc Å¿igno Vinces: his ouercomeing the Tyrant Maxentius; his baptiÅ¿me here by S. SilueÅ¿ter:
his burning the Libels againÅ¿t Catholike Bishops, preferred to him by the Arrians: his kiÅ¿Å¿ing the wounds of thoÅ¿e good Bishop in the Council of Nice, who had either their fingars cut off, or one eye put out by the Tyrants.

On the other Å¿ide of S. Iohn Laterans Church, Å¿tands the Scala Santa, The Scala Santa. and the Sancta Sanctorum. The Scala Santa is called from the Å¿tairs, twenty eight in all, vp which our Sauiour was led in this paÅ¿Å¿ion to Pilats houÅ¿e. Vpon Å¿ome of them you Å¿ee the places where the pretious blood of our Sauiour had fallen: and for that reaÅ¿on they are couered with little grates of braÅ¿Å¿e, which let in eyes, but keep of knees: I Å¿ay kneeÅ¿; for none go vp theÅ¿e holy Å¿tairs otherwiÅ¿e then kneeling, and this out of reuerence to him who often fell vpon his knees, as he was draggd vp and downe theÅ¿e Å¿tairs. Its painfull enough to go vp theÅ¿e Å¿tairs vpon your knees; yet I Å¿aw it done hourly in the Iubily yeare, by continual flocks of deuout people both men and women; of
great condition as well as of great deuotioÌ„ â–ª theÅ¿e holy Å¿taires were Sent from HieruÅ¿alem to ConÅ¿tantin the Great, by his Moter Queen Helen, together with many other Relicks kept in S. Iohn Laterans Church. They are of whit marble, and aboue Å¿ix foot long.

The Å¿ancta Sanctorum.At the head of theÅ¿e Å¿tairs Å¿tands the Chappel called Sancta Sanctorum, becauÅ¿e of the Holy things kept in it. Hence ouer the Altar in this Chappel, are written theÅ¿e words.
div.q: Non eÅ¿t in toto Sanctior Orbe Locus.
div.p:
Vpon the Altar is kept the miraculous picture of our Sauiour, it repreÅ¿ents him about thirteen yeares old,See Pancirola. and onely his half body. Its about a foot & a halfe long: and its Å¿ayd to haue been begun by S. Luke, but ended miraculouÅ¿ly by an Angel. Others Å¿ay,Lib. Della Nottia de Æ²ocaboli EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tici, in verbo Achyropoeta. that S. Luke hauing onely prepared the ground, and before he had drawne one Å¿troke, fell to his prayers to beg of God that he might draw his Son right, and riÅ¿eing vp againe he found his picture already finished. Hence Domenico Magri (a learned Antiquarie) is of opinion, that this
pisture of our Sauiour is that very picture which AnaÅ¿taÅ¿ius B â€¢ bliothecarius in the life of Steuen the II, calls Achyropaeta, that is, made without hands. Round about this picture goes a Å¿et of great iewels enriching the frame of it. Vnder the Altar repoÅ¿eth the body of S. AnaÅ¿taÅ¿ius, of whoÅ¿e head and picture I Å¿poke aboue in the deÅ¿cription of the Church of this Saint at the Tre Fontane. Here are alÅ¿o kept the Heads of S. Agnes and S. Praxedes, with many other pretious Relicks.. Anciently, (as the Records here mention) the Holy Prepuce, or Foreshin of our Sauiour was kept here too: but being taken away in the Å¿ack of Rome, by one of Bourbons Å¿oldiers, it was left in a a country towne called Calcata, Calcata. Å¿ome fifteen wiles diÅ¿tant from Rome by the Å¿ame Å¿oldier,Menochio Centuria 1. c. 10. who could not reÅ¿t day nor night, as long as he had that relick about him. I once paÅ¿Å¿ed by that towne (Calcata) by chance, and by the ciuilityes of the Lord of the towne, Count of Anguillara, at whoÅ¿e houÅ¿e we were nobly entertained all night, had the happineÅ¿Å¿
the next morning, to Å¿ee this pretious Relick through the cryÅ¿tal caÅ¿e: This Count keeps one key of it, and the Parish PrieÅ¿t the other, without both which it cannot be Å¿een.

Triclinium LeonisNeare to the Scala Santa is Å¿een a famous peece of Antiquity of ChriÅ¿tian Rome, called Triclinium Leonis: where is Å¿een a MoÅ¿aick picture of our Sauiour reÅ¿uÅ¿citated, and holding out a booke to his DiÅ¿ciples, in which are written theÅ¿e words: Pax vobis: Peace be to you: Which picture Leo cauÅ¿ed to be made eight hundred yeares ago, as an emblem of his peaceable returne againe to his Å¿eat, after he had been chaÅ¿ed out by his enemyes. Vpon a pillar on the right hand, is painted our Sauiour Å¿itting vpon a Throne, and giuing with one hand, the Keys of the Church to S. Peter, and with the other, the Imperial Å¿tandard to ConÅ¿tantin the Great. Vpon the other pillar on the left hand, is repreÅ¿ented in MoÅ¿aick worke alÅ¿o, S. Peter Å¿itting in a Chair, and with one hand giuing vnto Pope Leo the III the Papal
Å¿tole; and with the other, the Imperial Å¿tandard vnto Charlemagne, who had reÅ¿tored this Pope Leo to his Å¿eat againe.

From hence paÅ¿Å¿ing againe by S. Iohn Lateran â€¢ Church, I Å¿aw firÅ¿t, the pallace of the Pope here, built by Sixtus Quintus: then the great Guglia (with Egyptian Hyeroglyphes figured vpon it) which had Å¿tood anciently in the Circus Maximus: its aboue 100 foot high, & was brought from Alexandria to Rome by ConÅ¿tantin the Great â–ª laÅ¿tly in a low roome ioyning to the Church, I Å¿aw the Statue in Bronze of Henry the IV of France, Å¿et vp here by the Canons of S. Iohn Laterans, for hauing cauÅ¿ed ten thouÅ¿and crownes a yeare to be reÅ¿toreÅ¿t to this Church, which was due to it in France.

I looked alÅ¿o into the faire HoÅ¿pital which Å¿tands hard by the foreÅ¿ayd Church, The HoÅ¿pitall of S. Iohn Laterans. and Å¿o well Å¿erued and tended, that many perÅ¿on of quality in their Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿ deÅ¿ire to be transferred hither, that they may be better looked to, then they can be at home.

S. Stefano Rotondo.Takeing the wall of the old Aquiduct of Claudius along with me I went to San Stefano Rotondo, Å¿tanding vpon the Mount Caelius too. This Church now belongs to the SeminariÅ¿ts of the German Colledge. Vpon the round walls are painted curiouÅ¿ly the martyrdoms of ancient martyrs, with the diuers inÅ¿truments of the Heathens, wherewith they tormented the poore ChriÅ¿tians.

S. Maria in Nauicella.Ouer againÅ¿t this Church Å¿tands the Church of Santa Maria della Nauicella, Å¿o called from a little Å¿tone ship which Å¿tands before it, being a vow of certain boatmen. This Church in ancient authors, is called in Dominica, or in Ciriaca becauÅ¿e of a holy woman called Ciriaca, in whoÅ¿e houÅ¿e here, S. Laurence diÅ¿tributed all the Church goods, hee as Deacon had in his hands, vnto the poore.

Villa Mathei.Hard by Å¿tands the Villa of the Duke Matthei, where I Å¿aw the neat houÅ¿e full of curious Å¿tatues, and cruÅ¿ted on the outÅ¿ide with rare anticaglie. Among the reÅ¿t I tooke particular notice of the Heads of
Brutus and Porcia, man & wife in one Å¿tone: the Å¿tatues of Cleopatra: of Hercules: of three little boyes Å¿leeping and hugging one another: the head of Cicero rarely wel cut: the Å¿tatue of Marcus Aurelius. A rare table of pretious Å¿tones. In an other houÅ¿e here (looking towards San SiÅ¿to) I Å¿aw the incomparable Statue of Andromeda expoÅ¿ed to the Sea MonÅ¿ter, its of pure white marble, and of the hand of Oliuiero. That other there of Apollo fleaing MarÅ¿ias, is an excellent peece too, and in white marble: Å¿o is alÅ¿o that of the Satyre pluking a thorne out of his foot. The curious alley, waterworks, grotts, walkes, wetting places, and the intricate labyrinth, are all very delightsome.

DeÅ¿cending from hence I went to the old Amphitheater, The Amphiteat â€¢ r. called now the ColiÅ¿eo, becauÅ¿e of a ColoÅ¿Å¿ean Å¿tatue that Å¿tood in it. This is one of the rareÅ¿t peeces of antiquity in Rome; and though Rome be growne againe, by her new pallaces, one of the fineÅ¿t Cyties of Europe, yet her very ruines are finer then her new buildings.

But the beÅ¿t Å¿tatue here, is that of the yong man picking a thorne out of his foot. Its onely of braÅ¿Å¿e, but worth its weight in gold. The Å¿tory of it is this. A yong foot poste bringing letters of Å¿ingular importance vnto the Senate, and pricking his foot as he ran, would not Å¿tay to pick out the thorne; but haÅ¿tening to Rome with all Å¿peed, deliuered his letters in full Senate prodigiouÅ¿ly Å¿oone, as it appeared by their dates. But then claping
himÅ¿elf downe vpon the ground before them all, he began to pick out the thorne, in the poÅ¿ture you Å¿ee him here. The Senate Å¿eing the haÅ¿te he had made, and the payne he had endured, decreed preÅ¿ently that his Å¿tatue in that poÅ¿ture, should be erected in the Capitol.

Thus the old Romans not hauing then recompences enough for well deÅ¿eruing men, or elÅ¿e not willing to recompence them otherwiÅ¿e, perÅ¿uaded men, that no recompence was like to that of a Å¿tatue in the Capitol, or to walke vp and downe the Å¿treets with a crowne of Laurel, or Oake leaues vpon their heads. Poore fooles! Was a crowne of leaues Å¿uch an honour, when euen baudy houÅ¿es and priuyes, Saith Tertullian, Tertul. de Corona Milit. Were crowned too? Or was it Å¿uch a Å¿olid honour to haue a Å¿tatue in the Capitol, when geeÅ¿e, and woolfes were honored Å¿o too? But quod rarum, charum eÅ¿t. Seneca l. 1. de Benefi. c. 13. And as Alexander the Great hearing that the Corinthians would make him a Citizen of their towne, Å¿corned it at firÅ¿t: but after he had been aÅ¿Å¿ured
that they neuer offered that honour to any man but to Hercules and him, he was well pleaÅ¿ed with that offer: Å¿o the rarity of hauing a Å¿tatue in the Capitol being an honour granted to few, and thoÅ¿e well deÅ¿eruing men, made men think it the higheÅ¿t of recompences. Among thoÅ¿e few, where Scipio, for hauing ouercomne Antiochus: Aemilius Lepidus for hauing, while he was but yet a boy, freed a Roman citizen in a battle: Metellus for Å¿auing the Palladium out of the burning Temple of VeÅ¿tae: Cornelia for hauing furnished corne to the people in a dearth, out of her owne moneys, and Å¿ome few others.

DeÅ¿cending againe into the garden I Å¿aw Å¿tore of wetting Å¿ports, and water workes, moÅ¿t curiouÅ¿ly coÌ„triueed:

For this cruel Emperor with his aÅ¿Å¿ociat Maximian, condemned forty thouÅ¿and ChriÅ¿tians to worke in this building for the Å¿pace of fifteen yeares together, and afterwards condemned many thouÅ¿ands of them to death for their religion. Thus men work for Tyrants. But Å¿uch is the wonderfull prouidence of God: Churches of ChriÅ¿tians now Å¿tand where Christians were condemned to death and torments. The blood of theÅ¿e martyrs was but the Å¿eed of ChriÅ¿tians; and when Diocletian condemned ChriÅ¿tians to worke here, me thinks he did but bid them go lay the foundation of a MonaÅ¿tery for CarthuÅ¿ians, and of a Church for the worship of that God he Å¿o much perÅ¿ecuted.

Hauing Å¿een this Church and MonaÅ¿tery, I went to Å¿ee the Popes Graneries, The Popes Graneries vaÅ¿t buildings two Å¿tories high, and alwayes full of wheat for the
preÅ¿ent vÅ¿e of the whole city. A world of officers and ouerÅ¿eers belong to theÅ¿e Graneries, and are alwayes turning ouer, and keeping the vaÅ¿t heapes of wheat from Å¿poyling and corrupting. The Church of S. Agnes.From theÅ¿e Graneries I went to the towne Gate, not farre off, called Porta Pia, and from thence Å¿treight along for a good mile, to S. AgneÅ¿es Church. From hence croÅ¿Å¿ing ouer the fields, I went to BorgheÅ¿is Villa and garden,BurgheÅ¿is Villa. which are a little half mile from the towne. This is the greateÅ¿t Villa thats about Rome. Å¿tatues of all Å¿izes, banqueting places Grottas, wetting Å¿ports, and a Å¿tately pallace adorned with Å¿o many rare Å¿tatues and pictures, that their names make a booke in octauo, which I referre you to. 2. In an other roome Å¿tands the Å¿tatue of one of the famous gladiators anciently, who fought alone againÅ¿t twenty others, and being wounded to death Å¿eems to threaten with his lookes all his beholders. Its terribly well made.
3. In one of the chambers aboue, is the head in profile of Alexander the Great cut in marble.

I Å¿aw here alÅ¿o Some toyes for yong men; as the clock which being wound vp playeth a tuneable dance, and little men and women of iron painted hanÅ¿omely, dance in a ring to that tune by vertue of the wheeles. Returning from this villa by the back dore which leadeth to the Porta del Populo, I Å¿tept into the Church of Madonna del Populo. Madonna del Populo. Going on from hence on the left hand, towards the Piazza di Spagna, I firÅ¿t paÅ¿Å¿ed by the great Guglia, or Egyptian pyramid carued all ouer with Hieroglyphs. Mounting from hence on the left hand,The Villa of the great Duke. to the top of the hill by the coach way, I went into the Æ²illa

Going out from this garden by the back dore, I croÅ¿Å¿ed ouer the Å¿treet, and was preÅ¿ently at the backdore alÅ¿o of the Villa LudouiÅ¿ia, Villa LudouiÅ¿ia. belonging to the Prince LudouiÅ¿io. Oriental polished IaÅ¿per. Here PhaÃ«ton in his Chariot in a Cameo, with the wheels of his Chariot of pretious Å¿tones; and a world of Å¿uch rich worke, which makes this BedÅ¿tead the non plus of art and magnificence, I do not know for all that, why beds should be made of Å¿tones though pretious ones. If it be for the PrinceÅ¿Å¿e of this houÅ¿e to be brought to bed in, it po â€¢ tends vnto her a hard labour: if to lodge in it the euerlaÅ¿ting Fame of the greatneÅ¿Å¿ of this Family, its a vaine labour; Å¿eing pretious Å¿tones will moulter â€¢ way in time, as other Å¿tones doe
â€¢ mnia mortalia mortalitati damnata.
for my part, the beÅ¿t vÅ¿e I know for it, is, to lay the petrifyed man in, whom we shall finde preÅ¿ently in the other pallace of this Villa: beds of Å¿tone are fitteÅ¿t for men of stone.

From hence croÅ¿Å¿ing through the garden, The Å¿econd houÅ¿e. Paul: Diuers curious pictures of the hand of Titian, Raphael, Michel Angelo, Carraccio and others: a rare head in marble of Scipio Affricanus: the head of Seneca in buÅ¿to of great value. One peece of the leg (broken to aÅ¿Å¿ure an embaÅ¿Å¿ador doubting of the verity of the thing) shewed me plainly both the bone and the Å¿tone cruÅ¿ted ouer it. The head and the other parts lye iumbled vp together in the boxe. Indeed I neuer Å¿aw a body Å¿o neatly entombed as this: you would Å¿weare that this Tombe is a pure IuÅ¿taucorps rather then a Tombe: it Å¿itts as cloÅ¿e as if a Tayler had made it. And that you may not think it an impoÅ¿Å¿ible thing. that men should be thus petrifyed,Ortelius in Tab. Geograph RuÅ¿Å¿iae. I muÅ¿t minde you what Ortelius Å¿ayth, that vpon the mountaines Å¿ituated in

The Church of TrinitÃ di MonteFrom hence I went Å¿treight on to the Minims of TrinitÃ di Monte belonging to France and S. Francis of Paula â€¢ Order. DeÅ¿cending from hence into the Piazza di Spagna, Piazza di Spagna I Å¿aw the fountain of the ship, which in Å¿ommer nights they let ouer flow, to coole the Piazza and the neighboring Å¿treets. Fontana de Treui.From hence I Å¿teered to the Piazza of the Fontana de Treui, and in my way, Å¿aw diuers Å¿tately pallaces inhabited by Cardinals, becauÅ¿e they Å¿tand neere the Foot of Montecauallo where the Pope reÅ¿ides. The Maronites Colledge.From hence I went nearer vnto the foot of the hill of Montecauallo, and Å¿tept into the Colledge of the Maronites, in whoÅ¿e Church, I heard them Å¿inging MaÅ¿Å¿e in their owne language, and after their owne rites, as the ChriÅ¿tians of Mount Libanus haue immemorably vÅ¿ed to do. From hence I went to the Church of the SS. Apostoli built in honour of the twelue ApoÅ¿tles by ConÅ¿tantin the Great, SS. ApoÅ¿toli. who in honour of thoÅ¿e holy ApoÅ¿tles, carryed out of the foundation twelue baskets of earth vpon his owne shoulders. In this Church lye buryed S. Philip and Iacob two ApoÅ¿tles.
