CroÅ¿Å¿ing from hence into the CorÅ¿o I tooke an exact obÅ¿eruation of this Å¿treet,The CorÅ¿o which is the faireÅ¿t in Rome. Its called the CorÅ¿o, becauÅ¿e here it is that they make horÅ¿es run againÅ¿t horÅ¿es, Iews againÅ¿t Iews, boyes againÅ¿t boyes, and the like, in Carneual time. Here alÅ¿o it is, that the MaÅ¿carades march in Carneual time, and make themÅ¿elues and others merry: and and all this is allowed the Italians that they may giue a little vent to their Å¿pirits which haue been Å¿tifled in for a whole yeare, and are ready els to choke with grauity and melancholy;
moÅ¿t men here liuing alone in their houÅ¿es and chambers. If our StateÅ¿men in England had gone on in the courÅ¿e their wiÅ¿e ancestours had shewed, and had Å¿uffered, as they did, Å¿ome honeÅ¿t recreations to the people, as bowling, shooting, raceing &c, to giue vent to their actiue Å¿pirits, we had all been happyer: but while both the Tribunals, and the Pulpits thundered out againÅ¿t moderate recreations and aÅ¿Å¿emblyes, out of feare and faction, they made the humour of the Englishmen grow Å¿o Å¿owre and bitter, that nothing would pleaÅ¿e them, but flat rebellion, and fanatick hereÅ¿ies. Now here in Rome, once a yeare, In Carneual time euery one vents his humour according to his fancy, and (as it Å¿eems) according to his need. One playes the Doctor of the Law, and goes vp and downe the Å¿treets with his booke in his hand diÅ¿puteing with euery man he meets and vttering pure raillerie: and if by chance two Å¿uch Doctors meet, they make Å¿port enough for half an houre by
their abuÅ¿eing one another. Four of theÅ¿e pretended Doctors, with their gownes and caps on, and their bookes of the Codex before them, got an AÅ¿Å¿e into their coach who had alÅ¿o an open booke before him; and thus they went along the Å¿treets Å¿tudyeing, and turning ouer their bookes. Another takes himÅ¿elf to be a Grand Cyrus, and goes a horÅ¿eback with a rich PerÅ¿ian habit and Plumes highly mounted. One went a foot grauely with a cloake on, & cryed a Å¿ecret againÅ¿t mice, and opening his cloake, shewd a cat that he had vnder his arme? Another went vp and downe the Å¿treet combeing his haire like a Å¿paniard Å¿aluting the Ladyes and twirling vp his muÅ¿taches with a Å¿tayed grauity. Some go in coaches and there play on inÅ¿truments: others go on great carts, with little Å¿tages of bordes throwne vpon them, and there act little playes as they go along, and abuÅ¿e tradsmen. One rides like a phyÅ¿itian vpon a mule with a world of vrinals hung round about him. Others ride grauely
through the Å¿treets with great clackbags behinde them as if they came from Polonia. Some Princes here make glorious Carro's, with four horÅ¿es on a breaÅ¿t drawing them, and with rare pageants vpon them, and a great traine of horÅ¿emen and trumpeters, clad exotically, accompanying the Carro in a moÅ¿t glorious manner. Some noblemen of higheÅ¿t quality, as Dukes, and Princes, I haue Å¿een going a foot pelting with Å¿ugar plums thoÅ¿e that were in coaches and windowes; and angering them with their Å¿ugar affronts. But neuer did any MaÅ¿carade pleaÅ¿e like that Å¿peculatiue Italian who mocked both the French and the Spaniards at once, by walking vp and downe the Å¿treet clad half like a Don, and half like a MonÅ¿ieur. OneÅ¿ide of his haire hung downe in a long curled lock powdered white: the other Å¿ide was black and Å¿weaty Half of his beard was turned downewards: the other half was turned vp with yrons and twirled in like the hilt of an old dragger. One eye
was bare: and the other had a glaÅ¿Å¿e, or half Å¿pectacle before it held on by a Å¿mall wyar from vnder his hat. Half his hat was a narrow three-fingered-brimd hat, with a little half feather vpon the brim: the other half of it was a broad brim with out Å¿o much as a hat band. One half of his band about his neck was of a broad bonlace Å¿tartched white: the other half was made of courÅ¿e lawne Å¿tartched blew and Å¿tanding out vpon a picky illy of wyar. Half of his face looked white with meale and pouder: the other half looked black and tawny. Half of his doublet was white Å¿atin with an open Å¿leeue and a world of shirt huffing about his wriÅ¿t and half of his waÅ¿te: the other half was of black freeze with a black taffetty Å¿leeue cloÅ¿e and Å¿trait to the arme, and a hanging Å¿leeue of freeze. One half of his breeches was of Å¿carlat and vaÅ¿tly wide at the knee, with a confuÅ¿io of rubans of Å¿ix colours: the other half was of black taffety cloÅ¿e at th â€¢ knee. Vpon one leg he had a linenen
Å¿tocking with a great laced canon turned downe to his half leg: on the other he had a black Å¿ilk Å¿tocking drawne vp cloÅ¿e. In fine, on one foote he had a white Å¿panish-leather shoo, with a Å¿tiff knot of Å¿ix coloured ruband a quarter of an ele long: on the other a little black flat Å¿oled shoo tyed with a short narrow ruband. Thus this moral Hermaphrodite and walking Emblem of peace betwen the two nations, walked vp and downe the CorÅ¿o grauely; yet laughing within himÅ¿elf, to Å¿ee how he carryed about him two Å¿uch antipathetical nations in one Å¿ute of clothes. By this you may geÅ¿Å¿e at their other fooleries in Carneual time, and Å¿ee how innocently they diuert themÅ¿elues: for you muÅ¿t know, that none are Å¿uffered to carry Å¿words or armes while they go masked thus; nor to enter into any houÅ¿e; nor to be abroad masked after it grows darke; nor to do, or Å¿peake any thing Å¿candalouÅ¿ly that may shok ciuility or publick view: for which
reaÅ¿on here are alwayes gards Å¿et, and Å¿argeants rideing vp and downe the Å¿treet of the CorÅ¿o, to keep all in order, and to make euen mirth obÅ¿erue decency.

In this Å¿treet alÅ¿o of the CorÅ¿o it is that noblemen and Ladyes take the ayre euery fair euening in their coaches. For this reaÅ¿on there are many fine pallaces built in this Å¿treet; as the Pallace of Signor VitelleÅ¿chi, Some Pallaces in the CorÅ¿o. where I Å¿aw tenn chambers on a floore, and all of them filled with a rare collection of pictures and Å¿tatues. Among the Å¿tatues I was pleaÅ¿ed exceedingly with that of Cincinnatus, and with that of Brutus defaced by the command of the Senate, where the very markes of the punches of the Halbards wherwith they defaced it, are yet Å¿een. Not farre from it Å¿tands the pallace of Prencipe Pamfilio, The Pallace of Pamfilio. in which I Å¿aw more riches and rare furniture then in any houÅ¿e in Rome or almoÅ¿t in Italy. For here they shewed me excellent plate of gold and Å¿yluer: an Agate CroÅ¿Å¿e fixed
vpon a foote of the roote of Saphirstone, and vnder it a baÅ¿is beÅ¿et round with Cameos cut into pictures: a great Å¿yluer Crucifix vpon an ebeny frame, the whole worth 12000 crownes: a rare cabinet with the picture of our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady in it, the whole valued at 6000 crownes: a sword whoÅ¿e hilt is of three great Turky Å¿tones of great Value: a baÅ¿in of gold Å¿et thick with Turky Å¿tones: three or four great BeÅ¿oars Å¿tones as big as pearmanes, which had been preÅ¿ented to Clement the VIII from all parts becauÅ¿e he Å¿tood in need of them: a rich miter Å¿et with pretious Å¿tones of great Value: a world of curious originals of the beÅ¿t painters hands: curious Å¿addles, harneÅ¿Å¿e, liueryes of show embrodered with gold and Å¿yluer, with many other rich curioÅ¿ities. The other pallaces in the CorÅ¿o are theÅ¿e; that of Prencipe Carboniano; that of Cardinal Franciotti; that of Don AuguÅ¿tino ChiÅ¿i, that of Prencipe L â€¢
douiÅ¿io, that of the Duke Caetano.

There are alÅ¿o in this Å¿treet Å¿ome
Churches worth takeing notice of; as that of S. Maria in Via Lata. Santa Maria in Via Lata. which Å¿tands neere the Pallace of the Prince Pamfilio. Its an ancient Church, and a Cardinals title. Baronius Å¿ayth, that its built there where S. Paul lodged at his firÅ¿t comeing to Rome. Its Å¿ayd alÅ¿o that in the Oratory here S. Luke wrote the Acts of the ApoÅ¿tles.

There is alÅ¿o in the CorÅ¿o the Church of S. Marcello, S. Marcello. a title of a Cardinal. It was built in the place where anciently Å¿tood the Temple of the infamous Egyptian GodeÅ¿Å¿e IÅ¿is, which Tiberius himÅ¿elf cauÅ¿ed to be pulled downe, the Idol throwne into Tyber, and all the PrieÅ¿ts of it to be crucifyed, for hauing fauoured a great crime comitted by a Roman Lady. Behinde this Church Å¿tands the Oratory of S. Marcello, called the Oratory of the holy Crucifix, where there is a famous Confraternity in which many noble men of Rome are enrolled. Euery friday in Lent there is excellent muÅ¿ick, and one of the beÅ¿t preachers in Rome. From
hence alÅ¿o in the Holy yeare I Å¿aw march a proceÅ¿Å¿ion of 15000 men, all in black buckram coats to the heeles, with a white torch in their hands; and they went from hence on the night of Manday ThurÅ¿day vnto S. Peters Church.
S. Carlo in CorÅ¿o.Then the Church of S. Carlo in CorÅ¿o, where J Å¿aw the heart of S. Charles Borromeo in a CriÅ¿tal caÅ¿e. This Church belongs to the MilaneÅ¿i.

S. Jacomo de gl'Incurabili.Then the Church of S. Iacomo de gl'Incurabili, a neat round Church belonging to the HoÅ¿pital here where they that are afflicted with incurable diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, are entertained and well tended.

The Conuent of the repented whores.LaÅ¿tly the Church of the penitent whores with their Conuent; where all thoÅ¿e poore Å¿ouls that repent themÅ¿elues of their bad life, are receiued, and kept all their life time, at the coÅ¿t of this Conuent. And here I found a great difference between this Conuent, and the houÅ¿e in AmÅ¿terdam, where whores are clapt vp. For here theÅ¿e poore Å¿ouls
are locked vp with their owne conÅ¿ent and deÅ¿ire: there they are lockt vp by force and violence. Here the poore women do great acts of auÅ¿terityes and penance, as the bloody walls of their Celles layd open by a conflagration shewed vnto all the Citie: there the yong women laugh, and are merry. Here no man is permitted to Å¿peak alone with them, except their ConfeÅ¿Å¿or, & phyÅ¿itian: there many men go to prattle and paÅ¿Å¿e their time with thoÅ¿e wanton girles, at a Å¿eparation of rayles. Here a Vayle hides theÅ¿e poore womens faces: there I Å¿aw diuers with black patches on their faces. Here all Å¿ignes of true repentance are Å¿een: there none. Here the loue of vertue and penaÌ„ce locks vp theÅ¿e: there the Vice of Loue locks in thoÅ¿e, and not true repentance. For really all the repentance I Å¿aw there: was, that it repented me, that I had Å¿uffered mine hoÅ¿te (who would needs shew me all the rarityes of AmÅ¿terdam) to lead me thither.
Objection.O but, Å¿ayd a Holander to me, the Pope allowes whores in Rome.

AnÅ¿wer.To whom I anÅ¿wered: no more Sr, then your Å¿tates do drunkenneÅ¿Å¿, which is a greater Å¿inn of the two, becauÅ¿e it rides double, and carryeth luxury behinde it. Do not drink wine in which is luxury. EpheÅ¿. 5.
Obiect.But Å¿ayth an English writer; I am told, that the Pope both permits them, and takes money of them too for that permiÅ¿Å¿ion.

AnÅ¿w. Fenton in his treatis of vÅ¿ury l. 2. c. 9. You haue been told many other falÅ¿e tales by thoÅ¿e who think it lawfull to tell vntruths, Å¿o they Å¿peak but againÅ¿t the Pope: in the meane time, I that haue been fiue times in Rome, can tell you the contrary, if by permitting you meane allowing and aproueing of them in that courÅ¿e. Theres a great difference between allowing, and permitting a thing. MoyÅ¿es allowed not, but yet permitted the libel of diuorce to the Iewes for the hardneÅ¿Å¿ of their hearts. So vÅ¿ury is permitted, Matth. 19.8. but not allowed in diuers countries, for trades Å¿ake.
But why takes he money of them?

This money is taken vp by you vpon credit not, the Pope. Obiect. AnÅ¿w. For the Pope is Å¿o farre from receiuing any money of theÅ¿e drabbs that he goes to great coÅ¿t, to hinder their trading. No man perhaps hath told you this, and therefore, Ile tell it you, know then that the Pope to hinder all yong women from being naught, hath founded HoÅ¿pitals for poore girles, where they are carefully brought vp till they become either marryed wifes, or Nunns. Nay, he giues them dowries alÅ¿o to execute this their choyce, diÅ¿tributeing yearly vpon the FeaÅ¿t of our Ladyes day in Lent, in the Church of the Domicans Å¿upra Mineruam, a purÅ¿e of money a peece, to three hundred yong mayds who are preÅ¿ented to him by the ouerÅ¿eers of the foreÅ¿ayd HoÅ¿pitals. Nor is this all: for he cauÅ¿eth yong girles of tender yeares, to be taken from their poore Å¿uÅ¿pected mothers, leaÅ¿t pouerty, quae cogit ad turpia, should make them Å¿acrifice thoÅ¿e tender virgins to rich
mens luÅ¿ts. In fine, he hath cauÅ¿ed a MonaÅ¿tery to be built in Rome to receiue thoÅ¿e poore vnfortunate women in,Petrus a S. Romualdo in his Cronologicall TreaÅ¿ur. who would leaue that infamous courÅ¿e, if they had but meanes to liue on. Nay, he granteth Indulgences to any that will marry any of thoÅ¿e women, to free them from that lewd courÅ¿e, and make them mend. All this the Pope doth; and much more; which would be a deÅ¿troying of his owne trade and gayne, if it were true, that he countenanceth and alloweth of whores for his gayne. No miller euer deturned the current of water from his owne mill.
But why doth not the Pope diÅ¿countenance and punish whores that are knowne to be Å¿uch?

Obiect. AnÅ¿w.He doth Å¿o. For is it not a diÅ¿countenanceing of them, to forbid them to come to publick meetings, and aÅ¿Å¿emblyes, where women of honour meet? as, at the CorÅ¿o, in the euenings; at publick mariages; at their Å¿ung operas; and the like? is it not a diÅ¿countenanceing of
them to forbid theÌ„ to go in coaches in the day time; or to Å¿tirre out of dores in the night? Is it not a punishment to them; to forbid them to liue together, where they might encourage one an other, and paÅ¿Å¿e their time more cheerfully? But for the moÅ¿t part they liue alone, condemned to the melancholy horror of their crimes, and the Å¿olitude of Å¿eauen whole weeks in Lent, when vpon payne of rigorous punishments and impriÅ¿onment, they dare not admitt of any cuÅ¿tomers. The like rigour is vÅ¿ed againÅ¿t them alÅ¿o in Aduent, that dureing the Å¿pace of thoÅ¿e holy times, theÅ¿e vnholy women may haue time to think of themÅ¿elues, and admit of Gods holy inÅ¿pirations for their amendment. Is it not a punishment to them to be obliged to enter their names publickly in the liÅ¿t of whores? For,Tacit. annal. 2. if Tacitus obÅ¿erues that the old Romans, Å¿atis paenarum aduerÅ¿um impudicas in ipÅ¿a profeÅ¿Å¿ione flagitij apud Aediles credebant, thought it punishment enough againÅ¿t
vnchaÅ¿t women, in their very profeÅ¿ing themÅ¿elues to be Å¿uch before the Aedils; I cannot but think it a great punishment to ChriÅ¿tian whores (who are at leaÅ¿t as Å¿enÅ¿ible as the heathens, of the horrible diÅ¿grace of haueing their name liÅ¿ted) to be thus defamed for euer, by remaining whores vpon Record. Is it not a punishing of them, to depriue them all their life time (as long as they liue whores) of the holy Sacraments; and after their death, of ChriÅ¿tian Burial? Is it not a punishment, and a deterring of them from vice, to throw their bodyes when they dye, into an obÅ¿cure place out of the walls of the towne, as if they deÅ¿erued no other Burial place then that of AÅ¿Å¿es? Is it not, in fine, a punishment to them, not to be allowed to make any Will, or TeÅ¿tament, but to leaue all their goods confiÅ¿cated either to the HoÅ¿pitals of poore honeÅ¿t girles, or to the maintaining of thoÅ¿e gards, that are to watch ouer their deportments? If theÅ¿e punishments
both of body, Å¿oul, and honour, be inflicted vpon whores in Rome, as they are, do not vrge any more, that whores are not punished in Rome, nor diÅ¿countenanced.
But why doth not the Pope punish them home,Obiect. and roote them quite out by banishment?

This hath been attempted by diuers Popes, AnÅ¿w. and namely by Pius Quintus of happy memory (as Thuanus in his hiÅ¿tory writes) but Å¿eeing greater inconueniences, and greater Å¿inns aroÅ¿e vpon it, prudence, which is the Å¿alt that muÅ¿t Å¿eaÅ¿on all moral actions, thought it not fit to carry on that rigour; nor yet allow of fornication neither. So that all the permiÅ¿Å¿ion of whores in Rome that can colourably be imagined; is onely a not punishing of them in all rigour; and euen that too, for a good end; and to hinder greater euils.
But the Pope being both a Temporal, and an EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Superiour, Obiect. is bound, in my mind, to break through all reÅ¿pects, and Å¿ettle innocency in the world.

AnÅ¿w.Its zealouÅ¿ly Å¿poken; and I wish he could do it: but difficilem rem optas, generis humani innocentiam: he wisheth a hard thing who wisheth for the innocency of mankinde, Seneca. Å¿ayth a wiÅ¿eman. And if Princes Å¿ometimes do not punish factious Å¿ubiects; when they Å¿ee, that the punishing of them would pull the whole State in peeces ouer their heads, and put the whole kingdome in danger, as it did in Henry the Thirds time in France vpon his cauÅ¿eing of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e to be killed in Blois: If Generals of armyes take no notice of Å¿ome treacherous commander, who is vniuerÅ¿ally beloued by the Å¿oldiers; leaÅ¿t the punishing of one man, looÅ¿e them the affection of the whole army, as we Å¿aw latey in the caÅ¿e of Lubemirsky (how truely guilty I know not) and Å¿ome yeares ago I remember in the caÅ¿e of WalÅ¿tein, whoÅ¿e punishment had almoÅ¿t vndone the Emperor: why may not the Pope without approueing the Å¿inn of whores, prudently waue the punishing of it with
all rigour, when he Å¿ees that Å¿uch rigour would cauÅ¿e greater diÅ¿orders in that hot nation, and in that citie where all nations Å¿eeme to club vices, as well as vertues? Hence learned AbulenÅ¿is, In c. 8. l. 1. Reg. a great Diuine Å¿ayth; Licet leges humanae aliqua mala permittant non puniendo, nullum tamen malum permittunt Å¿tatuendo.
But the Pope should not gouerne according either to human policy,Obiect. or human Lawes and Examples.

You pretend zeale, AnÅ¿w. but you would do well to take her Å¿iÅ¿ter Prudence with her, as our Sauiour did, who when he heard his diÅ¿ciples deÅ¿ireing him to let them call downe fire from heauen vpon the criminal Samaritans, anÅ¿wered them calmely, Luke 9. you know not of what Å¿pirit you are. Nay, doth not God himÅ¿elf, who being able to punish all criminal perÅ¿ons, and roote them quite out of the world, Å¿uffer both his Sun to riÅ¿e and shine vpon Å¿inners, and Å¿inners to offend in this Å¿unshine, and often by it?S. Tho. 2.2. q. 10. art. 11. in corpore. Hence S. Thomas Å¿ayth
much to my purpoÅ¿e: Humanum regimen deriuatur a diuino regimine, & ipÅ¿um debet imitari. Deus autem quamuis Å¿it omnipotens, ac Å¿umm â€¢ bonus, permittit tamen aliqua mala fieri in vniuerÅ¿o, quae prohibere poÅ¿Å¿et; ne iis Å¿ublatis, maiora bona tollerentur, vel maiora mala Å¿equerentur. Humane gouerment is deriued from diuine gouerment, and ought to imitate it. Now God, allthough he be allmighty and highly good, yet he permits euils to be done in the world, which he could hinder, leaÅ¿t by taking away them, greater goods should be taken, away or greater euils should follow. But I wade too farre into this puddle: yet remember who thruÅ¿t me into it, and youl pardon me.

S. SylueÅ¿tro in Capite.Behinde the Church and Conuent of the foreÅ¿ayd Penitents, Å¿tands the Church of San SylueÅ¿tro in Capite, Å¿o called from the picture of our Sauiours head and face, which our Sauiour himÅ¿elf made by miracle, and Å¿ent to Abagarus King of EdeÅ¿Å¿a, as you may read at length
in Baronius, and in BoÅ¿ius in his rare booke called Roma Sotterranea. Now this picture is kept here in this monaÅ¿tery; and with great probability, Å¿eing it was here that diuers Greek Monks driuen out of their country by ConÅ¿tantin Copronimus for the defence of Å¿acred Jmages, were entertained by the Pope Paul the FirÅ¿t; and its very likely that theÅ¿e good men brought with them this famous picture of our Sauiour to Å¿aue it from the fury of the IconoclaÅ¿ts.

Returning from hence into the CorÅ¿o againe I went to Å¿ee there the Colonna d'Antonino, Colonna Antonina. the Great Pillar of Antoninus the Emperor. Its built iuÅ¿t like that of Traian deÅ¿cribed aboue. It was built by Marcus Aurelius Antoninus the Emperor in honour of his Father Antoninus Pius. Its all of white marble engrauen without with a baÅ¿Å¿o rilieuo from top to bottom, containing the memorable actions of Marcus Aurilius. Its 175 foot high, & hath in it 206 Å¿tairs which lead vp to the top
of it, and 56 little windows giuing light to thoÅ¿e Å¿tairs: and yet this high Pillar was made of 28 Å¿tones of marble. The caruing that is vpon it, contains the braue actions of Marcus Aurelius ouer che Armenians, Parthians, Germans, Wandals and Sarmats, or Polonians: but age hath Å¿o defaced theÅ¿e baÅ¿Å¿i rilieui that its hard to decipher them. He thats curious to know them, may buy them in the printed cutts Å¿old in Rome. Vpon the top of this pillar Å¿tands mounted the Å¿tatue in braÅ¿se guilt of S. Paul Å¿et vp here by Sixtus Quintus. From the top of this pillar I had a perfect view of Rome, and of almoÅ¿t all the Seauen hills vpon which it is built,The Seauen hills of Rome. Mons Capitolinus and are within the wals: which are theÅ¿e.
1. The Capitolin hill where now Ara Coeli Å¿tands and the ConÅ¿eruatorio.
2. The Palatin hill I could not Å¿ee becauÅ¿e it Å¿tands behind the former. It was Å¿o called from the Emperors Pallace that Å¿tood vpon it.Palatinus
3.Auentinus The Auentin hill Å¿o called from Auentinus king of Alba buryed here where now S. Sabinas is.
4.Coelius. The Coelian hill beginning at S. Gregories and running to S. Iohn Laterans.
5.EÅ¿quilinus. The EÅ¿quilin hill, exquilinus quaÅ¿i excubinus, becauÅ¿e of the nightly watch and gard vpon it. Here Å¿tands S. Mary Magiors.
6. The Æ²iminal hill, Viminalis Å¿o called from Vimina, that is, OÅ¿iers, where with it was anciently couered. Here Å¿tand the Thermae Diocletiani and the Villa of Montalto.

7.Quirinalia. The Quirinal hill Å¿o called from the temple of Quirinus, or Romulus which Å¿tood vpon it. Here now Å¿tands Montecauallo. TheÅ¿e were the Seauen ancient Hills of Rome, to which were added three more, to wit; The Ianicule Hill, Ianiculus. Å¿o called, from Ianus buryed here. Here Å¿tands S. Pietro Montorio.
The Vatican Hill, Vaticanus Å¿o called from the Vaticinations and Å¿outhÅ¿ayings made here. S. Peters Church Å¿tands now vpon it.

Pincius or HortuoruÌ„.The Pincian Hill, now called Montrinita. DeÅ¿cending from hence I went to the Pazzorella, where they keep madmen and fooles; and Å¿aw there Å¿trange variety of humours in folly: yet I was pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿ee with what charity and care thoÅ¿e poore men were tended there.
The Pazzorella.From hence I Å¿tept to conÅ¿ider, in the piazza di Pietra, the row of curious pillars which adorned the BaÅ¿ilica of the Emperor Autoninus who had his pallace here, and his Forum.
The Roman Colledge.Then turning by little vnfrequented Å¿treets, I came to the Roman Colledge belonging to the IeÅ¿uits.

Its a faire building, and Å¿tands conueniently for concourÅ¿e of Å¿chollers from all parts. Here I Å¿aw the Å¿chooles, & Gallery of famous AthanaÅ¿ius Kerkerius, Kerkerius his gallery. full of pretty curioÅ¿ityes and experiences both mecanical, mathematical, and hydraulical: yet in my opinion, its farre short of Canonico Settalas gallery in Milan, or MonÅ¿ieur Seruiers in Lyons. Heres alÅ¿o a faire Library
hauing no fault in it but the common fault of moÅ¿t Libraries, to-wit, Locks and keys to it. Good bookes should be as common as the Å¿un, Å¿eing they are the lights of our mindes and made publick by the preÅ¿Å¿e: and I camot but pitty a booke thats empriÅ¿oned and locked vp in a Library, by Å¿aying vnto it: OdiÅ¿ti claues & grata Å¿igilla pudicae, Paucis oÅ¿tendi gemis, & communia laudas. In fine, I Å¿aw here the Apothecaries shop where a Lay brother maKes excellent Roman Treacle, and other odoriferous diÅ¿tillations of Å¿ouerain Vertue. The Church belonging to this Colledge is deÅ¿igned to be a noble thing, but its but half built for want of a whole founder.

From hence I went to the Dominicans Conuent, called la Minerua, La Minerua. becauÅ¿e its built vpon the Place where anciently Å¿tood the Temple of Minerua. Hence alÅ¿o the Church is called Sancta Maria Å¿upra Mineruam. In this Church I Å¿aw many neat Tombes, as thoÅ¿e of Leo the X,
and Clement the VII, both Popes of the houÅ¿e of Medices: they Å¿tand in the Quire, and are neatly wrought by that great artiÅ¿t Baccio Bandinelli. Then the Tombe of Cardinal Pimentelli a moderne Cardinal. The tombe of great Cardinal Morone, Legate for the Pope in the Council of Trent, and a man who had been thirteen times Legatus a Latere. Here alÅ¿o lye buryed the ashes of Egidio FoÅ¿carari Bishop of Modena called in the Council of Trent, Luminare Maius. The tombe of a Lady of the family of the Raggi, is very neat for the new manner of Å¿preading (as I may Å¿ay, and as you would think) of black marble vpon an other coloured marble; and both of them vpon a round pillar. Here on the goÅ¿pel Å¿ide of the high Altar Å¿tandeth a Å¿tatue of our Sauiour made by Michel Angelo, of white marble, a rare peece. At the entrance of the great dore of this Church, lyes buryed vnder a plain flat Å¿tone, Thomas a Vio Caetanus S. Thomas of Aquins Second, his
Brother in Religion, his NameÅ¿ake, his learned Commentator, and onely not hee. Out of humility he would not be buryed within the Church, but out of it. In the SacriÅ¿ty of this Church, I Å¿aw the Chappel of S. Katherine of Siena, and this Chappel was once her very chamber in Siena: Cardinal Antonio Barberino Protector of this order, cauÅ¿ed it to be transferred hither from Siena. Her body lyeth vnder the Altar of the RoÅ¿ary in this Church.

From the Minerua I went to Saint Andrea de la Valle, Sant Andrea della Valle. a fine Church belonging to the Theatins. Its built vpon the place where the Theater of Pompey Å¿tood anciently; and where in latter times Å¿tood the Pallace of the family of the Picolomini; and perchan â€¢ this was the reaÅ¿on why two Popes of that family, to-wit, Pius Secundus, and Pius Tertius are now buryed in this Church. The Cupola was painted by Caualier Lanfranco; the three corners vnder the Cupola and the tribune are of the hand of Domenichini. The neat
Chappel of the Barberini made by Pope Vrban the VIII while he was but yet Cardinal, is built vpon the very place where S. SebaÅ¿tian was beaten, and throwne into a Å¿ink after he had been shot. There had been formerly a little Church built vpon this place, and ouer this Å¿inke, but Sixtus Quintus gaue leaue it should be pulled downe, vpon condition a chappel of the new deÅ¿igned Church should be built in place of it. In fine, take all this Church together, and it is one of the neateÅ¿t Churches (except the BaÅ¿ilicae) that are in Rome, being of the Architecture of Maderna.

In the piazza, or rather, the Å¿treet which goes before this Church, liued not long agoe, Pietro della Valle that ingenious Roman gentleman, Pietro della Valle. who hauing Å¿pent great meanes in traueling, hath left vs three volumes in quarto of his curious relations of Voyages. In his houÅ¿e here he had three whole Mummies with their coffins or caÅ¿es painted anciently, and adorned with diuers hyeroglyphs.
He Å¿pent much money in buying many other rarityes, which he kept alÅ¿o here.

Behinde this Church liued, when I firÅ¿t was acquainted with Rome, an other great VirtuoÅ¿o and Gentleman of Rome, I meane the ingenious Caualier Pozzo with whom I was brought acquainted,Caualier. Pozzo. and Å¿aw all his rarityes, his curious pictures, medals, baÅ¿Å¿i rilieui, his excellent bookes of the rareÅ¿t things in the world, which he cauÅ¿ed to be painted, copied, and deÅ¿igned out with great coÅ¿t.

From hence I went to the Pallace of the Duke Matthei, The Pallace of Matthei. where I Å¿aw many good pictures and Å¿tatues, eÅ¿pecially that long picture repreÅ¿enting fully the manner of Clement the VIII his going from Rome to take poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of Ferrara.

Thence falling in at S. Carlo in Catenari, a neat round Church, I went to the Cancellaria. The Cancellaria. This pallace was built of the Å¿tones of the ColiÅ¿eo by Cardinal Riarij. The chief thing I Å¿aw in it was the gallery
of pictures of Cardinal Barberin, who being Vicechancelour, liueth alwayes in this pallace to exerciÅ¿e his charge the better.

San Lorenzo in DamaÅ¿o.This pallace lookes into the Church of San Lorenzo in DamaÅ¿o, a Collegiate Church. Vnder the high Altar repoÅ¿eth the body of S. DamaÅ¿us Pope. The walls of the body of the Church are rarely painted with the hiÅ¿tory of S. Laurence.

Not farre from hence Å¿tands the Pallace of FarneÅ¿i belonging to the Duke of Parma. The Pallace of FarneÅ¿e. Before it Å¿tands a noble piazza with two rare fountains in it. The Pallace it Å¿elf is one of the beÅ¿t in Rome, or elswhere. It makes an Ile, that is, it hath no houÅ¿es ioyning to it. The forme of it is Å¿quare, and it hath in the midÅ¿t of euery Å¿quare, a great dore letting you into the court. This Courtis built vpon pillars and arches, with a faire open gallery aboue letting you into Å¿eueral appartiments. In this Court I Å¿aw the famous Å¿tatue of Hercules leaning vpon his club, which was found in the Thermae of
Antoninus Car â€¢ calla: one of the legs is moderne, the reÅ¿t old, and made by Glyco an Athenian, as the Greek words vpon it told me. There is an other Å¿tatue of Hercules oppoÅ¿it to it, and iuÅ¿t like it, but not Å¿o good, being but a copie of the former. The other Å¿tatues here of the two Floras, the two Gladiators, and others, are excellent peeces. Mounting vp the great Å¿tairs to go into the chambers and open Gallery, I Å¿aw the curious Statue of the boy and the Dolphin: and at the dore of the great Hall, the Å¿tatues of two Parthian captiue Kings. Where are now thoÅ¿e rare peeces of antiquity which hiÅ¿toryes rather mention, then we finde now in Rome? as the Cymboum Marij; the GregoÅ¿taÅ¿is; the Curia HoÅ¿tilia; the Golden HouÅ¿e of Nero; the Theater of Pompey, Tertull. Lib. de Spectac. c. 10. of which Tertullian Å¿ayth, Pompeius Magnus Å¿olo Å¿uo theatro minor; the Forum Neruae; the Theater of Statilius Taurus; the Septizonium Seueri; the Tower of Mecenas; the Hippodromus; the HouÅ¿e of Gordianus; the Circus Flaminius; the Circus Maximus; the
Atrium Libertatis; Scipios houÅ¿e; the Triumphal Arch of AuguÅ¿tus CaeÅ¿ar, of Domitian; and a world of other Å¿uch rare buildings, whereby the Romans thought to haue eternized their memories; if you aske for theÅ¿e things in bookes, you shal finde their names onely; if you looke for them now in Rome, you shall finde no markes at all of them: which makes me cry out with Petrark; Crede mihi aliis quam lapideis fundamentis eget gloria, Petrarc. In Remed. vtriuÅ¿q. Fort. vt Å¿it manÅ¿ura: beleeue me true permanent glorie Å¿tands in need of other foundations then thoÅ¿e of Å¿tone. Hence Ianus Vitalis an ingenious Italian Poet, hauing obÅ¿erued, that all the old maÅ¿siue buildings of Rome are moultered away, and that Fluide Tyber onely remains Å¿till, cryes out with this Å¿weet moral.

q.l: DiÅ¿ce hinc quid poÅ¿sit fortuna; immota labaÅ¿cunt,
Et quae perpetuo Å¿unt fluitura, manent.

div.p:
But I cannot leaue Rome without taking notice of the Deuotion, MuÅ¿ick, Ceremonies, shows, Gouerment, and the inhabitants of this place: of
each of which I will giue a touch, both for my Trauelers Å¿ake, and my Readers.

Deuotion in Rome.And firÅ¿t, for the Deuotion of Rome I found it to be very great and real in thoÅ¿e places where the Quarante Hore and Stations are kept. For all the yeare long the Quarante Hore go from one Church to an other, through all the Churches of Rome â–ª and there you shall alwayes Å¿ee a world of deuout people praying and meditating, and hearing the Å¿ermons, and giuing of almes, and all this with that profund reÅ¿pect and Å¿ilence, with that aÅ¿Å¿iduity and concourÅ¿e, with that feruour and zeale, that you need not aske where the Å¿tation is, but onely obÅ¿erue where you Å¿ee the people flocking Å¿o faÅ¿t in the morneing, and where the poore make the greateÅ¿t hedge and lane. In other Churches of Rome vpon their feÅ¿tiual dayes (which happen almoÅ¿t euery day, in one place or other) they haue the beÅ¿t muÅ¿ick can begot and though this Å¿eems to draw mens eares to the Church, rather then their hearts; yet when
I remember what eleuated thoughts it breeds in the minde; and how innocently it detaines men from doing worÅ¿e, I cannot but place Church muÅ¿ick among the acts of deuotion.

Now, as for this muÅ¿ick, The muÅ¿ick of Rome. it is the beÅ¿t in the world, and in the beÅ¿t kinde, which is voyces. For my part, hauing read in a learned Author, that the hateing of muÅ¿ick is a Å¿igne of a Å¿oul quite out of tune, and not right Å¿trung for predeÅ¿tination; and that the Scythian king, who held the neighing of his horÅ¿e, to be farre better muÅ¿ick, then the pipe of famous Thimotheus, was held for an aÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elf; I thought it both comely and lawfull to loue muÅ¿ick: & being in a place where the beÅ¿t muÅ¿ick was, I frequented it often with Å¿ingular Å¿atisfaction. Now the beÅ¿t muÅ¿ick I heard, was the muÅ¿ick of the Popes Chappel conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of pure voyces, without any organ, or other inÅ¿truments: euery Å¿inger here kowing his part Å¿o well, that they Å¿eem all to be maÅ¿ters of muÅ¿ick. Then the muÅ¿ick of the ChieÅ¿ â€¢
Noua; of S. Apollinaris; vpon S. Cecilyes day in the Church of that Saint the PatroneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ingers; of the Oratory of S. Marcello euery Friday in Lent; of the IeÅ¿uits dureing the Quaerante hore in Shroftide; of euery good Church of Nunns vpon their patrons day; eÅ¿pecially that of the Nunns of Campo Marzo, where I heard often FonÅ¿eca Å¿ing Å¿orarely well, that she Å¿eemed to me, to cheere vp much the Church in its combats; & to make the Church Militant either looke like the Church Triumphant, or long for it. In a word, whoÅ¿oeuer loues muÅ¿ick and hears but once this of Rome â–ª thinks he hath made a Å¿aueing iourney to Rome, and is well payed for all his paynes of comeing Å¿o farre.

Haueing giuen my eares many a break-faÅ¿t vpon the muÅ¿ick, I gaue my eyes many a Collation vpon the Ceremonies of Rome, The Ceremonies. which were chiefly theÅ¿e. The Ceremony of the Popes opening of the Porta Santa, of S. Peters Church in the Iubily yeare. The Ceremonies of the Popes Chappel,
when he aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts there, eÅ¿pecialy vpon CandlemaÅ¿Å¿e day, PalmeÅ¿unday, Mandy ThurÅ¿day &c The Ceremony of the Popes washing of thirteen pilgrims feet; of his Å¿inging maÅ¿Å¿e publickly in S. Peters Church vpon S. Peters day and other great dayes; the Ceremony of Beatifyeing and of Canonizeing of Saints; the Ceremony of his creating new Cardinals, and giuing them their capp in publick ConÅ¿iÅ¿tory, the Ceremonie of the MaÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ung in Greek and according to the Greek rites, in the Church of the Greek Seminary, vpon the FeaÅ¿t of the Epiphany, and S. AthanaÅ¿ius his day; the Ceremony of baptizeing the Iews; with a world of others. One ceremony I was not vnwilling to miÅ¿Å¿e in my fiue Å¿eueral voyages, becauÅ¿e it alwayes implies the death of a Spiritual Father, I meane, the Ceremony of a Sede Vacante: and of all the bad complimen â€¢ s that euer I heard made, I like none Å¿o ill as that of a noble man of Germany, who being asked by Pope Innocent the X, whether he had Å¿een all the Ceremonies of Rome, anÅ¿wered,
that he had Å¿een all, but a Sed â€¢ Vacante, as if he had Å¿ayd; Holy Father, I haue Å¿een all the fine Å¿ights of Rome, but your death. A horrible Tramontane compliment, which put euen the Pope himÅ¿elf to a Å¿mile.

As for the Showes, I Å¿aw diuers, both Sacred and Prophane. As the wipping ProceÅ¿Å¿ions in the Holy week. The great ProceÅ¿sion from S. Marcellos Oratory to S. Peters Church vpon Mandy ThurÅ¿day in the Holy yeare. The Shows of Rome. Sacred. The Spanish ProceÅ¿sion in Piazza Nauona vpon EaÅ¿ter day in the morning in the Holy yeare. The ProceÅ¿Å¿ion of the Zitelle vpon our Ladyes day in Lent. The ProceÅ¿sion of the Priests of the Oratory vpon shrof-tueÅ¿day to the Å¿eauen Churches â–ª with fiue or Å¿ix thouÅ¿ands perÅ¿ons following of them, all whom they treat in an open field, giuing euery one a couple of hard eggs, and a Å¿lice of Å¿alÅ¿igia, with bread and wine. The Å¿eueral Caualcatas of the Pope and Cardinals. The Spanish Caualcata vpon S. Peters Eue, when the Spanish EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador preÅ¿ents the purÅ¿e of gold, and the Gennet. The Girandola and fire workes vpon S.
Peters Eue, and diuers Å¿uch like Å¿acred triumphs.

For the Prophane Showes, Prophane I Å¿aw the Å¿olemne Entryes of EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of Obedience, wh â€¢ ere each Princes EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador Å¿triue to out vye the other, and by exceÅ¿Å¿iue expences make their maÅ¿ters greatneÅ¿Å¿ appeare aboue that of others. Their Caualcatas to Court vpon their publick audience: their reception in a publick ConÅ¿iÅ¿tory: their audience of Leaue, are all Å¿tately. Then the curious Opere, or muÅ¿ical Drammata recited with Å¿uch admirable art, and Å¿et forth with Å¿uch wonderfull changes of Scenes, that nothing can be more Å¿urprizeing. Here I haue Å¿een vpon their Å¿tages, riuers Å¿welling, and boats rowing vpon them, waters ouerflowing their bankes and Å¿tage, men flyeing in the aire, Å¿erpents crawling vpon the Å¿tage, houÅ¿es falling on the Å¿uddain, Temples and BoÅ¿cos appearing, whole townes, knowne Townes, Å¿tarting vp on the Å¿uddain with men walking in the Å¿treets; the Å¿unn appearing and chaÅ¿eing away darkeneÅ¿Å¿, Å¿ugar plumms fall vpon the
Å¿pectators heads like haile, rubans flash in the ladyes faces like lightning with a thouÅ¿and Å¿uch like repreÅ¿entations. In fine, the Carneual pompes in the Å¿treets exhibited by noblemen with great coÅ¿t and glory.

The Gouerment of Rome.As for the Gouerment of Rome, I found it diuided into two parts: the Gouerment of the Citie; and the Gouerment of the Church. That of the Citie is exactly performed by a Gouernour (Å¿ome Prelate of great parts) conÅ¿tituted by the Pope to watch ouer the Citie carefully,That of the Citie. and to render him an acount weekly of all that paÅ¿Å¿eth. This Gouernour liueth alwayes in the heart of the Citie, and hath beÅ¿ides his owne gards, a Barigello or Captain of the Sbirri or Sergeants, to keep all in order and awe, both day, and night. This Barigello hath, Argus like, a hundred eyes to Å¿py into the deportments of all that liue in Rome, and, Briareus like, as many hands, to carry to priÅ¿on thoÅ¿e that infringe the Lawes. Hence iuÅ¿tice here is as exactly performed, as orders are diÅ¿creetly giuen out. The prices of
all things are printed and affixed in publick places and shops; Inns and Tauernes are bound to haue them Å¿et vp in their entrance, that Å¿trangers may know the rates of all prouiÅ¿ions, and blame none but themÅ¿elues, if they be couzened. So that its as hard a thing to be couzened here, as its hard not to bo cozened in other places. And for thoÅ¿e that cannot read, or Å¿peake the language well, Sbirri wil aske of them, what they payd a meale, how much for a pound of meate, how much for a pinte of Å¿uch and Å¿uch wine, &c. and if they finde them to haue been cozened either in the quantity, weight, or price, theyle right the Å¿tranger beyond his expectation, and punish the delinquent beyond his deÅ¿ire. The laÅ¿t Iubily yeare I was showne Å¿ome of the Sbirri in Pilgrims habits on purpoÅ¿e, to mingle themÅ¿elues with the other pilgrims, the better to obÅ¿erue how they were vÅ¿ed or abuÅ¿ed by their HoÅ¿tes in Inns and Tauernes, and accordingly punish them. In fine, iuÅ¿tice is Å¿o well adminiÅ¿tred here, and impriÅ¿oning
caÅ¿es Å¿o many, that the laÅ¿t Prince of Conde being in Rome, Å¿ayd he wondred much at one thing there, which was to Å¿ee Å¿o many men go out of their houÅ¿es in the morneing, and returne home againe to dinner without being impriÅ¿oned. A kinfe in a mans pocket, a darke Lanterne, a Å¿word worne without leaue, &c. will Å¿uffice to make a man be Å¿ent to priÅ¿on: and a pockes piÅ¿tol found about you, or in your cloakbag, is enough to make you be Å¿ent to the Gallyes with tre tratti di corda, that is, the Å¿trappada thrice: yet they mitigate the rigour of theÅ¿e lawes to Å¿trangers who offend out of ignorance.

That of the Church.As for the gouerment of the Church, thats done partly by the Pope himÅ¿elf in Å¿eueral Congregations held before him: partly by his Vicar General, a Cardinal who hath vnder him a Vice-Gerent (a Bishop) to help him. Theres Å¿carce a day in the week but the Pope holds one Congregation or other, about Church affairs, in which Congregations not onely Cardinals interuene, but alÅ¿o Bishops and Doctors; and where all buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es
are headed, as well as handled with great deliberation. Euery three weeks the Pope holds a ConciÅ¿tory, where all the Cardinals that are in Rome, meet his HolyneÅ¿Å¿, as at a Grand CounÅ¿el, to aduiÅ¿e with him concerning the neceÅ¿Å¿ary affairs of the Church. And its pretty to Å¿ee how like the motions of a well ordered watch, all buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es here moue at once, and yet neuer interfere or clash with one another.

As for the Inhabitants of Rome, The Inhabitants of Rome. they follow the fortune of their Citie; and as when Rome was but yet a new towne, the inhabitants where but three thouÅ¿and in all, Å¿ayth DionyÅ¿ius, and when it was comne to its full grouth, it had three or four millions of people, in Å¿o much that in a great plague the Bills of mortality came to ten thouÅ¿and men a day, EuÅ¿eb. in Chronico. and this for many dayes together: Å¿o now Rome haueing been Å¿ix times Å¿ â€¢ ckt and ruined (as I Å¿ayd aboue) is not the tenth part Å¿o populous as heretofore it was; and euen thoÅ¿e inhabitants that are now in Rome, are for the moÅ¿t part originary from other parts of
Italy and Europe; and haue been drawne to take vp here either by preferments or buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿. The Nobility it Å¿elf is for the maior part forrain and Å¿prung out of Å¿uch families of Popes, Princes, and Cardinals as haue been forrain before their promotions and preferments. The true ancient and illuÅ¿trious Roman families I found to be theÅ¿e few, VrÅ¿ini, Colonna, Sauelli, Frangepani and Å¿ome few others.

Hauing thus, as Painters do, taken Rome in all her poÅ¿tures, I confeÅ¿Å¿e it happened to mee, as it did to Apelles takeing the picture of CompaÅ¿pe; that is, by looking Å¿o often and Å¿o attentiuely vpon Rome I began to be Å¿o farre in loue with it, as not onely to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe to CaÅ¿Å¿iodorus his opinion,CaÅ¿Å¿iod. EpiÅ¿t. who affirmes it to be akind of crime not to liue in Rome, when you can do it. Piaculi genus eÅ¿t abÅ¿entem Å¿ibi Romam dintius facere, qui in ea conÅ¿titutis poÅ¿sit laribus habitare; but alÅ¿o to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe to our old Britain Kings, Cadwallader, Cedwalla, Coenred, offa, Ina and Burrhed, who thought Rome
alÅ¿o to beÅ¿t place to dye in. For if thoÅ¿e places be thought by all men, the beÅ¿t places to liue in, Rome a fine place to liue in. where a man may learne the moÅ¿t experimental knowledge, & how to menage great affairs; where can a man learne more knowledge then in Rome? where all languages are Å¿poken, all Å¿ciences are taught, the ableÅ¿t men of Europe meet, all the beÅ¿t records are found, all wits appeare as vpon their true theater, all forrain EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors render themÅ¿elues, all Nuncios at their returne to Rome vnload themÅ¿elues of the obÅ¿eruations they haue made abroad; and where euery Å¿tone almoÅ¿t is a booke; euery Å¿tatue a maÅ¿ter; euery inÅ¿cription a leÅ¿Å¿on, euery Antichamber an Academy? And againe, if thoÅ¿e places be the beÅ¿t to dye in, And a fine place to dye in. where all comforts of the Å¿oul are beÅ¿t had; what place can be better to dye in then Rome? the very center and boÅ¿ome it Å¿elf of Catholick Communion; and where there is Å¿o much Deuotion, and Å¿o much Vertue partiÅ¿ed; and where you haue this comfort alÅ¿o in you
graue; that you lye in a ground which hath been bathed in the blood of Å¿o many thouÅ¿and martyrs.

And thus much of Rome, in the deÅ¿cribeing of which, if I haue been too Frolixe, remember that great Ladyes are long in dreÅ¿Å¿ing: if too short, remember that I onely relate what I Å¿aw there, not all that is to be Å¿een there.

My iourney from Rome to Naples.Hauing thus Å¿een Rome, I agreed with the Procaccio, to carry me to Naples. Others take with them a Vetturino, that lets them haue horÅ¿es, and dyets them to; I meane, defrayes a man for meat and drink and horÅ¿t hire both going, and comeing, and your horÅ¿e fiue dayes at Naples (but not your dyet there) and lets you haue his horÅ¿es two dayes, to go Å¿ee Æ²eÅ¿uuius and Pozzolo; and all this for fourteen, or fifteen corwnes a man. Its true, a man is ill lodged, and bad by treated in that iourney, but it doth a gentle man good to be acquainted with hardship.
Parting then from Rome by the Gate of S. Iohn Lateran we paÅ¿Å¿ed through theÅ¿e places.
Marino, Marino. a neat little towne belonging to Cardinal Colonna. It lookes like a painted towne.
Veletri, Veletri. famous for the birth of the anceÅ¿ters of AuguÅ¿tus CaeÅ¿ar. Heres a brazen Statue of Vrban the VIII, and a neat pallace and garden of Cardinal Ginetti. Its an EpiÅ¿copal towne.
The Tre Taberne where S. Paul was met,Tre Taberne. at his firÅ¿t comeing to Rome, by the ChriÅ¿tians of Rome. Act. 28. v. â€¢ 5.
Peperno where Camilla the Amazon was borne.Peperno.

FoÅ¿Å¿a N â€¢ oua where S. Thomas of Aquin going to the Council of Lyons, FoÅ¿Å¿a N â€¢ onaâ–ª
fell Å¿ick and dyed.

Taracina (old Anxur) the head towne of the VolÅ¿ â€¢ ians, Taracina but now bare and bald; showing nothing but Å¿ome old ruines of the hauen which Antoninus Pius here adorned; and of an old Temple. Its an EpiÅ¿copal towne.

Not farre from hence Å¿tood anciently the towne Amyclae, Amiclae. that Pythagorical, or Puritanical towne,
which was ruined by Serpents, becauÅ¿e none would kill them; Pythagoras his doctrine forbiding men to to kill any liuing creature.Seru. in lib. 10. Aeneid. An other time it was ruined by Å¿ilence; no man dareing to Å¿peak of the enemyes comeing; too many falÅ¿e alarums haueing made the magiÅ¿trats forbid vnder payne of death, that no man should Å¿peak any more of the enemyes comeing: Å¿o that when they came indeed, no man durÅ¿t Å¿peak of it.Amyclas Å¿ilentium perdidit. Prouerb. apud S. Hieron. Thus not onely PhiloÅ¿ophy, but euen Silence it Å¿elf and Obedience, two noble Vertues, are hurtfull to men, if they bee not accompanyed with diÅ¿cretion.
From Taracina we went to Fundi to Å¿upper, hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed through a foreÅ¿t of baye trees, and through an open gate called Portello, which lets men into the kingdome of Naples.

Fundi is Å¿o called becauÅ¿e its built in a low flat. Its ancient if you beleeue you eares, not your eyes. For it lookes yonger,Fundi. then the other townes I had paÅ¿Å¿ed through before. The reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e this towne was burned Å¿ome 130 yeares ago by
Caradin Barbarozza, admiral of the Great Turk Solyman. Leo Aferâ–ª It was this Caradin, who of Ã¡ famous Pyrat, became King of Algiers, hauing perÅ¿waded thoÅ¿e of Algiers to shake off the Spanish yoake. This Caradin being vpon the Mediterranean Sea, and hea â€¢ ing by his Å¿pyes, that Julia GonÅ¿aga (widdow of VeÅ¿paÅ¿ian Colonna, and the hanÅ¿omeÅ¿t woman in the world) liued here in Fundi, landed his men in the night, and Å¿ent them to catch her napping; reÅ¿olueing to make a fine preÅ¿ent of her to his lewd maÅ¿ter Solyman. But she leaping out of her bed, rid a way in her very linnen, eÅ¿caped Å¿o narrowly, that had she Å¿tayd to put on any clothes, she had for euer, put off all liberty. The Pyrats miÅ¿Å¿ing of this fair Helena, fayled not to make a burning Troye of Fundi; ranÅ¿acking it and carryeing away the beÅ¿t of its inhabitants: Å¿uch dangerous things are great beauties to weak townes.

From Fundi we went to Mola, vpon the Via Appia, The Æ²ia Appia. Å¿o called becauÅ¿e Appius Claudius a noble
Roman made it at his owne coÅ¿t dureing his ConÅ¿ulat. This CawÅ¿ey is one of the greateÅ¿t proofs of the Romans greatneÅ¿Å¿ and riches. For it was fiue dayes iourney long, begining at Rome, and reaching through the kingdome of Naples, to BrunduÅ¿ium. It was as broad as two carts might eaÅ¿ily meet vpon it and paÅ¿Å¿e: it was all of great black flint Å¿tones, each one as big as two men can carry,See Plutarch in Graccho. and layd Å¿o cloÅ¿e together, that they haue held together theÅ¿e 1800 yeares, and Seeme, as Procopius Å¿ayth ingeniouÅ¿ly, to be rather congeniti, then congesti, borne together, Procop. l. 1. d â€¢ bell. Goth then layd together. The frequent paÅ¿Å¿ing of horÅ¿es and mule â€¢
(for Å¿o many yeares) vpon this cawÅ¿Å¿ey, haue made it both Å¿o Å¿mooth and shyneing, that when the Sunn shine â€¢ vpon it, you may Å¿ee it glitter two miles of, like a Å¿yluer highway.

Mola. Formiae.Arriueing at Mola, called anciently Formiae, I went to Å¿ee Ciceros Tombe which Å¿tands in a garden not farre off. And I the more willingly beleeue it to be his Tombe,
becauÅ¿e its certain, that Tully had a Villa in Formiis (which was this place) and thither he was going in his litter, when he was ouertaken by the executioners of the Triumuiri and beheaded.Val. Max. l. 1. c. 4. There are no words vpon his Tombe; of which if you aske me the reaÅ¿on, I can onely tell you, that either words in proÅ¿e could not Å¿peak, their Tully being dead; or verÅ¿es would not, out of enuy, prayÅ¿e him, who had made proÅ¿e Å¿o famous.

Hauing Å¿een this, Å¿ome of our Company and I, tooke a boate and four luÅ¿ty watermen, to row vs to CaÃ«ta and back againe,CaÃ«ta. while the reÅ¿t Å¿tayed at Mola to prouide dinner. Arriueing in little more then half an houre at CaÃ«ta, we went vp to the CaÅ¿tle, where we Å¿aw the skelleton of Charles Bourbon, once ConÅ¿table of France, but afterwards takeing againÅ¿t his owne King vpon a diÅ¿guÅ¿t, he Å¿erued the Emperor Charles the V, and was made one of his Generals, and Gouernour of Millan. Where haueing borrowed mony of the MilaneÅ¿i, and
hauing layd a deep curÅ¿e vpon HimÅ¿elf (wishing the might dye in the firÅ¿t enterpriÅ¿e he vnder tooke) if he payd not back the monye by Å¿uch a time,The Bp. of Belley in his hiÅ¿toryes. he fayled in his word, but his curÅ¿e did not. For his next enterpriÅ¿e was to go Å¿ack Rome: and there his curÅ¿e met him as he Å¿caled the walls; & being shot with a musket bullet he was forced to pay his debt to nature. His body was carryed to CaÃ«ta, Bourbons Body. where it Å¿tands with its clothes, bootes and Å¿purrs on, in a long boxe Å¿treight vp, with this Spanish Epitaph ouer his head.

q.l: France gaue me milk, Spayne great employments gaue,
Rome gaue me death, and here GaÃ«t a graue.

div.p:
This CaÅ¿tle Å¿tanding vpon a Promontory ouer looketh the towne, and thirty miles of Sea. In the end of the towne, towards land Å¿ide (for this towne is a pure PeninÅ¿ula) I Å¿aw the Clouen Rock, The Clouen Rock. which Tradition
here holds to haue been thus clouen at our Sauiours death: The long Å¿tairs going downe between the two mountains in the very open gash, and rendering you to a neat chappel below, Å¿trike you all the way long with a Å¿acred reuerence, and are able almoÅ¿t to rend alÅ¿o a Å¿tony heart in two, with the thought of our Sauiours paÅ¿sion.

Vpon the top of all this Promontory there is an ancient monument of Manutius Plancus an old Roman, with a great deale of old Latin vpon it; but my rideing boots put me out of all reading humour, and I was very willing to let Plancus lye quietly in his monument aboue, Å¿o I could but recouer againe our boate & there Å¿it Å¿till. Of this towne was the famous Cardinal CaÃ«tanus, of S. Thomas Aquinas his name, order, and almoÅ¿t learning. This towne was built by Aeneas in honour of his NurÅ¿e CaÃ«ta who dyed here.
Returning againe to Mola we went after dinner to Å¿ee Ciceros Grotte, Ciceros Grotte. and Å¿o away.

Hauing paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer the riuer in a Ferry boat, we entred vpon the
medows, in whoÅ¿e fennes called (the Fens of Minturna) Caius Marius lay hid a while, and there with his Å¿terne lookes and manly voyce, Å¿aying, DareÅ¿t thou kill Caius Marius? Å¿o terrifyed the Å¿laue that was Å¿ent thither to kill him, that he let him eÅ¿cape to his ship, and Å¿o into Africk. Plutark. He may Å¿peak big that Å¿peaks for his life; and any lookes become a man, when he lookes to himÅ¿elf well in dangers.

While we rod along theÅ¿e medows we Å¿aw before vs the mountain of Garo, anciently called Mons MaÅ¿Å¿icus, famous for excellent wines; as well as the country there about, which was called Ager Falernus, Å¿o famed by Poets for its Vinum Falernum.

PaÅ¿Å¿ing thus along we came at night to S. Agathas, and the next morneing betimes we enterd into Campania Foelix, Campania Foelix Å¿o Å¿urnamed becauÅ¿e of its admirable ayre, wonderfull plenty of corne and wine, and pleaÅ¿ants proÅ¿pects on all Å¿ides, which makes an Ancient call it, C â€¢ rtamen Cereris & Bacchi, the Strife of
Ceres and Bacchus. It was this country which with its delights, broke Hannibals army; which neither Å¿now could coole, nor Alpes Å¿top, nor Romans Æ²anquish, Å¿ayth Seneca. Indeed the pleaÅ¿antneÅ¿Å¿ of this country made vs a full mends for all the ill way we had had before: nature hauing Å¿et that Å¿curuie way there a purpoÅ¿e, that men might like her Fauorite Campania the better after it. I call this country Natures Fauorite, in imitation of Pliny, who calls it, Opus gaudentis naturae, that is, a country made by nature when she was in a good humour. Its a Heathen that Å¿peaks, and you muÅ¿t pardon him.

We intended that day to haue gone to Capua to dinner,Capua. but when we came thither, we did not finde it at home. For this towne now called Capua is two miles diÅ¿tant from the place where old Capua Å¿tood. Indeed the old Capua was a towne of importance: for it was either the Å¿econd, or third in the world; and Å¿tood in competition, as Carthage did, with Rome: Nay, it demanded

And S. Thom. 2.2. qu. 64. art. 5. who to auoyd the inÅ¿olencies of the French Å¿oldiers (receiued into the towne friendly) leapt into the riuer Vulturno to Å¿aue their Virginity & honour, from their lewdneÅ¿Å¿: an action rather wonderfull, then warrantable. From Capua we paÅ¿Å¿ed through AuerÅ¿a, AuerÅ¿a. a Å¿weat Seat of a towne, and once great, till Charles the I, King of Naples, almoÅ¿t ruined it. Its a Bishops Seat Å¿till. from one of the Syrens. Its now called Neapolis, Petr. a S. Roma aldo in his Cronolog. As for Naples, its now the head of a great kingdome Å¿o called. This kingdome is of great importance to Spayne. Its importance to Spayne. It makes his party too Å¿trong for France in Italy. In fine, it beareth vp notably the intereÅ¿t of Å¿payne in the Court of Rome: and it Å¿queizeth it Å¿elf now and then, into huge Å¿ummes, four millions of crownes, to Å¿end tribute into Spaynes coffers. It hath in it twenty Archbishops Seats;Its GreatneÅ¿Å¿e. a hundred and twenty fiue Bishops Seats; a thouÅ¿and fiue hundred Bourgs; two millions of Å¿oules:Its Å¿trenth ten principalityes; twenty three Dutchies; thirty MarquiÅ¿ats; fifty foure Countyes; and about a ThouÅ¿and Baronies, whereof four hundred are ancient. As for the towne it Å¿elf of Naples, The towne of Naples. if it be the third of Italy for greatneÅ¿s, it is the firÅ¿t for strength &
neatneÅ¿Å¿; and therefore deÅ¿eruedly Å¿urnamed, La Gentile, the Gentile. MoÅ¿t of the houÅ¿es of Naples are made flat at top, to walk vpon: a moÅ¿t conuenient thing to breath vpon in the fresh Euenings,

The Churches of Naples The Domo is ancient, and therefore out of the mode a little: yet it hath a moderne Chappel, which is very beautifull: and is one of the fineÅ¿t in Europe, both for brazen Å¿tatues & rich painting. Baronius. & Breuiarium Rom. A French nobleman Count of la Val, was conuerted from CaluiniÅ¿me to the Catholick Religion vpon Å¿ight of this wonder. S. Maria No â€¢

Then we mounted vp that windeing

Then
I was led into the apartment of the Padre ViÅ¿itatore, where I Å¿aw moÅ¿t neat roomes, and Å¿ome good pictures. Then I went to Å¿ee the three
CaÅ¿tles; That of S. Elmo, CaÅ¿tle S. Elmo. which is hard by the CarthuÅ¿ians, was built by Charles the V. It Å¿tands well vpon its owne gard by reaÅ¿on of its high Å¿ituation: but I doubt whether it can offend any enemy, except Naples it Å¿elf which is vnder it.

TheÅ¿e there CaÅ¿tles are garded by natural Spaniards; and well furnished with great Cannons, by whoÅ¿e language (which is vltima Ratio R â€¢ gum, Kings laÅ¿t arguments) the Neapolitans are either catechized into duty, or threatened into obedience. with Å¿naffles, it hath often plunged vnder the King of Spayne, but could neuer fling him quite out of the Å¿addle, merce a gli tre CaÅ¿telli.

The Markets.Then I went to Å¿ee the markets here, and fouÌ„d them moÅ¿t admirable, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of fruit, which Campania Å¿ends hither: and where but the taxes taken off, or reaÅ¿onably moderated, Naples would be the cheapeÅ¿t and richeÅ¿t place in the world. But the Kings officers if they Å¿uck in Milan, and Fleece in Sicily, they Flea in Naples: which vÅ¿age droue the people Å¿ome yeares paÅ¿t, into Å¿uch a deÅ¿perate humour, an. 1647 that they tooke vp armes vnder the coÌ„maÌ„d of Mazaniello: his true name was Thomas Angelus Maia, a poore fisherman without Å¿tokings or shooes, who for ten dayes together, Å¿waggered here Å¿o powerfully in the head of two hundred thouÅ¿and mutinous people, that when he commanded them to burne a houÅ¿e, they did it: when he commanded them to caÅ¿t into the fire all the goods, papers, plate, beds, hangings &c. of the Gabelliers, they did it without reÅ¿erueing
the leaÅ¿t pretious peece to themÅ¿elues: when he commanded them to cry out: Downe with the Gabells, they did it: when he put his finger to his mouth, they were all Å¿ilent againe; as if this poore fisherman had been the Å¿oul that animated that great body of people. It was prodigious indeed that Å¿uch a poore yong man (not paÅ¿t 23) in waÅ¿tcoat and drawers, and his fishers cap on, should finde Å¿uch obedience, from Å¿uch rich and witty citizens. But as tumultuous people make armes of euery thing their fury meets with, Å¿o they make Captains of euery man that will but head them; and as the Prouerbe goes, In Å¿editione vel Androclides belli ducem agit. They shewed me the houÅ¿e of this fisherman: but the other houÅ¿es shewd me his fury. ThouÅ¿ands haue not yet recouered thoÅ¿e ten dayes tumults. Thus we Å¿ee, that when men are ripe for rebellion, Cromwells and Mazaniells are cryed vp for great men: or rather when God hath a mind to punish, flyes and gnats are powerfull things euen againÅ¿t Princes.
The Academies of wits.Here are two Academies of w â€¢ ts the one called the Ardenti, to show their ardour in Å¿tudyeing: the other the OtioÅ¿i, wiÅ¿ely inÅ¿tituted as an allay to the others heat.

Learned men.Some of the famous men for learning of this towne were, old Statius, rare Sannazarius, Alexander ab Alexandro, and Iohn BaptiÅ¿t Marini: three excellent PoÃ«ts, and one Antiquary. Naples hath furnished the Church with 18 Popes.

Hauing thus Å¿een the towne it Å¿elf of Naples, I was moÅ¿t willing to Å¿ee the wonders of nature which are neare vnto it. HorÅ¿eing therefore betimes one morneing, we went with a guide to Å¿ee VeÅ¿uuius the burning mountain, The MouÌ„tain VeÅ¿uuius. Å¿ome Å¿eauen miles diÅ¿tant from Naples. Our honeÅ¿t guide had Å¿tudyed the hiÅ¿tory of this hill, and could tell, how often it had broken forth into flames Å¿ince the beginning of the world, that is, twenty times. Xiphilinus the EpitomiÅ¿t of Dio, relates at length one that happened vnder the Emperor Titus. But the laÅ¿t which happened in the yeare 1631, he rememberd
very well, and related it to me as we went along, with a Å¿ad preface, of Infandum Peregrine iubes renouare dolorem, becauÅ¿e he could alÅ¿o Å¿ay; Et quorum pars magna fui, haueing been an Actor in that diÅ¿order. For he was Å¿onn to a rich huÅ¿bandman here, and with much a do, Aeneas like, he had reÅ¿cued his old Father from the ashes of VeÅ¿uuius, which ouerwhelmed and buryed whole Æ²illages. Here Å¿ayd hee, pointing to the place, Å¿tood a great vineyard one of the beÅ¿t of the Country; but now three fathom deep in ashes. Here Å¿tood a Village full of rich husbandmen and goodly houÅ¿es; but now ruined by the Å¿tones shot at it from VeÅ¿uuius. Here Å¿tood once a pleaÅ¿ant Villa beautifyed with curious walks, orange trees, fountains, and arbors, but I am cinis eÅ¿t vbi Villa fuit. In a word, aboue two thouÅ¿and people were burnt, lamed, or Å¿tifled in this eruption. Then he showed me the vaÅ¿t Å¿tones which ouerchargeing the Å¿tomach of VeÅ¿uuius, he had vomited vp, with Å¿uch a boaking, that
Naples thought the day of Iudgement had been at hand. Then he shewed me a channel, where a Riuer of fiery green matter mingled with brimÅ¿tone, allum, iron water, and Å¿altpeeter, had run from that Å¿pewing hill. The manner of this breaking out was thus. The hill began firÅ¿t to Å¿moke more vehemently then before. Then it flamed and caÅ¿t out a cloud of ashes, which, had the wind Å¿tood toward the Citie, had couered all Naples, and buryed it in thoÅ¿e ashes. Then it began to roare as if Madame Nature her Å¿elf had been in labour. Thunder was but piÅ¿tolcrack to this noyÅ¿e: and the mouth of a Cannon a full mile wide, muÅ¿t needs giue a great report. It bellowed and thundered againe: Naples trembled: the ground Å¿welled: The Sea it Å¿elf shiuered for feare; when the hill tearing its entrals with huge violence, was brought to bed of a world of vaÅ¿t Å¿tones, and a fludd of Sulphurious matter which ran from the top of the mountain into the Sea for the Å¿pace of three miles. All this he tould me, and
this he shewed me afterward, in a publick inÅ¿cription vpon a fair marble Å¿tone erected hard by. And all this made me but the more deÅ¿irous of Å¿eeing this mountain. Wherefore Å¿purring on, we came Å¿oone after, to the foot of the hill; where leauing our horÅ¿es, we began to crawle vp that Å¿tep hill for a good mile together, to the midlegg in ashes. At laÅ¿t, with much a doe, we got to the top of the hill; and peeping fearfully (remembring Plinyes accident) into the great hellow from the brinck of it, found it to be like a VaÅ¿t Kettle, See Bakers Cronicle in Henric. â€¢
farre greater then thoÅ¿e Hell Kettles near DeÅ¿lington in the Bishoprick of Durham, made by earthquakes. For the orifice of this Kettle is a mile or two wide, and very nigh as deep. In the bottom of it is a new little hill riÅ¿eing out of the hollow of the old, and fumeing perpetually with a thick Å¿moke, as if it alÅ¿o would play tricks too in its turne. Hauing gazed a while at this Chimney of Hell (for Tertullian calls Aetna and VeÅ¿uuius, Hells Chimneys Fumariola
inferni) we came faÅ¿ter downe then we went vp. Hee that is not content with this my short deÅ¿cription of the burning of this Hill, let him read Iulius CaeÅ¿ar Recupitus, who hath made a little booke alone of it, called, De VeÅ¿uniano incendio Nuntius.
Hauing recouered our horÅ¿es againe, we came back to Naples; and the next morning takeing a new guide, we went to Å¿ee the wonders of Nature about Baiae and Puzzu â€¢ lo. Our iourney to Puzzuolo.

Sincerus MusÃ¢ proximus, vt tumulo.
His name was Iacobus Sannazarius, but he changed his name for that of Sincerus, at the requeÅ¿t of Pontanus, who alÅ¿o changed his name too, and cauÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf to be called Iouianus, as Iouius in Elogiis virorum Doctorum Å¿ayth. Not farr of this place, nor farr from the entrance of the Grotte of PauÅ¿ilipus, in the Gardens of S. Seuerino, Å¿tands Virgils tombe, Virgils tombe. couered almoÅ¿t ouer with Laurel, or Ba â€¢ -trees: as yf that PoÃ«ts Laurel were growne into a Shadybower, to make a whole tombe of Laurel for the Prince of PoÃ«ts.

From thence we returned againe into our way, and preÅ¿ently came to the entrance of the Grotte of PauÅ¿ilipus. this Mountain lyeing at the very back of Naples, and rendering the paÅ¿Å¿age to Naples extreamly inconuenient for carriages, it was thought fit to cut a cart way vnder ground, quite through the mountain: Å¿ome Å¿ay it

The Grotte of PauÅ¿ilipo.Entring into the Grotte of PauliÅ¿ipus, we found it to be about forty foot high, and broad enough for two carts laden to meet with eaÅ¿e. They Å¿ay here, that it is a full mile long; but I thought it Å¿carce Å¿o much. We rid Å¿ome forty paces by the light of the wide entrance; but that Vanishing, we were left in the darke a good while, till we came to the halfway, where there hangs a burning Lamp before the picture of our Sauiour in the B. Virgins armes. The light of this Lamp was very gratefull vnto vs; and I am confident, a Puritan himÅ¿elf, were he here, would be glad to Å¿ee this Lampe and Picture, and loue them better for it euer after. All the way of this Grotta is very euen and Leuel, but hugely duÅ¿ty; as a roome muÅ¿t be, that hath not been Å¿weept theÅ¿e Å¿ixteen hundred yeares. The people of the country meeting here in the
darke, know how to auoyd one another, by going from Naples on the right hand; and returning on the left; that is, by keeping on the moutain Å¿ide going, and returning on the Sea Å¿ide: and this they expreÅ¿Å¿e by cryeing out often; A la Montagna, or, a la Marina; To the mountain Å¿ide, or to the Sea Å¿ide, to giue notice whether they come, or go. AlmoÅ¿t all the way we rid in it, we shut our eyes, haueing little vÅ¿e of them; and our mouths and noÅ¿es too, for feare of being choked with the duÅ¿t: Å¿o that our exteriour Å¿enÅ¿es being thus shut vp, our interiour begaÌ„ to worke more freely, and to think of this odd place. My thoughts, comeing newly from Sannazarius and Æ²irgils tombes, fell preÅ¿ently vpon Poetry (for all this country is a Poetical country) and I began to think whether this were not Polyphemus his den, becauÅ¿e Homer makes it to haue been neare

But at laÅ¿t I concluded that this was the place where the merry Gods and GoddeÅ¿Å¿es, after their iouial Å¿uppers, playd at hide and Å¿eek, without being hood-winckt. The experiment is this. A man takes a dog aliue, and holding downe his head with a woodden forke to the ground, the dog begins firÅ¿t to cry, and then to turne vp the white of the eyes, as if he would dye. que videre & all men that haue Å¿een Rome onely once deÅ¿ire to Å¿ee it againe: Hence the Romans takeing leaue of a Å¿tranger departing from Rome, after his firÅ¿t Voyage, Å¿ay ieÅ¿tingly to him, a Riuederci;

For my part, I confeÅ¿Å¿e I was of this Å¿entiment in my firÅ¿t iourney; but now hauing Å¿een it fiue Å¿eueral times, I tooke a long leaue of it, and began to think of returning homeward by the way of Loreto, and Venice. We Å¿et out of Rome by the Porta del Populo, all along the via Flaminia, Via Flaminia. which rearched as farre almoÅ¿t on this Å¿ide of Rome, as the Via Appia did on the other; that is from Rome to Rimini. Following on the way, we paÅ¿Å¿ed by CaÅ¿tel Nuouo, Ciuita CaÅ¿tellana, Vtricol â€¢ , & Å¿o to Narni:Narni. Å¿o called from the riuer Nar. Dukes. Hence Rome loÅ¿t her ConÅ¿uls, NarÅ¿es and BaÅ¿ilius being the two laÅ¿t ConÅ¿uls) and was gouerned by a Duke too, as well as Spoleto. Hence I remember that Plato Å¿ayth, abiectori armorum maximÃ¨ conueniret, vt in mulierem ex Viro tranÅ¿latus, Å¿ic puniatur: Plato l. 12 de Legib. a man that caÅ¿ts away his armes in a battle, ought to the punished, by being changed from a man into a woman. This towne of Spoleto giues the name to the pleaÅ¿ant Valley of Spoleto, The Valley of Spoleto. which lyes neare it. Its
aboue thirty miles in compaÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿urrounded on all Å¿ides with Hills, and thoÅ¿e Hills, are clad with many fine townes: people willingly dwelling here were the ayre and the earth, our chiefeÅ¿t nurces, are Å¿o purely good.

From Poligni, climbeing vp the Apennins, we came to Tolentino, Tolentino. famous for the Tombe and Reliks of S. Nicolas Tolentinas â–ª of this towne was Philelphus a learned and noble Knight, who deÅ¿irous of poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ing the Greek Tongue in perfection, was not onely content to go into Greece in perÅ¿on, and there viÅ¿it the ruines of Athens, and the tombes of the ancient PhiloÅ¿ophers; but brought thence with him a Grecian Lady, whom he had marryed at ConÅ¿tantinople, by whoÅ¿e dayly

WitneÅ¿Å¿ that diÅ¿pute which he had with Timotheus a Grecian, about the force and accent of a Greek word, where both of them growing hot, and betting at laÅ¿t their beards, which they both wore then long, Philelphus wone the others beard; and cauÅ¿ed it to be shaued off immediatly, and kept it in his family as a Trophey: though the poore Grecian, would haue redeemed it with a conÅ¿iderable Summe of Money. Indeed they deÅ¿erued both to looÅ¿e their beards, that could be Å¿o hot about Å¿uch a hairs matter, as the accent of a word. The Å¿tatue of this notable shauer, victorious Philelphus I saw here in the towne houÅ¿e.

ReÅ¿oluing but to Å¿tay here one day,
we put out all our time to vÅ¿e preÅ¿ently, and Å¿pent that afternoone, and the next day, in viewing exactly this Å¿acred place which is Å¿o much frequented by the deuout Pilgrims of all Christendome. This place at firÅ¿t was nothing but a plain highway, till the Chamber of our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady (in which the Angel announced vnto her the myÅ¿tery of the Incarnation of our Sauiour in her wombe) was tranÅ¿lated thither miraculouÅ¿ly by the hands of Angels, about the yeare 1294, when Infidels and Turks ouerÅ¿preading the Holy Land, would otherwiÅ¿e haue profaned that holy place, which euen from the ApoÅ¿tles time had been turned into a Chappel. For my part, though this be no article of faith, yet when I remember what was Å¿ayd in this Chamber by the Angel to our Lady, to wit, non est impoÅ¿Å¿ibile apud Deum omne Verbum, nothing is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to God, I eaÅ¿ily beleeue that hee, who placed this great world it Å¿elf in a place where there was nothing before, can eaÅ¿ily place a houÅ¿e there where there was no houÅ¿e before;

Now that it was Å¿o tranÅ¿lated de facto, both ancient records, Å¿olid depoÅ¿itions, See TurÅ¿elinus his hiÅ¿tory of the HouÅ¿e of Loreto. conÅ¿tant tradition, and the beleef of all, almoÅ¿t, the Catholick of Princes of Europe (who haue Å¿ent rich preÅ¿ents hitherâ–ª do teÅ¿tify. BeÅ¿ides, I can Å¿ay this, that the walls are of Å¿uch a Å¿tone as is not vÅ¿ed in any houÅ¿e in all the country round about: a great preÅ¿umption, that this wall is exotick. Againe, the Holy HouÅ¿e here hauing no foundation in the ground (as we Å¿ee plainely) it is not credible that it was built here by men, who would haue giuen Å¿ome little foundation at leaÅ¿t to walls of that thickneÅ¿Å¿e, and to a houÅ¿e of that bigneÅ¿Å¿, eÅ¿pecially standing alone in the fields, as it did at firÅ¿t, and expoÅ¿ed to all weather. Now, as for the Holy HouÅ¿e it Å¿elf,The Holy HouÅ¿e of Loreto. it Å¿tands in the midÅ¿t of a great Church, which hath been built ouer it in Later times, for the better coÌ„ueniency of the peoples deuotion, and the Church Å¿eruice: and round about it more immediatly, there hath been built a decoration of white marble, which Å¿tands half a foot diÅ¿tant from the Holy HouÅ¿e, that men may Å¿ee it was not intended Å¿o much for a prop, as for a decoration to it, as alÅ¿o to keep is from the hands of deuout pilgrims who otherwiÅ¿e would haue made no Å¿cruple to haue bine nibling at the Å¿tones of the walls here, and Å¿o in time, haue much defaced the Holy HouÅ¿e, with their Pious thefts. In the end of the Holy HouÅ¿e, there is a window, where it is imagined the Angel entered when he came EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to the Virgin Mary concerning the great buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿ of the Incarnation of his Lord and MaÅ¿ter. This window is now cheeked and enriched with
Å¿yluer. CloÅ¿e behinde the Altar runns quite croÅ¿Å¿e the Chappel, a great iron grate, through which you Å¿ee the Statue of Cedar of our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady, with her Å¿on in her armes. Its Å¿ayd to haue been made by S. Luke, and was brought hither together with the Chappel, or Holy HouÅ¿e. It Å¿tands vp high in the Very farther end of the Chappel. Between this Statue of our Lady and the Iron Grate, hang a row of Lampes, (about twelue in all) of pure gold, and all as big as a mans head; one were of exceeds the reÅ¿t in curious workemanship; and it was the guift of SigiÅ¿mond King of Polonia. TheÅ¿e I yet remember: to wit, The image in Å¿yluer of the eldeÅ¿t Sonne of Ferdinand the III Emperor with a chain of diamands about it. this Prince of CondÃ© in Å¿yluer kneeling, a vowe of his mother when he went firÅ¿t to warre. The BuÅ¿to of S. Barbara in Å¿ylver, Å¿et with iewels; the guift of an Archduke of AuÅ¿tria. An other BuÅ¿to of S. Girione, Å¿et with Iewels alÅ¿o; a guift of a Queen of Bohemia. The Statue of S. LadiÅ¿laus in Å¿yluer; the guift of LadiÅ¿laus the IV. King of Polonia. The heart enriched with Diamands, with a great Emeraud in the middle of it, of an exceÅ¿Å¿iue bigneÅ¿Å¿ the guift of Henry III. of France at his returne out of Polognia. In an other, the rich enamelled three cornerd iewel, with the picture of the BleÅ¿Å¿ed Æ²irgin in the middle of it; the preÅ¿ent of two Bohemian Counts and a Gentleman, who being throwne out of a high window in Prague by the Calumnists, and recommending themÅ¿elues to Gods protection and our Ladyes interceÅ¿Å¿ion, fell downe all three gently without the leaÅ¿t hurt. a Gentleman that was Secretary to Count Slauata, who being throwne out the laÅ¿t, and falling vpon the Count his maÅ¿ter, cryed him mercey for his rudeneÅ¿Å¿ in falling vpon him; a great argument that they were little hurt, when they could compliment with one an other. In an other cupbord I Å¿aw Å¿eueral great chaines of gold, giuen by great men; and Å¿ome of theÅ¿e by great Generalls. In an other, A great Heart of gold, as big as both a mans hands, enameled with blew, and Å¿et on the outÅ¿ide of it with theÅ¿e words in pretty big Diamands, IESVS, MARIA, and within it are the pictures of the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Virgin on one Å¿ide; and of the Queen of England Henrietta Maria on the other; the Heart opening it Å¿elf into two leaues. In an other, a neat little heart alÅ¿o of gold enameled, and Å¿et with iewels; the preÅ¿ent of Madame ChriÅ¿tina
DutcheÅ¿Å¿e of Sauoye, and Å¿iÅ¿ter to the ForeÅ¿ayd Queen of England, with her owne and her Å¿onns picture in it. In an other, the picture of our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lady with her Å¿onne IESVS in her armes, cut in a great pearle, and Å¿et in gold. In an other cupbord, I Å¿aw a picture of our B. In an other, a great cuÅ¿todia of cryÅ¿tal giuen by ChriÅ¿tina of ToÅ¿cany. In an other, a cuÅ¿todia of Lapis Lazuli. In an other a Diamand valued at twelue thouÅ¿and crownes, the guift of the Prince d'Oria in Genua. An other of almoÅ¿t equal price giuen by a German Prince. In an other a curious booke of gold couered with Diamands with the leaues of gold, but rarely painted in miniature, the guift of a Duke of Bauaria. In an other, the Samaritanâ–ª Well of gold, with the pictures of our Sauiour, and the Samaritan
woman in gold alÅ¿o; the preÅ¿ent of Cardinal Brancaccio. In diuers other cupbords I Å¿aw a world of Iewels of all Å¿ortes, which confounded my memory as well as dazeled my eyes. In other great cupbords, they shewed me excellent Church ornaments of moÅ¿t rich Å¿tuffs embrodered with Å¿yluer and gold, but one there was (to wit a whole compleat Å¿ute for the Altar, PrieÅ¿t, Deacon, and Subdeacon) Å¿o thick couered with an embrodery of pearle, and thoÅ¿e no little ones, that I could not preceiue the ground of the Å¿tuff for pearle: all theÅ¿e were the preÅ¿ent of Catherine Zamoisky wife of the Chancelour of Polonia; and they are valued at a hundred and thirty thouÅ¿and crownes. From hence we went to Å¿ee the

They have away to take out a peÃ©ce of their broad Å¿ides, and Å¿o make them cleane. Holy HouÅ¿e too great, you may eaÅ¿ily coniecture, when Å¿o many perÅ¿ons are fed dayly, as I mentioned aboue, and Å¿o many thouÅ¿and pilgrims paÅ¿Å¿e Å¿o frequently that way. Hauing refreshed our Å¿elues in this Celler, we went to the Apothecaries shopâ–ª The Apothecaries shop. belonging to the Holy HouÅ¿e alÅ¿o, and furnishing phyÅ¿ick to Å¿ick pilgrims for nothing. Catholica.From hence we paÅ¿Å¿ed by Catholica a poore Village, adorned with nothing but a Å¿tately Name, and an InÅ¿cription vpon the wall of the Chappel, rendering you the reaÅ¿on
why this towne is called Catholica, which was this. When the Emperour ConÅ¿tantius a fierce Arrian vÅ¿ed violence to the Fathers that had been aÅ¿Å¿embled in the Council of Arimini [a towne not farre off) and would not Å¿uffer them to depart (their buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿ being done, which they came for, to wit; the Catholick Faith of the Council of Nice being here aÅ¿Å¿erted and confirmed) till they had complyed with the Emperors faction conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of Arrians; Many of them too weakly (being weary of Å¿o long a Å¿tay from their Seats) fell to an vnworthy complyance with the Arrian party. Which the zealous orthodoxe Fathers Å¿eeing, left Rimini, and came into this little Village, becauÅ¿e they would not communicate with the Arrians: Wherevpon this Æ²illage got the name of Catholica, becauÅ¿e the true Catholike and orthodoxe Fathers retired hither. If you aske me then, whether this Council of Rimini were good or no; I anÅ¿wer you, that
the Council was good and orthodoxe, and confirmed the Fayth of the Nicen Council againÅ¿t the Arrians; which was the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿ it was called about. And what happened afterwards when the Council was ended by the oppreÅ¿Å¿ion of the Emperor, is not to be imputed to the Council; but to Å¿ome weake Fathers as an error of conuerÅ¿ation, and a too vnworthy complance.

ny of Padua in confirmation of the
â€¢ eall PreÅ¿ence. The HiÅ¿tory is too long, but Å¿een here painted round the Chappel, with a caÅ¿t of an eye.

From hence we went through CeÅ¿ena an EpiÅ¿copal towne;CeÅ¿ena. and Forli, Forli. Forum Liuij an other BPÅ¿. Å¿eat; in the way before we came to CeÅ¿ena we Å¿aw an old inÅ¿cription in Å¿tone Å¿et vp by a little riuers Å¿ide, which I found to be the very Decree of the old Senate of Rome, forbiding in general, any Officer, or Å¿oldier whatÅ¿oeuer to paÅ¿Å¿e ouer the Rubicon vpon payne of being iudged an enemy to his country and guilty of High TreaÅ¿on. By which words I gathered that this little riuer here now called PiÅ¿tatello, was Rubicon, Rubicon. mentioned in the Decree of the Senate; and that this Decree pointed at Iulius CaeÅ¿ar and his army. Yet CaeÅ¿ar being reÅ¿olued to march vp to Rome with his army, made aÅ¿peech to his Å¿oldiers; and finding a compliance in their reÅ¿olutions, paÅ¿Å¿ed ouer Rubicon, cryeing out: Iacta eÅ¿t alea: â€¢ e muÅ¿t now either Å¿ink or Swim, and Å¿o paÅ¿Å¿ed on to Rome, which he Å¿oon poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed himÅ¿elf of & then of the world. When once powerfull men draw their
Å¿words, they throw away their Å¿cabbards: and when once they haue offended beyong pardon, they Å¿trike at the very throat of authority; running vpon that horrid maxime, that Å¿celera Å¿celeribus Å¿unt tuenda.

From Forli we paÅ¿Å¿ed on the right hand to Faenza, Fauentia in Latin â–ª (leauing the way on the left hand, which leads to Imola & Bolognia.) In the way I found little worth obÅ¿ervation, except onely that as we traueled one night Å¿omewhat late, for cooleneÅ¿Å¿, I Å¿aw millions of little flyes in the ayre, carrying a bright light about them like glowwormes, They continued all the way to our Inne for two houres after Å¿unÅ¿et, eÅ¿pecially vpon the corne fields and high graÅ¿Å¿e. It was huge pretty me thought, to
