A Po â€¢ t would haue Å¿worne by all the cordes of Apollos harpe, that Iupiter then was makeing Vulcan paue the Vault of heauen with a MoÅ¿aick worke of Diamands, and that theÅ¿e were onely the Å¿parks that fell from him: or that he was repareing the old cauÅ¿Å¿ey of the Via Lactea with fresh Å¿tarrs, and that theÅ¿e were the old ones which he had throwne away. I catched Å¿ome of theÅ¿e fiery flyes, to Å¿ee where it was that they carryed their little Lanternes and candles, and I found it was in their tayles. The country people call them Lucciole. And I beleeue,Plin. l. 18. c. 26. AriÅ¿t. l. 1. de partib. animal. c. 3. theÅ¿e are thoÅ¿e flyes which Pliny calls Cicindelas, and AriÅ¿totle calls ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ .

The Rarities.1. The D â€¢ mo, ancient rather then beautifull.

â€¢ ere the Popes Legate lyeth.

5. The Diamand Pallace, The Di â€¢
mant Pallace. as they call it, is of white marble without, whoÅ¿e Å¿tones are all cut diamant wiÅ¿e into sharp points. 6. The MonaÅ¿tery of the Benedictins is Å¿tately, in whoÅ¿e church I found the Tombe of ArioÅ¿to author of the long PoÃ«me called Orlando FurioÅ¿o. ArioÅ¿to Tombe. He was eÅ¿teemed in his life time a great PoÃ«t, and as Å¿uch was crowned Laureat PoÃ«t by the Emperor
Charles the V. but he was oftentimes Å¿een, euen in the Å¿treets, to be too much tranÅ¿ported with PoÃ«tick fury, and to become ArioÅ¿to furioÅ¿o, while he was penning his Orlando He had a rich Æ²aine, but a poore purÅ¿e; and while his head was crowned with Laurel, his breeches were often out behinde, as well as thoÅ¿e of Torquato TaÅ¿Å¿o, of whom Balzac sayth, that though he were a good PoÃ«t, yet he had des fort mauuaiÅ¿es chauÅ¿es.

Embarking then betimes in
the morning at Padua in a Pi â€¢ tta, a neat little barge, taken to our Å¿elues, and much more honorable then to go in the great tiltboate, where all Å¿ortes of looÅ¿y ruffians and idle people throng you vp; we Å¿aw a world of Å¿tately Pallaces and gardens Å¿tanding vpon the bankes of the riuer Brenta, and sewing vs that we were approching to a great towne indeed.

Some fiue miles short of Venice, we left the riuer and the horÅ¿es that drew vs, and â€¢ owed through the Shallow Sea which enuironeth Æ²enice on all Å¿ides for aboue fiue miles Å¿pace. This low Sea is called here La Laguna;La Laguna. and the water is Å¿o shallow, that no great ships can come to Æ²enice: little veÅ¿Å¿els come by certain channels which are well fortifyed with caÅ¿tles, forts, & chaynes: Å¿o that no man can come to Venice but with Leaue, or knocks. the midÅ¿t of the Sea; and Å¿tanding fixed where euery thing els floats.

Venice at firÅ¿tâ–ª was nothing but a company of little dry Å¿pots of ground, The origin of Venice. which held vp their heads in a Shallow Sea furnished by Saeuen riuers, Piaua, Sila, Liuenza, Po, Adige, Brenta, and Tagliamento, Which runn into it. This many men did: & made at laÅ¿t a fine
towne here, and greater then her mother Padua. This happened twelue hundred years agoe, which makes Venice glory, that she is the ancienteÅ¿t Republick in Europe. To which purpoÅ¿e I cannot omit to tell here a pretty Å¿tory which was told me in Paris of Ã Æ²enetian EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, who reÅ¿ideing in the Court of France, and finding himÅ¿elf in a viÅ¿ite where there were many Ladyes, was Å¿eriouÅ¿ly asked by a graue old Lady (who heard him Å¿peak much of the Seignorie of Venice).EÅ¿t-elle belle? Whether the Seignorie of Æ²enice were fair or no? yes Madame, Å¿ayd hee; one of the faireÅ¿t in Europe. EÅ¿t elle grande? Is she great? Å¿ayd the Lady again: yes, Madame, Å¿ayd the EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, she is great enough. Is she riche?EÅ¿t elle riche? Å¿ayd the Lady
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ worth millions, replyed the EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador. Me thinks then, Å¿ayd the Lady, she would be a good match for MonÅ¿ieur the Kings Brother: yes, Madame, replyed hee againe, but that she is a little too old.Quelle aige a elle? Why how old is she I pray you? Å¿ayd
the Lady. Madame, anÅ¿wered the EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, she is about twelue hundred years old. At which the company Å¿mileing, the good Lady perceiued her errour with blushing, and MonÅ¿ieur was vnmarryed for that preÅ¿ent. Indeed CoÅ¿mography, and Topography are hard words; and as the old Å¿aying is, aliud Å¿ceptrum, aliud plectrum, a looking glaÅ¿Å¿e is not the Å¿ame thing with a Map.

As for Æ²enice now,Venice now. its one of the faireÅ¿t Cities in Europe, and called by the Proverbial Epithete, Venetia la Ricca, Venice the Rich. Its well nigh eight miles in compaÅ¿Å¿e, and in forme Å¿omething like a Lute. It hath no walls about it to defend it: but a mote of water that is fiue miles broad which Å¿urrounds it. It hath no Å¿uburbs, but a world of little Ilands cloÅ¿e by it. The Streets of Venice are all full of water; and for this reaÅ¿on they vÅ¿e no c â€¢ aches here, but viÅ¿it in boats.

TheÅ¿e boats they call here Gondolas, The Gondolas. and there are aboue twenty thouÅ¿and of them. For beÅ¿ides that euery noble Venetian or rich
man hath two or there of his owne, there are alwayes a world of them Å¿tanding together at Å¿eueral publick wharfs; so that you need but cry out, Gondola, and you haue them lanch out preÅ¿ently to youâ–ª theÅ¿e Gondolas are pretty neat black boats like ou â€¢
oares, holding Å¿ix perÅ¿ons conueniently vpon the Seats, which are couered ouer head with a thick black cloath, with windows at either Å¿ide, which in winter defends you from the winde, and in Å¿ommer from the Sun. Ordinary people here may go vp and downe the towne by little back allyes, which they call here Calle; theÅ¿e by winding vp and downe, and deliuering them ouer Å¿eueral bridges, hugely puzzle Å¿trangers at firÅ¿t. Of theÅ¿e bridges there are aboue 1500 in Venice, Bridges in Venice. all of Å¿tone and of one arch reaching from one Å¿ide of a Å¿treet to the other, while the Gondolas run vnder the Arch.
The greateÅ¿t of theÅ¿e bridges is called the Rialto, The Rialto. built ouer the Canal Grande, all of white marble. This is one of the fineÅ¿t bridges in Europe, becauÅ¿e of the one arch onely, & of the vaÅ¿t wideneÅ¿Å¿e and height of that arch; the Chanel here being as wide as any man can throw a Å¿tone. This bridge bears vpon its back two rowes of shops, and little houÅ¿es couered with lead; and leaÅ¿t this great weight should make the foundation Å¿ink, they built it vpon piloties, that is, great trees ramed into the ground, to the number of Å¿ix thouÅ¿and in all. In fine, this bridge coÅ¿t two hundred and fifty thouÅ¿and crownes. It were a fine Å¿ight, to Å¿ee in a hard froÅ¿t, the Å¿treets of Æ²enice all frozen, and people walkeing vp and downe vpon diamant Å¿treets, or a cryÅ¿tal pauement. In the meane time its no vnpleaÅ¿ing Å¿ight to Å¿ee the Å¿treets full of water, and Å¿uch Å¿tately pallaces on either Å¿ide, eÅ¿pecially the Canal Grande, which runns quite through the midle of
the Citie, and is hedged in on either Å¿ide with Å¿tately houÅ¿es, among which are counted two hundred pallaces fit to lodge any King. The whole Citie hath in it 32 MonaÅ¿teryes of Religious men, 28 of Religious women, 70 Parish Churches; and about a hundred and fourscore thouÅ¿and inhabitants.
Hauing Å¿ayd thus much of the Å¿ituation of Venice, I will now Å¿peak of the Gouerment, Strength, Riches, Religion, and IntereÅ¿t of this Republick, and then fall to the particulars I Å¿aw in it.

To run through all the MaegiÅ¿trats and Officiers of this Republick, the Pregiadi, the Å¿aui Grandi, the Å¿aui di Terra ferma, the Å¿aui de gli Ordini, the conÅ¿iglio de dieci, &c. would be aworke too long for a traueler, and too tedious for my reader. He is now choÅ¿en by the whole Senate, and is for life: heretofore he was hereditary till the yeare 1032. the manner of baloting in chooÅ¿ing the DogÃ© is Å¿uch a puzzle, that I had rather you should read it in Sabellicus, then I giue my Å¿elf the trouble of deÅ¿cribing it. Being choÅ¿en once, he cannot Å¿tirre out of the Laguna without leaue. TheÅ¿e Å¿ix Å¿it with him in CounÅ¿el, & execute with him all buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es, as to giue audience, read letters, grant priuiledges, and the like: which
cannot be executed by the DogÃ¨, if there be not four CounÅ¿elours with him; and yet they can execute and act without the DogÃ¨: and its they that haue authority to propoÅ¿e in the Great CounÅ¿el, things of concerne. In giuing Å¿uffrages, his Å¿uffrage is no more then an ordinary Senators, in the Sanate; but he hath two voyces in the Great CounÅ¿el. The DogÃ¨ and theÅ¿e CounÅ¿elours are called Il C â€¢ llegio, but then in main publick affairs there enters into this CounÅ¿el, Å¿ix Saui Grandi, fiue Saui di Terra Ferma, fiue Saui de gli Ordini, and tre Capi de Quaranta Criminali. This full Colledge diÅ¿tributs buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es to the other MagiÅ¿trats to be handed, hauing been headed here.

The Habit of the DogÃ¨ is ancient, and hath Å¿omething of the Pontifical habit in it. For the moÅ¿t part the DogÃ¨ is choÅ¿en out of thoÅ¿e, whom they call here, Procuratori di S. Marco. Procuratori di San Marco. TheÅ¿e Procuratori are of high ranck and eÅ¿teeme in this Republick. Heretofore there was but one Procuratore di San Marco, whoÅ¿e office was, to haue a care of all things belonging to S. Marks Church and the TreaÅ¿or. But now there are twentyfiue, moÅ¿t of which haue made their circle of EmbaÅ¿Å¿yes in forrain Courts, and are fit wood to make DogÃ¨s of: though Å¿ome of them of late haue been aÅ¿Å¿umed to that dignity for money; the State now makeing money of all men, as well as of all things.

Their Strength.As for the Strength and Power of Æ²enice, its very Great; their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions in Italy, being full as great as the Popes; and out of Italy, farre greater. In Italy they hold fourteen Prouinces vnder them. They are
Lords of the Gulph, or Adriatick Sea.
They poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e the coaÅ¿t of Dalmatia beyond the Gulph. They hold the Iles of Corfu, Cephalonia and Zante.

Candia, or the Ile of Creta, belongs to them by due. The kingdome of Cyprus alÅ¿o is pretended to by them; and by it, and Candy, whoÅ¿e two crownes they shew vs in the TreaÅ¿or, Venice is Å¿tiled SereniÅ¿sima. The kingdome of Cyprus came to the Venetians by Katherine Cornaro â–ª who was made heire of it by her Å¿on the King thereof, who dyed yong and with out yÅ¿Å¿ue about the yeare 1438. The Å¿toty is this.LoÅ¿chi in Compendi â€¢ HiÅ¿tor. Katherine was daughter of Marco Cornaro, and neece of Andrew Cornaro two noblemen of Venice. Andrew was Å¿ent Auditore Generale into the Kingdome of Cyprus, in the time of Iames King of that Iland, and helpt him to many thouÅ¿and crownes, where by he Å¿etled his tottering crowne. One day as the King was talkeing familiarly with him, he let fall (whether by chance, or deÅ¿igne) a little picture in miniature,
of a Very hanÅ¿ome Lady. The King curious to Å¿ee it, called for it ciuilly, and viewing it well, fell hugely in loue with the Original of it, which Andrew aÅ¿Å¿ured him to be farre hanÅ¿omer then the copie â–ª and withall added, that if his MaieÅ¿ty liked her, she was his Neece, and that therefore he offered her freely to him, for his wife, with all the money he had already lent him, and a hundred thouÅ¿and crownes more. The King bit willingly at theÅ¿e two baits, beauty and Money, and was not quiet till he had marryed her. Of her he had but one Å¿onn, whom (dyeing) he left under his mothers protection: but he dyeing alÅ¿o not long after, left his mother heire of the kingdome; and she at her death, left this crowne and kingdome to the Venetians by Will and Guift. This whole hiÅ¿tory I Å¿aw painted in the Pallace of Cornaro by the hand of Paulo Veron â€¢ Å¿e. As fo â€¢ the Å¿trong holds which the Venetians poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e in Italy, they are theÅ¿e: Crema, Bergamo, BreÅ¿cia, PeÅ¿ch â€¢â€¢ ra,
ChioÅ¿a, and Palma Nuoua in Fruth. Palma Noua. This laÅ¿t is one of the beÅ¿t places in Europe Is hath nine royal baÅ¿tions; eighteen caualiers, which command all the neighboring campagnia; it hath di â€¢ ches of water about it thirty paces broad, and twelue deep; Its ramparts behinde the wall are high and couering, and they are alwayes fringed with a hundred peÃ©ces of Cannon, and ready to receiue Å¿ix hundred more, which are alwayes in its magazin ready upon all occaÅ¿ions. And for men and armour, as the great ArÅ¿enal in Venice hath alwayes armes in readyneÅ¿Å¿ for a hundred thouÅ¿and men; Å¿o this State being peopled with three millions of men, would eaÅ¿ily finde three or four hundred thouÅ¿and men of Å¿eruice, and a hundred Gallyes: yet their ordinary militia is but of fourÅ¿core thouÅ¿and foot, and Å¿ome 6000 HorÅ¿e; and about thirty Gallyes.

As for their Riches;Their Riches. though their ordinary reuenues (before theÅ¿e late warrs with the Turk) exceeded not four millions, yet now
they Å¿purre themÅ¿elues, and the country â€¢ , vp to exceÅ¿Å¿iue Å¿umms. Few dye but they bequeath Å¿omething to Å¿uch a ChriÅ¿tian Å¿eruice as this warre is. BeÅ¿ides this, the taxes are much augmented, and Å¿eizures & forfetures more narrowly looked into, to help publick expences. In fine, beÅ¿ides the great trading which Venice driues, (Aleppo alone bringing in Å¿ome yeares, four millions of gold) the Venetiant haue found out a Very compendious way to rayÅ¿e, in one quarter of an houre, and by one deash of a pen, fifty hundred thouÅ¿and crownes, to help themÅ¿elues withall at a dead lift, and incommodate no man. This they did An 1646, when fifty rich familyes in Æ²enice gaue to the State a hundred thouÅ¿and crownes a peÃ©ce to be made noble Æ²enetians. The like courÅ¿e they took to rayÅ¿e money, about a hundred yeares ago, when they were Å¿et vpon by moÅ¿t of the Princes of Europe at once.

Their Religion.As for their Religion, its Roman Catholick, and they haue neuer
changed it Å¿ince the begining of their Republick. Hence Mr. Raymond in his Mercurio Italico page 188. Å¿ayth truly, that Venite hath this property aboue all other States; that she is a Æ²irgin, and more, from her firÅ¿t infancy, ChriÅ¿tian: hauing neuer yet fell, from her Principles either in Gouerment, or Religion. It began to be built the Very Å¿ame yeare, that S. AuguÅ¿tin dyed, (as Baronius obÅ¿erues.)

As for the IntereÅ¿t of this Republick, Their IntereÅ¿t. they are now well with the Emperor; not out with Spayne, no â€¢ too Å¿ecure of his Friendship; kinde with the French, as long as they keep out of Italy; well affected to England; and iuÅ¿t friends with the Pope.
Now for the particulars which I Å¿aw in Venice, they were theÅ¿e.

1. The men ThemÅ¿elues here,The noble men of Venice. who looked like men indeed: and as a PhiloÅ¿opher anciently Å¿ayd, that when he came from Corinth to Sparta, he Å¿eemed to come from horÅ¿es to men: Å¿o me thought, when I came from France to Venice I came from boyes to men. For here
I Å¿aw the hanÅ¿omeÅ¿t, the moÅ¿t Å¿ightly, the moÅ¿t proper and graue men that ever I Å¿aw any where elÅ¿e. They weare alwayes in the towne (I Å¿peake of the noblemen) a long black gowne a black cap knit, with an edgeing of black wooll about it, like a fringe; an ancient and manly weare, which makes them looke like Senators. Their hair is generaly the beÅ¿tâ–ª I euerÅ¿aw any where; theÅ¿e little caps not preÅ¿ing it downe as our hats do; & Perywigs are here forbid. Vnder their long gownes (which fly open before) they haue hanÅ¿ome black Å¿utes of rich Å¿tuffs with Å¿tockins and garters, and Å¿panith leather shoos neatly made. In a word, I neuer Å¿aw Å¿o many proper men together, nor Å¿o wiÅ¿e, as I Å¿aw dayly there walking vpon the Piazza of S. Mark. I may boldly Å¿ay, that I Å¿aw there fiue hundred gentlemen walking together euery day, euery one of which was able to play the EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador in any Princes Court of Europe. But the miÅ¿ery is, that we Å¿trangers cannot walk
there with them, and talk with them, but muÅ¿t keep out of their way, and Å¿tand a loof off. The reaÅ¿on is this: This Å¿tate (as all Republicks are) being hugely gealous of her liberty and preÅ¿eruation, forbids her Noble men and Senators to converÅ¿e with Forrain EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, or any man that either is an actual Å¿eruant or follower of an EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, or hath any the leaÅ¿t relation to any Princes Agent, with out expreÅ¿Å¿e leaue; and this vpon payne of being Å¿uÅ¿pected as a Traitor, and condignly punished. This makes them shy to all Å¿trangers, not Knowing what relation they may have to Å¿ome forain Å¿tates man of Agent. For the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on they will not let their wifes viÅ¿it the wifes of forrain EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors reÅ¿ideing in Venice, for feare of being Å¿uÅ¿pected to commit treaÅ¿on by proxie. They haue in the wall of the Pallace, in diuers places, certain wide mouths of marble Å¿tone, ouer which I found written theÅ¿e words: Denuncie Å¿ecrete, Priuate informations, into which they caÅ¿t Å¿ecretly
papers of accuÅ¿ations, by which they accuÅ¿e Å¿ecretly any officer, or nobleman, whom they durÅ¿t not accuÅ¿e publickly. This maKes men Å¿tand hugely vpon their garde, and be wary with whom they conuerÅ¿e, and what they Å¿ay.

The noble women of Venice â€¢
2. As for the women here, they would gladly get the Å¿ame reputation That their huÅ¿bands have, of being tall and hanÅ¿ome; but they ouer do it with their horrible cioppini, or high Shoos, which I haue often Å¿een to be a full half yard high. I confeÅ¿Å¿e, I wondered at firÅ¿t, to Å¿ee women go vpon Å¿tilts, and appeare taller by the head then any man; and not to be able to go any whither without reÅ¿ting their hands vpon the shoulders of two grave matrons that vÅ¿sher them: but at laÅ¿t, I perceiued that it was good policy, and a pretty ingenious way either to clog women at home by Å¿uch heauy shoos (as the Egyptians Kept their Wifes at home by allowing them no shoos at all); or at leaÅ¿t to make them not able to go either
farre, or alone, or inuiÅ¿ibly. As for the yong ladyes of this towne that are not marryed, they are neuer Å¿een abroad, but masked like MoÅ¿carades in a Å¿trang diÅ¿guiÅ¿e, at the Fair time, and other publick Å¿olemnityes or Shows, Being at other times brought vp in MonaÅ¿teries of Nunns, till they be marryed.

3.S. Marks Church. Then I went to the Church of S. Dominick, the other of S. The little ArÅ¿enal.6. Hauing Å¿een theÅ¿e Chambers of Iudicature, we were led about to the Sala of the ConÅ¿iglio de Dieci, (otherwiÅ¿e called, the little ArÅ¿enal) in the Pallace Å¿till. This armory is to Å¿ecure the DogÃ¨ and the Senators (while they are aÅ¿Å¿embled in counÅ¿el) from such like treaÅ¿ons as haue been plotted againÅ¿t them whilÅ¿t they were Å¿itting in counÅ¿el. Butcher of his Prince and countrymen. here alÅ¿o in this ArÅ¿enal we Å¿aw the Å¿word and armes of braue Scanderbeg Prince of Albania, who wonne Å¿eauen battles ouer Å¿eauen the moÅ¿t illuÅ¿trious BaÅ¿Å¿as the Great Turk had, and dyed after all, peaceably in his EÅ¿tates, in Å¿pite of Amurath. This caÅ¿e was made for a great Lookeing glaÅ¿Å¿e which the Venetians Å¿ent vnto the SultaneÅ¿Å¿e of the great Turk; but the ship that carryed it, meeting in the way a Fregat which brought the news of a great Victory gotten ouer the Turks by the Venetians vpon Sancta IuÅ¿tinas day, it returnd back againe with the preÅ¿ent, and

The boxe of botargos here is iuÅ¿t Å¿uch another inuention. A piÅ¿tol in a pocket booke here, is as bad as the others, which being charged and let off, would preÅ¿ently read your doome. Swords and daggers, with piÅ¿tol and little gun barrels runing along their blades, which being held drawne with the broad Å¿ide to a man, appeare to be onely plain Å¿words and daggers,

The Piazza of S. Mark.Hauing thus Å¿een this Cabinet of Mars, we went out of the Pallace into the Piazza of S. Mark, vpon which both the foreÅ¿ayd Church of S. Mark, and the DogÃ¨s Pallace looke. Theodorus; the other, the Lyon of S. Mark, theÅ¿e two Saints, S. Mark and S. Theodore, being the two Patrons of this City. TheÅ¿e two pillars were erected here by a Lombard, who required no other recompence for his paynes, then that it might be lawfull for dice-players to play at dice between theÅ¿e two pillars without being punished or moleÅ¿ted, nay though they playd falÅ¿e play. Ouer againÅ¿t the Pallace Å¿tands the Mint, in a place called La Zeccha, and from hence the gold coyned here is called Zecchino, a peÃ©ce of gold worth Å¿ome Å¿eauen shillings fixpence of our mony. 8. TheÅ¿e three maÅ¿t â€¢
Å¿ignify the three nobleÅ¿t parts of the Venetians dominions, to wit the kingdomes of Cyprus, and of Candy, and the State of Venice. In this Piazza I found alwayes a world

In this Piazza alÅ¿o Å¿tands the Campanile, or High Å¿teeple of Æ²enice, diÅ¿tant Å¿ome fifty paces from the Church of S. Mark. of it is almoÅ¿t as deep vnderground, as the top of it is high aboue ground; a wonder, if you conÅ¿ider rhat it Å¿tands in Venice. Marks Church, its FrontiÅ¿pice, its Cupolas and the four horÅ¿es of braÅ¿Å¿e guilt which Å¿tand ouer the FrontiÅ¿pice. The ArÅ¿enal.9. Takeing therefore a Gondola, we went to the ArÅ¿enal, Where after the ordinary formalityes of leauing our Å¿words at the dore, and paying the Porters fees, we were admitted, and led through this great Shop of Mars. The expences of theÅ¿e workemen amount to a thouÅ¿and Ducats euery day in the yeare: Å¿o that they make accompt that they Å¿pend in this ArÅ¿enal four hundred & thirty thouÅ¿and crownes a yeare: Enough almoÅ¿t to maintain a pretty army conÅ¿tantly. Euery workeman here hath wine twice a day, and that
very good too, but that it is a little mingled with water. We were led through all the vaÅ¿t rooms of this Magazin, rooms like vaÅ¿t Churches. In one of them I Å¿aw nothing but great
â€¢ ares for Gallyes, Å¿eauen men going to one oare. In another, nothing but vaÅ¿t Å¿ternes. In another, nothing but vaÅ¿t nayles for Gallyes and ships. In another they were making nothing but Salpeeter for gunpowder. In another they were caÅ¿ting great Cannons, Morter peÃ©ces, and Chambers. In an other they had nothing but a pair of vaÅ¿t Scales to weigh Cannons with. In another, MaÅ¿ts for Gallyes and ships of a prodigious greatneÅ¿Å¿ and length; and yet of Å¿uch a rare timber, that one filipping vpon one end of them, you heare it eaÅ¿ily at the other end, by applying your care to it. Some of theÅ¿e maÅ¿ts are worth fourÅ¿core pounds. In other vaÅ¿t roomes I Å¿aw Å¿tore of Cannons of all Å¿izes both for ships and Gallyes: where alÅ¿o I Å¿aw Å¿ome Turkish Cannons with words vpon them in the Turkish

There I Å¿aw alÅ¿o one Cannon shooting three shotts at once: another fiue: one great Cannon found buryed in Candy-full of gold medals: the great Cannons caÅ¿t here while Henry the III. of France dined in this ArÅ¿enal. They had heretofore a prodigious quantity of Cannons here, but now theÅ¿e roomes are much emptyed by reaÅ¿on of this warre with the Turks. Then mounting vp into the Chambers aboue, I Å¿aw in two vaÅ¿t roomes, armes for fifty ThouÅ¿and men. in another, armes for twelue Gallyes: in another, armes for Fifty Gallyes. Here alÅ¿o I Å¿aw the Å¿ute of armour of Scanderbeg: that of the DogÃ¨ zani, the Lanterne of Don Iohn of AuÅ¿trias ship in the battle of Lepanto: the Lanterne of a Turkish Galley: the armour of Baiamante Theopoli and his complices, with one arme onely: Å¿ome armes taken from the Turks in the battle of Lepanto, other armes taken from the GenueÅ¿i; a great
CroÅ¿Å¿ebow, shooting VaÅ¿t arrowes of iron aboue fiue quarters long: an inuention of great vÅ¿e before Gunne were found out. A cannon bullet with four long irons, like the tops of halbards, which shut vp cloÅ¿e into it when you put it into the Cannon, but open againe of themÅ¿elues, as Å¿oon as the bullet is out of the Cannons mouth; and Å¿o Å¿preading into four parts, cut all they meet, with Å¿trange fury: a dangerous inuention in Sea battles, to to Å¿poyle cordage and tackling. Then deÅ¿cending from thence, we went to Å¿ee the places where they make new Gallyes, and mend old ones. The AÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿a.10. I happened to be at Æ²enice thrice, at the great Sea Triumph, or feaÅ¿t of the AÅ¿cenÅ¿ion, which was performed thus. Then I enquired what learned men had adorned Venice, The Learned Men. and I found theÅ¿e to haue been the chiefe, Laurentius IuÅ¿tinianus, Hermolaus Barbarus, Petrus Bembus, AloyÅ¿ius Lippomanus, Paulus Paruta, BaptiÅ¿ta Egnatius, Ludouicus Dolce, Paulus Manutius, with diuers others. The Academy of wits.30. Heres an Academy of wits called Incogniti, and for their armes, they haue the riuer Nilus, with this motto; Incognito, e pur noto: vnknowne, and yet famous.
The HiÅ¿torians.He that deÅ¿ires to know the hiÅ¿tory of Venice, let him read Andrea MoraÅ¿ini, Paolo Paruta, Sabellico, Bernardino TomaÅ¿ino, Corid â€¢ , and Nani.

Hauing thus Å¿een all Æ²enice, ouer and ouer againe, in a months Å¿tay there, I was moÅ¿t willing to leaue it; hauing found it true of Venice, what Socrates Å¿ayd of Athens, that is was melior meretrix, quam uxor; a fine towne for a fortnight; but not to dwell in alwayes;The Defects of Venice. and this, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome Å¿tinking channels; bad cellers for wine; worÅ¿e water; and the moiÅ¿t ayre of the Sea not the moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿ome; Å¿carcity of earth euen to bury their dead in; and little fewel for fireing. So that findeing the four elements wanting here in their purity, I was willing to leaue theÅ¿e polished Holanders, and returne to Padua.

Paduaâ–ª
Padua is the Å¿econd towne of the
Venetian State, though once the Mother of Æ²enice. Its old enough to be mother of Rome it Å¿elf; haueing been built by Antenor, whoÅ¿e Tombe is yet Å¿een here. The towne is very great, and fuller of good houÅ¿es, then of men of condition: taranny, and too frequent murthers haueing much depopulated it, in point of nobility. It Å¿tands in the Marca Treuigiana. The walls about it are Å¿trong, and backt vp with fine ramparts. It lyes neare the Euga â€¢ ian hills, in a fertile Å¿oyle, and plain, which makes the Prouerbe Å¿ay: Bologna la graÅ¿Å¿a, ma Padua la paÅ¿Å¿a. Its famous for the Å¿tudy of PhyÅ¿ick, as many of our thrice worthy PhyÅ¿itians in England can teÅ¿tify. The chief things I obÅ¿erued in it are theÅ¿e.
1.Antenors Tombe. Antenors Tombe, with Gotick letters vpon it: which makes me doubt whether this Tombe be Å¿o ancient as they make it.
2. The publick Schooles, called here Il Bue, or Oxe; what if the firÅ¿t Readers here came from Oxford, as they did to the VniuerÅ¿ity of Pauia?
3. The PhyÅ¿ick garden, to acquaint the Students in PhyÅ¿ick, with the nature of Å¿imples.

S. Antonies Church.4. The Church of S. Antony of Padua, whoÅ¿e body lyes in the open Chappel on the left hand; and this Chappel is adorned with curious figures of white marble repreÅ¿enting the chief actions of this Saints life. Vnder the Altar repoÅ¿eth his bodyâ–ª and before it, hang Å¿ome 27 great Lampes of Å¿yluer, or Å¿yluer guilt. OueragainÅ¿t this Chappel, Å¿tands iuÅ¿t Å¿uch another open Chappel, called, the Chappel of San Felice, which is rarely painted by famous Giotto, who made the Campanile of Florence. In a Å¿ide Chappel on the right hand, is the tombe of braue Gatta Mela, whoÅ¿e true name was EraÅ¿mo di Narni, of whom more by & by. The Tombe of Alexander Contareno General of the Venetians, and it is one of the beÅ¿t cut tombes I haue Å¿een: Its faÅ¿tened to a Å¿ide pillar. The Quire of this Church is all of inlayd woodâ–ª In the CloiÅ¿ter of the Conuent are Å¿een many tombes of learned men: and in that quarter
of the cloiÅ¿ter, which lyes vpon the Church, I found written upon a black marble Å¿tone, theÅ¿e words: Interiora Thomae Howardi Comitis Arondeliae: The bowels of the Earle of Arondel, late Lord MarÅ¿chal of England. No wonder if his bowels be enchaÅ¿ed in marble after his death, who in his life time, loued marbles con todas Å¿us entranias, with his whole bowels. His Marmora Arondeliana, commented vpon by learned Mr. Selden, shew this Å¿ufficiently. This great man dyed here in Padua, and yet in a manner at home; becauÅ¿e he had made Italy familiar to him while he liued at home.

5. Going out of this Church I Å¿aw the EqueÅ¿tris Statue of Gatta Mela, the Venetians General, whoÅ¿e tombe I Å¿aw euen now in the Church. He was nicknamed Gatta, becauÅ¿e of his watchfulneÅ¿Å¿ in carryeing buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿.

6. The Chu â€¢ ch of S. IuÅ¿tina is one of the fineÅ¿t Churches of Italy;S. IuÅ¿tinas Church & MonaÅ¿tery. and no wonder, Å¿eing its architect was Palladio. Vnder the High Altar of this Church, lyes buryed the
body of S. IuÅ¿tina. The fine Cupolas; the curious Pauement of red and black marble; the rich High Altar all of pietre commeÅ¿Å¿e; the curious Å¿eats in the Quire, with the hiÅ¿toryes of the old and new TeÅ¿tament cut in wood in them; the fine picture at the end of the Quire, ouer the Abbots Seat, containing the martyrdome of S. IuÅ¿tina, by the hand of Paolo Æ²eroneÅ¿e; the Tombe of S. Luke the EuangeliÅ¿t; and that of S. Matthias; the Well, full of Relicks; and the Tombe of S. ProÅ¿dochimus S. Peters diÅ¿ciple, and firÅ¿t Bishop of Padua, do all make this Church very conÅ¿iderable. Before this Church and MonaÅ¿tery, lyes the Campo Santo, and a faire field where they keep monthly a mercato franco, and where the euening CorÅ¿o is kept, by Ladyes & noblemen in their coaches in Å¿ommer.

7. The MonaÅ¿tery here is alÅ¿o one of the faireÅ¿t in Italy, and the Å¿econd of that Order. The painted cloiÅ¿ter, the neat Library, and the picture of S. IuÅ¿tina in the Abbats chamber, made by Paolo VeroneÅ¿e,
are all worth your curioÅ¿ity. The Domo is not Å¿o well built, as it is endowed with rich prebendaries. A hundred thouÅ¿and cownes a yeare go to the maintenance of a hundred Cleigy men, and officers belonging to it. The Prebends are 27, and ordinarily gentlemen.
28. The Pallace of the Capitano GrandÃ¨ is Å¿tately without: here Å¿tands the curious Library.

9. The great Hall called here,The great Hall. Il Palagio di Ragione, is a vaÅ¿t roome 180 paces long, & 40 broad, without pillars. It hath four great dores to it, and ouer euery dore the Statue of a learned Paduan. S. Dominico. 12. In the Dominicans Church there is a very Å¿tately High Altar of pietre commeÅ¿Å¿e. Behind the Altar (in the Quire) are the neate Tombes of the Carari, once Signors and Princes of Padua, till they were put out by the Venetians.
13.S. FranceÅ¿co. In the Church of San FranceÅ¿co Grande I Å¿aw a curious Altar of white polished marble, which pleaÅ¿ed me vety much, and the tombes of Caualcante & Longolio.

14. In the little neat Church of the Oratorians, called the Church of S. Thomas of Canterbury, S. Thomaso di Cantuaria. lyes buryed the Lady Katherine Whitenhall, in a vault made for the nonce, and couered with a white marble Å¿tone. She was daughter to the late Earle of Shrewsbury, and wife to the Noble and Vertuous Thomas Whitenhall EÅ¿quire. If you would know more of her, read here the ingenious Epitaphe written vpon her tombe, and made by her Å¿ad huÅ¿band. For my part, hauing had the honour to Å¿ee her often in her Trauels, I cannot but make honorable mention of her here in mine; She haueing Å¿o much honoured my profeÅ¿Å¿ion of Traueling by her generous humour of Traueling. She was as nobly borne as the houÅ¿e of Shrewbury could make her: as comely, as if Poets had made her. Her behauiour was Å¿uch, that if she
had not bien noble by birth, she would haue paÅ¿Å¿ed for Å¿uch by her carriage. Her good qualityes were Å¿o many, that if they had been taken in peÃ©ces, they would haue made Å¿eueral women Noble, and Noble women happy. She was wiÅ¿e beyond her yeares; Å¿tout aboue her Å¿exe; and worthy to haue found in the world all things better then she did, except her Parents and Husband. Her onely fault was that, which would haue made vp other Ladyes prayÅ¿es, too much courage; which befell her with the name of Talbo â€¢ . But whilÅ¿t her onely courage haled her on to journeys aboue her Å¿exe and force (haueing Å¿een Flanders, France, and Italy, accompanyed by her noble Husband, and a hanÅ¿ome traine) In her returne back; like a tall ship, comeing laden home and fraughted with pretious acquiÅ¿itions of mind, she Å¿unck almoÅ¿t in the hauen, and, alas! Dyed.

Hauing thus Å¿een Padua, we Å¿teered towards Milan againe, to make the compleat gyr â€¢
of Italy. The firÅ¿t dayes journey was to Vicenza,

Here we Å¿aw, the neat TownehouÅ¿e and large piazza: the houÅ¿e and fine garden of Count Valmerana, with the curious Labyrinth in the garden: the Arcus Triumphalis made by Palladio at the townes end, letting you into a fair field called the Champo Marzo, where Ladyes and Caualiers, in great Å¿tore, meet at the CorÅ¿o in their coaches euery Å¿ommer Euening: the admirable Theater The Theater. for playes and

2. The Cathedral, or Domo, ancient rather then Å¿tately. In it is buryed Pope Lucius the III, with this ingenious Epitaphe vpon his tombe:

5.The Amphitheaterâ–ª The rare Am â€¢ hitheater, built at firÅ¿t by the ConÅ¿ul Flaminius, and repayred Å¿ince by the towneÅ¿men; and now the moÅ¿t entire amphitheater in Europe.

The famouÅ¿eÅ¿t men for learning

From Verona we went to BreÅ¿cia by the way of PeÅ¿chiera and DiÅ¿enÅ¿an â€¢ . PeÅ¿chiera is a Å¿trong Fort belonging to the Æ²enetians, PeÅ¿chiera. and
garded by a conÅ¿tant garriÅ¿on. It Å¿tands vpon the Lago di Garda, Lago di Garda. Lacus Benacus anciently, and is almoÅ¿t Å¿urrounded by its CryÅ¿talin waters. Its a moÅ¿t Regular Fortification, with fiue Bastions, and high Rampar â€¢ s, which couer the whole towne.

From hence after dinner, we arriued betimes at BreÅ¿cia, BreÅ¿cia. another Å¿trong towne of the Venetians. From BreÅ¿cia I went once to Crema and Bergamo, Crema. two Å¿trong townes of the Venetians, and both frontiers to the State of Milan. The
firÅ¿t is very Å¿trong and famous for fine linnen made here.Bergamo. The latter is Å¿trong too, both by its CaÅ¿tle, good walls, and its high Å¿ituation vpon a hill, which giues you a fair proÅ¿pect into the MilaneÅ¿e for twenty or thirty miles. In the Church of the AuguÅ¿tins lyes buryed AmbroÅ¿ius Calepinus author of the excellent Latin Dictionary, which learned PaÅ¿Å¿eratius hath Å¿et out Å¿ince with great additions. Its in Å¿ix languages.
From Bergamo I went to Milan, one days journey. An other time I went from BreÅ¿cia to Milan by the way of Mantua, and Mirandola.

Mantua. Mantua belongs to a Soueraine Duke, or Prince, of the houÅ¿e of GonÅ¿ague. Its Å¿tands in the midÅ¿t of Marshes which are nurrished by the riuer Mincius: Å¿o that theres no coming to it but by two long bridges ouer the Lake. And yet this towne was taken Å¿ome forty yeares ago: no towne being impregnable where an AÅ¿Å¿e laden with gold can enter; or
where faction keeps one gate. For about that time, the Emperors Army, by Å¿ecret intelligence, preÅ¿enting it Å¿elf before it, was let in; and Å¿acked the towne. At the entrance of the towne gates, they obÅ¿erue the fashion of many other townes in Italy, to make Trauelers leaue their piÅ¿tols and carabins at the gate where they enter, and not Å¿ee them againe till they meet them at the other gate where they goe out; giueing them, for all that, a contraÅ¿egno or little talley, where of you keep one peÃ©ce, and the other is tyed to your piÅ¿tols, where by you may clayme and challenge them. This is an ancient cuÅ¿tome in the Romans times, as I finde in Æ²alerius Maximus, who Å¿ayth, it was the practiÅ¿e of thoÅ¿e of MarÅ¿eilles (then a Roman Colonie) vt hoÅ¿pitia Å¿ua,
Æ²aler. Maxim. l. 2. c. 1.
quemadmodum aduenientibus humana Å¿unt, ita ipÅ¿is tuta Å¿int. As for Mantua it Å¿elf, its well built, and full of good houÅ¿es. The Dukes Pallace was heretofore one of the richeÅ¿t of Italy. I was told that it had Å¿eauen changes of
hangings for euery roome in the houÅ¿e; beÅ¿ides a world of rare pictures, Statues, plate, ornaments, cabinets, an Vnicorns horne, an Organ of AlabaÅ¿ter; Å¿ix tables, each one three foot long, the firÅ¿t all of emerauds, the Å¿econd of Turky Å¿tones, the third of hyacinths, the fourth of Saphirs, the fift of Amber, the Å¿ixt of IaÅ¿per Å¿tone. But the ImperialiÅ¿ts Å¿wept all away. The origin of the houÅ¿e of GonÅ¿ague is from Germany. The Dukes Family. For a long time they were onely MarquiÅ¿es of Mantua, till Charles the V. made them Dukes. The Reuenues of this Prince are about fiue hundred thouÅ¿and crownes.
His Reuenues.
His Interest. His IntereÅ¿t (as that of the other leÅ¿Å¿er Princes of Italy) is to ioyne with the Å¿tronger of the two Nations France, or Spayne. And he hath bine often forced to put now and then a French ga â€¢ riÅ¿on, now and then a Spanish garriÅ¿on into his Å¿trong towne of CaÅ¿al, CaÅ¿al. one of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t places I Å¿aw in all Italy: His Å¿trenth. hauing an excellent Cittadel at one end of it; a Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle at the
other, and Å¿trong ditches, walls, and ramparts euery where. In fine, this Duke can rayÅ¿e, about fifteen thouÅ¿and foot, and two thouÅ¿and horÅ¿e.
Of Mantua were theÅ¿e two excellent Latin Poets; old Virgil, its Learned Mem. and moderne BaptiÅ¿ta Mantuanus a Carmelit.
He that deÅ¿ires to know the hiÅ¿tory of Mantua, Its HiÅ¿tory. let him read Mario Aquicola.

From Mantua we went to Mirandola, Mirandola being inuited thither by its wonderfull name. It is a principality farre more ancient then great; and it is Å¿o called, from Three children borne here of a great Lady, FranciÅ¿cus Pius. Leander Albatus. at one birth. The Å¿tory as it is pretty, Å¿o it is related by good authors, and therefore I will give it you here, in the end of this my Italian iourney, as a faire well. And tis this. ConÅ¿tantius the Emperor, Sonn of ConÅ¿tantin the great, had Ã daughter called Euridis; who beeing growne vp in yeares, fell in loue with Manfred a courtier of her Vncle ConÅ¿tantin, Ã hanÅ¿ome well bred
yong gentleman. Manfred was both courtier enough, and wiÅ¿e enough, to vnderÅ¿tand this to be no Å¿mall honour; and therefore embraced her affection with a correÅ¿ponding flame. In a word, they meet often; talke of it; giue mutual promiÅ¿es; make all the money they can, and iewels, and flye away Å¿ecretly. They come into Italy, land at Naples, from thence to Rauenna; and at laÅ¿t pitch vpon this country where now Mirandula Å¿tands. It was then a place ouerÅ¿pred with thickets and vnderwoods, and furnishing Å¿ome paÅ¿turage for sheep, and cottages for shepheards. Here then they chooÅ¿e to liue priuately and conuerÅ¿e with none but country Å¿waines, and shepheards. Blind loue whither doeÅ¿t thou hurrey, PrinceÅ¿Å¿es, to make them preferre cottages before Courts? At laÅ¿t with their money they buy land, and Manfred grows Soone to that authority among his neighbours, that they chooÅ¿e him for their Head; and recurre vnto him, vpon all occaÅ¿ions for his aduiÅ¿e and protection:
In the meane time (haueing Å¿olemnly marryed Euridis at his arriual in Italy) she brings him forth three Å¿onns at once, Picus, Pius, and Papazzo; and Manfred growes farre more conÅ¿iderable dayly in theÅ¿e parts. At laÅ¿t the Emperor ConÅ¿tantius comeing into Italy vpon his accaÅ¿ions, and being complimented by all the Å¿eueral provinces thereof, this Prouince among the reÅ¿t, choÅ¿e Manfred as their EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to the Å¿ayd Emperor, to carry to him the tender of their reÅ¿pects and homage. Manfred accepted of the employment, and carryed himÅ¿elf Å¿o gallantly in the EmbaÅ¿Å¿y, that the Emperor knighted him, and vpon further tryal of his worth, rayÅ¿ed him to high fauour. Manfred Å¿eing the realityes of the Emperor, thought it now high time to diÅ¿couer himÅ¿elf vnto him. WhereforecaÅ¿ting himÅ¿elf one day at the Emperors feet, and begging his pardon, he diÅ¿couered himÅ¿elf vnto him, and told him his whole Å¿tory, and aduentures.
At fitÅ¿t the Emperor was a little troubled; but findeing Å¿uch freedome and gallantry in his carriage, mingled with Å¿uch humble ingenuity in the ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of his fault; he not onely pardoned what was paÅ¿t, but preÅ¿ently Å¿ent for Euridis and her children to come to him, and liue at court with him. This done he makes Manfred Count and Marquis, of a great part of theÅ¿e countryes, and gives him leaue to build townes and CaÅ¿tles there: and for his armes giues him the black Eagle. In fine, in memory of the three children borne Å¿o wonderfully at one birth, he commands that the chief towne thould be called Miranda. After the death of ConÅ¿tantius, Manfred and his Lady returned with great riches vnto their old dwellind place, and there began to build Miranda, which in proceÅ¿Å¿e of time was called Mirandola. This true Å¿tory if it looke like a Romance, you muÅ¿t not wonder; Å¿eing Romances now a dayes, looke like true Å¿tories.
The Prince of Mirandola receiues yearly fourÅ¿core thouÅ¿and crownes.
The greateÅ¿t ornament of this country, was that famours Ioannes Picus Mirandulanus;Io Picus Miranduilanus. whoÅ¿e life S. Thomas Moore wrote, and hauing written it, liued it.

From Mirandula I struck to Parma, and Å¿o to Piacenza, Lodi, and Marigno, deÅ¿cribed all aboue; and at laÅ¿t to Milan againe, where I had been before, and where my giro of Italy ended, as now my Iourney and deÅ¿cription doth. I takeing here a new riÅ¿e from Milan, and croÅ¿Å¿ing through SwiÅ¿Å¿erland by the Lake of Como, and ouer mount S. Godart, came to BaÅ¿il. Where embarking vpon the Rhene, I Å¿aw Strasbourg, BriÅ¿ac, Spire, Philipsbourg, Openhem, Coblentz, HamerÅ¿tede, Wormes, Francfurt, Mayence, Colen, DuÅ¿Å¿eldorp, SkinkÅ¿conce, Rais, WeÅ¿el, Arnehem and diuers Å¿uch fine Rhenish townes. Then haueing Viewed Holand and Flanders, I came at laÅ¿t to Calais, and Å¿o home to my owne Deare Country England, by the way of Douer.
